HEADLINE: More Power to the Tribes

BYLINE: By Bill Richardson; Bill Richardson, Democrat of New Mexico, is chairman of the House Subcommittee on Native American Affairs.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The nation tunes in to Indian issues only when there is a crisis like the mysterious illness plaguing the Navajo reservation in Arizona. Or when Donald Trump files a lawsuit to stop Indian gaming. Or when a movie like "Dances with Wolves" attracts movie stars lamenting the plight of our reservations.
Indian reservations are among the poorest areas in the United States: 93,000 Indians are homeless or have inadequate housing, according to the Bureau of Indian Affairs. Of the 1.8 million Native Americans, 603,000 live below the poverty line. 
 Unemployment on reservations has always exceeded 50 percent nationally and sometimes reaches more than 80 percent. Indians have the highest rates of diabetes and tuberculosis and the lowest life expectancy.
These troubles have a long history, but in recent years there has been one obvious culprit: the wasteful and patriarchal Bureau of Indian Affairs, which in large measure has held back tribes from helping themselves. Although Indian tribes are sovereign, many tribal governmental activities are mired in the Federal bureaucracy.
It is time to junk or radically transform the bureau, which has a central office in Washington and more than 100 other offices scattered around the country. We need a system under which the money goes directly to the reservation rather than to an inflated bureaucracy. Perhaps the most egregious example of the bureau's mind-boggling inefficiency is its mismanagement of nearly $2 billion in funds belonging to Indian people and tribes, who have no say in how their money is handled. Since 1820, the Government has held tribal funds in trust, and it was not until 1966 that it even began investing the funds.
Today, according to the General Accounting Office, the bureau has a poor accounting system, weak internal controls and a badly trained staff. Though it functions as a bank, the bureau has no regular audits and cannot say how much money is in the accounts.
Revenue from oil and gas royalties on Indian lands, grazing fees and other income isn't directly distributed to the tribes or individuals. Instead, it is deposited in a variety of bank accounts that the bureau has not been able to reconcile. In the last two years, Congress has pressed for an audit of the accounts, but business goes on as usual.
A creative new approach that encourages tribes to take control of their own futures would also get them out from under the bureau. It is a bold experimental project, started in 1988, in which 30 tribes bypass the bureau and enter into self-governance compacts with the Interior Secretary. Instead of the bureau providing services to the reservation, the tribes participating in this experiment establish their own spending priorities with the Secretary. This kind of tribal self-determination will not only save the taxpayers money, it will give the tribes more autonomy. Congress needs to encourage such initiatives, and we will be drafting legislation to make the project permanent, so that it will be an option for all tribes.
Indians should be given the means to attract investment on reservations: tax incentives, enterprise zones and development banks. Indian gaming, only 3 percent of the gambling industry nationwide, is a $6 billion industry in Indian America and has successfully reduced unemployment on many reservations and made some tribes self-sufficient.
Why must the Government help Indians at all? Besides the obvious moral obligation, there is a legal responsibility. Since the founding of the country, the U.S. has promised to uphold the rights of Indian tribes, and became the trustee of Indian lands and resources. The U.S. vowed that Indians would be housed, educated and provided with decent health care. We have failed on nearly every count, and every one of the more than 300 treaties with tribes has been broken.
When Federal and state agencies were searching for the cause of the epidemic that began on the Navajo reservation, they had the wisdom to listen to the tribal medicine men, who pointed to a key food source that attracts rats, the probable carriers of the disease. So it is with Indian policy. Only the tribal perspective holds the cure to the lingering injustices and poverty in Indian country.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Lend Russia Money and a Tough Accountant

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Waffling and Wavering on Russian Aid" (Op-Ed, June 27), Dimitri Simes is unhappy with the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund for refusing "to relax their loan requirements" and the I.M.F. director for "stonewalling on Russian aid." He recommends that the Group of Seven set up a "public-and-private entity on the model of the Marshall Plan," presumably with less stringent criteria, for shaping Russian aid. 
 It is difficult to see how softer conditions on aid will help the Russian Government close unviable factories, cut back state subsidies, trim currency outflow and strengthen the ruble. The model of the Marshall Plan can help Russian reformers, not because it was lenient, but because it was strict on use of American dollars appropriated by Congress for Western Europe and channeled by the European Cooperation Administration.
Despite the quick tempo of Russian sales of shops, restaurants and trading and service outlets to private owners, and conversion of large factories to joint stock companies, readiness to shed labor and to junk idle machines is hardly in evidence.
In my recent visits to factories and interviews with managers, the answer to whether or not workers would be laid off for factory restructuring was a resounding nyet. A manager of a submarine plant turning out household heating systems, irons and tea kettles, said: "I have risen to the rank of a manager after 30 years in this factory. The workers are my family. When they have problems, they do not run to Yegor Gaidar and Boris Fyodorov, who threaten their livelihood. They come to me."
Another manager of a large Moscow factory acknowledged that workers on part-time employment were moonlighting elsewhere, but laying them off was complicated. If they were fired and removed from the factory payroll, they would lose their housing. The large factories in company towns are eager to be free from providing subsidized apartments to the vast labor force and the responsibilities of maintaining dilapidated housing. But the local administrations are unwilling to pick up the tab, and the privatization of factory housing is at a standstill.
Then there is the insider-outsider conflict in privatized units in which the citizens have placed vouchers in exchange for shares. The outsiders fear that the labor collectives may decide to convert a bakery into a boutique and a Moscow supermarket into a five-star hotel. The fears are so real that a recent shareholders' meeting of the Bolshevik Biscuit Factory broke into a pandemonium.
In the meantime, creating employment opportunities in privatized shops and new trading and service outlets is hobbled by crippling taxes, erratic prices and extortion charges by the mafia, which are keeping ahead of the inflation. The dynamic, young manager of a Nizhni Novgorod restaurant mentioned tax rates of 70 percent to 90 percent on the income in the restaurant and 16 shops in his ownership. The marketing and accounting staff everywhere is juggling tax payments, hassling with volatile price quotations from suppliers, fighting off demands for higher wages and bonuses from employees and keeping the mafia at bay.
Many among the young and the daring would take on the challenges of private activities in sales and service if they were less risky.
The Government must pick winners and losers among the factories, select candidates here and there for bankruptcy proceedings. Last March, Izvestia reported that an official, four-page list of bankrupt enterprises to be subjected to slow demise had mysteriously disappeared. In the meantime, the I.M.F. representative in Russia complained about the lack of a policy on which enterprises should be supported, which should be closed and which should survive on their own. The Russian cabinet, meeting last May, failed to agree on a selective subsidy plan because the new first deputy prime minister, Oleg Lobov, wanted to include more sectors for state support.
The I.M.F., contrary to Dimitri Simes's assertion, has been pressured to release support for a member country that has failed to fulfill its pledge on earlier funds: the Russian commitment to keep the budget deficit at 5 percent of domestic income (the condition for releasing a $1 billion I.M.F. loan in July 1992). Indeed, the credit-financed purchases of machines, materials and spare parts were sold by the Government to Russian buyers at such throwaway prices that the 1992 budget deficit (including massive subsidization of imports) was estimated at a whopping 20 percent. On the eve of the Tokyo meetings, the I.M.F. has just released the first installment of $1.5 billion in aid.
The I.M.F. traditionally rewards positive performance with more financing and penalizes nonfulfillment of a pledge by canceling additional credits. This on-again, off-again approach has worked. But standard I.M.F. monitoring cannot succeed in Russia, where a policy consensus is missing, a commitment to carry out obligations is absent despite good intentions, and serious economic indicators such as the inflation rate and budget deficit have lost importance.
Besides, softer aid conditions for Russia are unfair to Hungary, Poland, the Czech Republic and developing countries that have undertaken market reforms. They also set a bad precedent for other former Soviet states, like Ukraine, a mini-nuclear power that is in a worse situation.
Hence the need for a special agency with an intrusive role of tracking and insuring the use of aid funds to serve a definite goal. For example, imports financed by the Russian Government with official credits should be sold to domestic Russian buyers at close to market prices. The resulting counterpart (ruble) fund on government account should be used for budgetary support to retrain and relocate workers of factories targeted for shutdown.
Such was the way the European Cooperation Administration operated in Western Europe during Marshall Plan days under President Harry S. Truman. Contrary to Mr. Simes's interpretation, the Marshall Plan mechanism was a coercive device for insuring that United States funds were used to fulfill the goals for which they were voted by Congress. The generous donor was a strict accountant, an on-the-scene operator and a pragmatic manipulator. Speedy European recovery could not have been managed without such underpinning.
More than four decades later, will another Democratic President rise to the challenge and secure market reforms in Russia?
 
PADMA DESAI
New York, June 30, 1993
The writer is Gladys and Roland Harriman Professor of Comparative Economic Systems at Columbia U.

GRAPHIC: Drawing.

HEADLINE: Lend Russia Money and a Tough Accountant;
Stemming Corruption

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Dimitri Simes fails to discuss corruption in "Waffling and Wavering on Russian Aid" (Op-Ed, June 27). He argues for increasing aid to Russia. However, current assistance to Russia is inefficient because of the corruption on the receiving end.
It is part of the Russian character to seek out and profit from loopholes in the bureaucratic structure. Gogol's character Chichikov profited from a loophole by buying up dead souls. The Soviet period did not alter this because Marxism did not contain an explicit ethical system. 
 Today, exploiting loopholes and other scams have led to outright criminal activity, from counterfeiting to phony voucher investment funds.
The International Monetary Fund has proceeded with proper caution. Its managing director commented that the I.M.F. is afraid to grant a $6 billion fund to stabilize the ruble because the money would end up in European bank accounts days later.
Production in Russian oilfields drops each year, yet oil exports have increased. One of three barrels of oil is exported to the West for hard currency by unofficial means. The revenue goes to private bank accounts. How has President Boris N. Yeltsin dealt with this problem? According to the Russian Petroleum Investor, Mr. Yeltsin allegedly abolished the Commission on Combatting Corruption after pressure by the Russian oil and gas producers accused by the commission of illegal exports and hard currency violations.
What can the United States do about this problem? I propose expanding the Peace Corps for Russia to include not only business advisers and teachers of English, but also American observers fluent in Russian to help prevent the diversion of food and medical supplies to the black market. The minimal costs needed would be more than offset by getting aid to the right people. Using most Russian officials to deliver Western aid is analogous to distributing food aid to Somalia through Somali warlords.
 
GREG MURRAY
Alexandria, Va., June 29, 1993

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Pact Reached On Incinerator For Brooklyn

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Thursday, July 8

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders reached a compromise Wednesday that would allow New York City to build a much disputed garbage incinerator in the Brooklyn Navy Yard. But in doing so, they imposed new hurdles that could slow the project or make it more expensive.
The agreement, which will partly exempt the incinerator from strict air-pollution regulations, left both its proponents and critics claiming victory. 
 The compromise came late Wednesday afternoon, as the Legislature rushed to close an extended 1993 session. In a flurry of activity, dozens of bills that had languished in what has been a slow and largely unproductive year came under last-minute consideration.
 
New Hurdles for City
 Later Wednesday, negotiators for Mr. Cuomo, Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin, a Queens Democrat, and Senate Majority Leader Ralph J. Marino, an Oyster Bay Republican, were trying to wrap up several major bills before daybreak today, when the lawmakers were hoping to adjourn until the fall.
Just minutes before midnight Wednesday, Mr. Cuomo signed legislation to extend rent-stabilization laws for four more years. The law includes new provisions, the first major changes to the rent regulations in 20 years, that are intended to remove rent protections from wealthier tenants by exempting apartments that rent for $2,000 a month or more from the laws.
The Dinkins administration said the legislative compromise on the incinerator removed a major obstacle and would allow the city to move ahead with its application for state permits on the project. But they acknowledged that the agreement, by only partially exempting the city from the air-pollution rules, could still lead to delays or drive up the cost of the $450 million incinerator, which is scheduled to begin operation in 2000.
"As it's framed now, it does leave some hurdles and that we'd rather not have," said Emily Lloyd, the city's Commissioner of Sanitation. "But it makes official the idea that our solid-waste management plan does go a long way to improving air quality."
Opponents of the project, including environmentalists and community groups from neighborhoods surrounding the Brooklyn Navy Yard, said the compromise -- while not killing the project outright as they had hoped -- provided them with new ammunition to attack it.
"It definitely provides new openings to delay or block it," said Larry Shapiro, a lawyer with the New York Public Interest Research Group, a consumer advocacy organization.
 
Last-Minute Hitches
 The compromise was reached after 24 hours of fitful and sometimes frantic negotiating in which a tentative agreement to exempt the incinerator completely from the regulations was reached on Tuesday afternoon only to be scuttled after a late-night lobbying effort by opponents, mainly Democratic Assembly members from Manhattan and Brooklyn.
The Dinkins administration has lobbied vigorously to exempt the incinerator fully from the regulations, saying the air pollution rules would place impossible demands on the city and virtually kill the project. Those regulations say that before the city opens the incinerator, it must first reduce more air pollution citywide than the incinerator is expected to create.
The Brooklyn Navy Yard incinerator, which is designed to burn 3,000 tons of waste daily, will enable the city to close aging incinerators in Queens and Brooklyn and reduce its dependency on the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island, city officials say.
Wednesday's agreement still requires the city to reduce air pollution citywide by a greater amount than what the Brooklyn incinerator would produce. But it allows the city to do that largely by taking into account the closing of old incinerators in Maspeth, Queens, and in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, as well as dozens of small apartment incinerators around the city. The apartment incinerators and the Maspeth incinerators have already been shut down.
Under the agreement, the city must study the possible health affects of the incinerator on the neighborhoods surrounding the Brooklyn Navy Yard. Opponents of the incinerator have said it would increase air pollution and pose a cancer risk to residents in neighboring areas like Williamsburg and Fort Greene.
 
More Review
 The agreement also requires the city to study the health effects of the incinerator in neighborhoods within three miles of the Brooklyn Navy Yard, where the city is seeking to begin other municipal projects.
Assemblyman Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat and a leading opponent of the incinerator, said the city will have to conduct such a study before it builds a planned sanitation garage on South Street in his district.
Whether the city might have to shut down additional sources of air pollution to satisfy the regulations remains unclear. If so, it could delay the project or increase its cost. But aides to Governor Cuomo said they did not believe that would be necessary.
"The one thing this clearly does is provide better air quality for the city," said Andrew Zambelli, Mr. Cuomo's chief of staff. "We don't believe this ultimately impacts the plant."
The incinerator agreement, which is expected to pass both the Republican-controlled Senate and Democratic-controlled Assembly, is part of broad legislation intended to bring New York State into compliance with 1990 changes to the Federal Clean Air Act. The state could have faced the loss of $1 billion in Federal transportation funds if it had not passed the legislation this year.
 
Pressure on Legislature
 "This will clean up the air, especially downstate, and it will do so without sitting on the downstate economy," said Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, a Westchester Democrat and chairman of the Environmental Committee.
This morning, negotiators for Mr. Cuomo and legislative leaders appeared close to a agreement on a plan to create a dedicated fund that would be used to purchase and preserve environmentally sensitive land around the state.
After being deadlocked for weeks over how to pay for the fund, the negotiators had tentatively agreed to provide $25 million starting in May 1994. Most of the money would be nonrecurring budget items, or one-shots, including $18 million from the refinancing of state debt and $5 million from the sale of state lands. The recurring sources of money would include $1 million a year from the sale of special license plates and $1 million a year from the leasing of underwater state properties.
But many details about the fund were still being discussed this morning, with just hours left in the session. Though aides to Mr. Cuomo said the fund would increase to $100 million in 1995, it was not decided where that money would come from. It was also not clear whether the Legislature and local municipalities would have any say in what land the state could buy, a power some Republicans have endorsed. And it was not clear that the fund would be fully dedicated to land preservation.
Despite the uncertainties, environmental lobbyists said they were pleased that money would again be provided for land preservation. "The three branches of government have made a commitment tonight that the environment deserves a permanent line in the budget," said Neil F. Woodworth, counsel to the Adirondack Mountain Club. "Now they can change their minds, but they basically have made a commitment."
And although money would not be available from the fund until 1994, environmentalists said, the promise of a dedicated state fund would help to preserve endangered parcels in the Long Island Pine Barrens and the Adirondack Park.
In the Pine Barrens, Suffolk County has said it will make available $10 million to finance the first stages of a preservation plan if the state promises to provide $10 million in 1994.
There was little sign early today that the Legislature would reach an agreement with Mr. Cuomo on a plan to take the savings produced by closing state psychiatric hospitals and funneling the money to community mental health programs. Aides to Mr. Weprin were not saying whether a bill agreed to by Senate and Assembly negotiators would be voted on in the Assembly.
Mr. Cuomo opposes the bill because it would restrict his ability to deal with budget shortfalls, and Mr. Weprin has said he may not want to pass a bill only to invite a veto.
In other action, the Assembly gave final approval Wednesday to a measure that would regulate what is becoming a veritable futures market in death, in which people who are terminally ill sell their life insurance policies to companies so that they can have some cash while they are still alive.
The legislation, which was passed by the Senate on Tuesday, seeks to protect AIDS patients, among others who sell their policies, from the practices of some brokers.

CLINTON'S WORLD DEBUT
President Clinton stepped onto the world stage with a flourish in Tokyo, sitting down with other leaders at the opening session of his first economic summit meeting. He hailed a limited pact to lower tariffs as a major breakthrough. Mr. Clinton also plunged into the streets to shake hands and chat with children. A1

HEADLINE: Recalling '88 Drought's Disaster, Farmers Say Deluge Is Not as Bad

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NICHOLS, Iowa, July 6

 BODY:
Five summers ago the worst drought in half a century left the fields around this tiny Iowa town as dry as bleached bones, stunting corn, killing soybeans and driving farmers out of business.
Farmers are recalling that dry summer with some measure of longing this week as the Middle West continues to be pelted by the heavy rain that has flooded the upper Mississippi River. 
 But the fond memories stopped there. The 1988 drought destroyed 45 percent of the nation's corn crop, causing losses of more than $10 billion and forcing thousands of farmers out of business.
No one is predicting those kinds of losses from this year's flood, despite weeks of heavy rains this spring and summer that have cut the production of corn and soybeans in Iowa, Minnesota, South Dakota and northern Illinois by 10 to 20 percent from what had been expected.
Moreover, experts say that while the flooding is pushing up the prices that farmers are paid for their commodities, it should not significantly increase consumer prices for food.
"This is nothing near the damage from the 1988 drought," said Dick Loewy, a commodity analyst in Chicago.
 
$1 Billion in Crop Losses
 That is not to say the losses are insignificant. The Department of Agriculture has estimated that the heavy rains and subsequent flooding along the upper Mississippi and its tributaries have caused $1 billion in crop losses.
And that figure may go much higher. The Iowa Department of Agriculture has put the crop losses in this state alone at $750 million, and some analysts say crop losses may already total as much as $2 billion.
Commodities markets have reacted sharply to the drenching in the upper Midwest with the swiftest rise in prices since the 1988 drought. Soybean futures prices for delivery in November have climbed by $1.25 in the last 20 days, to more than $7 a bushel. Corn futures prices have risen 20 cents to $2.58 a bushel.
[The soybean market closed on Wednesday at $7.15, up 17.25 cents from Tuesday. Corn prices dropped slightly Wednesday to $2.57.]
Nonetheless, commodity analysts and economists say that if the agricultural damage does not grow worse, food prices are not likely to be significantly affected. Though crops in Iowa, Minnesota, South Dakota and northern Illinois have been ruined, other important growing regions are thriving. Farmers in Ohio, Indiana and central Illinois are likely to produce record crops, the analysts said.
 
Meat Prices May Go Down
 Most of the nation's corn and soybeans are fed to livestock and poultry and account for a small percentage of the overall cost of the price of meat in the supermarkets, they said. Corn and soybean meal, for instance, make up about 15 cents of the cost of a pound of hamburger that retails for $1.30, said Michael Sands, an economist with the Western Livestock Marketing Project, a Federal and state research project in Denver.
Mr. Sands said meat prices may actually decrease. As the cost of feed climbs, beef producers often cull from their herds the least productive animals, like cows that have trouble becoming pregnant. As a result, the supply of meat is likely to rise and meat prices are likely to fall for the rest of 1993, followed by falling supplies and rising prices in 1994 as the producers keep animals off the market to rebuild their herds. That was what happened after the drought in 1988.
"At least at this point it looks to us as though this event will be relatively minor as far as food costs," said Mr. Sands. "If your field is flooded, that's a different story. As far as the big picture, though, we're not talking about a major impact."
Grain traders said the effect of the Mississippi flooding on export sales is also likely to be temporary and slight.
 
River Is Overseas Link
 The river provides the link for Midwestern farmers with the foreign-bound freighters down river in New Orleans, but July is historically a slack period for the United States in the global grain trade. Analysts said that even with the corn and soybean losses, the nation would have ample stores of both crops to satisfy international buyers.
"The rains will not affect trade," said Richard Feltes, vice president and director of commodity research in Chicago for Refco Group Ltd., the world's largest futures brokerage house.
And though the rains are no help, the losses are not expected to drive nearly as many farmers out of business as did the 1988 drought, farm consultants and farmers say.
Five years ago, they said, many more farmers were burdened by high debts from buying land and machinery in the late 1970's; losses from the drought then drove thousands into insolvency. Farm debt is significantly lower in the 1990's, the consultants said, and exceptionally good crops were produced last year and the year before. As a result, farmers are in better financial shape overall than they have been in some time, the consultants said.
 
States With Worst Damage
 "I have 175 clients and less than a handful, maybe one or two or three, are hanging on by their teeth and could be forced out of business by the rains," said Dean Phelps, a farm accountant and adviser here. "That's still a lot when there are so few farmers. But in the 1980's, it was much different. There were auctions every week."
In spite of the general view that the flood will not be as devastating as the 1988 drought, some growers feel the opposite. "This will be worst crop losses this farm has ever had," said Gayle Kaalberg, who farms 770 acres just outside this town of 200. "We could use a few weeks of dry weather. But it doesn't seem to be going that way, does it?"
The heaviest damage from the rains has occurred in the two states north and northwest of Iowa -- Minnesota and South Dakota. In Minnesota, according to state agriculture officials, farmers were expected to plant 6.3 million acres of corn, but perhaps as many as 500,000 acres were not planted. State officials estimated that another 400,000 acres are flooded. Corn generally dies or is severely stunted if its roots are under water for longer than four or five days.
In South Dakota, some 250,000 acres of the state's 3.6-million-acre corn crop was not planted because the fields were too muddy, Federal farm officials said.
And here in Iowa, the nation's largest corn-producing state, farmers were expected to plant 12.1 million acres of corn, as well as some 7.3 million acres of soybeans.
 
Water Is Everywhere
 The state's Secretary of Agriculture, Dale Cochran, said that at least 375,000 acres of corn and 1 million acres of soybeans had not been planted. Another million acres of both crops have been damaged from soaking rains and flooded streams.
Economists at Iowa State University, in their latest estimate, predicted that rains would cost Iowa farmers $750 million in crop damage.
Evidence of why that is so is easy to see across Muscatine County, which is drained by the Iowa and Cedar Rivers. Both rivers overran their banks weeks ago, flooding thousands of acres of fields that are now impossible to plant.
Rain runoff from the rolling countryside has burst many drainage pipes and culverts, flooding thousands more acres. And even land on the sides of hills that should be well drained is so saturated that troughs of deep water lie in the furrows between crop rows.
Gary Mincer, a 55-year-old farmer from Riverside, Iowa, a few miles west of here, said a quarter of his 480-acre farm is beneath the water from the Iowa River. "And the planting dates have expired," he said.
But Mr. Mincer said he is in better condition than he was during the 1988 drought. "The higher land away from the streams is going to be damaged by the rain but not to the extent it was in 1988."

HEADLINE: Perot Bloc Is Here to Stay, Clinton Pollster Finds

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 7

 BODY:
Voters who supported Ross Perot in last year's election remain deeply committed to him and are "increasingly skeptical" of President Clinton, who wants their support to win re-election, a national survey released today by Mr. Clinton's pollster has found.
While the pollster, Stanley B. Greenberg, said Mr. Clinton could draw support from Mr. Perot's backers, the findings underscored how difficult that effort could be. Mr. Clinton would have to prove that his policies fundamentally improved the economy, the study said, and to persuade the Perot voters that he had significantly changed Government by cutting waste and bureaucracy and greatly curbing the influence of special interests. 
 The survey was commissioned by the Democratic Leadership Council, a centrist group that was a base for Mr. Clinton's Presidential campaign and that has since battled Democratic liberals over what the new President's White House should represent. Today, the council's leaders sought to use the findings to make a case that Mr. Clinton should follow many of its recommendations to draw Perot voters into his camp.
In a strategy for expanding Mr. Clinton's support beyond the 43 percent of the electorate that voted for him and for drawing some of the 19 percent that voted for Mr. Perot, the council cited the survey as evidence that the President must create new jobs, reform Government, demonstrate that he spent taxpayer money with discipline, be more assertive toward Congress and more clearly invoke the values of work, family and individual responsibility.
Given the Perot voters' disaffection with the political parties, Mr. Greenberg said it would not be easy to win their support. "We're dealing with something that's big," he said. "The depth of alienation is so strong and deep, it's hard to imagine they will be moved over to any direction until there is evidence of change."
 
Survey and Focus Groups
 Mr. Greenberg said he had agreed to conduct the study over the last three months because he and the White House were concerned that Mr. Perot could be a serious threat to Mr. Clinton's political future. He said the White House was not involved in the poll and had no role in producing or releasing it, though he planned to share the results with officials there.
The telephone survey of 1,200 Perot voters nationwide was the most comprehensive of that voting group taken since the election, said Mr. Greenberg, who later conducted discussions with six focus groups among Perot backers in California, Maine and Ohio. The survey also included 800 voters who did not support Mr. Perot.
The national survey was conducted from April 12 to April 20, and the margin of error for the full sample of Perot voters was plus or minus three percentage points. The focus groups were held May 13 to May 18, after which the results were collated and studied.
"The Perot block is for real and has considerable staying power," the study concluded. "Perot voters remain committed to their 1992 vote and, for the moment, want to stick with Perot in 1996, even if he were to run as a Republican. That is a measure of their independence and alienation, which will remain important in our future national elections."
 
Opportunity or Danger?
 Al From, the president of the Democratic Leadership Council, said Mr. Clinton had an opportunity to form a governing majority just as President Richard M. Nixon did when he followed a "Southern strategy" to win support from disaffected Democrats who had voted for George Wallace in 1968. "Perot supporters, unlike those of third party candidates in the past, have not aligned with either party since the election," Mr. From said. "Rather, they remain a defiantly independent force."
There are obvious contradictions if Mr. Clinton is to pursue the strategy envisioned by Mr. From and Will Marshall, president of the Progressive Policy Institute, a research group affiliated with Mr. From's group. For example, they noted that the Perot supporters were more critical of Congress than any other voting group and urged the President to take on Congress more aggressively.
But such a move could further damage Mr. Clinton's relations with lawmakers in his own party, threatening the future of legislation on health care, change in welfare and other initiatives that Mr. From and Mr. Marshall said the President must get through.
Mr. From played down the damage Mr. Clinton could possibly suffer if he takes on Capitol Hill, saying, "I'm not recommending that he bash Congress but that he take a welfare reform package and push it through, even if there's opposition within his own party."
 
Dethroning the Deficit
 The survey challenged the conventional wisdom that reducing the deficit was the overriding concern of Perot voters. It found that only one-fourth of them cited the deficit as the first or second most important problem facing the country. Far more gave higher priority to the economy, jobs and health care.
While Perot voters wanted Mr. Clinton to succeed and were not particularly critical of his policies, their biggest doubts -- what Mr. Marshall called "a wall of skepticism" -- concerned whether he could deliver what he promised, the survey found.
Mr. Marshall said it was critical that the President demonstrate "much bolder and assertive leadership" or "risk blowing an historic opportunity to bring about realignment."
The survey said the Perot voters represented the "radical middle" made up of conservatives and liberal/ moderates, in addition to traditional independents. Their voting histories were largely Republican, but they were alienated from both major political parties. On important policy questions like improving the economy and family values, they were divided about which party had a better position.
About one-quarter of the Perot voters have Democratic leanings, and another quarter have Republican leanings, the survey found. The poll identified nearly half of the Perot voters as "straight independents" who "stand out for their intense anti-Government and anti-establishment views."
As evidence of the loyalty of Mr. Perot's supporters, the poll found that three-quarters of them now said they would back the Texas businessman if he ran in 1996 against Mr. Clinton or "a serious candidate" on the Republican side, like Bob Dole or Jack F. Kemp. About 13 percent said they would go back to the Republicans, with Mr. Clinton getting 9 percent.
Though Congress is distrusted by most Americans, the survey found that Perot voters were particularly critical of the institution.
"Ross Perot emerges in some sense as the antidote to Congress," Mr. Greenberg said, "somebody who can break through this mess and get things done."
 
Questions on Temperament
 But the survey did find that even his supporters had doubts about Mr. Perot's temperament and questioned whether he would be a reliable leader. But they also see that independence as attractive.
Mr. Greenberg said the easiest group of Perot voters to convert to the Clinton camp would be the almost 20 percent under age 30, who are considered the most politically rootless. Their disaffection is driven by their being among the most financially pressed Perot voters. But they are viewed as open to Democratic appeals because they are anti-establishment but not anti-Government, and 60 percent have never voted for a Republican.
The toughest for Mr. Clinton to win over, Mr. Greenberg said, would be the college-educated Perot backers who clearly would have voted for President Bush had Mr. Perot not been in the race.
Mr. Perot's organization, United We Stand America, criticized the survey as a waste of money. "America needs someone who cares for the people and earns their vote," said Sharon Holman, Mr. Perot's spokeswoman, "not another study about how to capture the vote."

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
A Switch From Hill to Foggy Bottom Offers a Suddenly Expanding World

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 7

 BODY:
Despite 18 years as a lawmaker on Capitol Hill, Timothy E. Wirth, now Counselor for the State Department and the Administration's point man on global issues, allows that he still has a lot to learn.
There was, for instance, the meeting he convened on May 20, attended by 25 representatives of refugee advocacy groups, experts who every day confront the issue of the many thousands of displaced people in places like Bosnia and Angola. 
 To the advocates' dismay, Mr. Wirth, who has worked to expand his areas of expertise from population control and the environment to other subjects in his new portfolio like human rights, spent most of his time at the meeting lecturing the group to the effect that major causes of refugee problems were overpopulation and pollution.
"Bosnia," one participant said later, "has absolutely nothing to do with environmental degradation."
 
Brighter Moments
 But if there have been some inauspicious moments in the post, there have also been some bright ones. Just nine days before his poorly received meeting on refugees, for example, Mr. Wirth told a United Nations conference that the United States was ending a decade of antipathy to population stabilization programs. As participants cheered, he also declared that his Government now believed that abortion should be made safe and available worldwide. Mr. Wirth calls that speech "the most important thing I have ever done."
Mr. Wirth's appointment last winter was widely seen in Washington as a consolation prize: the 53-year-old former Democratic Senator from Colorado had hoped to be named to a Cabinet post in the new Administration.
But in the several months since then he has embraced his new job with its bulging portfolio, delving into a host of unfamiliar subjects.
The education is necessary for the job, with its wide focus on "transnational issues" -- problems that transcend national borders and are deemed to pose global threats. His province includes the environment, population, refugees, narcotics, counterterrorism and human rights, subjects that Vice President Al Gore calls "central to the world's agenda."
"These are subjects that may have been at times peripheral for diplomats during the cold war but are essential now," Mr. Gore said in a recent interview. "They have already created new international realities that can produce nightmares if we don't deal with them successfully."
 
Advocate for New Agenda
 The Administration says that by consolidating these issues under one official with a rank equivalent to that of Under Secretary, it has elevated them to the same level of importance as bilateral relations with other countries. Mr. Wirth's task is to push to include them in all aspects of American foreign policy.
"That's what I've been asked to do here," he said, "to be an advocate for a new set of issues and to build that into American foreign policy. I'm not shy about trying to get these things done."
Already there have been some pronounced shifts from the policies of the Bush Administration. In addition to announcing the change in global population and abortion policy, Mr. Wirth represented the United States in recently signing the Biodiversity Treaty, which is intended to protect the world's plants and animals.
At the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro last year, the United States, maintaining that the treaty would be a threat to economic growth, was the only major industrialized country that refused to endorse it. In contrast, at a meeting of a commission in June to translate the Rio accords into action, Mr. Wirth led an American delegation that won praise for proposals on bridging the gap in development between rich and poor countries and on sharing technology to protect the environment.
But as his experience with refugee groups shows, Mr. Wirth has demonstrated little expertise in areas other than the environment and population control. And his diverse portfolio has left him spread thin. "I've had a lot to learn," he said. "It's like cramming for exams every week for the last four months."
Congressional staff members who have worked with Mr. Wirth say he is a serious student who throws himself into his subjects. "He's very smart, and he does his homework," said an aide who has worked with Mr. Wirth on military issues.
Still, he faces other barriers to his effectiveness. He is unschooled in the State Department's bureaucracy, for instance, and despite calling himself an advocate for refugees, he has been unable to move the Haitian and Bosnian refugee problems to the front of American foreign policy concerns.
 
Legacy of Strained Relations
 His relations with Congress, particularly with his former colleagues in the Senate, whom he severely criticized in a magazine article last year, are still in need of repair. Some say his tendency to blurt out his views, unvarnished, has hampered him in building consensus with Congress and with foreign governments.
He also finds himself struggling against the impression that his post is a make-work job created for him at the last minute after he was passed over for Interior Secretary or Energy Secretary, the jobs his friends say he really wanted.
Although denying that he coveted the Energy Department, Mr. Wirth, a native Westerner, acknowledges that he "would have done Interior in a New York minute."
A year ago, friends say, Mr. Wirth was unsure where he wanted to be, except that it was not in the United States Senate. Elected to the House with the reform-minded class of 1974, and to the Senate in 1986 to replace Gary Hart, he had become disgusted with a lawmaker's life, which he described as increasingly shallow.
In April 1992, he announced that he would not seek re-election. Last August, in an article in The New York Times Magazine, he poured out his contempt for the partisan bickering and political posturing that he described as typical of the Senate's work.
 
'Real Issues Get Lost'
 "How many times should we have to count the yeas and nays on Robert Mapplethorpe and the National Endowment for the Arts, or on flag burning or on such mischievous and misconceived ideas as the constitutional amendment to balance the budget?" Mr. Wirth wrote. "Meanwhile, the real issues get lost. The deficit looms larger. Campaign-contribution abuses grow. The Government in Washington, paralyzed by division, falls further into disrepute."
Looking back on that article now, Mr. Wirth says it was perhaps a mistake. "I suspect that if I had to do it again, I wouldn't do it," he said. "One's hindsight is perfect, right? On the other hand, I think it was a valuable commentary, and I think it was important to me to do that when I wrote it."
His friends and former staff members say Mr. Wirth's disillusionment with electoral politics was deepened by the death of a close friend and prep school classmate, Senator John Heinz of Pennsylvania. Mr. Heinz was killed in an airplane crash in April 1991.
"When Jack Heinz was killed, he changed," a former aide said of Mr. Wirth. "I don't know what it was. I didn't see the fire in his eye anymore. It was almost as if he began to look at things differently."
Still, Mr. Wirth threw himself into Bill Clinton's Presidential campaign, focusing on environmentalists, the Western states and the youth vote. But despite Mr. Clinton's success with those constituencies, Mr. Wirth was not given a Cabinet post.
In part, friends and associates say, he was done in by the Administration's push to place members of minorities and women in Cabinet positions and by what associates describe as a Republican whispering campaign that tried to link him to a failed California savings and loan association.
 
Acceptance of Reality
 "He knew the reality," said Carter Eskew, a Democratic strategist and friend, explaining why Mr. Wirth did not protest his treatment publicly. "He knew where the problems were. He didn't want to get hung out to dry."
Mr. Wirth is reluctant to talk about all that. He says his goal now is to master his subjects, master the State Department bureaucracy and have an effect on American foreign policy.
"I have found it fascinating in dealing with a very large and very, very sophisticated and subtle bureaucracy," he said. "The State Department has developed to an art form the capacity to say no. But if you figure out how to use the State Department to get all these incredibly good elements going with you, you can have enormous impact. You can have a great success."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "That's what I've been asked to do here," said Timothy E. Wirth, who was appointed Counselor for the State Department last winter, "to be an advocate for a new set of issues and to build that into American foreign policy. I'm not shy about trying to get these things done." (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

BORN: Sept. 22, 1939, in Santa Fe, N.M.
 
HOMETOWN: Boulder, Colo.
 
EDUCATION: Bachelor's degree, Harvard, 1961; master's degree in education, Harvard, 1964; doctorate in education, Stanford, 1973.
 
CAREER HIGHLIGHTS: Deputy Assistant Secretary of Education, 1969-70; manager, Rocky Mountain office of Arthur D. Little Inc., 1970-74; member of House of Representatives, 1975-86; United States Senator, 1987-92; Counselor of the State Department, April 1993-present.
 
FAMILY: Married to the former Wren Winslow. They have a son, Christopher, 25, and a daughter, Kelsey, 23.
 
HOBBIES: Fly fishing, horseback riding in back country, tennis, reading, whitewater rafting.

HEADLINE: U.S.-JAPAN TALKS ON SURPLUS STALL

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 7

 BODY:
Even as the leaders of the Group of Seven industrial democracies announced a breakthrough in their discussions on liberalizing the world trading system, Japan and the United States engaged in an increasingly tough war of words today over how to reduce Japan's huge trade surpluses, and their talks dragged on inconclusively.
Taking time off from what have turned into a parallel set of negotiations to the Group of Seven summit meeting here, American officials said they abandoned the talks with Japan once, but returned with some reluctance after a personal appeal from Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa to President Clinton. Nonetheless, they said, progress has been modest at best. 
 Adding to the strains is the fact that the United States, which wants Japan to agree to measurable results in opening its markets to more foreign goods, wants the talks to continue for years.
Japanese officials have countered that the American proposal to battle Japan's surplus with the United States -- which is expected to top $50 billion this year -- with quotas and market-share targets threatens the principle of free trade, and thus the world trading system. That is why Japan has insisted that it will not budge in rejecting such targets.
 
Bitterness on Both Sides
 The bitterness of the exchanges results from the fact that the stakes are enormous, since the flow of goods between the two countries is so large, and because these negotiations appear to reflect a fundamental mistrust between the two countries.
The basic United States position is that all the years of trade agreements between the two countries have failed to achieve their basic aim: permanently reducing Japan's surpluses. Thus, American officials here said, unless Japan is forced to accept some measurable goals on reducing the surpluses, its markets will not open further.
Japan, on the other hand, is fearful that any benchmarks agreed upon to measure the openness of Japanese markets will be used by the United States as justification for retaliation if Japan does not meet the goals.
A Japanese Government official said that his country was willing to use some measures of progress in opening Japan's markets, but only those that were not based on fixed targets. He added that all that separated the two sides was a sentence the Japanese wanted inserted in the agreement stating that the United States would not seek to transform the agreements into rigid goals that had to be met on pain of being hit with penalties.
 
'Surprised and Confused'
 "We are surprised and confused and very much concerned that the Americans won't include that sentence," the official said. "It should be universally accepted that no target for the future can be allowed in a market economy."
Senior American officials flatly denied that such a sentence was holding up an agreement and also denied they were seeking quotas. They said they were only trying to apply such measures to parts of the Japanese economy that were being improperly controlled by the Government or cartels.
The officials explained today that the United States was prepared to walk away from the talks again, even if that means President Clinton will return home next week without having achieved one of his key aims.
They said that discussions had essentially broken down a week ago, and that the American delegation had flown back to Washington on June 28.
Bowman Cutter, the deputy head of President Clinton's National Economic Council, had just gone to bed, the officials said, when Koichiro Matsuura, Japan's Deputy Foreign Minister, telephoned at 3 A.M. Washington time asking for a resumption.
The call was followed by a round of visits by Japan's Ambassador to the United States to Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, Secretary of State Warren Christopher and other officials.
 
A 'Chilly Response'
 "He got a correct but chilly response," said one senior Administration official. That prompted Mr. Miyazawa's appeal, in a letter to Mr. Clinton that the official said asked that the talks be given another try and "hinted at some new ideas" without giving any specifics.
A number of Administration officials resisted the idea, but President Clinton prevailed on them to resume, a senior Administration official said.
The American officials said they have sought to include flexible tests to measure whether Japanese markets are open. For instance, the officials have said, they would consider using such measures as how many Japanese manufacturers were including American parts in the designs of their products, the degree to which American products have been picked up by Japanese wholesalers, or the degree to which American products are designed into Japanese-made finished goods. They said they United States could also use the aggressiveness of Japan's enforcement of its own antitrust laws as another possible benchmark.
"We cannot accept targets or commitments for the future," said a Japanese Government official involved in the discussions. "People would see that as a declaration of managed trade."
But the senior American official said that targets "will be in the agreement. It is non-negotiable."

HEADLINE: Housing Secretary Carves Out Role As a Lonely Clarion Against Racis

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 7

 BODY:
Henry G. Cisneros, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, has staked out a striking role: that of a Cabinet-level contrarian on the volatile question of race.
In an Administration that has been largely silent on the subject, Mr. Cisneros has gone out of his way to call racism a driving force behind many social ills, particularly urban poverty. 
 In a recent interview he criticized those he calls "quote, New Democrats," the party centrists being courted by President Clinton. He accuses them of "failing to acknowledge that the problems are as severe as they are." Mr. Cisneros called racism a "malignancy" and "the great Achilles' heel of our nation's future."
 
Change in Subsidized Housing
 Mr. Cisneros's role is more than rhetorical. He is moving to reverse decades of Federal housing policy that he says has not just tolerated racial segregation but promoted it. Most notably, he is trying to make subsidized housing less concentrated in central cities and more prevalent in white suburbs, an effort, he acknowledges, that will be met with fierce local opposition.
"I'm not naive about how difficult this is," he said. "Suburban settings don't want to accept public housing."
Mr. Cisneros, as is his manner, has been careful to avoid criticizing his colleagues by name, though he has cited disagreements with the Democratic Leadership Council, the organizational umbrella of "New Democrats" that Mr. Clinton once headed.
He has been careful to praise Mr. Clinton's racial sensibilities, saying, "I am perfectly respectful of where the President's instincts bring him out on this issue."
 
'Race Is Core of Problems'
 But Mr. Cisneros's critique of urban poverty places him at odds with a view endorsed by many Democrats, including some of the Administration's top appointees.
That view acknowledges the historic impact of racism. But it argues that the quandary of the black urban ghettos today stems more directly from other problems, like family break-up, drug abuse, failures in education and the economic shifts that have reduced the number of well-paying, low-skilled jobs.
By contrast, Mr. Cisneros insists that "race is at the core of the problems which confront America's urban areas" and says, "That is not a message that resonates well with some of the New Democrats."
Mr. Cisneros's housing proposals are also, in many regards, at odds with those of his predecessor, Jack F. Kemp. Mr. Kemp also criticized racial division and talked about the need for poor people and minorities to have choices in where they live. But he placed his greatest emphasis on plans to let inner-city residents improve, not flee, the ghettos, by buying their homes.
It is unclear how much support Mr. Cisneros will ultimately find at the White House. He said the President has been "very supportive" of his views, and in mid-April he gave a well-received presentation to senior White House aides.
But during the Presidential campaign, Mr. Clinton sought an image of independence from minority advocacy groups, which, like Mr. Cisneros, have argued that racism remains a central fact of American life. And Mr. Clinton has been seeking to court the centrist and conservative legislators most likely to be skeptical of Mr. Cisneros's actions and views.
In a recent interview in his office, Mr. Cisneros summoned several top aides for what became a mini-seminar on race in America.
Recounting a night he had recently spent in the Ida B. Wells public housing development on the South Side of Chicago, Mr. Cisneros painted an eerie portrait of waking to morning fog and young corpses, victims of gang warfare.
In telling the story, he emphasized what he called the "spatial separation" of that public housing complex and others from the rest of society. That isolation, he said, keeps residents away from good jobs and good schools and breeds such problems as violence and drug abuse.
 
New Policy in Dallas
 Conservative analysts have viewed the same circumstances and faulted inert bureaucracies in public schools, rampant teen-age pregnancy or leniency toward crime; Mr. Cisneros argues that the villain is racism.
"This was deliberate," said Mr. Cisneros, contending that even now, Federal rules cause public housing to be concentrated in areas dominated by poor minorities. "This didn't just happen." He characterized the Government's historic attitude as, "Let's just put them on the other side of the tracks and keep them there."
One tangible result of his thinking can be seen in Dallas, where Mr. Cisneros has said he will reverse a previous HUD plan to expand a sprawling public housing development, arguing that it would concentrate too many poor people and minorities in one place.
Mr. Cisneros has also begun negotiations with some suburban governments, like those outside Detroit, to encourage them to accept a larger share of a metropolitan area's subsidized housing. The department may offer financial incentives, like increased block grant money, to governments that cooperate.
Similarly, Mr. Cisneros is looking to expand voucher programs that give residents of public housing the opportunities to move to private apartments in the suburbs.
Beyond the area of subsidized housing, Mr. Cisneros has pledged stricter enforcement of the nation's fair housing laws, which forbid discrimination at any income level.
And he is seeking greater Government scrutiny of banks and insurance companies to prevent discrimination against minority customers.
Some conservatives have accused Mr. Cisneros of reviving a bankrupt philosophy that tries to portray poor minorities only as victims. In a recent article in Reason magazine, James P. Pinkerton, a domestic policy aide to President George Bush, assailed Mr. Cisneros as being "politically correct."
But many housing advocates are praising the new emphasis on race. "It's the most important shift in housing policy I've seen in 25 years," said Florence Roisman, a lawyer with the National Housing Law Center, which provides advice to lawyers for the poor.
 
An Equation of 2 Parts
 At times, Mr. Cisneros's comments seem a bit puzzling. While he has criticized the Democratic Leadership Council, for instance, he has also adopted a good amount of the group's thought and language.
That is the case when he argues, as he almost always does, that the focus on race should not obscure "other questions of behavior and individual responsibility."
Mr. Cisneros also approvingly cites the work of William Julius Wilson, a sociologist at the University of Chicago who has helped provide a theory of the black underclass that draws on both economic and social explanations. What is odd about the reference is that Mr. Wilson came to prominence by de-emphasizing the role of racism; he even wrote a book called "The Declining Significance of Race."
Mr. Cisneros responds by saying that he is simply trying to emphasize both parts of the equation, the role of racial discrimination and the importance of upright personal behavior.
The force of Mr. Cisneros's statements has invited the speculation that he may also be sending a subtle message beyond HUD, toward a President or a party that he may sense drifting toward the right.
Indeed, at one point in the interview while discussing racial issues, Mr. Cisneros sounded as if he might be reprising some of the criticism leveled against Mr. Clinton during the Presidential campaign. For instance, he criticized unidentified people who "play the wedge politics of winning favor with one group by disparaging another."
That sounded very much like what Mr. Clinton's critics had said of him, after he appeared before a group of the Rev. Jesse Jackson's supporters and criticized the rap performer Sister Souljah.
But Mr. Cisneros is known for courting, not confronting, his patrons, and he added that the "particular genius of President Clinton is his ability to find the language that bridges."
He insists that his argument is not with the Administration but with the culture at large.
"I know this is a difficult subject and that people tire of hearing of the role of race," he said. But he added: "It is so clear, the effect that it has in America's urban settings, that I think we have to deal with it."

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN TOKYO;
MANY LOOSE ENDS MUST BE TIED UP

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 7

 BODY:
An agreement to cut tariffs that was heralded here today as a significant achievement still leaves several contentious issues to be resolved before the completion of an accord to lower worldwide barriers to trade.
Officials at the meeting of leaders of the Group of Seven industrial democracies said today that despite its shortcomings, their agreement could end up as the biggest surprise and their most important accomplishment here, breathing new life into trade talks that have dragged on for years. 
 Under the agreement, reached today by the United States, Canada, Japan, Germany, France, Italy and Britain, tariffs would be eliminated on products ranging from beer to bulldozers, and from pharmaceuticals to furniture.
 
Beyond Expectations
 Details released today show that the "market access" package is less comprehensive than what had been hoped for, but is nonetheless broader than what had been expected, owing in part to a dramatic last-minute move by Japan to break a logjam by agreeing to eliminate tariffs on liquor.
The package is now expected to serve as the basis for resumption of global trade talks on Monday in Geneva. This talks, known as the Uruguay Round, are sponsored by the international convention known as the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
Trade officials acknowledged that there is a great difference between restarting the seven-year-old Uruguay Round and finishing it by Dec. 15, the deadline for presenting the proposed treaty to Congress, which must vote on the accord without amending it.
In addition, some unesolved issues were just swept under the rug. In that sense, today's agreement is not so much a specific list of tariff cuts as it is a framework for how to proceed.
 
What Is Not Covered
 There was no real agreement, for instance, on tariff reductions for electronics products imported by Europe and wood imported by Japan, both of which would benefit United States companies. Nor is there an agreement on trade in services, leaving unresolved such contentious issues as laws that protect United States shipping companies and let Europe restrict foreign television programs.
In the case of United States imports of textiles and apparel, there is an expectation that some particularly high tariffs will be cut by up to a half, but that is subject to more talks. "The real negotiations on textiles have yet to take place," said Hugo Paemen, a European Community negotiator.
The renewed sense of optimism was nonetheless widely shared.
"Today was truly a breakthrough," Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, said at a news conference, describing the accord as the largest package of tariff cuts in history. He added that it would create jobs and give "new confidence in not only our trading system but in our economy."
Roderick Abbott, a European negotiator, estimated that the accord would reduce tariffs on trade between the United States and the European Community by 40 percent.
But even if the outstanding issues are resolved among the major traders, the other 100 or so members of GATT must rejoin negotiations and ratify the tariff cuts if they are to become truly global. Some less developed nations that depend on textile exports might want to see deeper cuts in textile tariffs by the United States.
Moreover, elimination of tariffs on industrial products is only one part of the broader GATT agreement being sought. The "market access" talks that took place here deliberately left out the most divisive issue standing in the way of a full agreement -- trade in farm products. Agriculture, as well as unresolved issues like unfair pricing, are to be addressed later this year.
Economists argue that free trade allows each country to produce what it makes best, so total world output rises. GATT estimates that extending global trading rules to cover services, textiles, agriculture and intellectual property could add $200 billion to the annual global income.
But elimination of tariffs and other protection can be painful for industries that are suddenly subject to foreign competition. With the world in recession, pressure for protectionism has been growing and the idea of free trade has been losing its luster.
 
The Trade Categories
 France's leaders have called for protection against products from low-wage countries and have expressed doubts about the market-access agreement. And while the United States supports the GATT process, anti-dumping duties levied on imported steel and the Administration's pursuit of numerical targets in trade with Japan are viewed by both Europe and Japan as violations of free-trade principles.
Today's agreement would phase out tariffs and non-tariff barriers on eight categories of products -- pharmaceuticals, construction equipment, medical equipment, beer and steel, and, subject to some exceptions, furniture, farm equipment and liquor. The United States is particularly strong in pharmaceuticals and medical equipment and might see increased exports.
Another category covers products on which tariffs are higher than 15 percent, which makes imports prohibitively expensive. These affect United States imports of textiles, apparel, glass and ceramics.
For these products, talks are to be held on halving the highest tariffs. United States negotiators said they are proposing phasing in tariff cuts to shield American companies.
Yet another category covers products for which no agreement could be reached. These are electronics, wood, paper, non-ferrous metals and scientific equipment.
For these items, four governments agreed to negotiate tariff cuts that average at least one-third over all the products. This gives countries room to protect certain industries. For instance, Europe might be able to avoid eliminating tariffs on semiconductors if it cuts tariffs for other products enough to average a 33 percent cut for the whole group.
Only two days ago, trade officials were pessimistic about getting much of an agreement. But on Tuesday, trade ministers met until late into the night to prevent what might have been the death of the Uruguay Round.
"There clearly was a looking-into-the-abyss kind of thing," said one participant.
As the clock approached 3 A.M., Japan came under pressure to reduce its tariffs on liquor. Yoshiro Mori, the Minister of International Trade and Industry, and Kabun Muto, the Foreign Minister, said they would have to consult with Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa, and the meeting adjourned.
This morning, Mr. Mori announced Japan's willingness to eliminate tariffs on brandy and whiskey. With that concession, Canada agreed to eliminate tariffs on beer and furniture. The European Community, which had been seeking an end to Canadian tariffs on furniture, said it would reciprocate by eliminating tariffs on farm equipment.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
What's $400-an-Ounce Gold Called? A Start

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
Now investors know this gold rally has legs. But how's its stamina?
So far, pretty good. Spot gold prices flirted with the level of $400 an ounce yesterday for the first time in almost three years, continuing the blistering rally that began in mid-April. 
 Prices settled back at $395.80, up $4.15, at the London afternoon fixing. In later trading at the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for August delivery continued the run-up, settling $4.70 higher at $397.80 an ounce. [Page D15.]
With investors willing to pay almost as much for gold as they were during the Persian Gulf war, is gold readying itself to burst through the psychological barrier of $400 an ounce? Absolutely, say the gold bugs, and not because of some wisp of market opinion that could dissipate in the morning air. This rally, they say, will be around a while, largely because of long-term supply and demand imbalances and a renewed interest by longtime gold investors.
"This is no flash in the pan," said Ian MacDonald, manager of precious metal marketing with Credit Suisse. "This is a long-term phenomenon. After more than a decade of poor fundamentals, things look good heading forward several years."
In recent trading, gold has closed near the highs of the day, often opening higher the next morning. The number of open gold futures contracts has risen along with the price, a sign traders say indicates investor comfort with these price levels.
That is not to say that gold is destined to head upward each trading session. Even the most bullish gold traders and analysts say they expect consolidation in coming weeks, as traders take profits. That alone could hold gold below the $400 mark anywhere from a day to several weeks.
And the experts say that gold is certain to hit more resistance between $425 and $450 an ounce, a range in which the prices begin to slow jewelry sales.
But the long-term trends will continue to point upward, as the long dormant market snaps alive again.
The trend underscores the unique investment nature of gold. Since it is both a commodity and monetary vehicle, its market is shaped by the widest range of events, from the collapse of the Soviet Union to violence in South Africa to drops in European interest rates to inflation in China to your neighbor's decision to buy his wife some jewelry for their anniversary.
To a large degree, the seeds of the resurgence of gold were planted during its precipitous fall in recent years that pushed it down as far as $325 an ounce just last fall.
Lack of market action for years pushed out many international traders, particularly Middle Easterners, who moved to other commodity markets where greater intraday movement meant more profit potential.
The 1991 collapse of the Soviet Union created new pressure on gold, as the Russian central bank began dumping thousands of tons of it onto the marketplace in a rapid grab for sorely needed international capital. As the price fell, more of gold's biggest admirers lost their affection.
For example, Swiss investment advisers, who had long urged that clients hold at least 10 percent of their portfolios in gold, lowered that figure to zero as the price kept sliding. "One of the biggest factors in Europe's avoidance of the market was that change by the Swiss," Daniel Weissman, head precious metals trader at MTB Bank in New York, said.
The price fall fed itself. Last fall, with gold prices so much lower, Belgian and Dutch central banks sold off gold all the way down to the bottom. "The central banks' action was part of the reason for the lower prices," said Joseph Rosta, research director for the CPM Group, a precious metals and commodities consulting firm.
But all this pessimism set up the rally now under way. Mining companies cut back on exploration because low gold prices made much of it uneconomical. That move, which could not be quickly changed because of the years needed for a single project, was sure to tighten the gold supply.
Gold demand soon exceeded supply. This year, the estimated demand for gold for jewelry and industrial needs is 83 million ounces, according to the CPM Group, up 6 percent from last year. The supply is estimated at only 80 million ounces.
At the same time, more potential demand was being created. The growing popularity worldwide of mutual funds led to the creation of more gold funds -- a ready stable of cash sure to be thrown at the market at the earliest turn. Nine of the 17 offshore gold funds and 12 of the 33 registered domestic open-end gold funds have been established since 1988, according to Lipper Analytical Securities.
Inflation fears in China created another drive in demand for gold that traders estimate has accounted for some 30 percent of the rally. And a huge bet on gold in April by Sir James Goldsmith, the British-French financier, and George Soros, a renowned fund manager and speculator, was the final spark the tinderbox needed.
Now, traders and analysts say, with the market's rise, Middle Eastern investors have jumped back in, pushing prices even higher. Swiss investment advisers raised their recommended holdings of gold to 10 percent again. Gold funds worldwide have been plowing capital into the markets, showing their strongest returns in years. Central banks no longer seem eager to sell gold.
"Small investors, medium-sized investors, institutional investors -- the whole myriad of investors are in now, from all over the world." Mr. Rosta said.

HEADLINE: Iraq and U.N. Open Talks on Limited Oil Sales

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, July 7

 BODY:
Negotiations on Iraq's request to sell a limited amount of oil to raise money for food and medicine opened at the United Nations today with the head of the Iraqi delegation saying he would stay in New York to negotiate for "as long as necessary."
After an initial two-hour session, the talks were adjourned until Thursday. 
 Riyadh al-Qaysi, the second ranking official in the Iraqi Foreign Ministry, arrived here on Tuesday to discuss a Security Council decision made almost two years ago that permits Iraq to resume limited sales of oil to raise money for humanitarian needs.
Iraq has all along spurned the offer, and therefore Iraq's apparent renewed interest in even restricted oil sales fueled speculation that the trade sanctions voted against Iraq after its invasion of Kuwait have been having an effect, with Iraq's foreign reserves dwindling and its population suffering shortages of basic supplies.
The Security Council resolutions on Iraqi oil sales, passed in August and September 1991, allow the country to sell up to $1.6 billion worth of oil, but under strict conditions. About 30 percent of the money raised would have to be used to pay reparations to Kuwaiti victims of the 1990 Iraqi invasion; another portion would help defray the costs of United Nations teams working in Iraq and Kuwait. The portion of the proceeds that would go to Iraq would have to be used only for humanitarian purposes and its disbursement would be supervised by the United Nations.
In rejecting the offer, Iraq has complained that the restrictions were an intrusion on the country's sovereignty. Among the specific issues to be negotiated is a requirement that the oil sold by Iraq would have to be shipped via a pipeline through Turkey, which would be easier to monitor than if the sales were allowed at Iraq's own ports on the Persian Gulf. The Iraqis have said that the fees they would have to pay Turkey are too high.
The apparent desire of the Iraqis to make a breakthrough on the issue led oil prices to fall last week to their lowest level since the Persian Gulf War. The decline came after the American representative to the United Nations, Madeleine K. Albright, said the United States would not object to Iraqi oil sales if the Security Council's conditions are respected.

Iraq Bracing for U.N. Showdown
 BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 7 (Special to The New York Times) -- The Iraqi Government appeared to be preparing for another showdown with the United Nations Security Council today over its refusal to allow surveillance cameras at two missile testing stations. The cameras are to insure that no steps are taken to develop long-range missiles.
Development of such missiles is forbidden under the terms of the cease-fire agreement negotiated following the Persian Gulf war in 1991.
Meeting in emergency session, the Iraqi Parliament voted overwhelmingly to stop the United Nations from carrying out "unfair action" against the country in the future and issued a threat to retaliate against any further American attacks.
"We respect the United Nations, its Security Council and Charter but we can't accept that the United Nations or its commissions take unfair action against Iraq and Iraqis," said the Parliament Speaker, Saadi Mahdi Saleh.
