HEADLINE: Haitian Senator Resists Terms of Pact on Aristide

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, July 7

 BODY:
For Thomas Eddy Dupiton, a silky politician who lays claim to the presidency of Haiti's boisterous and badly split Senate, news that the United Nations is seeking a purge of some of his institution's members as part of a settlement of Haiti's crisis falls somewhere between a surprise and an annoyance.
Although Haiti's army signed an accord last week in New York that is expected to lead to a return of democracy, Mr. Dupiton, the leader of a bloc of parliamentarians who have fought for months to obstruct diplomatic efforts aimed at restoring the country's elected President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, shows no signs yet of giving in.
 
A Donkey Out of Place?
 Told that Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, who presided over Father Aristide's overthrow in September 1991, had signed the accord on Saturday, Mr. Dupiton, a courtly man with a gift for the quick aphorism, exclaimed, "Each donkey should bray in its own pasture!" 
 United Nations mediators who brokered the agreement, intended to reinstall Father Aristide on Oct. 30, see the agreement of General Cedras as a crucial breakthrough, but in this country, where the political class is habitually frozen in irreconcilable schisms and the flair for political sabotage is highly developed, no one is taking Mr. Dupiton's resistance lightly.
Haiti's economy has ground almost to a complete halt under the weight of international sanctions, including a June 23 United Nations ban on oil shipments to the country. Under the terms of the recent settlement, the embargo cannot be lifted until the Parliament is purged of members who won office in a January election that is widely seen as illegitimate, after which Father Aristide's choice for a new Prime Minister must be ratified.
Although few see any chance that Mr. Dupiton will be able to craft a legislature that could prevent Father Aristide's return, diplomats and Haitian political analysts say that by merely stalling, he is stoking potentially explosive complications that could derail the hard-won settlement.
 
Link to Army Suspected
 In fact, given the adamancy of his resistance, many have begun to wonder if the 51-year-old former New York City messenger and social worker has secret backing from elements of the army.
Mr. Dupiton, a tall man given to fine suits and animated gestures, claims that he has been misunderstood all along. Rather than opposing Father Aristide, he says, he is eager to welcome him home with "a kiss of peace and a fraternal hug."
Mention of the nine contested senators and four deputies who were elected in January, however, elicits a more combative response.
"If Father Aristide persists in questioning the right of the parliamentarians in saving the country, we must understand that he wishes for the explosion of the state," he said. "The only thing I can do is maintain my serenity and wait for their attack, saying, 'Fall on me. You can hurt me, but you can never vanquish my spirit.' "
 
Preparations for Exile?
 Political adversaries say they have learned to watch carefully what Mr. Dupiton does and not what he says.
"He is buying goods and houses and land in New York, and I have precise information," said Rony Mondestin, a rival senator. "He is benefiting from this crisis."
Father Aristide's allies, meeting to figure out how to peacefully force the contested senators from office, have concentrated so far on conciliatory gestures. One widely circulated idea has been to offer jobs to two or three of the senators who would lose their positions, or promise not to oppose them in a future election, hoping the others would be forced to follow.
But so far, Mr. Dupiton has shown no sign of accepting a graceful way out.
"I don't know what people mean by the term normalizing the Senate," he said, "but since we already consider ourselves normal, the question is closed."

HEADLINE: State Police Link Possible 18th Victim to Suspect in Slayings

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., July 7

 BODY:
State police officials said today that they were intensifying their investigation of Joel Rifkin, the unemployed gardener who confessed to killing 17 women, after linking him Tuesday night to a possible 18th victim that he had not told them about.
The latest victim, Mary Katherine Williams, 31, an aspiring actress originally from Charlotte, N.C., was identified by the Yorktown police as the woman whose naked and badly decomposed body was found Dec. 21 in a wooded area of Westchester County. She is the first victim Mr. Rifkin did not confess to killing, but whose death has been connected to him through evidence the police collected in a search of his East Meadow bedroom.
 
Inquiry to Widen
 "It is clear that Mary Katherine Williams is now one of 18 possible victims," Capt. Walter Heesch of State Police Troop L Headquarters in East Farmingdale said in a statement. "Although Joel Rifkin did not state to investigators any details of that particular case, identification papers bearing her name were found in Rifkin's bedroom." 
 Credit cards belonging to Ms. Williams, taken from Mr. Rifkin's room, allowed the police to trace the victim to Charlotte, where her father, Dr. Egbert Williams, provided her dental records for a positive identification, said Lieut. Anthony Masi, of the Yorktown Police Department.
State police say the total number of Mr. Rifkin's victims, whom he described as prostitutes he had patronized, is unknown. So far, the police have connected 10 women by name to Mr. Rifkin and four others whose bodies have not been positively identified. Another newly identified victim was Maryann Holloman, 39, whose body was found in a 55-gallon drum in Coney Island Creek last July.
"The 17 number was based on his admitted cases," said State Trooper Kelly Shonholz, a spokeswoman. "This case in Yorktown, the whole investigation, came about based on evidence that we found in his home, not on his confession."
Officials say their investigation, the most extensive since the capture of another serial killer, Arthur Shawcross in Rochester in the early 1980's, would broaden. There are 50 state police investigators and troopers -- along with countless local law-enforcement officials -- sifting through evidence found in Mr. Rifkin's room and checking it against the records of women whose bodies have been discovered in the last few years.
Robert Sale, Mr. Rifkin's attorney, said he would not comment on the new allegations. In the past, he has complained that the police were unjustly seeking to blame Mr. Rifkin for a disparate array of unsolved crimes in the New York region.
 
Questions About Search
 Today, Mr. Sale said he had asked the Nassau County District Attorney, Denis E. Dillon, to investigate the search the police conducted of Mr. Rifkin's bedroom, about which he said he had "serious questions." He declined to specify his misgivings.
Ed Grilli, a spokesman for Mr. Dillon, said an assistant district attorney had so far found no irregularities.
Investigators declined to say whether Mr. Rifkin's link to Ms. Williams had altered their view of the confessed serial killer's selection of victims or his approach.
"I don't know if it indicates a different m.o. for him," Trooper Shonholz said, using the abbreviation for modus operandi. "It may indicate that he obviously didn't tell us everything. Not all of these women have been confirmed prostitutes either."

HEADLINE: $166 Million Distributed for Summer Jobs

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 7

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration said today that it was distributing $166.5 million to the states for additional summer jobs for poor teen-agers, bringing to 700,000 the number of jobs available to them. .
Despite the new money, the number of jobs is just half the 1.3 million the Administration had planned to provide this year. In his $16.3 billion proposal to stimulate the economy last winter, President Clinton sought $1 billion for summer jobs in addition to the $868 million left over from last summer and available from earlier appropriations. 
 But the request was withdrawn after a Senate filibuster led by Republicans, and Mr. Clinton had to settle for the $166.5 million, which was included in a $1 billion appropriations measure passed by Congress last Thursday.
The jobs for the poor aged 14 to 21 include clerical work in city offices, recreational work at parks, nursing assistance in hospitals and supervision of children at day-care centers.
A Labor Department survey of 40 cities in May and early June suggested that federally subsidized jobs would be available this summer for only about half the applicants.
The additional funds now being distributed include about $408,000 for states like Delaware, Hawaii, North and South Dakota, Vermont and Wyoming, to $12 million for New York and more than $21 million for California.

HEADLINE: Office Rents Tops in Tokyo

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 7

 BODY:
Office rents in Tokyo were the highest in the world in a 1992 survey of such charges in major cities, but placed second to London if other costs like taxes and management fees were included, Japan's Economic Planning Agency said today.
An agency official attributed the high rents to demand in Tokyo, noting a vacancy rate of 5 percent compared with 15 percent in New York. He said the agency surveyed office rents in the best business districts in major cities. 
 The official said the average monthly rent for 37 square feet of office space in Tokyo was $379. It was followed by Paris at $306; London, $251; Frankfurt, $217; New York, $182; Chicago, $134; Los Angeles, $126, and Brussels, $100.

HEADLINE: George Squibb Dies; Drug Executive, 78, Chided the Industry

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
George S. Squibb, a retired drug company executive who sometimes criticized the pharmaceutical industry, died on Sunday at a hospital in Providence, R.I. He was 78 and lived in Jamestown, R.I.
The cause of death was heart failure, a family spokesman said. 
 Mr. Squibb worked for 30 years for E. R. Squibb & Sons, which was founded by his great-grandfather, Edward.
Early in his career, Mr. Squibb worked in the company's distribution and sales divisions. In 1949 he was promoted to secretary of the company and in 1953 became the director of domestic administrative operations. Later he was the vice president in charge of sales and marketing.
In 1967, after he retired, he gave testimony critical of the pharmaceutical industry before the Senate Subcommittee on Monopoly.
He accused some in the industry of "exploitation of medicines used in life-preserving situations by setting prices far above the cost." He said this was wrong "no matter what justification or economic temptation is felt by the manufacturer."
Because of the public need for medicine, he said, the industry has a special obligation and should lower prices even if it means lower profits. He also said the industry sometimes did poor research and wasted money.
Mr. Squibb was born in Brookline, Mass., and grew up in Providence. He graduated from Harvard in 1936 and earned a law degree at New York University in 1953.
He was the former commodore of the Larchmont and Saunderstown Yacht Clubs and past president of the National Club Association of Washington and the Dunes Club in Narragansett, R.I.
His first two wives, the former Ida Ellerson and Beatrice Read, are dead.
He is survived by his wife, the former Thayer Keeler; two sons, George S. 3d of Pomfret, Vt., and John E. of North Branford, Conn.; two daughters, Colin Reeves of Little Rock, Ark., and Mary Patterson Squibb of Denver, and three grandchildren.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold Prices Continue Rally As Fears of Inflation Grow

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold futures continued their move higher on New York's Commodity Exchange yesterday as interest rate cuts in Europe helped touch off inflation fears.
On other markets, soybeans rallied while grains fell, energy futures declined, copper rose and livestock and meat futures were mixed. 
 Trading in gold futures followed movement in the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 key commodity prices, considered an indicator of inflation.
The index fluctuated broadly in reaction to the selloff in grain and energy futures, and gold responded in kind, Bette Raptopoulos, an analyst with Prudential Securities, said. But gold recovered well and maintained its gains, she said, approaching the $400 threshold.
Contributing to gold's strength was instability in the currency markets, where traders were shifting some money to gold, Ms. Raptopoulos said. She also noted that Germany and other European countries had cut interest rates to stimulate their economies, which could cause inflation.
Gold for August delivery settled $4.70 higher at $397.80 a troy ounce; July silver was four-tenths of a cent higher at $5.10 a troy ounce.
Soybean futures continued their rally on the Chicago Board of Trade as wet weather plagued the Midwest crop area and forecasts called for more rain.
The Agriculture Department's crop progress figures, released Tuesday, indicated that more than four million acres intended for soybeans remained unplanted through Sunday. Some acres that have been planted are threatened by flooding and disease because of the rain.
Grain futures fell as traders decided to take profits from Tuesday's price surge.
Crude oil futures fell on the New York Mercantile Exchange on weakness of gasoline futures, which declined on rumors that several ships carrying European gasoline were sailing to the United States.

HEADLINE: 9 New Jersey Hospitals Sue Blue Cross Over Ban

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, July 7

 BODY:
Nine hospitals that were excluded from a program of managed medical care filed suit in Federal court here today against Blue Cross-Blue Shield of New Jersey, charging that the program violated antitrust laws.
Blue Cross-Blue Shield, New Jersey's largest health insurer with 2.3 million customers, eventually wants to enroll most of its policyholders in a health maintenance organization. It announced in April that it had signed up 56 of the state's 85 acute care hospitals for the program; they would provide services at reduced rates in exchange for high patient volume that allows some economy of scale. 
 The issues in the suit reflect the turmoil that underlies the national debate over health-care reform, as insurers, doctors and patients confront the fact that reduced costs often equal reduced choices on where medical care is offered.
 
29 Hospitals Left Out
 "What you are seeing here is someone trying to stop a runaway train by standing on the tracks and waving their hands and yelling, 'Stop!' " said Fred Hillmann, a spokesman for New Jersey Blue Cross.
He said the insurer was aware of the suit, although it had not yet seen it. "From everything we know, it is a frivolous suit and proves that anyone can hire a lawyer," Mr. Hillman said.
Although 29 hospitals were left out of the new managed care network, only nine of them joined in the lawsuit, he noted. "If this is such a critical question, why aren't the 20 others involved in this suit?" Mr. Hillman said.
Representatives of the hospitals bringing the suit said the others had chosen to seek remedies through legislative or other paths.
 
Hardship on Patients Seen
 Dr. Joseph N. Micale, president of the Medical Society of New Jersey, said that while the society is not a party to the lawsuit, it "shares the concerns over access and quality of care with the hospitals filing the lawsuit."
While the society understands the need to look at the role of managed care in the health-care system, he said, "Blue Cross's recent decision to exclude certain hospitals from its HMO Blue network places a tremendous hardship on many patients who have had their access to care severely reduced."
Judah I. Labovitz, the lawyer for the nine hospitals in the suit, said that a major issue is a Blue Cross requirement that participating hospitals agree not to charge a competitive insurer a rate any less than it charges Blue Cross without automatically giving Blue Cross that same rate.
In doing so, Mr. Labovitz said, "Blue Cross has sought to fix prices and restrain competition from alternative health care plans."
He also said that the big insurer had discriminated against non-network hospitals by announcing that it would pay subscriber claims to network hospitals within 48 hours, but could take up to 60 days to make payments to non-network hospitals under law.
Mr. Hillmann of Blue Cross said, "If we do that, it is part of getting an additional discount" for quick payment. "We negotiate contracts to benefit our subscriber base," he said.
Mr. Labovitz said that no date had been set for a hearing in the case. He also said that he would seek an injunction to stop implementation of the new managed care plan, but acknowledged that he had not yet done so pending some response from the insurer.
The nine hospitals taking part in the suit are Beth Israel, Passaic; Dover General, Dover; Hospital Center, Orange; Montclair Community, Montclair; Newcomb Medical Center, Vineland; Palisades General, North Bergen; St. Elizabeth, Elizabeth; St. Mary's, Passaic; and Warren Hospital at Phillipsburg.

HEADLINE: Revolution of People Power Wells Up in the Bronx;
Residents Who Survived Bad Times Alter Development Plans for Their Neighborhood

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
Tissue-thin maps laced with a tangle of free-hand drawings covered the tables and walls of an urban planning studio where small clumps of architects and designers were sketching their vision for a new 30-block community in the South Bronx.
Theirs is an atypical atelier -- a ground-floor apartment on Courtlandt Avenue in Melrose. Even unlikelier, however, are their partners in planning -- a group of neighborhood people who not long ago beat back the plan and the possibility of eviction from their houses, apartments and stores. 
 Tales of scrappy residents heading off development schemes are reasonably standard fare in a city that roots for the underdog. But what's going on in Melrose is something else again: In an effort that city officials admit must be the wave of the urban-renewal future, Yolanda Garcia, Glen Stupart, Pedro Cintron and dozens of their neighbors have become grass-roots planners in dissecting, discussing and developing a new design for Melrose Commons, a housing development proposed for an area long buffeted by arson, abandonment and crime.
With each park, building and plaza they help design, residents say, they are insuring that they will not be rewarded for staying put during the lean years by being pushed out to make way for progress.
It is a sign of changing times -- or grass-roots revenge -- that this comes in a borough whose decline some trace to the master builder Robert Moses and his community-be-damned attitude when the Cross Bronx Expressway steamrolled through neighborhoods that never quite rebounded.
"If this area deteriorated, it wasn't because of the people -- it deteriorated because of poor city planning," said Yolanda Garcia, a leader of the We're Staying Committee whose family has owned a carpet store on Third Avenue for decades. "If we kept our area up when it was in dire need of repair, we should be part of the progress."
Officials say the collaboration has caused them to question how they have planned in the past, adding that such grass-roots partnerships that involve residents in planning rather than after-the-fact reviewing will increasingly determine the fortunes of any large, publicly financed urban renewal project.
"People have to feel they have to create and own whatever is happening in their communities in order to feel an interest in sustaining it," said Richard A. Kahan, chairman of the steering committee for the Bronx Center, a major development plan that encompasses Melrose Commons. "This is the strongest and most effective way to carry out an urban renewal process. The priorities have to be from the community. It's not about us selling our priorities."
 
Scaling Back
 Plans for Melrose Commons date back to the early 1980's, when city planners and housing officials tossed about ideas for development of what had become the largest contiguous stretch of municipally owned land in the city -- a tract that snaked through the area south of 161st Street, to the east of Yankee Stadium. At one point, they envisioned a middle-income community of 4,000 units spread out among 30 city blocks of small, attached houses. The plan changed as officials grappled with financing, and in its most recent incarnation was scaled back to 2,600 units and became part of the Bronx Center, a 300-block agenda of government, housing and commercial construction.
The planners now envision a mixed-income Melrose Commons. But there has been one constant throughout -- relocation. An environmental impact statement conducted in preparation for certification by planners and the City Council estimated that at worst, 78 private homes, 80 businesses employing 500 workers and 400 tenants might be displaced. While certification would have provided for a public comment period, some members of the plan's steering committee said Melrose Commons was being touted as a fait accompli.
"That was consistent with this whole idea that there's nothing there so let's clear it out anyway," said Harry DeRienzo, a housing advocate and member of the Bronx Center steering committee. "There was a whole community there, but no one ever walked the streets to talk to these people."
 
Angry Confrontation
 Residents said they first learned about Melrose Commons last summer, when one of their neighbors bumped into a city worker who was taking notes outside her house. When the Bronx Center people conducted a series of public forums late last year, Pedro Cintron angrily confronted city and borough officials.
"I got up and told them, 'Hell, no!" said Mr. Cintron, who has lived in Melrose for some 30 years. "How are you going to come here and bring out-of-town people and advocate on our behalf? They don't even know we're here."
Mr. Kahan, who had sat wordlessly in the audience, said it was a turning point in his thinking about the project. The abstractions of computer screens and blueprints had collided headlong with the realities of flesh-and-blood people.
"There was an issue here and a group of people here that we hadn't reached," said Mr. Kahan, who once headed the state's Urban Development Corporation. "This is about people living here who want to stay. We may have touched on it in an intellectual way, but after that meeting it was a very visceral issue."
With the encouragement of the office of Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer, the group met several times with city officials and were given the services of an organizer, who helped them form the We're Staying Committee. Borough officials also helped to halt the plan's certification while the group canvassed residents and met regularly to redraw the plan.
 
Gaining a Constant Role
 Among the group's goals are a gaining a constant role in the new plans, eliminating the need for relocation, and if some relocation is unavoidable having current residents receive priority for any new housing.
Working out of office space donated by a longtime resident, the group convenes weekly, sometimes traveling downtown to learn of new programs from various city agencies. During a recent meeting they discussed the possibility of attracting Federal funds for housing for the elderly as well as debating how much parking is needed for new houses.
They had already met with officials from the Department of Transportation to go over street patterns, which cannot be substantially disrupted without requiring additional environmental impact studies. They had also scrapped plans for a four-acre park that would have been in the development's center, after residents criticized it as an indefensible magnet for addicts and criminals. Instead, they are discussing the possibility of a series of mews running through the area, as well as smaller parks and plazas that would become the focus of neighborhood life.
The group gathered around a long table and began to toss out ideas for what to do with a proposed park near public restrooms on East 161st Street near Courtlandt Avenue.
"We want the comfort station to stay and become a market, a taxpayer where the merchants could take care of the park, too," she said.
Glen Stupart, who has lived in the area for 15 years, scanned the maps at a recent meeting and explained how he wanted the plan to respect the community's old-fashioned values.
"We have mom-and-pop stores, extended families and there's a certain manner the community has established, a way of life we have that's not commonplace everywhere," he said. "Those are ideas that have served this community well."
 
'Aware of What's Happening'
 "We got people understanding and aware of what's happening," said Hector Rodriguez, a member of the We're Staying Committee. "They really have an idea of what's about to happen, and the city came forward and gave us an opportunity to work on it."
City planners and housing officials said they have been impressed with the group's commitment to making the plan work. "Where we are now is at a very collaborative effort," said Sarah Gerecke, Assistant Commissioner for Production and Planning at the Department of Housing Preservation and Development. "They're interested in learning what it takes to make this happen."
Bernd Zimmerman, the former head of the Bronx city planning office who now works for the Borough President, said there was some truth to the resident's complaints that they were mostly unaware of what was in store for their area unless they happened to speak with their community board or with other city agencies.
While many of the public officials involved in the project portray it as a successful example of government's heeding the demands of the people, many in Melrose remain wary. After all, residents said, they are dealing with the same people who formulated the original concept.
Indeed, committee members vowed to continue organizing their neighbors to remind politicians that they cannot be taken for granted and they have set a deadline of July 26 for the final revised plan, well in advance of the primaries. To drive home their point, they have also embarked on a voter registration campaign.
"The government is cooperating but by no means are they the savior," Ms. Garcia said. "We want to make sure all the promises are kept. If the project takes 10 years to complete, we'll be around for 20."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Yields Stay Near Lows

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Interest rates were little changed yesterday as traders and investors marked time while yields on Treasury notes and bonds remained near their lowest levels in 20 years or more.
With yields so low, many investors are wary about new purchases of long-term Treasury issues. But with short-term interest rates barely above 3 percent, they are not willing to ignore the long-term market completely. 
 Three-month Treasury bills are at their lowest level since 1963, according to a Salomon Brothers compilation of monthly average interest rates since 1945. Two-year notes are about the lowest since early 1965, and long bonds are the lowest since early 1973.
For many investors, the answer has been to follow a middle road, buying issues that seem unusually cheap and avoiding investments aimed at profiting from a rise or fall in rates. These investors figure that even if bond yields rise, causing prices to fall, the extra yield they have earned by holding bonds rather than short-term issues will more than compensate for the price declines.
 
 
Market Is 'Too Choppy'
 "The market has become too choppy, with a big swing to higher rates when inflation looks like it is rising, and then a few weeks later another swing in the opposite direction when inflation looks lower," said Eric K. Cheung, a vice president and manager of fixed-income securities at the Wellington Trust Company of Delaware.
For the moment, the Treasury market is "fairly priced," Mr. Cheung said, as long as the Federal Reserve keeps the overnight rate for bank loans at 3 percent and inflation stays in a range of 3 percent to 3.5 percent. But he expects higher rates by next year, particularly for short-term maturities, as people become more willing to spend rather than to accumulate savings at very low interest rates.
Late yesterday, the Treasury's new 4 1/8 percent notes due in 1995 were offered at 100 1/4, unchanged, to yield 3.99 percent, while the 7 1/8 percent bonds due in 2023 were 105 25/32 , up 1/32 , to yield 6.67 percent, down from 6.68 percent on Tuesday.
 
 
New Mania for Munis
 In the municipal market, securities dealers anticipate stronger demand when investors recognize that Federal tax rates will rise for those with high incomes. In addition, they believe that many investors whose bonds were retired before maturity when local governments issued new bonds have still not reinvested the proceeds.
Such expectations led securities dealers to set yields on a new $355.3 million issue of the New York Local Government Assistance Corporation high enough to insure a quick sellout.
A member of the syndicate of securities dealers that handled the sale said, "There was some good institutional demand, but underwriters still took down some of the issue, and there are bonds available on the street."
The Local Government Assistance Corporation, which was created in 1990 to issue bonds to finance New York State's accumulated deficit and eliminate the state's annual spring borrowing, is rated A by Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's. The S.& P. rating is slightly higher than the A- rating it assigns to New York State's bonds because the state is required to put a fourth of its sales tax receipts in a special reserve fund, which can be used only to pay interest and principal on the corporation's bonds. In addition the corporation is allowed by law to issue no more than $4.7 billion of bonds.
 
 
State Corporation's Offering
 The corporation's bonds were offered yesterday through Goldman, Sachs & Company, with yields ranging from 4.4 percent for bonds due in 1999 to 5 percent in 2003 and 5.59 percent in 2011. Longer-term bonds included issues yielding 5.63 percent in 2013 and 2017 and 5.760 percent in 2018.
Investors seeking higher yields on bonds whose interest payments are exempt from New York State, New York City and Federal income tax may wait until the week of July 19, when New York City is expected to come to market with an offering of more than $700 million.
Dealers estimated yesterday that a city bond due in five years would yield about 4.9 or 5 percent, with 10-year bonds at 5.40 or 5.50 percent and bonds due in 20 years and more yielding slightly more than 6 percent. Those yields were unchanged from late last week when S.& P. said it would retain its A- rating on city bonds. Moody's reduced its rating on city bonds to Baa-1 a few years ago.
The city is one of the few issuers in New York that offers a 6 percent yield. This keeps demand strong enough that few of its bonds are available, except when new issues are offered.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mostly Up but Dips Vs. Yen as Group of 7 Meets

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday against major European currencies but weakened against the Japanese yen as leaders of the Group of Seven industrialized nations met in Tokyo.
Randolph Donney, the director of research at Pegasus Econometric Group in New York, said trading was relatively quiet, with news reports fueling the dollar's action against the yen and European denominations. 
 "It was pretty much waiting and watching to see what comes out of the G-7 at this stage," Mr. Donney said.
A Japanese news account quoted unnamed finance ministry officials as suggesting an exchange rate of 95 to 105 yen to the dollar was acceptable to the Japanese Government. That helped depress the dollar toward that range.
The dollar recovered somewhat on news from the meeting that the United States and its major trading partners had reportedly rescued stalled trade talks by agreeing to lower tariffs on hundreds of goods.
In New York, the dollar was quoted late yesterday at 107.65 yen, down from 108.83 late Tuesday. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 108.55 yen, up 0.30 yen from the Tuesday close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 107.68 yen.
Mr. Donney said a British news report that interest rates in Britain could come down in the near future had bolstered the dollar against the British pound. That strengthening also helped the dollar gain against other European currencies.
 
British Pound Lower
 Lower domestic interest rates tend to weaken a country's currency, because investors will often seek higher returns elsewhere.
In New York, the pound was trading at $1.4935, down from $1.5025 on Tuesday. In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.4925, down from $1.5104 late Tuesday.
Other late New York dollar rates, compared with late Tuesday, were: 1.7065 German marks, up from 1.7050; 1.5130 Swiss francs, up from 1.5115; 5.7735 French francs, up from 5.7668; 1,551.00 Italian lire, up from 1,546.00, and 1.2852 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2844.
Other European rates for the dollar, compared with late Tuesday, were: 1.7072 marks, up from 1.6997; 1.5160 Swiss francs, up from 1.5103; 5.7760 French francs, up from 5.7520; 1.9181 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9100; 1,550.00 Italian lire, up from 1,544.00.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Health Care in Rich and Poor Lands: Some Issues Are the Same.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
"Government needs to promote greater diversity in the financing and delivery of health services. . . . Regulation can strengthen private insurance markets by improving incentives for wide coverage and cost control. . . . Spending on health should be redirected to more cost-effective programs that do more to help the poor."
THE message sounds familiar. The medium, however, is not Hillary Rodham Clinton but the World Bank's latest World Development Report, published this week. And the subject is not the $800 billion lavished on the care of 250 million Americans, but the frugal $170 billion worth of services doled out to the 4.1 billion citizens of the globe's low- and middle-income countries. 
 The World Bank's focus is necessarily on who gets access to penicillin and clean drinking water rather than who is eligible for the fruits of modern medical technology like MRI scans and bone marrow transplants. Yet the core economic problems in rationing health services efficiently without much help from free markets (or moral philosophers) seem remarkably similar.
While very little is spent on health in the poorest two-thirds of the world, the report suggests that a little goes a long way. Child mortality has plummeted and life expectancy risen sharply over the last two decades, even in places that are testing humans' lower limits of subsistence.
This is modest comfort, however. The probability of a child dying before the age of 5 is still 30 times higher in Mozambique than in Singapore. By the World Bank's broadest measure of health -- the portion of the average life lost to disabling illness or premature death -- the rich industrial economies are five times healthier than sub-Saharan Africa and three times healthier than India.
Economic growth and education remain the fixes of choice, the main chance for people who are weakened by malnutrition and lacking knowledge of the rules of survival in a world seething with disease. But the bank's economists also point to the failure of poor countries to squeeze the biggest possible bang from a buck spent on health.
For example, basic treatment of leukemia typically adds just one-tenth of a year to an adult's life at a cost of about $5,000. Shifting the $5,000 to the provision of vitamin A supplements for children could generate 10,000 additional years of healthy life. Or it could mean an extra 1,500 to 5,000 years of life if invested in measles immunization.
By the same token, the payoff from relatively cheap improvements in the environment could be awesome. Keeping human and animal waste out of drinking water would reduce the total burden of disease in poor countries by 10 percent. More surprising, eliminating the smoke inside dwellings from cooking and heating could cut childhood pneumonia by half and reduce the burden of disease by 5 percent.
The World Bank staff estimates that a bare-bones package of public health services plus clinical care might cost as little as $12 a person in the neediest countries, yet reduce the burden of disease by 25 percent. Total cost: an extra $15 billion a year, a barely noticeable sum in a global economy with purchasing power that exceeds $20 trillion.
All this may seem frustrating, like one of those public service ads that promise to transform your pocket change into enough powdered milk to nourish a thousand starving infants for a year. If life-saving is so cheap, what are governments doing with the billions from charity and foreign aid?
An easy answer is that a good chunk of the money sent to poor countries is spent on toys for the ruling classes, weapons in particular. The answer emphasized in the World Bank report, one that links the health-care problems of the richest countries to the poorest, is that it is very hard to deliver any service efficiently without a lot of help from free markets. Third parties that only incidentally benefit from cost-effective outcomes -- insurance companies, governments, health delivery bureaucrats -- are not likely to make the right decisions.
For example, poor countries generally spend far too much of their health-care budgets on urban hospitals that offer sophisticated services to a tiny fraction of the population. By no coincidence, much of the subsidies for medical care go to middle- and upper-income families who have the least moral claim to public resources.
A part of the solution, the World Bank report argues, is to decentralize delivery and force deliverers to compete on cost and health outcomes -- in a phrase, to manage competition. But just as there is no panacea for health-care reform in America, there is none for the third world. Someone has to make basic choices about who gets what quality of medical care, and that someone is probably government.
Efficient health-care systems, it seems, may not be able to live with big government. But as a practical matter, they probably cannot live without it.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: First-Aid Kit: Forget Caboodle

BYLINE: By DEBORAH HOFMANN

 BODY:
STATISTICS compiled by the National Safety Council show that each year nearly 13 million children suffer preventable injuries serious enough to require medical attention. Yet too often, the medicine cabinet holds four brands of toothpaste but nothing for a sting or scald. Only after an accident or onset of illness does a panicky hunt begin for items to clean, cure and comfort.
Medical experts say that while a wisely stocked, convenient and orderly first-aid kit may not fully treat a health crisis, its value is in helping to limit pain and complications until a doctor's examination. 
 "It's idiotic not to have one," said Theodore Tyberg, a cardiologist at New York Hospital who helps patients set up kits for home and travel.
Beverly Hoover, a spokeswoman for the American Red Cross, said: "Cost is no excuse. And you don't need to be a medical student to put a good one together."
What should a thorough kit contain? Experts agree that consumers should not assume that any kit, even one bought in a surgical supply store, is complete, nor that the contents are necessarily safe.
Packaging differences can be confusing. Fancy kits marketed for boaters, campers or hikers may be identical to a generic home kit. And sizes range from wallet to attache case. So priorities must be clear. Is portability, say in a diaper or school bag, important? Do individual doses of ointments make more or less sense than full-size quantities?
Most often, a prepackaged kit will contain much of what you should have. But some items typically in kits are held in disfavor these days. Hydrogen peroxide, not long ago the most popular wound cleanser, "can damage tissue as it's bubbling dirt out," said Inspector Charles DeGaetano of New York City's Emergency Medical Service. Items like tourniquets require expertise; unskilled users can cause a loss of limb or fatally infect the victim's bloodstream.
Skeptically examine the label, which typically says a kit contains perhaps 200 items. "Be careful that most of what you're getting isn't just a million and one adhesive strips in a million and one sizes, and tiny samples and droplets of everything else," Mr. DeGaetano said. Helpful staples, yes. But far from a MASH unit. In addition, know that a lot of what's in some kits may never be used or will expire before they might be needed. Do not let a boast of scissors or tweezers be a deciding factor in paying more. In most kits, they're little better than toys. Buy good efficient instruments separately.
Other extras depend upon household needs. Children need more adhesive bandages, while an elderly person might need ammonia salts. So, a kit you build from scratch may or may not be more economical. Bought a la carte, costlier name-brand items are no better than generic ones. "If you're bleeding, it won't matter whose name is on the bandage," said Dr. Palmo Pasquariello, a Manhattan pediatrician.
Nearly all commercial kits contain basic pamphlets on first aid. Some kits meet American Red Cross standards and are often for sale at fund-raising activities through the organization's 2,700 chapters. Those made by Johnson & Johnson and by First Aid Only are among those that meet the criteria. All hold gauze pads bathed in iodine, antibacterial cream and alcohol, gauze stretch bandages, first-aid cream and antiseptic wipes.
First Aid Only, based in Vancouver, Wash., packages kits in 40 styles that are sold at drug and office supply stores, lumberyards and auto repair shops. The pocket-size "Personal Pack" and the children's "Ow-wee Pack," each with 29 items (of which 18 are adhesive strips), and "Sting Aid Pack, with 25 items (11 adhesive strips), are priced at $3, but discount stores often sell them for half that.
The comprehensive kit of 129 items ($25, often found for $20) contains gauze dressing pads (18), breathable, fabric adhesive bandages (52), an ammonia inhalant, latex gloves (disease barriers), "instant ice" compress, iodine, alcohol and antibacterial pads, eye pads, finger splints and, yes, scissors and tweezers. Versions with flashlight, a survival blanket and flares cost about $10 more.
Johnson & Johnson, based in New Brunswick, N.J., makes three popular kits at $5 to $12.
The New York Baby Proofing Company, 476 Columbus Avenue (83d Street), carries seven kits. Its best seller, said Tony Simnowski, a store owner, is the "Boo Boo and Comfort Kit," $35, made by Quality Kids Products in Santa Rosa, Calif.; (707) 527-1727 for direct orders. It holds generous bottles and tubes of antibiotic cream, calamine lotion, acetaminophen elixir, Ipecac syrup, tape and gauze pads, an "instant ice" compress, fever strips and cotton. Tweezers and scissors are a bit better than in the other kits. Animal motifs adorn the graduated toddler-style medicine spoon and adhesive bandages. Ignore the hydrogen peroxide.
Finally, the best first-aid kits are not meant to be portable emergency rooms. "They are there for acute issues," Dr. Pasquariello said. "Let an ambulance do the rest."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
New Agency Wins A Toyota Account

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
Four former executives at Martin, Davis, Omon & Partners of New York have left the agency to open their own shop: Oasis International Group Ltd. Oasis was awarded the Toyota corporate advertising account last month. The account, previously at Martin, Davis, Omon, has billings estimated at $5 million to $10 million.
The four partners are: Paul Bernasconi, 27, creative director; Rand Pearsall, 36, account director; Eric McClure, 30, media director, and Hilde Oord, 35, planning director. 
 Mr. Bernasconi said Oasis (the name is an acronym for "outstanding advertising sells itself") planned to hire six more employees and seek other accounts.
Tim Andree, group manager of external affairs at Toyota Motor Corporate Services of North America in New York, said Oasis was awarded the account after a review that included other agencies, but he declined to disclose their identities.

HEADLINE: Drugs, Crime and Punishment;
The War On Drugs Is Self-Defeating

BYLINE: By Jack B. Weinstein; Jack B. Weinstein is a judge in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

 BODY:
In the debate over national drug policy, too many policy makers, unsure of what might work or why, appear to rely upon what seems politically safe: harsher law enforcement based on more prison time.
A nonpartisan Federal Commission on Drugs needs to be formed. Its object should be to report candidly on the costs, benefits, risks and advantages of present and potential national drug policies. Such a commission could provide the fact-finding and serious analysis lacking in the political climate surrounding drugs. 
 The nation can look for guidance to the Wickersham Commission, appointed by President Hoover in 1929, whose report led to a full debate on Prohibition laws and a constitutional amendment returning responsibility to the states for control of alcohol. Also instructive is the National Commission on Marijuana and Drug Abuse, appointed by President Nixon in 1971, which recommended ending prosecution for possession of marijuana for private use.
So urgent is the issue that Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist in a speech in June said, "The law by itself is not going to solve the problems of drugs and violence," raising "questions of public policy which must be decided, not by lawyers, judges or other experts, but by the popularly elected branches of government" -- and ultimately, I think, by a well-informed electorate.
Attorney General Janet Reno, confronting the problem of drug crime immediately upon assuming office, emphasized the importance of reconsidering the existing policy.
America has had three national drug policies. Before 1914, a freedom model reigned. Opiates were sold as over-the-counter household remedies and marijuana was a legal crop. In 1914, we began to tax narcotics to control them, but we, like Britain, relied primarily on a medical model of treatment and prescriptions.
In the 1930's, we embarked upon a strict punitive model, and the medical profession was largely pushed out of the field. The drug supplier-law enforcement complex was enormously expanded by the war on drugs in the 1980's at an annual cost of tens of billions of dollars.
Meanwhile, in my judicial district, the Federal probation service has had to radically cut its drug-testing and medical treatment program; many parents have no place to send their children for help; educational and other nonpenal controls are ineffective, and, too frequently, ghetto youths seek to emulate sellers and thugs who brazenly walk city streets.

Largely because of drug prosecutions, our justice system is in crisis. Nationally, over one-third of all new inmates are drug offenders. Over 60 percent of those in Federal prisons have been convicted of drug offenses.
In the Eastern District of New York, we sentence about 400 drug "mules" each year. These are usually poor people who smuggle drugs, primarily heroin, from Nigeria and cocaine and heroin from Colombia. They are cheaply hired for one trip. Before the adoption of guideline sentencing, they were sentenced to 30 months and paroled in about one year.
Now they must serve an average of two additional years, and sometimes a 10-year minimum, leading to at least 800 more penal years, at millions of dollars of added expense for incarceration in our district alone.
Largely because of mandated and unnecessarily harsh sentences for minor drug offenders, which fail to deter, I have exercised my option as a senior Federal judge not to try minor drug cases.
When I wrote a report on drug laws for the City Bar Association in the early 1950's and then served as chairman of the lay board of the North Brothers Island Hospital -- the first for teen-age narcotics users -- I believed a modified medical model was desirable. In the 60's, as a father I supported some form of criminal model because I thought that it might discourage drug use by young people. As a judge, in the 80's and 90's, I have become increasingly despondent over the cruelties and self-defeating character of our war on drugs.
A national commission could address the difficult questions. How should marijuana be treated? Has it become such a large and widely available cash crop that prohibition is neither attainable nor affordable? (In some districts Federal prosecutors decline cases involving less than a ton, while in other places people are sent to prison for years when they possess a few plants for their own use.)
How dangerous is marijuana? Does it have useful therapeutic values? How much money could be saved in law enforcement by decriminalizing its use? Would savings be offset by an increase in health and other costs attributable to a rise in consumption? Or would we find that noncriminal social controls -- ranging from taxation and bans on smoking in public places to peer pressure -- would reduce use, as they have for cigarette smoking?
For hard drugs, a national commission should consider the tradeoffs between medical controls and education, and our current punitive approach. Our investments in increased law enforcement are no longer providing adequate returns. If we reduce our criminal-penal efforts, how much of the savings could be better utilized for education and medical efforts to decrease demand? What is the optimal balance?
We must also consider moral and religious issues. Would decriminalization imply society's approval? Is there an overlooked moral dilemma in our penal approach that results, for example, in one in four black males in their 20's being under the control of the criminal justice system?
Different strategies might be required in dealing with different sectors of society. An airplane mechanic testified before me that he stopped using cocaine and marijuana when random drug testing was imposed, for fear of losing his job. Should we take greater advantage of alternative forms of control? Would such forms of control help those who may have lost hope for better lives?
Many such questions require analysis by economists, scientists, law enforcement specialists, sociologists, ethicists, religious leaders and others.
In considering loosening legal controls on narcotics, we must weigh the claim that our inner cities would be devastated against the price we now pay in daily body counts from gunfire. Unthinking acceptance of the current policy is unreasonable. It is time to compile the likely results of different drug policies. Only a national commission can do this. If we are fortunate, a national debate would follow. Perhaps then we could reduce the violence, moral degradation and waste associated with drugs in a more humane, effective and cost-efficient way.

HEADLINE: Drugs, Crime and Punishment;
Don't Let Judges Set Crooks Free

BYLINE: By Phil Gramm; Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, is a member of the Senate subcommittee on Commerce, Justice, State and Judiciary.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Two Federal judges recently announced that they would refuse to take drug cases because they oppose mandatory minimum sentences. One judge, Jack Weinstein of Brooklyn, confessed to a "sense of depression about much of the cruelty I have been party to in connection with the war on drugs." The other, Whitman Knapp of Manhattan, heartened that President Clinton "has not committed himself to the war on drugs in such a way as the Republican Administration had," hoped his action would influence the President to abandon tough mandatory sentencing.
If the Clinton Administration listens to these voices, and their echoes, and tries to roll back minimum mandatory sentences, it will certainly win applause from some criminal defense lawyers, judges and the media -- and no doubt many criminals -- but it will betray millions of Americans who took the President at his word when he promised to be tough on crime. 
 Contrary to conventional wisdom, most criminals are perfectly rational men and women. They don't commit crimes because they're in the grip of some irresistible impulse. They commit crimes because they think it pays. Unfortunately, in most cases they are right: In America today, crime does pay.
Morgan Reynolds, an economist at Texas A&M University, has calculated the amount of time that a person committing a serious crime in 1990 -- the last year for which we have complete statistics -- could reasonably expect to spend in prison. By analyzing the probability of arrest, prosecution, conviction, imprisonment and the average actual sentence served by convicts for particular crimes, Professor Reynolds has reached some shocking conclusions.
On average, a person committing murder in the United States today can expect to spend only 1.8 years in prison. For rape, the expected punishment is 60 days. Expected time in prison is 23 days for robbery, 6.7 days for arson and 6.4 days for aggravated assault. And for stealing a car, a person can reasonably expect to spend just a day and a half in prison.
Given this extremely low rate of expected punishment, is it any wonder that our nation is deluged by a tidal wave of crime? In trying to account for the six million violent crimes committed annually, analysts point to the breakdown of the family, the effects of television violence and the failure to teach moral values in our schools. While these factors have an impact, they overlook the main culprit: a criminal justice system in which the cost of committing crimes is so shamelessly cheap that it fails to deter potential criminals.
Mandatory minimum sentences deal with this problem directly. When a potential criminal knows that if he is convicted he is certain to be sentenced, and his sentence is certain to be stiff, his cost-benefit calculus changes dramatically and his willingness to engage in criminal activity takes a nose dive.
Again, Professor Reynolds's statistics are revealing. He found that since 1950, the expected punishment for a serious criminal has declined by two-thirds, while the annual number of crimes has risen seven-fold. In 1950, each perpetrator of a serious crime risked, on average, 24 days in prison. By 1988, the amount of risked time was 8.5 days. Over 38 years, soft sentencing -- treating criminals as victims of dysfunctional families, of predatory capitalism, of society at large -- has brought a dramatic decline in the cost of committing a crime and a dramatic increase in crime.
Critics of mandatory minimum sentences point out, often with considerable indignation, that mandatory sentencing denies judges discretion in imposing sentences. And they are perfectly right. That's what we want.
Americans have lost faith in our criminal justice systems. Too many violent criminals have walked away with light or even no prison sentences. Mandatory minimum sentencing is a massive no-confidence vote by the American people in the discretionary powers of our judges. If judges and parole boards were legally liable for the actions of convicted felons who walk the streets due to their decisions, I would have more confidence in their judgment. But they are not.
"But what about fairness?" critics of mandatory minimum sentencing ask. "Is it fair that someone who has never committed a crime in his life should go to prison for 10 years because one day he sold drugs to some kid? Shouldn't we distinguish between a major drug dealer and a minor drug offense?"
Once again, the critics are right: There is a distinction between major and minor drug offenses. A minor drug offense takes place when a pusher sells drugs to somebody else's child; a major drug offense takes place when he pushes drugs on yours. Only when our nation's elites are as outraged about what happens to someone else's child as they would be were it happening to their own will we deal with crime effectively.
Of course, there is the cost issue to be considered. At a time when we are desperately trying to reduce the Federal deficit, can we really afford to sentence more criminals to jail for lengthier periods of time?
Of course we can. In 1990, the Department of Justice's bureau of statistics found that it costs from $15,000 to $30,000 to keep a felon in prison for a year. A Rand Corporation study calculated that the active street criminal imposes a financial cost of $430,000 a year on the general public -- not to mention such immeasurable but very real costs as grief, fear and anger. By Washington standards (or anybody's, for that matter), spending $30,000 a year to save $430,000 a year is a brilliant allocation of resources.
In dealing with our nation's crime problem, cost is not the fundamental issue. Indifference is. I am appalled by the shoulder-shrugging approach some Americans take to the issue of crime in this country. Americans saw the pictures of starving children in Somalia and were outraged; we saw "ethnic cleansing" in Bosnia and were furious. But our outrage and fury evaporate when American children are the victims of criminals.
Like Judge Weinstein, all too many are ready to agonize over the "cruelty" that mandatory sentencing inflicts on drug pushers, and to overlook the cruelty that mandatory sentencing avoids by keeping these criminals off the streets and preventing them from brutalizing your children, mine or even Judge Weinstein's.
With the end of the cold war, domestic crime is now the greatest threat to the safety and well being of Americans. And just as the U.S. developed a military strategy -- "containment" -- to deter Soviet aggression by raising its costs, so today we need a legal strategy to contain, and reverse, the growth of violent crime.
That is why, along with many other Americans, I am a strong supporter of mandatory minimum sentences. In fact, I will go so far as to say that as long as I am in the Senate, we will be imposing more minimum sentences, not repealing them.

HEADLINE: Immigration Strains California Resources

 BODY:

To the Editor:
That Americans increasingly favor reduced levels of immigration, as a New York Times/CBS News Poll shows (front page, June 27), should come as no surprise. However, it is unfortunate that you use the unnecessarily pejorative terms "anti-immigrant feelings" and "hostility." 
 Previous eras of high immigration to the United States were followed by periods of very low immigration. From 1920 to 1970, immigration averaged only 180,000 a year. In recent years, rates have gone up and up, and now exceed one million a year.
Certainly the economy has something to do with changing sentiments. A recent study by Donald Huddle, a Rice University economics professor, concluded that immigration imposed a net cost of $45 billion on United States taxpayers last year, yet this report received scant attention.
There are myriad other reasons for reducing immigration. Here in California -- destination of almost half the country's immigrants -- the population growth rate exceeds that of India. Half the population growth is due to immigration. Recent immigrants, with their larger families, have driven up the state's fertility rate until it exceeds that of any industrialized country.
Population growth is California's most serious environmental problem. It also plays a major role in the state's educational, economic and budgetary crises.
 
RIC OBERLINK
Executive Director, Californians
for Population Stabilization
Sacramento, Calif., June 29, 1993

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN TOKYO;
7 Nations Hasten Aid to Russia; Will Push for Growth and Trade

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, July 9

 BODY:
Leaders of the world's seven major industrial democracies agreed today to provide an immediate $3 billion in aid to Russia and pledged to push for economic growth and lower trade barriers.
The leaders also agreed to send senior officials to the United States this fall for what Administration officials have described as a "jobs summit" that would address the problem of unemployment that persists even when economies are growing. 
 After three days of talks, however, the seven heads of state broke no major new ground in addressing the world's economic problems.
The $3 billion in loans, grants and export credits for Russia was mostly a reallocation of funds previously committed, but the money is to be disbursed more quickly and directed more precisely toward putting state-owned companies into private hands.
The package was put together as President Boris N. Yeltsin arrived Thursday in Tokyo to join the seven leaders on their final day of talks.
The economic communique, a central feature of the talks, was described by Administration officials as reflecting Washington's concerns about the global environment. It also praised the United States for making "long overdue" efforts to reduce its budget deficit and encouraged European nations to lower interest rates.
 
Focus on Unemployment
 "What the leaders perceive is that there are common elements to the problem," said a senior Administration official.
The communique cited widespread unemployment as one of the single greatest threats, saying part of the response hinged on individual nations' efforts "to improve efficiency of markets, especially labor markets." An Administration official said such language was aimed primarily at Europe and Japan, where work rules are less flexible.
Acknowledging that many of the actions the leaders were calling for would require changes in each nation's domestic economic policies, the leaders pledged that their policies would be "mutually reinforcing and compatible with our shared goal of a strengthened and recovering world economy."
The leaders also agreed to "curb protectionism in all its manifestations." That passage is especially significant as Japan and the United States embark on last-ditch efforts today to reach an agreement to reduce the United States trade deficit with Japan.
President Clinton received a warm reception from many Japanese, who have expressed resentment of his harping on Japan's trade surplus and trade barriers.
Mr. Clinton, who has been jet-lagged and stretched thin by a hectic schedule since he arrived Monday, seemed buoyed today by the deal on Russian aid and by a request from the Japanese Prime Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, for a private meeting over dinner today.
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said the United States would contribute $375 million to the $3 billion aid package for Russia and had persuaded other members of the Group of Seven to chip in $125 million in cash and export credits. The balance of the package, he said, will include $1 billion in export credits and $1.5 billion from the World Bank, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development and other development agencies.
The $3 billion is to be distributed over 18 months.
 
'Real Success,' Clinton Says
 "I think based on where we were five or six weeks ago, this is a real success," Mr. Clinton told reporters Thursday night. "I'm very pleased."
In April the United States had proposed a $4 billion aid package to help Mr. Yeltsin's Government turn state industries over to private control, and suggested that half the money should come from the Group of Seven.
But that plan collapsed because few leaders were in the position to make the unpopular case for more foreign aid. Only Mr. Clinton has won such a battle with any ease; grants covering $125 million as part of the original United States proposal are making their way through Congress now.
In the revised package, the proportions of assistance were adjusted to reflect more in loans from international lending institutions and less in direct cash from foreign governments.
 
'A Huge New Market'
 "I think it shows the confidence in President Yeltsin, and that's very important," Mr. Bentsen said. "Obviously, this by itself cannot make that major a change, but it does give the initiative for them to be able to demonstrate what they can do toward further privatization and democratization of that Government."
Mr. Clinton said the new private industries helped by the aid would eventually provide "a huge new market for American goods and services."
Mr. Bentsen said in a statement: "The job of world leaders is to lead us. For years they've focused on maintaining a nuclear peace. Today, though, leadership is measured by the impact it has on our pocketbooks."
Mr. Clinton is also to meet today with Mr. Yeltsin, who came to Tokyo to make his own personal plea for aid. At a gala banquet at the Imperial Palace Thursday night, Mr. Clinton was seated next to Crown Princess Masako, a former diplomat, with Mr. Yeltsin on her other side.
 
An Important Meeting
 Administration officials were encouraged by Mr. Miyazawa's request for a second private session with the President after it appeared that the bilateral trade talks had stalled.
American officials said that there was no set agenda for the dinner today, but that the prospect of another session raised hopes for a breakthrough.
"I think they are interested in moving our relationships forward," Mr. Clinton said of the Japanese. "Whether we can agree on exactly what the shape of that should be at this time, I don't know."
The leaders sent a somewhat mixed message on Bosnia and Herzegovina, announcing that they would withhold reconstruction aid if a solution was not reached that was acceptable to the country's Serbs, Croats and Muslims.
 
Attack on 'Ethnic Cleansing'
 "If the Serbs and Croats persist in dismembering Bosnia through changes of border by force or 'ethnic cleansing,' they will place themselves beyond the pale of the international community and cannot expect any economic or commercial assistance, especially reconstruction aid," the political communique read.
But the statement did not go as far as the United States has in calling for lifting the arms embargo that prevents arms shipments to the beleaguered, Muslim-dominated Bosnian Government.
"I don't think it reflects a change in their position," an Administration official said, alluding to Western European resistance to military intervention in Bosnia or re-arming the Bosnian Government.
One of Mr. Clinton's smaller triumphs came Thursday with his effort to break down some of the formalities that govern summit meetings. The afternoon meeting ended an hour early, Mr. Clinton said, because the leaders dropped the formal roundtable structure of their previous discussions.
"And we agreed this afternoon to make next year's session even more informal so that we could focus on a few big things, cut out a lot of the bureaucracy and all the other stuff that goes with these summits," he said.

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN TOKYO;
President Hears Complaints On Doing Business in Japan

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, July 9

 BODY:
President Clinton today got an earful of complaints from American business people about barriers to Japan's markets, as well as some strong endorsements for his efforts to negotiate a new trade agreement with Japan.
In a meeting with Americans who are trying to penetrate Japan's market, the President and Cabinet officials were told that it is possible for a foreign company to succeed in the world's second-largest market. 
 But they were also treated to a litany of difficulties about doing business here, from deliberate attempts by the Japanese Government to impede American banks to the cultural challenges faced by Domino's Pizza in delivering pies in a nation where streets are not named.
The nearly two-hour forum was meant to be a miniature version of the economic forum Mr. Clinton held in Little Rock in December. But the real audience wasn't the 350 American business people who had shown up at 6 A.M., but Japan's Government and consumers, who would see a united force of American executives and Government officials on television.
 
Clinton Seeks Advice
 Mr. Clinton, who appeared for only the last 35 minutes, said he came "to know what you think we should be doing to help you." He particularly asked for advice in what the Government could do in overcoming cultural -- as opposed to governmental -- problems that make it difficult for American companies in Japan.
The executives who participated in the panel discussion represented eight companies, including Apple Computer, Warner-Lambert and Chemical Bank, that have largely succeeded in Japan, rather than those, like auto companies, that have generally failed.
The idea was to show that even successful companies have problems in obtaining market access in Japan and to avoid the public relations problem encountered by former President George Bush when he came here in 1992 to drum up business for American automobile companies. The trip backfired because it was too easy for the Japanese to disparage the quality of American cars and the meager efforts made to sell them here.
 
Perception 'Lags Reality'
 "You can feel confident that you are representing high quality products," said Richard Dyck, representative director of Teradyne, a Boston-area electronics company, told Mr. Clinton.
"This is an area where public perception, even in the United States, lags reality," the President replied. "That's something we need to hammer home, and we have to hammer it home back home too."
Before Mr. Clinton and Secretary of State Warren Christopher came, the business executives spoke with Treasury Secretary Lloyd M. Bentsen, United States Trade Representative Mickey Kantor, and Robert E. Rubin, chairman of the National Economic Council. Flanking the stage were logos of American companies from Kodak to Kellogg's who are members of the American Chamber of Commerce in Japan, which sponsored the event.
Some executives endorsed the efforts of the Administration to negotiate a new trade framework with Japan that would use numerical goals to measure Japan's progress in opening its markets and reducing its trade surplus. Administration officials said that so far the two Governments remain divided, though there is still some chance an accord might be reached by the time the President leaves here Saturday.
William O. Howe, the president of the Japanese subsidiary of Intel Corporation, a maker of computer chips, said the company had benefited from a semiconductor trade agreement that set a goal of 20 percent foreign market share in Japan. The semiconductor agreement is considered a model for what the Administration wants to do with the broader new trade agreement.
"Without the semiconductor agreement, we would never have had a chance to compete," Mr. Howe said.
Mr. Dyck of Teradyne recommended giving Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Company, Japan's main telephone company, an "ambitious goal" for purchases of foreign products. He said his company helped develop equipment to test the telephone company's phone lines in 1988, only to see much of the business of supplying that equipment go to Japanese companies.
"We were asked to become a member of a group of companies specifically to copy Teradyne's technology," he said. "That gives a new meaning to the word chutzpah."

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN TOKYO;
Yeltsin Arrives in Tokyo As Aid Plan Is Prepared

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 8

 BODY:
Arriving at the economic summit meeting as leaders of the seven leading industrial nations were preparing a new aid package for his country, President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia offered unusually conciliatory words today in an effort to warm decades of icy relations with Japan.
The financial package, announced as a near certainty late today by Treasury Secretary Lloyd M. Bentsen, includes funds for training, grants and loans to help put Russia's state-owned companies into private hands. 
 Although most of the $3 billion involves just a reallocation of money committed previously by the leading industrial nations, Government officials praised the package because it targets a critical aspect of Russian economic reform -- privatization of state-owned companies.
Mr. Yeltsin got the visit off to a strong start with a cordial statement at the airport. For the first time he stated clearly that Russia's relations with Japan -- a country Mr. Yeltsin has gone out of his way to snub in the past -- "constitute one of the highest priorities of Russian foreign policy."
 
Yeltsin Offers Regrets
 He also responded to a long-standing Japanese demand by offering his personal regrets for having abruptly canceled twice in the past year planned visits to Tokyo.
For some countries it would have been a standard arrival speech, but in the context of strained Japanese-Russian relations it was interpreted as a possibly historic step forward.
Mr. Yeltsin completed his grand entrance by joining the heads of the Group of Seven nations -- the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada -- at a glittering banquet this evening at which he was seated next to Emperor Akihito. Mr. Yeltsin's wife, Naina, was placed beside Empress Michiko. The image of this one-time Communist leader seated alongside the Japanese Emperor underscored Russia's rapid integration with the industrialized world.
 
Dispute From World War II
 Japan and Russia have failed to fully normalize relations because of a territorial dispute left from World War II. Japan has demanded that Russia return four islands at the southern end of the Kurile chain that the Red Army seized after hostilities ended in 1945. Even with the end of the cold war, Russia had rebuffed Japanese demands for talks on the issue.
Japan has contributed billions of dollars as part of the Group of Seven's financial assistance packages for Russia, but it has insisted that it will be inhibited from fully helping finance Russia's transformation into a market economy until the two sides tackle the dispute and sign a peace treaty.
Today that seemed to have changed.
"Russia is ready for an extensive and positive discussion of all the problems which are of interest to both sides," Mr. Yeltsin said. "It is my conviction that it is in our power to remove the obstructions of the past and to reach a final peaceful settlement in our relations."
In a 35-minute meeting later in the afternoon, Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa told Mr. Yeltsin that Japan would not demand immediate negotiations over the islands, but he laid out Japan's basic policies of seeking a resolution of this festering problem before relations can be normalized.
Mr. Miyazawa rewarded Mr. Yeltsin by agreeing to proceed with discussions to set up a new date for an official visit by Mr. Yeltsin.
 
Complex Aid Package
 The aid package announced today was complex, and included many parts, but it was intended to push Russia more rapidly down the path of transforming its old centrally planned system into a market economy.
The package contained less cash and more credit than had been originally hoped; the original $4 billion proposal sought by the Clinton Administration would have been half cash.
Mr. Bentsen said that the plan, which was to be announced formally on Friday, the last day of the conference, would include $500 million of technical assistance to help put state-owned companies in private hands, $1 billion of credits to finance Russian imports of industrial equipment and other products, and $1 billion in loans from international lending bodies, such as the World Bank.
In addition, he said, the package would contain $500 million more from the World Bank to help communities where state-run enterprises had previously provided an array of social services. Those services are likely to be cut when the enterprises are sold to the private sector.
Treasury officials said that the United States would provide $125 million of technical assistance and $250 million of export credits. Japanese officials, who are expected to be the second-largest donors, said their Government would provide about $100 million of technical assistance funds and a little more than $200 million in export credits.
The package clearly amounted to less than met the eye. Much of this money, some experts pointed out, is just a reallocation of funds committed by the Governments of the Group of Seven in April, when they fashioned a $28 billion assistance program to boost the struggling Russian economy.
Nonetheless, the package had the advantage over the original plan of being targeted for relatively swift disbursement. Mr. Bentsen said that the aim is to provide the funds over the next 18 months. The original $4 billion plan was expected to run over a period of years.
"It is in the right direction," said a Japanese official. "The important thing now is implementation, not the amount."
