HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN TOKYO: Reshaping Japan;
Clinton Pushes Free Trade to a Nation More Interested in Cleaner Politics

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 8

 BODY:
From the moment Air Force One touched down here three days ago, President Clinton has been riding the wave of change sweeping through Japan's political system, hoping to seize the moment by talking directly to Japanese voters about why they pay so much for food and feel so poor in one of the world's richest countries.
Already he has begun to win some praise: Newspapers are blaring the Japanese word for change -- henka -- across front pages here just a week and a half before the most critical election in Japan's post-war history. 
 The suspicion with which many Japanese viewed Mr. Clinton before his arrival has begun to melt a bit, particularly after he took time out from the summit meeting to put in a call to the parents of a Japanese exchange student slain in Louisiana and talked about the need for America to cure its own social ills.
 
What Kind of Change?
 But it is still unclear that the kind of henka Mr. Clinton is talking about, getting consumers here to join in his effort to break down trade barriers, is also the kind Japanese have in mind. Change, after all, means something very different on Tokyo's streets than on Washington's. And these days, most Japanese say that what really needs to be changed in Japan is the one-party rule that has abetted greed and corruption, not the fundamental policies that have built this country into the world's second-largest economic power.
"There are many meanings for the word 'change' in Japan," Shinichi Kitaoka, a professor of political science at Rikkyo University, said today. "People say the policies we have are good. It's just that the party is losing the capability to rule the country."
Without question, Mr. Clinton's comments are echoing through the political system here, perhaps more loudly than his advisers anticipated. Though the President has said repeatedly that he is strictly neutral in the June 18 election, in which the Liberal Democrats seem certain to lose power for the first time since 1955, Japanese newspapers noted this morning that his message about the need for change must hurt the elderly men who run the country.
 
A Boost for Party Rebels
 After 38 years in office the Liberal Democrats have a tough time convincing anyone that they stand for real change. As a result, Mr. Clinton's appeals to embrace economic changes that "will benefit both of us" are being interpreted as an endorsement of the rebel groups that have broken from the party, and some reformers who remain within it.
The Asahi Shimbun, one of Japan's largest dailies, said on Wednesday that Mr. Clinton's comments have created the view that "even the U.S. Government has deserted Miyazawa's Government," a remarkable statement given four decades of American support for the Liberal Democrats.
The opposition leaders are clearly delighted. "I think the general public all feel Japan must change," Ichiro Ozawa, the power behind the largest group of defectors from the ruling party, said in an interview this morning. "So the President's words are received as quite natural. We are also stressing change, and our emphasis is that we must change in the direction of participating more in international society and that domestically we must have more deregulation. So we received his words very happily."
 
Discomfort for Ruling Party

"But it might have been a little uncomfortable for the L.D.P. and Mr. Miyazawa," Mr. Ozawa said.
Mr. Clinton's approach -- never before attempted by a President visiting Japan -- was set in a meeting late last week at the White House. Uncertain of the best strategy for dealing with Japan at a time of remarkable political turmoil, Mr. Clinton brought in a group of outsiders with considerable experience dealing with Japan.
Among them was the Speaker of the House, Representative Thomas S. Foley, Democrat of Washington, who has come to Japan annually and gotten to know many younger members of the ruling party; Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, who also comes here frequently; James Fallows, the Washington editor of The Atlantic magazine, who lived here for several years; Edward Lincoln of the Brookings Institution, and Susan J. Pharr, a professor of Japanese politics at Harvard University.
Each member of the group addressed the members of the Clinton Administration most involved in Japan policy, including Secretary of State Warren Christopher, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, and the Ambassador-designate to Japan, former Vice President Walter Mondale.
 
'Ride the Wave'
 "The trick was to find a way to ride the wave of without getting ahead of it, and without seeming to come down on one side of the election," said one participant in the meeting, who insisted on not being identified.
He said there was agreement that Mr. Clinton had to talk directly to consumers. But there were also some cautions: Mr. Clinton, it was decided at the meeting, should not go shopping -- which could invite price comparisons that would embarrass his hosts -- but should say, as he did at Waseda University, that "the average Japanese family pays more than twice as much of your income for food as the average American family."
"To me he has struck the right note, very appropriate," said Ms. Pharr. "He has sent out a line to everyone, treated Miyazawa with respect, and shown that whoever emerges he is well-positioned."
The only problem with such an approach is that Japan and the United States operate under quite different social contracts. Prices here have been sky-high for a decades, but no long-suffering consumers have taken to the streets. Japanese know they pay the highest prices in the world. But many say they believe that it is worth it if it keeps their economy strong, their factories running, their unemployment level at 2.3 percent.
"The President's approach," one of his senior aides conceded today, "presupposes the view that Japanese interests are moving from production-driven to consumer-driven. It is not clear how fast that is happening."
In fact, revolutions in Japan rarely start on the street. Nor is it clear whether the "reformers" that the President has met will actually bring about the kind of change he wants. The Socialist opposition, which could be an important part of a future coaliton government, has a long record of protectionism and dislike for American pressure. And Mr. Ozawa, a friend of America's, has yet to say what he will do internationally if his new party comes to power.

HEADLINE: Cash-Poor Cities Still Face Hard Choices

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS

 BODY:
After three difficult years, most American cities are learning to make do with less, according to an annual survey made public yesterday by the National League of Cities.
But with virtually no growth in revenues in the fiscal year 1993, there has been a price to pay: most cities balanced their budgets by moderately reducing such services as garbage collection and fire fighting while also raising taxes. Others reined in expenses even more by streamlining services and reducing labor costs. 
 "It's not a gloom-and-doom picture," said Michael A. Pagano, a professor of political science at Miami University in Ohio who wrote the survey of 688 cities. "Cities are not so much in fiscal crisis as they just haven't rebounded from the recession."
The Clinton Administration, which has been struggling with the sluggish recovery from the recession of 1990 and 1991 and the growing deficits of the 12 years of Republican rule, cannot offer much help.
Mayors, who were clamoring for more Federal assistance earlier this year, now say that their expectations from Washington have diminished. "We're getting more understanding of our problems and greater willingness to help from the Clinton Administration," said Mayor Donald M. Fraser of Milwaukee, a Democrat who is president of the National League of Cities. "But they are severely constrained by the budget deficit they inherited."
 
Appeal to Congress
 At a news conference yesterday in Washington, where the survey was made public, Mr. Fraser and other mayors cautioned Congress not to focus exclusively on the Federal deficit, saying that economic recovery would be hastened by investing more heavily in the cities.
"We're at a crisis turning point in our cities," Mayor Sharpe James of Newark, a Democrat, said in an interview after the news conference. "We can go forward, recognize the importance of cities by investing in them, or we can see more and more social problems developing that will drain our revenues."
The survey reports that city revenues grew by a meager eight-tenths of 1 percent from fiscal year 1992 to 1993. City spending, held under tight rein by city managers, grew by only 2 percent, or less than the estimated 3.3 percent rate of inflation. Cities made up the shortfall in revenue by reducing services and by increasing taxes and fees by $1.7 billion -- or less than half the increases imposed last year.
The survey reports cities' financial conditions in the fiscal year 1993, which coincides with the calendar year for most cities. For other cities, the fiscal year runs from July 1 to June 30.
 
No More Reserves
 Lean budgets have become the norm in recent years, and city officials say the situation is not easing. In fact, two-thirds of the budget officials surveyed said they were less able to cope with this year's expenses than they were with last year's, and nearly three in four officials predicted that the fiscal year 1994 would be even more difficult. That is largely because cities have exhausted funds they hold in reserve for balancing budgets, Professor Pagano said.
Most cities have reduced capital investments and deferred maintenance, decisions that save money immediately but often cost much more in the long run. In Tucson, Ariz., for instance, city officials again postponed buying garbage trucks in an effort to help reduce spending by $13.9 million and balance its $200 million budget, said Ronald L. Meyerson, director of operations.
"We're spending $2.65 a mile to operate each of our old garbage trucks, when a new truck would cost only $1.25 a mile to operate," Mr. Meyerson said. If the city had $650,000 to buy six new trucks a year, he said, the city would save about $900,000 a year in operating expenses.
 
Savings Prove Illusive
 Tucson was not alone in trying to hold back expenses by deferring either equipment or services; one in six cities did this. Kansas City, Mo., stopped collecting yard waste to try to save $800,000, but saved only $600,000 because people began illegally dumping leaves and trees on back roads, said Donald K. Ewbank, a city spokesman.
About 40 percent of the cities raised taxes, and the same percentage reduced the number of city employees by attrition or layoffs or by contracting with private companies to perform city services.
Services in many cities have been cut to the bone and into the marrow. "We've been cutting day care, foster care, services to AIDS patients and increasing classroom size," said Philip R. Michael, budget director for New York. "We're still functioning, but we could be doing a lot better."
The city, which began the fiscal year 1994 on July 1, has to close a $2 billion deficit in its $31.3 billion budget. The city will, among other things, eliminate through attrition 3,000 to 4,000 of its 210,000 employees. It also plans to raise fees by $174 million and sell $215 million in property acquired from delinquent taxpayers. The city is also starting to work on a projected $1.7 billion deficit in the fiscal year 1995.
The situation will not improve any time soon. "In the past four years, the city lost 350,000 jobs and $7 billion in anticipated revenue," Mr. Michael said. "We've bottomed out, but the city is going to recoup at a very slow pace over the next several years."
Western cities have had to deal with the largest budget shortages this year, but Northeastern cities felt the most pain because they had the least amount of cash reserves to offset their shortfalls. Most Midwestern cities are also coping with shortfalls this year, and Southern cities with growing populations are faring the best.
At the same time, austerity budgets can provide the impetus for streamlining management. Philadelphia, which has made a striking return to black ink, is on track in the first year of a five-year plan to save $1.1 billion by freezing the wages of unionized city employees, slashing health-care spending, laying off scores of political appointees and bringing efficiency to City Hall with the help of local businesses and universities.
"The good thing about fiscal austerity and the anti-government mood is that it makes it politically possible for cities to do the hard things that they can't do in better times," said Richard P. Nathan, director of the Rockefeller Institute of Government in Albany.

HEADLINE: Holdout No More: U.S. Grabs Narrow Trade Deals

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 8

 BODY:
A tariff-reduction agreement reached on Wednesday at the economic summit meeting in Tokyo signals a shift in the United States' negotiating stance toward pragmatically seizing opportunities to grab narrow but important deals instead of holding out indefinitely for broad ones.
Several politically complicated industrial issues, like European tariffs on computer chips or American textile barriers, were excluded from the deal in Tokyo in favor of cutting levies on other manufactured goods. 
 Wednesday's arrangement "is a serious agreement, but it's an agreement to settle for what's attainable, and a judgment to cash whatever chips are now available," said I. M. Destler, a public policy professor at the University of Maryland and a trade policy historian.
 
 
World Deal May Be Near
 The compromise in Tokyo by Japan, Canada, the United States and the European Community suggests that after seven years of stalled negotiations, a comprehensive world trade deal may be in sight. But whatever comes forth now seems likely to be more modest than many Bush Administration officials and economists had envisioned.
Last month, Congress set a deadline of Dec. 15 for completion of the talks under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. "The chances are now better than even, perhaps even 70 percent, that we will have an agreement by the deadline," said John H. Jackson, a law professor at the University of Michigan who was President Richard M. Nixon's top trade lawyer.
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, has said several times that he envisioned a sweeping world trade deal. Wednesday's agreement was clearly presented as a preliminary compromise, with the expectation that negotiators in Geneva will try to broaden it to cover more industries.
"This is an indispensable step on the way to a broader agreement," a senior Administration trade official said today.
But Mr. Kantor's actions this week have followed a pattern that suggests the United States' goal now is less ambitious, in line with the policies of past Democratic Administrations that preferred to strike limited deals rather than seek to rewrite the rules of international trade all at once.
In his first three months, for example, Mr. Kantor partly settled a long squabble over the refusal of European state-owned utilities to buy American electrical-power-generation and telecommunications equipment. Mr. Kantor creatively persuaded the Europeans to accept American power-generation equipment while the two sides imposed modest trade sanctions to symbolize their disagreement over telecommunications equipment.
By settling on Wednesday for a deal that included no clear United States commitment to dismantle textile trade barriers, nor any European Community agreement to eliminate computer chip and electronics tariffs, Mr. Kantor runs the risk that neither industry will be made significantly more open to free trade in the final agreement. A weaker compromise on tariffs among industrial nations means that they have less to offer poor countries when they ask those nations to open their markets for banking, insurance and other services, said Jagdish Bhagwati, an economics professor at Columbia University.
 
 
Something to Show for It
 But the tariff compromise assured that world leaders had something to show beyond words from the Tokyo summit meeting. Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany had said here in March that if the participants labored mightily merely to produce another pledge of commitment to world trade talks, "there will be a roar of laughter."
Curiously, while the Republican Party has been the leading advocate of free trade for several decades, no Republican President since Dwight D. Eisenhower has concluded a round of GATT talks. Presidents Ford, Nixon, Reagan and Bush all struggled unsuccessfully for years to achieve ambitious deals.
Mr. Kantor seems instead to be following closely the example of his longtime mentor, adviser and confidant, Robert Strauss. Mr. Strauss, a former head of the Democratic Party who became President Jimmy Carter's United States trade representative, wrapped up the last world trade round in 1979 by abandoning the free-trade positions of his Republican predecessors on agriculture.
The 1979 deal excluded some of the same agricultural issues that have bogged down the current talks, and included separate, voluntary codes on procurement and subsidies that many GATT member nations never bothered to endorse. Yet the result was a deal that expanded international trade, although not as much as some experts had hoped.
Similarly, a world trade deal this year could lock in significant compromises made last year on curbing farm subsidies, protecting patents and copyrights and helping international investors.
The main sticking points now are farm quotas, trade in services and limits on unilateral trade sanctions. Congress is especially fond of laws that allow American officials to impose sanctions unilaterally on countries that subsidize exports, sell them at unfairly low prices or allow violations of American patents and trademarks. Yet restrictions on such sanctions are among the top demands of the European Community, Japan and Southeast Asian nations.

LENGTH: 989 words

HEADLINE: Albany All-Nighter: Cleared Desks and Unresolved Issues

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 8

 BODY:
As it closed its 1993 session this morning, the New York State Legislature passed legislation to create a fund to preserve environmentally sensitive lands across the state, but failed to decide how to dispose of radioactive waste from power plants and hospitals.
In a challenge to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, the Democratic-controlled State Assembly also passed legislation to divert savings from closed psychiatric hospitals to community mental health services, virtually defying the Governor, also a Democrat, to veto a proposal he has consistently opposed. The bill has already passed in the Republican-controlled Senate. 
 But legislators left several important issues unresolved, including proposals to change the way New York City schools are governed and a $9.5 billion plan to make scores of major bus and subway improvements.
The legislators pulled their annual all-nighter in a final frenetic sprint to end the session, clearing their desks of scores of bills that had piled up in the preceding and less productive six months.
 
Action on School Custodians
 Among the other measures approved here in the last 24 hours was a seven-month extension of bank deregulation laws, a bill intended to increase competition for medical malpractice insurance, and legislation that would cap the salaries of superintendents for Board of Cooperative Educational Services school districts.
The two chambers also agreed on legislation that would give New York City principals greater authority over school custodians. However, time ran out on the session before the Assembly could reconcile minor differences between its bill and a Senate version. The bills' sponsors said they expect the legislation to receive final approval in the fall.
Today, as weary Legislators packed their bags, Mr. Cuomo and Legislative leaders sought to put the best face on a languorous session that was extended by almost a week because of a bitter debate over rent-stabilization laws.
"All that was accomplished could have been accomplished much sooner and with less pain and confusion," Mr. Cuomo said today. "But the achievements of the whole session were more significant, in my opinion, than the delays that preceded it."
 
Mishap Before Departure
 To many, the Republicans' major accomplishment for the year was removing rent protections for wealthier tenants. But Senate Majority Leader Ralph J. Marino, an Oyster Bay Republican, soft-pedaled the victory, saying: "I'm just pleased that we were able to establish some Republican philosophy on the rent problem in New York." He added, "This was a beginning, and hopefully in four years hence we'll do more."
For Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin, a Queens Democrat, the last day of the session provided a particuarly painful moment. As he was leaving his hotel for a final news conference, Mr. Weprin tripped and fractured his upper right arm. He was treated at a local hospital before returning, arm in sling, to New York City.
In an end-of-the-session statement made before his accident, Mr. Weprin said passage of a clean-air bill and the land preservation fund had made 1993 "the year of the environment."
The land preservation fund created this morning was far more modest than proposals endorsed earlier this year by Mr. Cuomo and the Assembly Democrats, and closer in some ways to what Senate Republicans had sought.
 
Environment Fund to Grow
 Originally, Mr. Cuomo wanted a fund of $271 million a year, most of it coming from new taxes or fees, while the Assembly had sought a $248 million fund. The Republicans had proposed a $100 million fund to be paid for almost entirely out of the state's general operating fund.
Under the legislation passed this morning, $26.5 million would be placed in the fund starting in 1994, most of it coming from non-recurring sources, or "one-shots," including the refinancing of state debt. And in an odd twist, about $5 million a year will come from the sale of state land -- meaning the state will be selling property to acquire property.
The fund, which would also be used for landfill closures and recycling programs, would grow to $94.5 million by 1996, with the additional money coming from the state's real-estate transfer tax.
Mr. Cuomo, who has painted a rather grim picture of the state's economy all year, insisted today that the preservation fund will not create a hole in next year's budget because he expects the real-estate market to pick up over the coming three years.
 
Muted Praise of Measure
 But projections made in February by the state's budget division forecast that the real-estate tax will increase by only $40 million by 1996 -- $47 million less than what is needed to pay for the fund. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which is financed partly through real estate transfer taxes, has also predicted that tax revenues will remain flat for the next three years.
Despite the tenuous nature of the fund, environmentalist said they were pleased that it passed, particularly after it was nearly killed just two hours before the Legislature adjourned.
The first parcels of land likely to be purchased through the fund are in the Long Island Island Pine Barrens and the Adirondack Park, including a 2,100-acre estate on Lake Champlain that was scheduled to be sold at auction in the coming weeks.
In a news conference this afternoon, Mr. Cuomo hinted strongly that he would veto legislation passed by both houses to direct more money into community mental-health programs as the number of patients in state psychiatric hospitals declines. He has said the bill would tie his hands in dealing with budget problems.
But proponents of the legislation asked why Mr. Cuomo had been able to find money in his budget over the last 48 hours for other programs. "Certainly his position is inconsistent, perhaps even disingenuous," said Assemblyman Steven Sanders, a Manhattan Democrat and a sponsor of the bill.

HEADLINE: At G.O.P. Meeting, an Uninvited Guest

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, July 8

 BODY:
It was business as usual for the Republican Party at the opening of its annual meeting here today. Once again, Haley Barbour, the party chairman, offered President Clinton mock praise for uniting the Republicans.
But lurking upstairs was the unusual: a Democrat. Soon after Mr. Barbour got through assailing the Democrats, David Wilhelm, the Democratic chairman, held a news conference of his own to fight back. 
 This attack-counterattack behavior was prominent during last year's campaign: Workers from one party would pop up at meetings of the other to defend themselves.
Today it is clear that the practice has become a continuing feature of political life. There may be no campaign going on, but the Democrats are not about to let their opponents have the last word. With colorful charts comparing the two parties' economic proposals, they have set up shop for the next two days at the Stouffer Riviere Hotel, one floor above where the Republicans are meeting.
 
Potshots at the President
 Mr. Barbour made light of the invaders, and he used the Democrats' ploy to squeeze in another dig. With a broad smile, he welcomed Mr. Wilhelm: "Any time the Democrats want to come and talk about Bill Clinton's economic plan, I am proud to give 'em a platform."
He also noted that Mr. Clinton had not campaigned in Texas for Senator Bob Krueger, who was overwhelmingly defeated by Kay Bailey Hutchison in a special senatorial election last month, and he said he would have been glad to pay for the President's plane ticket.
But before acknowledging the Democrats' presence, he his own attacks. Mr. Barbour announced that the Republican Party was beginning to broadcasting radio commercials around the country today that will make targets of 30 House and Senate Democrats in 20 states who voted for the President's economic package.
With background music from "Jaws," the announcer on the commercials urges listeners to call their representative to "send this package back." He warns: "It's Bill Clinton and the tax-and-pretend Democrats in Congress at it again -- raising taxes while pretending to cut spending."
Mr. Barbour said the party planned to spend $110,000 to broadcast the commercials, particularly in swing districts where lawmakers might be more likely to change their votes. The first ones playing today were in the districts of four Democrats: House Speaker Tom Foley of Washington and Representatives Peter Hoagland of Nebraska, Dan Glickman of Kansas and Louise Slaughter of New York. The ads give the lawmakers' telephone numbers.
Even as he sought to upstage Mr. Barbour's announcement with his own stunt, Mr. Wilhelm acknowledged that the Republican commercials, intended to rally public opposition to the President's budget, will "make it harder to get our message out."
While the Democratic Party has radio commercials that promote Mr. Clinton's plan while urging people to call their representatives and tell them to "stand up to special interests," Mr. Wilhelm said the party would not hesitate to produce new ads that answer the Republicans directly.
"I'm here to talk about something Haley doesn't talk about very often and that is mentioned nowhere in his radio ads," he said. "And that is the Republican economic plan. I believe that there's a good reason for this: Because it is more of the same, because it goes to extraordinary lengths to protect the rich."
Despite his effort to answer the Republicans, Mr. Wilhelm insisted that he would not make a habit of trailing Mr. Barbour, and said he was here today anyway for a meeting of state attorneys general.
"I don't plan to follow Haley Barbour around," he said, but he added, "We're getting used to each other."

HEADLINE: THE WICKED WEATHER;
Clinton to Seek Federal Aid For Midwest Flood Victims

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 8

 BODY:
President Clinton said today that he would ask Congress to approve emergency Federal disaster aid for victims of the Midwest flooding, which experts called one of the worst on record.
The flooding, afflicting eight states, has already claimed 16 lives and caused property damage estimated at more than $1 billion, Federal officials say. The President toured the area last weekend and pledged $1.2 billion in emergency funds for crop loss and damage to homes and businesses. 
 High water has disrupted highway, rail and barge traffic in a wide area of the Midwest. Barge traffic has been halted on the Mississippi River since last week, and was halted for the most part on the Missouri River on Tuesday.
Highways and railroad tracks are under water, and many bridges over the rivers are closed. All commercial airports were open, but six small airfields serving non-commercial aircraft were closed.
 
Safety, Then Transportation
 "Our first priority is safety," said Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena. "Our second priority is to move relief supplies into the area and to keep as much of the transportation system operational as possible."
Mr. Clinton, who is in Japan attending his first economic summit meeting, made a radio address from Tokyo in which he told flood victims that their plight had not been subordinated to the demands of geopolitics, but did not announce any new aid plans.
"I am determined to have a Federal response that rises to the occasion and deals effectively with the problems you're facing," the President said.
The Army Corps of Engineers described the flooding as one of the worst in history. The Mississippi has already crested at a record 23.34 feet in Burlington, Iowa, nearly two feet higher than the previous record of 21.5 feet set in 1973.
The 1973 flood caused property damage of $1.15 billion, which would total $3.9 billion in today's dollars.
 
Eight States Affected
 Last Friday Mr. Clinton declared parts of Wisconsin a Federal disaster area. Illinois has requested the same status. Flooding has also occurred along rivers in Iowa, Kansas, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska and South Dakota.
"This is one of the broadest geographic areas that we've ever seen flooded," said George Halford, a spokesman for the Corps of Engineers.
The designation as a disaster area is made by the President, a spokesman for the Federal Emergency Management Agency said, and is determined on the basis of the extent of the damage and its economic impact on a community.
Residents and businesses in a disaster area are eligible for Federal grants and loans for a wide range of programs. These include:
*Rental payments for temporary housing for up to 18 months for those whose homes are unlivable.
*Minimal repairs to homes.
*Unemployment payments for workers who temporarily lost jobs because of the flooding.
*Low-interest loans of up to 8 percent to cover uninsured private and business property losses.
*Loans of up to $500,000 for small businesses with disaster-related cash-flow problems.
*Loans of up to $500,000 for farmers.
 
Other Agencies Involved
 These grants and loans are processed by the Federal Emergency Management Agency, which was severely criticized for a widespread breakdown in its efforts to deliver this kind of disaster aid last year after Hurricane Andrew battered South Florida on Aug. 24.
Other Federal agencies active in the stricken area include the Department of Agriculture, the Small Business Administration and the Department of Transportation.
Private insurance is expected to make up only a small part of the flood losses, because private insurance companies do not insure against floods. Flood insurance is provided by the Federal Government, but only about 20 percent of those eligible buy this insurance, according to Marc H. Rosenberg, a spokesman for the Insurance Information Institute.
One of the the largest floods on the upper Mississippi River occurred in 1927, but there is no record of how big an area was affected. In 1965 the river crested up to four and a half feet above previous levels in some places.
 
Train Service Disrupted
 The flooding this year has disrupted passenger train service. Amtrak announced that the California Zephyr would detour between Chicago and Omaha, missing stops in Illinois and Iowa. Amtrak suspended service between St. Louis and Kansas City, Mo., and announced that the Southwest Chief would not make station stops at Fort Madison, Iowa.
Freight traffic was also disrupted. The Burlington Northern and Union Pacific railroads were hardest hit, the Association of American Railroads reported.
Union Pacific was working to open one of its two tracks between Kansas City and St. Louis. The Union Pacific line between Kansas City and Omaha line was under water in Atchison, Kan.
The Burlington Northern reported delays ranging from 24 to 48 hours as it rerouted rail traffic from its main line, between St. Louis and Kansas City, which was closed.

HEADLINE: Fewer Seeking Jobless Benefits

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 8

 BODY:
Applications for jobless benefits from newly laid-off Americans fell last week to the lowest level in five months, the Labor Department said today.
First-time claims for unemployment insurance dropped by 12,000, the second decline in two weeks. The 327,000 new claims were the fewest since 325,000 applications were filed in the week that ended on Feb. 13. Many analysts had predicted an increase of several thousand. 
 The four-week moving average, which smooths out the volatility of the weekly claims and is considered a better gauge, fell by 4,000, to 340,500 -- the lowest level since the average stood at 339,500 in the four weeks that ended on May 22.

HEADLINE: Borrowing Declined in May

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 8

 BODY:
Consumer borrowing declined in May for the first time in 10 months, though the reason for the decrease was more technical than it was a reflection of spending habits.
The $802 million decline in May consumer credit outstanding contributed to a 1.3 percent decrease in the annual rate of borrowing, the Federal Reserve said in its report today. 
 The Fed's report tracks credit card borrowing, auto loans, mobile home loans and personal loans. It does not include home-equity loans, which have grown in popularity.
But the bulk of the May loss reflected a shift of about $3 billion in mobile home loans and personal loans sold to companies not tracked by the Fed's monthly report.
Without this technical change, consumer borrowing would have climbed by $2.67 billion as auto borrowing rose $1.737 billion and credit card use climbed $942 million.
This would coincide with analysts' expectations for an increase of $2.36 billion in May consumer borrowing.
May's level of consumer credit, a seasonally adjusted $753.92 billion, follows a revised $2.99 billion gain in April to $754.72 billion. The gain was first reported as $2.3 billion.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

DATELINE: Dollar Rises Against Yen And Gold Prices Fall Back

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed yesterday as traders looked to the summit meeting of the major industrial nations in Tokyo for clues about the direction of foreign currencies.
In late New York trading, the dollar rose to 108.54 Japanese yen, up from 107.65 yen late Wednesday. But the dollar slipped against the German mark, ending the day at 1.7023 marks, down from 1.7065. And the British pound rose to $1.4960 from $1.4935. 
 Gold prices fell back, breaking the rise toward $400 an ounce that brought the precious metal to levels it had not seen in more than two years.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, the actively traded gold contract for August delivery ended the day at $395.60 an ounce, down $2.20. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted spot gold at a late bid of $393.50 an ounce, down $3.50.
Walter Simon, a first vice president at Bank Julius Baer & Company, said traders had thought the United States wanted to help correct its trade deficit with Japan through a strengthened Japanese yen. That would make Japanese goods imported to the United States more expensive.
But since President Clinton and his team attending the summit talks did not concentrate on that aspect in Tokyo, but rather on opening up markets, "some of the upward pressure on the yen was relieved," Mr. Simon said.
 
Accord on Tariffs
 In fact, the first announcement out of the summit meeting that began on Wednesday was about an agreement to lower tariffs on hundreds of goods.
"Now the issue in Japan will refocus on politics there," with the fall of the Government of Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa and the elections set for July 18, Mr. Simon said. A country undergoing elections tends to see a flight from its currency until the uncertainty passes, he added.
Kevin Lawrie, foreign exchange manager and vice president at the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh, said "the market is still moderately bullish" but "is without incentive" and awaiting some statement from Mr. Miyazawa about which direction the Japanese want to go, Mr. Lawrie said.
"Over all in the New York session, things have been relatively quiet," Mr. Lawrie said. "Everything is hinging on the Tokyo summit and right behind it our inflation picture and the strength of our economy."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Listerine, a venerable brand of mouthwash, has been rejuvenated by its minty line extension.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
A BRAND born of anxiety, which found fame by persuading people it could cure a problem they never knew they had, is finding relief from anxieties of its own with a variation of its venerable formula.
A year after the Warner-Lambert Company introduced Cool Mint Listerine, a bluish, minty variety of its 115-year-old Listerine antiseptic, the new flavor is selling strongly. It has so far avoided significantly cannibalizing its amber-colored parent, the country's best-selling mouthwash, by stimulating garglers to buy more bottles or switch from rival brands. 
 That speaks to the ability of marketers to keep sales of some full-priced brands growing amid a shelfful of difficulties, from a sluggish economy to competition from cheaper rivals. It indicates that innovation, well-focused advertising and ample spending can overcome problems overwhelming brands like Marlboro and Pampers.
"Cool Mint Listerine exemplifies the power of brands, if you can take a No. 1 brand and grow it even further," said Susan Jacolow, Listerine product manager at Warner-Lambert in Morris Plains, N.J.
In the 52 weeks ending May 23, according to Nielsen Marketing Research data, Listerine's total share of the mouthwash market climbed 22.6 percent, to $221.1 million, in retail outlets the company tracks, which account for around 80 percent of mouthwash sales. That compared with a 4.3 percent increase, to $670.9 million, for the entire category.
Cool Mint Listerine, at $80.1 million, had already captured a hefty 11.9 percent of the market, more than compensating for a 21.8 percent decline in original Listerine's sales, now at almost $141 million.
An earlier attempt to mint up Listerine, a green minty brand called Listermint, continued to suffer a sales slide, by 29.8 percent, to $19.6 million, but that mouthwash is virtually moribund.
John P. O'Donnell, vice president and director of analytical services at Nielsen in Hackensack, N.J., said that research revealed the largest portion of Cool Mint Listerine's sales volume, at 36 percent, was attributable to Listerine users buying more mouthwash.
Ms. Jacolow said the new variety was proving particularly popular among consumers 25 to 45, supplementing the original product's strength among those 45 and older.
That is welcome news for Warner-Lambert because of fears that while previous generations dutifully submitted to unpleasant tasks, like gargling with a strong-tasting mouthwash, younger consumers shun them. That required a product not perceived as "medicine-y," to cite the tweaking term often heard in advertising for Procter & Gamble's Scope, Listerine's biggest rival.
Yet Listerine is predicated on its sometimes harsh taste serving as a signal that it is powerful enough to freshen breath and kill germs -- "the taste people hate twice a day," as recent ads proclaimed. Listerine was among the first mass-market products to succeed by, as critics of advertising would charge, creating anxieties in order to solve them.
In the 1920's and 1930's, "halitosis" -- Listerine's concocted term for bad breath -- was as menacing a threat as gangland rubouts in Chicago. Some of the hardest-selling ads of all time displayed distressed young women and the headline, "Often a bridesmaid but never a bride," with such mournful text as: "Edna's case was really a pathetic one. Like every woman, her primary ambition was to marry" -- an ambition thwarted, as she aged "toward that tragic 30 mark," by halitosis.
There is, however, a looming question that Warner-Lambert may find hard to swallow. If Listerine excelled by cautioning consumers that mouthwash must taste bad to work good, what does a good-tasting Listerine do?
"You sometimes can't be all things to all people," said Al Ries, chairman at Trout & Ries Inc., a marketing consulting company in Greenwich, Conn. "A good-tasting version of Listerine tends to undermine the core message of turning a negative into a positive."
He added: "People might say: 'Hey, these good-tasting mouthwashes really work. So I'll try Scope.' "
That is why, in $25 million worth of Cool Mint Listerine ads by J. Walter Thompson New York, a stern-voiced announcer simultaneously stressed that while it "works like Listerine," it "tastes like cool mint."
"The idea was to combine the brand's tremendous equity, the therapeutical benefits historically associated with amber Listerine, with the great mint taste," John Haskin, an account supervisor at Thompson New York, said.
So animated television commercials showed a heroically styled bottle of Cool Mint Listerine trekking, Tarzan-like, through a leafy green jungle -- a setting "perfect to talk about fresh, minty taste," Mr. Haskin explained -- to rendezvous with a bottle of the original flavor.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A year after its introduction, a new, minty variety of Warner-Lambert's best-selling Listerine mouthwash has proven a success. In a television commercial, Cool Mint Listerine swings through the jungle, Tarzan-style, and lands next to a bottle of the original, amber Listerine. (J. Walter Thompson, New York)

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Wall St. gives Ericsson a second look, and likes what it sees.

BYLINE: By Anthony Ramirez

 BODY:
AS cellular telephone service continues to explode in the United States, with some 11,500 new subscribers every day, the companies that supply the radio transmitters, telephones and computer switching equipment that make wireless calls possible are also thriving.
L. M. Ericsson of Sweden is an unheralded success story in cellular, unlike its dominant rival, Motorola Inc. Ericsson has been piling up an impressive record of fat contracts -- it won more than $1.6 billion worldwide in the last 90 days, many of them from new customers in the United States, like a $150 million contract in Dallas two weeks ago. Much of the recent order growth, analysts say, is coming at Motorola's expense. 
 Analysts say Ericsson has about a third of the $1 billion cellular-equipment market in the United States and nearly half of the $1 billion market outside this country.
The huge order volume has begun to attract attention from Wall Street, which had been cool to the stock because of the company's poor earnings. Last year, Ericsson reported a profit of $11 million, or 24 cents a share, on revenue of $3.68 billion.
On Wednesday, Neil Barton, the London-based telecommunications analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company, raised his rating of Ericsson from "neutral" to "above average" for the intermediate term.
"They are experiencing tremendous success," he said in a telephone interview. "Their business is rather like mainframe computers in their heyday. When people bought I.B.M. and Honeywell computers in the 1960's, they would have to buy future machines from the original supplier. That is the same situation with Ericsson."
Mr. Barton also raised his 1993 earnings estimate to $1.13 for each American depository receipt, up from $1 a share previously. He expects 1994 earnings, fattened by recent contracts, to total $1.92 for each A.D.R., and in 1995 to total $2.37. One of Ericsson's American depository receipts, a method for foreign companies to raise equity capital in American markets, is equal to one Ericsson share.
Mr. Barton also sees Ericsson's compound annual growth rate in earnings per share totaling 30 percent in the 1992-97 period, up from his previous estimate of 20 percent, made only six months ago. Ericsson's earnings per-share growth in the last three years has been only 2.2 percent a year.
The stock of Ericsson has surged powerfully since October, when its A.D.R.'s languished in the low $20's. The stock price has settled into the $40's since May 11, when Ericsson reported a rise in first-quarter profit to 16 cents a share, compared with a loss of 31 cents a year earlier.
Ericsson's A.D.R.'s closed yesterday at $43.875, up 12.5 cents each, in Nasdaq trading.
Ericsson has prospered in part because it has spent heavily on research and development, resulting in products that are popular with its rarefied customer base of American regional Bells, cellular companies like McCaw Cellular and government-owned carriers in China, Greece and Hungary.
Ericsson's spending has been especially heavy in cellular, which will make up about 40 percent of the company's 1993 annual revenue, up from 25 percent in 1990. Mr. Barton of Merrill Lynch estimates that Ericsson spent 45 cents of every dollar received from cellular equipment on cellular research and development.
Its earnings were hurt because it began the heavy investment just before the European recession of several years standing, Mr. Barton said.
"Profitability evaporated because they continued to spend on their future," he said. "Well, the future has arrived."

HEADLINE: Review/Pop;
X Dives Back Into the Turbulence

BYLINE: By JON PARELES

 BODY:
On Wednesday night at the Academy, John Doe of X looked down at the slam-dancers and said: "Now don't anybody hurt themselves down there. I know you kids are probably new at this." His tone was fatherly, and no wonder; as prime movers in Los Angeles punk-rock, X has seen uncounted slam-dancers since the band formed in 1977. The group disbanded after releasing a live album in 1988, but has reunited for a new album, "Hey Zeus!" (Big Life/Mercury), and a tour.
Although X helped create a wave of California punk-rock, it was always an idiosyncratic band. It revolved around the wide-spaced vocal harmonies and fractured, neo-Beat lyrics of Exene Cervenka and John Doe. The songs were usually loud and fast, but they were rarely symmetrical; they hurtled from one section to the next, earnest and urgent, revealing West Coast roots from Bakersfield-style country music to San Francisco psychedelic rock. And with Mr. Doe on bass and D.J. Bonebrake on drums, X boasted one of the best rhythm sections in punk-rock, at once driving and limber. 
 The current lineup is X's late-1980's configuration, with Tony Gilkyson on guitar rather than a founding member, Billy Zoom. Mr. Gilkyson is fond of Chuck Berry licks and countryish slides that shift the band even closer to country. But after its hiatus, the band still has its old fire, playing 13-year-old songs with the same fervency as the new ones. Ms. Cervenka rarely stopped dancing, even between songs.
The set bounced between selections from "Hey Zeus!" and X's oldest material: "Johnny Hit and Run Paulene," "In This House That I Call Home," "Nausea," "We're Desperate," "White Girl" and "The World's a Mess; It's in My Kiss."
While the new songs are just as propulsive as the old, there are some differences. Like much of punk-rock, X's early music was the work of talented outsiders, putting together songs without much regard for rules; the singers would wail, try a melodic hook, and wail some more. The newer songs are less free-form; they usually have clear-cut verses and choruses, trading only a little momentum for more catchiness.
The lyrics, while still nonlinear, have also changed. The band's early songs were about a scene that X was observing directly (and some apocalyptic fantasies that went with it); Ms. Cervenka and Mr. Doe, who were married and then divorced, also wrote tersely and tensely about romantic strife.
A decade later, both Mr. Doe and Ms. Cervenka are married (to other spouses) with children, thinking about the larger world, and new songs like "Country at War" and "Clean Like Tomorrow" consider the Los Angeles riots and the recession. But they can still create vivid, sharply observed images, and the band hurls them forward as if they're a matter of life and death.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Exene Cervenka, left, and John Doe of X performing at the Academy on Wednesday night. (Ebet Roberts)

HEADLINE: Review/Art;
Explosive Painting: The Path to Pop

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN

 BODY:
"HAND-PAINTED Pop: American Art in Transition, 1955-62," organized by the Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art and opening today at the Whitney Museum of American Art, handsomely recalls American painting at one of its most fulminatory moments. Even decades after the works on view here were first exhibited, you can still sense the spunky rebelliousness, and in some cases outrageousness, that inspired them.
Right off the bat is one of the most calculatedly outrageous paintings of the era, Larry Rivers's "Washington Crossing the Delaware," a work that seemed to critics when first shown in 1953 to mock the heroic aspirations of Abstract Expressionism (not to mention one of America's heroes). In the next gallery is Robert Rauschenberg's "Small Rebus" (1956), with its melange of pseudo-Abstract Expressionist squiggles and drips, its incongruous collage of sports figures and its reproduction of Titian's "Rape of Europa" (amusingly misidentified in the show's catalogue as "a Baroque painting of a woman on the back of a bull"). 
 Coming as they did at a time when the first generation of the New York School had established lofty abstraction as the be-all of American art, Mr. Rivers's and Mr. Rauschenberg's works, with their populist allusions and their wry manipulations of paint, seemed like virtual declarations of war. Abstract Expressionism may have put American painting on the international art map once and for all, but American popular culture in the prosperous Eisenhower years had achieved its own worldwide renown, and it was from this largely untapped resource that younger artists sought to draw. The first generation New York School painters came of age during the Depression and World War II. This new generation, after all, was coming into its own in a very different kind of America, and their work necessarily reflected it.
"Hand-Painted Pop," which brings together 117 works by 21 artists, charts a course from paintings of the 50's like "Washington Crossing the Delaware" and "Small Rebus" to quintessential Pop creations of the early 60's like James Rosenquist's "President Elect," with its crisp, flat colors and near-billboard scale, and its archetypal all-American imagery of a smiling President John F. Kennedy juxtaposed with a shiny Chevrolet.
The show's thesis is not new: two years ago in London, a big and otherwise disappointing survey of international Pop art began with much the same point: that the seeds of American Pop, epitomized by the work of an artist like Mr. Rosenquist, were sown during the 1950's in the achievements of figures like Mr. Rivers and Mr. Rauschenberg. The classic definition of Pop is an art that derives not only its subject matter but its forms, as well, from popular culture and mass production: Roy Lichtenstein's comic-book reproductions in reproduction Ben Day dots. Yet Pop has in fact always been a fluid concept, and grew out of a much more varied, more "handmade" kind of painting. Contrary to the simplistic but still widely held view that it signified a complete break from Abstract Expressionism, the one movement actually evolved from the other.
"Blam! The Explosion of Pop, Minimalism and Performance, 1958-1964," at the Whitney Museum of American Art nine years ago, covered some of this ground even earlier than the London survey; and just within the last few years there have also been shows devoted to early Rauschenberg, early Ellsworth Kelly, early Warhol and early Rosenquist that each in its own way dealt with the same period.
But "Hand-Painted Pop," while retracing material from these shows and others, goes far beyond them all in describing how artists, beginning especially with Mr. Rivers and Grace Hartigan and continuing with Jasper Johns and Mr. Rauschenberg, picked up the path established by the New York School and pointed it toward Pop.
It turns out to be a path fraught with detours and dead ends, and one that could have been charted by this exhibition in various other ways. Why haven't Ed Kienholz's painted sculptures been included along with Oldenburg's painted reliefs? Why explore what is in this context the byway of Cy Twombly's art but not the early works of Agnes Martin, which included found objects, or of Mr. Kelly, who derived his abstractions partly from the life of the street, or Bob Thompson or George McNeil? Why Jess but not Ray Johnson?
To the credit of the organizers of "Hand-Painted Pop," Paul Schimmel and Donna De Salvo, they acknowledge in the catalogue the messy problems posed by a period in which American art, energized by the New York School and fueled by a booming economy, was moving in several directions at once.
There was, for instance, the direction Ms. Hartigan pursued. Reliant on the gestural and expressive qualities of the New York School, she also espoused figuration and relied on posters, magazine illustrations and Manhattan street life, among other things, for works like "Billboard," with its lively grid of brilliantly colored patches that teeter on the fence between abstraction and figuration. Pollock and de Kooning had already returned to figuration by the early 50's, and so Ms. Hartigan was actually following their lead. But she and Mr. Rivers (as well as Alex Katz, Mr. McNeil and others) extended considerably the range of figurative references, embracing above all the quotidian.
Ms. Hartigan did not, as it turned out, become a Pop artist, and in fact derided the movement as "not painting because painting must have content and emotion." The show is full of artists, not just Ms. Hartigan and Mr. Twombly, who cannot be described as Pop figures, although their work evolved in the same milieu and, the show aims to prove, helped in one or another way to establish a context for Pop.
John Wesley's work is also included. One sees in Mr. Wesley's works from the early 60's an emphasis on signs and symbols and a sharply delineated style that can appear at first blush to constitute Pop, but that was not always based on contemporary consumer culture and that had a cryptic and evocative quality altogether its own.
Certainly, Allan Kaprow's incorporation of everyday objects in his work inspired Pop painters, but Mr. Kaprow ultimately traveled far from Pop. Like Ms. Hartigan and Mr. Rivers, he at first learned from Mr. de Kooning and Pollock. Among the show's highlights are the pair of vigorously painted abstractions from the mid-50's that betray his New York School connections. Not such a long way from Mr. de Kooning's work, they are also not a long way from the Pop paintings of Jim Dine.
Nor did Wayne Thiebaud think of himself as a Pop painter, although his lightheartedness and his creamy, sensuous depictions of cakes and pies have sometimes led people to consider him one as well. In this exhibition, he holds especially high the banner of the Bay Area figurative painters of the late 50's and early 60's. They, too, were schooled in Abstract Expressionism before moving in their own direction: one that never quite severed links with abstraction while embracing the everyday.
The show has its share, in other words, of provocative choices of artists who nonetheless turn out to make a kind of sense in this context. One of the most unexpected inclusions is Jean Follett, whose relieflike paintings have largely been forgotten but who is nicely restored to public attention here. Not Pop, her works nonetheless incorporate banal objects in images of mythological intent that recall the mythic ideals of the New York School, but with a definite twist: feminized, modernized, tethered to the life of the street.
The show is also full of mainstream figures, of course, with rooms of important early works by Mr. Johns and Andy Warhol, by Roy Lichtenstein and Mr. Dine and Ed Ruscha. Warhol is shown at his most personal in paintings like "Strong Arms and Broads" and "Girl Sucking Forefinger," awkward in his scumbly, sketchy handling of paint but also more affecting than when he turned from the handmade to the mechanically produced.
And Mr. Lichtenstein is shown afresh, too, not only in the early freewheeling drawings of Bugs Bunny and Mickey Mouse of 1958 and in his surprising Abstract Expressionist "Untitled" of around the same time, when he was still clearly searching for his voice, but also in an even more youthful essay: his own version of "Washington Crossing the Delaware" predates Mr. Rivers's by two years and is, in its cartoonish, faux-primitive way, equally outrageous.
The show was even bigger and had more room to spread out at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, where it was first presented. At the Whitney it has by necessity a slightly crowded, helter-skelter quality. But this is a quibble, and anyway the installation is somehow appropriate for an exhibition documenting a time of remarkable vitality and rapid change in American postwar art.
"Hand-Painted Pop: American Art in Transition, 1955-62," remains at the Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, through Oct. 10. It is supported by a grant from Philip Morris Companies Inc.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
A Return Trip From Paradise

BYLINE: By MALCOLM MORAN

 BODY:
THE good news is that nobody bought the house.
Thanks to the wonders of the real estate marketplace, it has remained the property of Joe and Marty McIlvaine long enough to provide a familiar place when their family makes its return from San Diego to Westchester. 
 At the end of a 34-month cross-continental adventure, which ended with an education in baseball's new economics in San Diego and the addition of exactly one word to the beginning of his old title with the Mets, the club's new executive vice president of baseball operations can soon move back with a thorough understanding of the professional baggage that was left behind.
That was not McIlvaine's plan. His introduction yesterday as the man to lead the baseball side of the reconstructed Met management, confirming weeks of expectation, would once have seemed about as likely as the possibility of the Mets having a poorer record than two expansion teams.
Nearly three years ago, his two tickets to paradise were one-way. There was no reason to expect anything else. McIlvaine, whose judgments contributed to both the rise and fall of the Mets throughout the past decade, had been given a team of his own.
The ownership of the Padres seemed ambitious. The scenery was breathtaking. The claustrophobic effect of New York was light years away. The area was a wonderful place to raise a family.
But that was before the pockets of ownership began to shrink, and McIlvaine's judgments of talent were affected by the organization's economic constraints. That was before the elimination of high salaries, San Diego's priority, led McIlvaine to leave and the Padres to follow the recent trend of youthful, more cost-effective replacements: Doogie Howser, G.M.
And that was before the free fall of the Mets made McIlvaine attractive to them and New York more livable to him.
But there is one unresolved problem in the homecoming of the man who yesterday admitted, "One of the reasons I get in trouble is I'm too honest." The worst aspects of the professional existence he left behind have gotten worse.
With media outlets in life-or-death conflict, the long-time New York competitiveness has been transformed into a clearly combative atmosphere. There are fewer and fewer distinctions between criticisms of individuals and their mistakes. If Davey Johnson's final days as manager in 1990 seemed harsh, don't ask Ray Handley about the end of his time as coach of the Giants.
"For 10 years, in New York, the media treatment, the fans, were, by and large, fair," McIlvaine said in early October 1990, the day after he accepted the San Diego job. "But the Davey Johnson thing last year, that was not. And this year, a lot of the front-office bashing was very unfair. . . .
"I said it before this year and I'll say it again: I think the media is taking on a National Enquirer mentality. And I think what's happening in New York is that there are too many over-thinkers who say and write their opinion instead of just reporting the story."
McIlvaine's past success has come in the fragile ways of a business in which one organization can use a first-round draft choice to select a player named Augie Schmidt, another can select a pitcher named Dwight Gooden shortly afterward, and one of the two disappears forever.
The success of McIlvaine's return, and his team's reconstruction, will be based in part on his ability to maintain a sense of conviction, and the patience he values so highly, as all the Mad Dogs in these parts have their say. In a corridor beneath the first base stands at Shea Stadium, even as a passing worker said, "Welcome back, Joe," McIlvaine heard the words National Enquirer and smiled. Does he have more of an ability to cope with that environment?
"I have to," he said. "You hope as you become more experienced, you get better at things like that. I think the process of becoming a public figure is passing from being thin-skinned, like most people, to being thick-skinned. That's my own definition.
"I've been here before. It's not like somebody coming in who hasn't been here before. I had another opportunity in the interim, and I hope that makes me better. If you're not trying to improve in your life, you're not getting any better. You're always trying to get better every day."
Early in the first game of an oppressive doubleheader, a missed cutoff man by Vince Coleman began a comically ineffective three-throw sequence. Once upon a Polo Grounds, there might have been laughter.
In Joe McIlvaine's old and new world, Shangri-La is a high draft choice, soft real estate market, thick skin, deep pockets and an air-conditioned office.

HEADLINE: Hyping the Trade Agreement

 BODY:
Mickey Kantor, the U.S. Trade Representative, declared the trade agreement announced by the industrialized countries in Tokyo the "biggest tariff-cutting agreement in history." Not to be outdone, John Major, the British Prime Minister, declared that the pact was "infinitely bigger than anything we have seen before."
But the extravagant rhetoric owes more to the desperate need of leaders to boost their sagging popularity at home than to the modest accord itself. None of the announced tariff cuts will take place unless the all-important Uruguay Round of international trade talks is successfully completed. And for that to take place, these leaders will have to summon far more courage than so far displayed. 
 All they did in Tokyo was announce tariff cuts on manufactured goods that for the most part had already been offered. Meanwhile, they sidestepped controversies that have deadlocked the Uruguay Round. Had they failed to agree to cut tariffs on manufactured goods, the Uruguay Round -- which could add trillions to the world's output over the next decade -- would have been stillborn. In that sense, the trade pact is important. But it's only a small step in the right direction.
The trade agreement would largely eliminate tariffs on pharmaceuticals, medical equipment and seven other categories of manufactured products. These across-the-board tariff cuts are welcomed because they will reduce consumer prices and therefore lift living standards around the world.
But the agreement didn't resolve tariff cuts on textiles and apparel, and other sectors where protectionist opposition has been ferocious. The leaders didn't touch trade in the service industries or agriculture. Nor did they resolve important disputes such as Washington's liberal use of sanctions to punish what it unilaterally regards as unfair trading practices by partners.
These are profound omissions. If the U.S. refuses to open its borders to foreign textiles, for example, the underdeveloped nations aren't likely to agree to honor copyrights and patents or open their markets to U.S. exports of financial services and movies. And if the U.S. doesn't win such access, Congress is unlikely to approve the final agreement.
None of the leaders displayed much bravery this week. Mr. Clinton refused to take on the maritime or the textile and apparel industries -- which is understandable since he will need every Southern Democrat's vote he can get to push his economic package through Congress. But the same political calculus impelled the Europeans to protect their electronics manufacturers and movie industries and Japan to protect its farm sector, wood products and financial services.
Cutting manufacturing tariffs was a necessary step toward an international trade agreement. But it was also a modest step, and time is running out; Congress has given Mr. Clinton until Dec. 15 to complete negotiations. He and the other industrialized nations' leaders may leave Tokyo smiling, but they still have to go back home and tackle strong protectionist forces. Only then will consumers reap the benefits that an international trade agreement will spread around the globe.

HEADLINE: Time to Normalize Relations With Vietnam

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The change in United States policy to permit loans by the International Monetary Fund to Vietnam (front page, July 1) is welcome news to the many American nongovernmental organizations with projects in Vietnam. They will provide more than $15 million in relief and development assistance this year.
Press accounts make it seem as if debate over this issue is a self-interested controversy between business on the one hand and prisoner-of-war and missing-in-action family groups on the other. A third dimension is reflected in the 200 organizations and institutions represented at the fourth annual conference of the United States Nongovernmental Organization Forum on Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos that was held at Marymount University in Arlington, Va., June 17 to 20. 
 These humanitarian, religious and educational institutions have not only been laying the groundwork for normalization between American and Vietnamese society for 18 years, but they are also a less visible pressure group for policy change. Attending the conference were large, long-established humanitarian aid and development organizations along with new, smaller groups founded by Vietnam veterans.
Representatives of universities, people-to-people exchanges, English-teaching programs and Indochinese-American groups play an increasingly important role in our meetings. A growing number of people from business and United States Government agencies also take part.
About half the participants signed a letter to President Clinton urging that he end American objection to loans from international financial institutions, lift the United States trade embargo and move toward normalization, including establishment of diplomatic liaison offices with consular authority.
 
JOHN MC AULIFF
JOY CAROL
New York, July 1, 1993
 
The writers are, respectively, coordinator and convenor, U.S. N.G.O. Forum on Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos.

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (96%); VIET NAM (95%); LAO PEOPLE'S DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC (92%);

HEADLINE: Skills Serve as Passport To a Liberal Education

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Tony Kushner deplores the recommendation of W. Ann Reynolds, Chancellor of the City University of New York, to eliminate 97 degree programs "chiefly in the humanities" in institutions "with the highest percentages of African-American and Latino students" ("University or Trade School?", Op-Ed, June 28).
These programs would be replaced by "technical and occupational programs." Beyond question this is unfortunate. However, the point is not that minority students need not be trained, as Mr. Kushner says, "as thinkers, writers and artists but rather as service-economy employees," but that they, like all students, must first have the skills and means to do so. Students need the sense of well-being and self-reliance that comes through learning a marketable skill. 
 Yes, reading and the thinking that it induces are what the humanities are about, but if students have not trained themselves to make their way in the world, their anger and frustration will crush them. Good books and libraries are available everywhere and so are the reading lists to go with them. I too am a teacher and lament the narrowing of educational opportunity, but with a marketable skill, such courses will become accessible.
 
THOMAS MONSELL
Greenport, L.I., June 29, 1993

HEADLINE: Mexico Rejects U.S. Request To Hold Chinese Found at Sea

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, July 9

 BODY:
The Mexican Government tonight refused a request by the United States to detain three shiploads of illegal Chinese immigrants intercepted this week by the Coast Guard.
Earlier in the day, the Administration had asked Mexico to allow the ships to dock in Mexican port, presumably under armed escort by the Coast Guard, which intercepted the ships on Thursday and discovered 659 Chinese aliens on board. 
 Coast Guard officials said the three ships were part of a fleet of seven tramp steamers attempting to smuggle immigrants into the United States.
The State Department, in its first test of President Clinton's vow to stop uncontrolled immigration, had argued that when intercepted, the ships had been closer to the Mexican coast than to the shores of the United States.
 
Delicate Problem for U.S.
 The United States' plan called for the Chinese to be allowed to land in Mexico, where they would be interviewed by United Nations officials to determine whether they had legitimate claims to political asylum.
"The only people who can determine legal refugee status in Mexico is the Mexican Government," a senior Mexico foreign ministry official said tonight.
Just after 11 P.M. New York time, Mexico's foreign ministry, the Secretariat of Exterior Relations, issued a statement saying that in strict adherence to international law, it was not in a position to accept the United States' proposal.
However, the Mexican Government's statement added that if the immigrants were to enter the 200-mile international waters boundary of Mexico, they would be treated as illegal aliens and immediately sent back to China.
The intent of that statement was not clear, since the United States Coast Guard had already escorted the three ships to a rendezvous within 70 miles of Mexico's coast, well within the 200-mile boundary.
The statement said that if the aliens were detained, they would be given humantiarian assistance, if needed, but that the tramp steamers on which they were being smuggled would be confiscated, and the crews and anyone else involved in bringing the aliens to Mexico would be prosecuted.
Mexico's refusal leaves the Administration with a delicate and potentially embarrassing problem, since the ships were intercepted in international waters southwest of San Diego.
State Department officials could not be reached late tonight for comment, and a White House press spokesman, Jeff Eller, said the Administration was still awaiting Mexico's response.
A diplomat in the United States embassy here said that embassy officials had met with Mexican authorities throughout much of the day, but were unaware that the request had been turned down.
The Administration hoped that intercepting smugglers' ships on the high seas would send a signal to the 100,000 Chinese who try to enter the United States aboard such vessels each year.
"We want to put a stop to the practice," Joe Snyder, a State Department spokesman, said earlier today. "The idea is that if you can show the people who are organizing these ventures -- and the victims, the poor souls who get caught up in them -- it's not going to result in their coming to the United States, then we won't have to worry about the problem in the future."
The four other ships in the flotilla, all seven of which are sailing under the flag of Taiwan, are still headed east toward the mainland. They are believed to be carrying hundreds more Chinese immigrants.
Mexico's refusal leaves the United States with a potentially volatie international problem on its hands. It is one thing to send Haitian refugees a few hundred miles back to Haiti, as Washington has done, and quite another to send Chinese refugees thousands of miles back across the Pacific Ocean.
United States immigration officials and immigrants' advocates said Mexico had no legal obligation to honor the United States' request. "The Coast Guard took these people into custody in international waters and bears responsibility for them," said Bill Frelick, senior policy analyst at the United States Committee for Refugees, an advocacy group in Washington. "If we repatriate them we have the potential of their blood on our hands."
The Chinese Government jailed and fined 112 people who were intercepted in the Pacific and repatriated by the United States in May, immigration officials said.
The three ships -- the Sing Li, with 236 passengers aboard, the Long Sen, with 169, and the To Ching, with 254 -- were spotted on July 3 by a Coast Guard jet on "a stepped-up air patrol due to the recent influx of undocumented aliens," said Petty Officer Liz Brannan, a Coast Guard official in Long Beach, Calif.
The plight of Chinese paying small fortunes to smugglers for a cramped passage to the United States came into sharp focus on June 6, when a shipwreck spilled nearly 300 immigrants seeking political asylum onto New York City's shores. At least eight passengers died in the wreck.
On June 18, President Clinton approved a plan aimed at stopping such smuggling operations, and the Administration stepped up its efforts to patrol international waters and seize suspect ships.
That plan was strengthened on June 21 by a Supreme Court ruling in a case involving Haitian refugees. The Court ruled that the President had unlimited power to order the Coast Guard to repatriate aliens intercepted on the high seas. The White House is now applying the ruling globally, using military and intelligence agencies to track ships in the Atlantic and Pacific.
The United States can reject people fleeing economic hardship rather than political persecution. But under the law, a request for political asylum by an illegal immigrant triggers potentially lengthy court proceedings.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
