HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN TOKYO: The Overview;
CLINTON ACHIEVES TRADE FRAMEWORK IN JAPANESE PACT

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Saturday, July 10

 BODY:
President Clinton and Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa reached a major accord this morning on a hard-fought "framework" for resolving a series of mounting trade disputes between the two nations. Mr. Clinton said it committed Japan to bring about "a highly significant reduction" in Japan's huge trade surpluses with the United States and the world.
The accord was announced after negotiations that lasted all night -- including a decisive 2 a.m. meeting in the President's hotel suite -- and hours after the Group of Seven summit meeting ended Friday, with Mr. Clinton declaring that his first major effort to create jobs through international trade negotiations had been a success. 
 The trade accord, the source of intense and often heated arguments between the two countries for more than three months, defines a series of five areas in which separate agreements will seek to close the $50 billion trade gap between the two countries.
 
U.S. Backs Down
 But the United States appeared to have backed down considerably from its earlier insistence on highly specific targets -- goals for increased shares of the Japanese market, for example -- by which it will measure the results achieved by future trade agreements. [Page 4].
Administration officials, clearly attempting to portray the agreement as a major victory for Mr. Clinton, insisted that they had persuaded Japan to agree on "objective criteria" that would enable them to assess how much progress they were making in cracking the Japanese market.
"For years we have had trade agreements that have failed to reduce our chronic deficits," President Clinton said this morning at a hastily-called news conference with Mr. Miyazawa. "Those agreements have not worked because they lacked a commitment to tangible results, and they lacked a means to measure success."
He termed this agreement "results-oriented," a phrase Mr. Miyazawa -- who in the past has denounced such an approach as a step toward managed trade -- declined to utter himself. "There is a definition problem," a Japanese trade official said this morning, saying his government was not making specific commitments for the future.
American officials said that the "highly significant" reduction in the trade gap meant that Japan would bring its surplus to under 2 percent of its gross national product. It is now more than 3 percent. But at Japan's insistence the agreement itself contains no such numbers. David Gergen, the president's special counselor, conceded that "there's a lot here subject to interpretation."
The deal also seemed to put off some of the hardest issues, such as what kind of precise measures of success will be used in the follow-on agreements in five specific areas. They include procurements by the Japanese government, deregulation, Japan's import of American autos and automobile parts, and direct investment in the United States and Japan.
The trade breakthrough capped what appeared to be one of Mr. Clinton's most successful weeks on the international stage.
 
Talks With Yeltsin
 This morning, just hours before he was scheduled to leave for South Korea, Mr. Clinton also ended talks with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, and declared that Moscow was continuing its "march toward democracy and free markets."
Mr. Yeltsin said that the two men had "cleared about 25 items" between them, and that his talks were "a guarantee of further developments and progress."
The all-night negotiations began Friday night after the leaders of major industrial nations ended their three-day meeting with a ringing call for more free trade.
Mr. Clinton, looking confident and relaxed at a news conference Friday night, said he had already met his goals for the summit: spurring on the world trade talks, gaining agreement among the Western allies on a Russian aid program, and taking steps "to restore the ability of all of our countries to create jobs and opportunities."
The tariff reduction accord was widely seen as only a step toward a complete agreement. It called for lower tariffs on a range of manufactured products, from bulldozers to pharmaceuticals, but such steps were contingent on solving a series of far harder disputes on agriculture and financial services by the end of the year.
"All of us are mindful that we have a long way to go to restore real growth and opportunity to the global economy, but we have made a serious start," Mr. Clinton said. "We have to figure out how to unlock the doors for people who are left behind in this new global economy."
For Mr. Clinton, the most challenging element of the summit proved to be dealing with his hosts, the Japanese.
In April he and Mr. Miyazawa pledged to put a framework for future trade negotiations together by the beginning of the Tokyo meeting, but failed amid an increasingly bitter dispute over how to measure whether any progress is being made in opening Japan's markets.
The United States insistence on "targets" made the Japanese think they might be subject to unilateral retaliation if they were not met.
Even as negotiators were trying to overcome the deadlock, Mr. Clinton seemed determined to put the Japanese-American relationship on a far better footing, saying he wanted to "go beyond the rhetoric and finger-pointing of both sides."
After spending a lot of the first part of his trip conspicuously courting the political opposition to the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, he worked hard not to snub Mr. Miyazawa, who is widely expected to resign after elections here on July 18.
The two men had a sushi meal Friday night at the Hotel Okura, where Mr. Clinton is staying, in what was described as a purely social dinner that contained no negotiating save for what kind of fish to order.
As the negotiators toiled in hotel rooms, Mr. Clinton was racing around the city, clearly enjoying his role as the central figure of his first summit. On Friday morning he wandered out of his hotel and wound through the twisting streets of Tokyo until he came to a baseball field, where he greeted young Japanese players.
Then he moved on to a meeting of American business executives here, and delved into a discussion of the difficulties of delivering pizza in a city without street names.
 
Meets Canadian Leader
 In the afternoon he met at length with Canada's new Prime Minister, Kim Campbell, promising to create a special post in the White House to deal with Canadian relations, especially trade. After his dinner with Mr. Miyazawa, Mr. Clinton strolled his hotel lobby posing for pictures with American guests.
The only presence who rivaled him in Tokyo was Mr. Yeltsin, who came to argue that his country was already "getting to the level of normal functioning of a free-market economy," and urging aid beyond the $3 billion in privatization funds that were finally arranged in the week.
Mr. Yeltsin's most surprising encounter, however, came alongside Mr. Miyazawa. The Russian President had refused two other visits to Japan because of pressures at home not to give up four Kurile islands the Soviet Union seized at the end of World War II and that Japan is now demanding back.
Both Mr. Miyazawa and Mr. Yeltsin seemed eager to play down their past differences, and they said they would schedule a full, official visit in October. But Mr. Yeltsin warned that if he acted too quickly on the question of giving back territory, "I might require a visa to get back to Russia.
For Germany and Japan, the meetings here came just as they were both formally notifying the United Nations that they want to join the Security Council. The Clinton Administration has backed the move, though several current members fear it would dilute their influence.
The Japanese were careful during the summit meeting to say little in public about their ambitions.
Mr. Yeltsin also seemed to be pressing for an expanded role in the world, as a member of a "Group of Eight" industrialized nations, rather than as a guest at the Group of Seven summit meetings.
"Time is on our side," he said at his press conference with Mr. Miyazawa. "We are bound to be a G-8," he added, "one year sooner, or one year later, who knows?"
Later Mr. Clinton, asked about Mr. Yeltsin's comments, said, he did not "want to make the argument against keeping Russia out of the G-7."
"I think that there will come a time when Russia will probably join this group, when there is a consensus" that it has become one of the world's most economically powerful nations.
On Friday, Mr. Yeltsin was invited to next year's summit meeting in Naples.
Despite the summit meeting successes, in some key areas there is reason to question how much was done.
The biggest success, however, may have been the agreement to reduce tariffs and open markets for manufactured goods under the Uruguay Round talks for the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, a 118-member world body that sets international trading rules. The negotiations had seemed hopelessly deadlocked.
An unusually delicate issue Mr. Clnton handled on his tour here, however, was the out-of-sight, away-from-the-microphones role played by his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton. Through the entire summit she was barely heard from. Yesterday she went sightseeing in Kamakura, an ancient Japanese capital near Tokyo. Mr. Clinton denied today that she had been muzzled, saying "she did what she wanted to do."
"I've been, frankly, impressed and gratified by the response that she's gotten from just the people in the street, especialy the young working women as well as the students at the university the other day," he said.
 
 
 
TALKING (AND TALKING AND TALKING) TRADE
 In Tokyo, the leaders of the Group of Seven nations expressed optimism that the Uruguay Round of trade talks, which began in 1986, could end in an agreement this year. It was not an unprecedented sentiment. Here are excerpts from the official communiques of the past seven meetings of the group of nations.
 
Venice summit, June 10, 1987:
"We note rising protectionist pressures with grave concern. The Uruguay Round can play an important role in maintaining and strengthening the multilateral trading system, and achieving increased liberalization of trade for the benefit of all countries. . . . We call on all contracting parties to negotiate comprehensively, in good faith and with all due dispatch, with a view to ensuring mutual advantage and increased benefits to all participants."
 
Toronto summit, June 21, 1988:
"A successful Uruguay Round will assure the integrity of an open, predictable multilateral trading system based on clear rules and will lead to trade expansion and enhanced economic growth."
 
Paris summit, July 16, 1989:
"We express our full commitment to making further substantive progress in the Uruguay Round in order to complete it by the end of 1990."
 
Houston summit, July 11, 1990:
"The successful outcome of the Uruguay Round has the highest priority on the international economic agenda. Consequently, we stress our determination to take the difficult political decisions necessary to achieve far-reaching, substantial results in all areas of the Uruguay Round by the end of this year."
 
London summit, July 18, 1991:
"We . . . commit ourselves to an ambitious, global and balanced package of results from the [ Uruguay] Round, with the widest possible participation by both developed and developing countries. The aim of all contracting parties should be to complete the round before the end of 1991. We shall each remain personally involved in this process, ready to intervene with one another if differences can only be resolved at the highest level."
 
Munich summit, July 8, 1992:
"A successful Uruguay round would be a significant contribution to the future of the world economy. . . . We regret the slow pace of negotiations since we met in London last year, but there has been progress in recent months . . . We expect that an agreement can be reached in 1992."
 
Tokyo summit, July 9, 1993:
"Our highest priority is a successful conclusion to the Uruguay round. ... There remain important issues to be resolved. We renew our determination to resolve them and to achieve with all our partners a global and balanced agreement by the end of the year."

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN TOKYO: How It Happened;
U.S. Appears to Retreat From Setting Targets to Increase Japan's Imports

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Saturday, July 10

 BODY:
In reaching an agreement covering trade relations with Japan today, the United States seems to have backed down from its earlier efforts to establish numerical targets for increasing Japan's imports and reducing its trade surplus.
The agreement, announced by President Clinton and Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa, contains wording that will allow both sides to claim victory. American negotiators said the agreement goes much further than ever before in being "results-oriented." 
 But that very vagueness of wording leaves a lot of room for intepretation. And already there are signs that the United States and Japan are interpreting the accord differently. If that is the case, the pact will merely postpone disputes until later and will fail to accomplish one of its major goals -- reducing trade friction between the two nations.
The new trade framework calls for Japan to take action to bring about a "highly significant" reduction in its massive trade surplus, which is about $50 billion with the United States alone. But it does not specify a numerical goal for reduction of Japan's global trade surplus, as the United States had wanted.
As for opening specific markets, the agreement calls for setting up "objective criteria" to judge progress. But it does not commit Japan to setting targets.
The agreement came at the end of an intensive week of negotiations aimed at reaching a conclusion while President Clinton was in Tokyo for the Group of Seven summit of leading industrial nations.
The American negotiation team met in the President's suite last night just before 2 A.M., briefing Mr. Clinton on the agreement. Final negotiations with the Japanese continued until early this morning.
The so-called framework is not an agreement on specific market opening measures. Rather it sets the ground rules for a series of talks that will forge more specific agreements within six months or a year, and then follow the implementation of those agreements over several years. "This establishes the rules of the game," W. Bowman Cutter, the chief American negotiator, said today. "The game is yet to be played."
 
More Imports by Japan
 These talks will develop plans for increasing Japan's imports of certain products, like automobiles or auto parts, and also allow for reforming its economic structure, for example by deregulating financial industries or toughening enforcement of anti-trust laws. The talks might also cover efforts to cut the United States budget deficit and reform some of its trade practices, like "Buy American" laws in Government procurement.
The United States had wanted Japan to agree to the principle of setting quantitative or qualitative goals for opening certain markets to foreign products or restructuring its economy. Japan had opposed this as "managed trade." The final agreement does not mention targets. It merely says the two nations will set up "objective criteria" that will allow them to agree on how to measure progress in opening Japan's markets.
A Japanese official said this means that targets will not be set. For instance, the two sides might agree that the way to judge the opening of Japan's auto parts market would be to count how many foreign products are designed into Japanese cars. But, he said, no targets for how many such "design-ins" will be set in advance. In that way, Japan has avoided the managed trade it abhors.
But Mr. Cutter, who is deputy chairman of the National Economic Council, said today that American negotiators "got precisely what we told ourselves we wanted a few months ago." American officials explained that since there are ways to measure progress and since Japan is committed to progress, the agreement will work. But this seems to leave open the possibility that the two nations will be arguing in the future over whether progress has been sufficient.
In addition, a Japanese official said, the agreement does not contain an explicit prohibition of targets, as Japan had wanted. That will allow Washington to claim victory.
In terms of Japan's overall trade surplus, the agreement does not include a key American demand that Japan agree to cut its current account surplus to 1 to 2 percent of its economic output from the current level of more than 3 percent.
United States officials said they interpret the "highly significant" reduction that Japan has committed to make in its trade surplus to mean getting the surplus below 2 percent of economic output. But Japanese officials say they do not interpret the phrase that way.

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN TOKYO;
President Clinton on Summit Conference: 'We Have Made a Serious Start'

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Clinton's news conference yesterday in Tokyo after the 19th summit meeting by the Group of Seven industrial nations, as recorded by the Associated Press:
 
STATEMENT
The summit we have concluded sends a message of hope to America and to the world. 
 Some have called this a jobs summit, and they are right, because the creation of new jobs in the United States and in all the other countries here present was at the center of all of our discussions. All of us are mindful that we have a long way to go to restore real growth and opportunity to the global economy, but we have made a serious start.
We reached an agreement here that can open manufacturing markets to American products and to all other products in ways that we have not seen in many years. Indeed, the agreement, if finally concluded, could bring the largest reduction in tariffs in world history.
While tough negotiations still remain, this world trade agreement captures the momentum that we have needed in these negotiations for a long time. We now can move toward completion of a broader trade agreement that could spur the creation of hundreds of thousands of jobs over the next decade in the United States, and millions throughout the world.
We also agreed that the other industrialized nations will send their top education, labor and economic ministers to Washington in the fall for a serious conference on the creation of jobs. All of the advanced nations are having difficulty creating new jobs, even when their economies are growing.
This was a constant cause of concern in all of our conversations, and we are now going to make a serious effort to examine the problem from every angle, and to try to come up with new and innovative solutions, which can be helpful in the United States and throughout the G-7 countries. We have to figure out how to unlock the doors for people who are left behind in this new global economy.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
$3 Billion Aid to Russia
This summit also held out fresh hope for other peoples of the world, especially those involved in democratic reform in Russia, led by President Yeltsin, who joined us here.
The $3 billion program we announced here to help Russia move to a market system will not only bolster prospects for freedom there, it is a very solid investment for the United States; funds to move state-owned industries to private hands to make the free enterprise system work, funds to make available operations for new enterprises, funds from the World Bank, and funds for credits for export. All these things will help Americans to do more business in Russia, and will help Russia to succeed in a way that will continue the path chartered by the end of the cold war; fewer nuclear weapons, fewer defense investments, more opportunities to invest in people and jobs, and a peaceful future.

 	 	 		. . .	 	I have said before, and I will say again, I came to this summit in the hope that we could get an agreement to open more markets to manufactured products, in the hope that we could get a strong program for Russian aid, in the hope that together we would demonstrate resolve to restore the ability of all of our countries to create jobs and opportunities for our people. I believe those objectives were achieved and I am pleased at the first of these G-7 meetings which I was able to attend.
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
Q. A host of Presidents have tried to convince Japan that trade is a two-way street. What makes you think you can convince them? What is the chance of getting an agreement on trade talks and what did you learn at the summit that you didn't know before?
A. I think we do have a chance to get an agreement and I think in part it is because we are coming to a common understanding that the serious imbalance in trade between our two nations cannot continue, and that in the end it is not in the interest of either country.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. You mentioned that further negotiation must be done toward a new world trade agreement. One of the major sticking points for a number of years has of course been the issue of agriculture subsidies, and agriculture generally. I wondered what, if anything, you may have heard here from your counterparts from Europe and the E.C., and from Japan that renews your hope, if it does, that such a thing may be possible by December, as you have suggested?
A. Well, if all the Europeans will adhere to the Blair House Accords, I think there is a good chance we can have an agricultural agreement. As you know, France has some problems with it, and has expressed those, and it was an issue in the last election in France. But as I pointed out, the United States cut our agricultural subsidies unilaterally and substantially in 1990 and we have proposed further reductions this year as part of the deficit reduction package.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. Before the summit started it was noted widely that your own approval ratings, as unhappy as you sometimes may be with them, were higher than those of any other political leader here. Virtually all of these people are either on the way out or in some great difficulty at home. How does that diminish this summit? And having been to one now and seeing how bureaucratic they can be, do you really think in these days of modern communications that these sorts of extravaganzas are necessary at all?
A. Well, first of all, I think that it did not diminish the summit. In fact, there was more done here, and there was more energy and more zip in it than I thought there would be. And I think part of it was -- apparently this summit was less bureaucratic than its predecessors. We ended two of our meetings an hour early, which I liked awful well, and there was an amazing amount of open, free flow of honest exchange, it was very, very good.
I think that anytime you have the world economies -- the major economies of the world in the doldrums, combined in some of these countries with a real impetus toward political reform, and a felt need of the people to make their political systems work better, you can't expect to see high poll numbers. When people are having a tough time making ends meet, they don't tend to be very happy with their political leaders. So that is a given.
Notwithstanding that, this summit produced real, substantive benefits for the people who sent these leaders here. Now, there was a reaffirmation, a unanimous reaffirmation on the part of the heads of state in this meeting, to make this process less bureaucratic, less expensive, and less cumbersome. And I think you will see an even more streamlined summit next year in Italy, one in which all the delegations are smaller and in which there is more flexibility and I think we -- I hope that something was learned out of this summit, that if you focus on one or two objectives and really work at it, and work at it, you can get something done.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Hillary Clinton Causes a Stir
Q. Your wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, has caused quite a stir in Japan, and yet she's followed a very traditional wives' schedule here, which frankly doesn't seem much like her. I wonder if she's been muzzled here, perhaps to avoid offending Japanese sensibilities.
A. No. She did what she wanted to do. She thought about it quite a lot, and I think that it was -- I've been, frankly, impressed and gratified by the response that she's gotten from just the people in the street, especially the young working women, as well as the students at the university the other day. And I think it's a real indication of the aspirations of younger Japanese people to see that everybody here has a chance to live up to their potential. I was really very pleased by it.
Q. When you return home in a few days, you're going to be facing kind of a do-or-die situation with the budget bill which got you so much play here. How do you relate your accomplishments from this week to what faces you when you get back next week?
A. Well, this certainly ought to strengthen the resolve of the Congress to carry through on this. There's no question that the other countries were very much encouraged by the determination of the United States to reduce its deficit, that they believe that's one of the things that has distorted the world economy for the last several years. And likewise, there is no question that some of our job growth we're going to have to do on our own. So a lot of these investments, both the private and the public investments in the economic plan to create jobs, should be adopted.
So, I am hoping that what happened this week will strengthen the resolve of the Congress to go ahead and pass the economic plan and to do it in short order so that we can go on to other things. We all, after all, have a lot of other things to do. We have to get the health-care cost controls in and provide basic health-care security to American families. We have to continue to deal with the transformation from a defense to a domestic economy and try to help people accommodate all those changes. We've got an enormous amount of work to do. We've got a crime bill we need to pass. We've got a lot of other things on the agenda, so we've got to get this economic plan passed.

 	 	 		.. .	 	Q. Within this city the Japanese Prime Minister said that he pitied the United States. It was a remark that you cited often in the campaign. In your talks with the Prime Minister, did you detect any change in that attitude, or do you think there is still pity for the United States?
A. I did detect a change, but I have to tell you, I have tried very hard to move this dialogue into a constructive frame of mind.
When I spoke to, at Waseda University, I acknowledged that one of the reasons that there was such a big trade deficit with Japan in the 1980's was that we had such a huge Government deficit we needed a lot of Japanese money to pay for our debt to keep our interest rates down. In other words, I tried to, to go beyond the rhetoric and finger-pointing of both sides. I also pointed out, however, that we have now had ten years of high manufacturing productivity growth, that, that we really are the high-quality, low-cost producer of many goods and services, and that we have to recognize we have to have a new relationship.
I think we should focus on things that are positive for both of us and be very, very firm about the need to change. But I don't sense a lot of ridicule here, and as a matter of fact, what I was hoping was that the Japanese would not be too concerned about all the changes going on in this country. I mean, I, a lot of the political changes are without precedent in the postwar era, post-World War II era. But they are the inevitable part of growing in a democracy and changing.

HEADLINE: Miami's Cuban Exiles May Lose TV Station

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, July 9

 BODY:
In a striking illustration of the waning influence of an organization that has dominated Cuban exile politics here and in Washington for a decade, Congress is making its most serious effort to eliminate TV Marti and drastically cut funds for Radio Marti, the last vestiges of cold-war broadcasting to the Soviet bloc.
The exile organization, the Cuban-American National Foundation, successfully lobbied the Reagan Administration to begin the broadcasts in 1985. Both the foundation and the advisory board of the Marti stations are led by Jorge Mas Canosa, a multimillionaire Cuban contractor who has built a power base here that resembles a government in exile, waiting for the fall of President Fidel Castro. 
 Though strongly identified with the Republican Party, the foundation made large campaign contributions during the 1980's through its political action committee to powerful Democrats in Congress, including Representative Dante B. Fascell, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee. But with the retirements of Mr. Fascell and several other well-placed Florida Democrats this year, only two junior Republicans, both Cuban-Americans, remain to champion the foundation's cause.
That political erosion, combined with an increasing diversity of views within the Cuban-American community and the pressure to cut the Federal budget, led to the decision late last month by the House Appropriations Committee to eliminate all $14 million in financing for TV Marti and to halve the support for Radio Marti to $8 million. The issue will come up before the full House and the Senate, which are due to return next week. The Senate is expected to restore some money for Radio Marti.
But Congress is likely to eliminate TV Marti, run by the Office of Cuba Broadcasting, a division of the Voice of America. Begun in 1990 at a cost of more than $65 million, the station has never reached many Cubans. Cuba has jammed all of its programming since it went on the air, and the blimp that transmitted the signal has been grounded for repairs since March. The signal is now being broadcast by satellite, so only owners of satellite dishes can receive the broadcasts.
 
Complaints From Rivals
 Rival exile groups here say that Mr. Mas, who founded the Cuban-American National Foundation in 1981 at the behest of the Reagan Administration, has used his position to insure that his activities are extensively and favorably covered by TV and Radio Marti, while other groups do not get the same treatment. Worsening conditions in Cuba have set off a widening debate in the exile community, and among dissidents on the island, about matters ranging from the efficacy of the United States' 30-year-old economic embargo of Cuba to the composition and policies of a post-Castro government, and competition to have those diverse views heard in Cuba is fierce.
With Radio Marti, the problem is not the size of its audience, which even critics acknowledge to be substantial, but the content of its broadcasts. As Representative Jose E. Serrano, a Bronx Democrat from Puerto Rico who is chairman of the Hispanic Caucus, put it during a recent debate, Congress is concerned that the station has become "a personal toy" for "a few people in Miami" seeking to advance their own interests.
Ernesto Betancourt, who was director of Radio Marti from its inception until he resigned in 1990, contends that the government stations have become a foundation satrapy. "I quit because Radio Marti was being converted into a vehicle of propaganda for Mr. Mas," Mr. Betancourt said last week. "Not only that, the station was taking decisions on foreign policy that completely contradict the State Department" but support the foundation, he added.
In December 1991, a Presidential task force, citing concerns about the impartiality of the station's coverage, recommended that the advisory board headed by Mr. Mas be abolished and that control of Radio Marti be transferred to the Board of International Broadcasting. The Bush Administration, however, took no action.
 
Impartiality Questioned
 With the advent of the Clinton Administration, new concerns about the impartiality of programming are again being raised by Radio Marti employees. On May 25, more than 60 workers sent a petition to Joseph D. Duffey -- who, as the new director of the United States Information Agency, oversees all foreign broadcasting -- to ask that the station "be maintained above any competing political factions existing within the Cuban exile community."
In the statement, the employees said they believed that "Radio Marti must broadcast with utmost objectivity while reflecting all possible viewpoints." They also requested that station directors and advisory board members "guarantee Radio Marti's objectivity and impartiality, and preclude any appearance of conflict of interest."
Rolando Bonachea, who supervises both Radio and TV Marti as the acting director of the Office for Cuba Broadcasting, said, "The people of Cuba are entitled to know all viewpoints, so I am not going to exclude anyone from participating in a responsible fashion in the programming of Radio Marti." He added that he was "convinced the value of Radio Marti is to continue to go right through the center, without allowing any particular person, group or faction to exercise control."
Mr. Mas has a policy of not responding to inquiries from The New York Times, explaining through a press spokesman that he has been dissatisfied with the paper's coverage of Cuba since the mid-1950's. Francisco Hernandez, president of the foundation, said neither Mr. Mas nor any other official of the organization dictated news coverage at Radio Marti.
Mr. Hernandez asked, "Isn't it fair that if we produce or generate 80 percent of the news related to Cuba in this community, we should get 80 percent of the air time?"
Current and former employees of Radio Marti said in recent interviews that they had been forced to lobby for the foundation during working hours.
Eugenio Rodriguez, a former reporter and union shop steward at the station, said reporters had distributed invitations to a foundation social event, "which damaged our credibility because it made it appear to the people we covered that we were working for Jorge Mas and not Radio Marti."

HEADLINE: Industry Too Must Share National Park Costs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
There are several reasons visitors to our national parks should not be forced to pay the full cost of operating them, as Terry L. Anderson suggests in "The Forest and the Fees" (Op-Ed, June 28). 
 Our country has many public institutions whose benefits are enjoyed by all Americans, regardless of whether or not they are on the premises. Should the entire budget of the Library of Congress be borne by those who use the main reading room? Should students and their parents underwrite the budget of West Point? Should every road assess tolls?
The national parks provide much more than recreational opportunities. They serve as natural laboratories, conserve biological diversity, help clean the air and water, preserve our history and lure foreign visitors, who boost our economy. One group should not be solely responsible for the costs of maintaining them.
Another problem with Mr. Anderson's proposal is that it would discourage use by those with limited incomes. Citing wilderness use figures, he claims that the nonwealthy rarely go to the parks anyway. But wilderness permit holders are not representative of park visitors.
If Mr. Anderson had surveyed the more than 21 million people who visited New York's Gateway and San Francisco's Golden Gate National Recreation Areas last year, he would have found very few with Park Avenue addresses. The parks in and around cities are natural lifelines for people of modest means.
Before park visitors are asked to absorb large fee increases, the Federal Government should stop subsidizing those companies that make profits off the public lands -- and often enjoy a taxpayer subsidy to boot. Last year American taxpayers underwrote at least $1 billion in subsidies for mining, grazing and logging interests that use national forests and other lands belonging to the public. That is more than Congress appropriated to finance park operations.
Additional help should also come from companies running concessions inside the parks. While enjoying monopoly conditions, they pay the Government only 2.5 percent of the money they take in from visitors.
Changes in national park finances are in order, and modest park entrance fee increases can be part of the mix. But soaking the visitor is indefensible.
 
KARIN P. SHELDON
President, The Wilderness Society
Washington, July 2, 1993

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Pep Rally for Jobs;
Clinton Plan for Unemployment Conference Is Aimed at Stirring Up Public Support

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 9

 BODY:
President Clinton's international conference on job creation, announced on the eve of the economic summit meeting in Tokyo, is shaping up as part educational seminar, part public relations for the White House and part pep rally to get people and governments to support new and perhaps expensive strategies to fight unemployment.
The meeting, which some call a "jobs summit" to heighten its significance in the public mind, will bring together labor, education and economics ministers from the seven most powerful industrial nations in an effort to get them to explore the causes of stubbornly high unemployment and to push for strategies to combat this problem. 
 Some Administration officials confess that they are unsure what the meeting, scheduled for this fall, will achieve. But if nothing else, they are confident that it will concentrate the leaders' minds on what the public perceives as the No. 1 economic problem: high unemployment. In the United States, after two years of recovery, the jobless rate remains stuck at 7 percent, while unemployment has surged in Europe to 11 percent.
At a news conference today at the Group of Seven meeting in Tokyo, President Clinton made clear that he thought his proposed jobs conference could rally support for new programs to fight unemployment. "If there are tough decisions to be made, he said, "It will be easier for each country to make them if the people who live in each country are aware that this is a worldwide problem and that there have to be some new and different directions taken."
President Clinton proposed the jobs meeting on Monday in a speech in San Francisco, in which he termed unemployment a "global crisis." Administration and European leaders have thrown up their hands at why, after years of economic recovery, unemployment remains so high.
Officials on both sides of the Atlantic say joblessness is still high because technological change is displacing many workers, especially unskilled ones, and because of heightened foreign competition, especially from developing countries. American officials are also convinced that foreign competition is a big factor behind American wage stagnation since 1973, especially among unskilled workers.
"Globalization has depressed the wage growth of low-wage workers," said Laura D'Andrea Tyson, who heads the President's Council of Economic Advisers. "It's been a reason for the increasing wage gap between high-wage and low-wage workers."
The ministers are likely to recommend that improved education and job training are a vital antidote to both long-term unemployment and wage stagnation. The jobs conference could help line up public support for Mr. Clinton's plans to increase spending on schools and training programs.
"The demand for workers seems to have shifted toward well-educated and skilled workers and away from relatively uneducated and unskilled workers," Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said in an interview.
Administration officials say one question the conference will examine is whether, for the first time in history, technological change is resulting in a net decrease in jobs rather than an overall increase.
Some officials fear that the meeting could prove risky because it will focus public attention on a nagging problem that the President cannot possibly solve quickly. The meeting also runs the risk of becoming yet another highly trumpeted gathering that produces high-flown oratory but little action.
 
 
'Educating People'
 Offsetting those risks, the Administration is likely to use the meeting to remind the public that Mr. Clinton did not create high unemployment. The Administration will also undoubtedly seek to show that the President, after being elected to turn around the economy, is doing his best to smite the unemployment dragon.
"It will be good for educating people on the nation's long-term problems and to explain that you can't solve long-term problems overnight," said Gene Sperling, an assistant to the President for economic policy.
While Western Europe has benefited from strong productivity growth and wage growth over two decades, Europeans are alarmed that their private sector has scarcely added any jobs in 20 years. America's plight has been largely the opposite: employment growth has been strong, but productivity growth has been sluggish, while real hourly wages have declined for 20 years.
In some ways, Mr. Clinton has asked the ministers to search for the Holy Grail of economics: achieving strong productivity growth and strong job growth at the same time.
European countries have invested generously in new equipment and job training, increasing productivity and creating high-paying jobs. But this approach has not produced a net increase in private-sector jobs.
 
 
More Low-Paying Jobs
 In the United States, partly because investment has been low in equipment and training, both productivity and wage growth have been slow. But there has been a boom in the number of low-paying jobs.
"Do industrial nations face a tragic choice between more jobs and better jobs?" Mr. Reich said. "Superficially, it would look that way, but there may be other alternatives."
In Tokyo, Group of Seven leaders pointed to several possible solutions. Their communiques talked about greater investment in education and training. And in an implicit reference to Europe, they said that greater wage flexibility was needed and that costly social insurance programs "that unduly discourage employment creation should be re-examined."
 Many European officials and economists are convinced that continental Europe's high minimum wages, high payroll taxes and restrictions on hiring temporary workers have hurt job creation. Changing any of those could meet stiff union opposition, however.

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN TOKYO: News Analysis;
A Clinton Debut: Fancy Footwork and a Bow

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

 BODY:
TOKYO, Saturday, July 10 -- Even before his negotiators wrested a last-second agreement from the Japanese on how to attack its enormous trade imbalance with the United States, it had been a big week for Bill Clinton.
Achieving the long-sought breakthrough with Japan, however tentative a first step it represents in an arduous process, sent the President and his entourage away from his debut in summit diplomacy in an ebullient mood. Even the determinedly dour Secretary of State, Warren Christopher, permitted himself the faintest touch of braggadocio. 
 "I want to avoid unnecessary bugling," Mr. Christopher said. "But it does seem to me that President Clinton has arrived on the world scene with a good deal of emphasis."
Mr. Clinton won last November by promising to put domestic policy ahead of foreign policy. In his campaign and in the early weeks of his Presidency, he argued that the national security of the United States, in the post-cold-war era, depended on rebuilding the domestic economy -- that economic strength at home and national success abroad were inseparable.
This week's summit conference of the seven leading industrial democracies gave him at last, on his first overseas jaunt as President, a chance to put those ideas into action instead of merely talking about them.
In addition, it gave him the chance, which he seized with all the zest of a rookie, to assume the leader's mantle. Politically weak as he may seem in the opinion polls, he was a Brobdingnagian among Lilliputians here, viewed against the untested and the shopworn leaders with whom he conferred.
To a considerable degree, he usurped the host's role, but then the Japanese were in no position to complain, with the governing Liberal Democratic Party wracked by scandal and Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa almost certainly in his last 10 days in office.
There is little doubt that, even if he failed to move the Japanese as far as he tried to, even if he fell somewhat short in numerous other ways, he did better than his immediate predecessor, George Bush, who came here in January, 1992. Mr. Bush left without credible evidence that he had created the "jobs, jobs, jobs" that he sought.
There is little doubt, either, that Mr. Clinton went some way toward putting to rest the doubts that Japanese, European and even a few Canadian officials have had about his capacity to exercise world leadership on behalf of the United States, the only plausible candidate for that role at the moment. His handling of the Bosnian situation and the early fumbles of his senior White House staff had generated widespread cynicism in recent weeks.
"The vacuum is not so profound as we leave Tokyo," said a British official. "This week showed that he can stay focused if he tries to."
A German politician commented: "Clinton moved quickly to the center of things, without showing off, without being rude, without offending."
Mr. Clinton is not about to turn into a foreign-policy President. He may have spent this week on the far side of the Pacific Ocean, but he found time in a punishing schedule to record a radio address about the Mississippi River floods.
And everyone remembered the campaign motto: "It's the economy, stupid." The agreement to reduce tariffs on a broad range of manufactured goods would create 1.4 million new American jobs, said Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, in a piece of artful hyperbole that no one could disprove.
Could the United States really afford aid for the Russians? "There's a lot of business to be done in Russia by Americans to create American jobs," the President said Friday. A "jobs summit" was cooked up by the White House and sold to the leaders of the six other nations represented here. A trade deal with Japan was touted by Bill Clinton, traveling salesman, as something that would "mean lots more jobs for our folks" and for Japan, too.
The White House labored mightily to turn discussions about arcane terms of trade and international economic formulas into tangible pocketbook issues. The President capped the effort at his news conference Friday night with the comment that it would be fair to describe this as "a jobs summit."
"When people are having a tough time making ends meet, they don't tend to be very happy with their political leaders," Mr. Clinton acknowledged, but he added: "Notwithstanding that, this summit produced real substantive benefits for the people who sent these leaders here."
 
Fell Short, in Some Ways
 Relatively little was said about what had not been accomplished in the quest for fuller employment. The vexing subject of agricultural tariffs, which sharply divides the United States from France and, to a lesser degree, the other European nations, was barely addressed here. The economic communique contained no 3 percent target for annual growth, as the United States had urged. There was less aid for the Soviet Union than Mr. Clinton wanted.
As he said at the news conference, Mr. Clinton was strengthened here by his success in pushing his budget package, with its deficit-reduction measures, through both houses of Congress. He was able to urge lower European interest rates and more accessible Japanese markets without fearing the rejoinder that Ronald Reagan and George Bush heard so often from their colleagues: First cut your deficit and then we'll listen to your sermons.
But that could prove a most transitory thing. The President will return to Washington to face the immensely complicated task of persuading both houses to pass the same bill. Failure would put Mr. Clinton back very close to square one.
"I am hoping," the President said at his news conference, "that what happened this week will strengthen the resolve of the Congress to go ahead and pass the economic plan and to do it in short order.
A number of journalists and officials marveled at a typical piece of intellectual gymnastics. Just as the President dazzled American specialists at his economic round-table meeting in Little Rock before taking office, he wowed many here by his off-the-cuff command of the subtleties of the European economic situation.
In much that happened in Tokyo, the hand of David Gergen, Mr. Clinton's new counselor, was clearly visible. But Mr. Bentsen, who has been less visible than expected in the first months of the new Democratic regime, also stepped smartly to the fore here.
The summit, Mr. Clinton remarked, had "more energy and more zip" than he expected. The consensus in the conference corridors as the leaders and their aides packed their bags then left town was that the new American on the block had provided much of it.

HEADLINE: Asians Seek To Restrict U.S. Airlines

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 9

 BODY:
In a spirit of unity never seen in the Asian airline industry, most of Asia's large airlines are banding together to overturn what they consider to be one-sided agreements that give American airlines the right to pick up passengers in Asia and fly them to other destinations in Asia, a right Asian carriers do not have in America.
Fifteen major Asian carriers here have announced that they will lobby their governments to scrap, or at least drastically revise, decades-old air-service accords with Washington that date to when the Asian carriers were in their infancy. 
 The move by the Asian airlines could not come at a worse time for their large American rivals, especially United Airlines and Northwest Airlines, the largest American carriers in Asia, which had come to see flights in Asia, the world's fastest-growing air travel market, as one of the last sure opportunities for growth.
The American carriers are seeking help from the Clinton Administration, which has announced its intention to assist them.
The Orient Airlines Association -- which represents Asian and South Pacific airlines, including Japan Airlines, Singapore Airlines, Thai Airways, Cathay Pacific Airways of Hong Kong and Qantas Airways of Australia -- started their collective attack last month.
The association's chairman, Chatrachai Bunya-Ananta, who is also the president of Thai Airways, said he would "urge Asia government negotiators to establish new, fairer agreements which provide a level playing field on which O.A.A. carriers can compete with U.S. carriers."
Under the current agreements, American air carriers were given broad freedoms to transport passengers from one point in Asia to another. But no similar rights were granted to the Asian carriers, which caused no great concern at a time when few Asian carriers flew to the United States.
Now, the reasons for the concern of Asian airlines is clear every day at major airports across this continent: It is possible for an American traveler to visit every major Asian business center on a single trip without flying on an Asian airline.
In Bangkok, travelers wishing to fly to Japan can choose from several daily flights on Thai Airways or Japan Airlines. They can also catch a late-night United flight or an early-morning Northwest flight. Both flights go on to the United States.
But Thai Airways flies to only one city in the United States, Los Angeles. Although it has the right to fly to other American cities, it cannot pick up passengers in one American city and drop them off in another.
Asian carriers say it can be difficult to compete with the American carriers, which lure passengers with deep discounts and with frequent-flier programs. Several major carriers in Southeast Asia, including Thai and Singapore, are starting their own frequent-flier programs this summer.
"The Asian airlines have quite a strong argument," said Stephen Miller, an airline consultant with Trinity Aviation in Hong Kong. "If the American airlines can fly from Taipei to Bangkok, or from Singapore to Hong Kong, the Asian carriers want the right to fly within the United States. But then the American side says, hey, you can't do this, because these are domestic routes."
Elliott Seiden, vice president for law and government affairs at Northwest Airlines, said his airline might be willing to support giving Asian carriers the authority to fly passengers within the United States, so long as American carriers retained their broad rights in Asia.
He said that Asian governments would take a serious risk if they tried to limit the American carriers.
"You can't close down airline markets without having a significant impact on free and open trade," he said, "and these are economies that are utterly dependent on free and open trade with the United States."

HEADLINE: Bosnia Threatened With U.N. Pullout, 2 U.S. Reports Say

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 9

 BODY:
As the humanitarian crisis in Bosnia worsens, two classified Administration reports say the international mediators in the Balkans are holding out the threat of seeking United Nations withdrawal from the country unless the Bosnian Muslims agree to negotiate on a partition plan.
In recent days, the mediators representing the United Nations and the European Community in the 15-month-old war have publicly warned that the deteriorating conditions could lead the United Nations to reconsider its mandate. Bosnian Government officials interpret the remarks as part of a pressure campaign intended to force them to accept the partition plan. 
 If true, the classified reports would suggest that the mediators are willing to use pressure tactics to push the Bosnian Muslims to the negotiating table. But it is not clear from the reports whether the mediators talked directly to the Bosnians about a United Nations withdrawal or were simply circulating the idea among other diplomats.
In Sarajevo, the Muslim-led Bosnian Government today renewed its appeal to the United States for political and military support in its fight to maintain Bosnia as a viable, multiethnic country. [Page 6.]
It also announced that it would reject a Serbian and Croatian proposal to end the war by dividing the former Yugoslav republic into three ethnic states.
If the United Nations pulls out, the Bosnian Muslims will lose their only outside source of protection and relief assistance.
The situation in Sarajevo has become so dire that an American disaster relief team that left the Bosnian capital this week reported to the State Department by telephone on Thursday that the city had become "the world's largest concentration camp" because there was no drinking water or fuel, and could collapse within 10 days.
 
Possibility of U.N. Pullout
 A State Department cable, sent from the United States mission in Geneva this week, quoted Sadako Ogata, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, as saying the two mediators had told her recently "that if the Bosnian Muslims did not agree soon to negotiate on the basis of the Serb-Croat partition plan," they will recommend to the United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, "that the U.N. withdraw from Bosnia."
The cable added, "If the U.N. decided to withdraw from Bosnia, Ogata made clear that U.N.H.C.R. would be part of that withdrawal."
Senior Administration officials said another classified report circulating within the United States Government today also reported that Lord Owen, who represents the European Community, and Thorvald Stoltenberg, the United Nations mediator, were raising the possibility of a United Nations withdrawal from Bosnia.
But in a telephone interview from Zagreb, Lord Owen denied that he and Mr. Stoltenberg were trying to blackmail the Bosnians into agreeing to a partition of their country.
"It's absolute nonsense," he said. "There isn't any dream, any possibility of that. There is no attempt to blackmail the Bosnian presidency. It must make its own decision."
In recent months, the increased fighting in Bosnia, attacks on United Nations workers by the three warring sides and the economic strangulation of Sarajevo and other urban centers by the Serbs and Croats have severely hampered the ability of United Nations peacekeepers to help deliver relief supplies.
Indeed, Nicholas Morris, the new head of the United Nations refugee operation in Bosnia, bluntly told diplomats last week that because of the dangers in delivering aid and the Serbian practice of demanding a portion of the aid as a price to allow delivery, "this operation should not be taking place and would not be initiated now if the U.N.H.C.R. were not already there," a separate classified State Department cable said.
United Nations officials announced on June 30 that because of the hazards and declining international contributions to the relief effort in Bosnia, shipments of food and other relief supplies would be cut by up to 50 percent in some parts of the country.
Muhamed Sacirbey, the Bosnian representative at the United Nations, said United Nations relief officials had told Bosnian officials that relief assistance would end if they did not accept the principles of the partition plan proposed by the Serbs and Croats. "I have asked the Security Council for an explanation," he said.
But John Mills, the spokesman for Mr. Stoltenberg, said in a telephone interview from Belgrade that the desire to get the Bosnian Muslims to negotiate was not related to warnings about a potential future withdrawal of United Nations operations.
 
'That Stage May Come'
 "That stage may come," Mr. Mills said, referring to a United Nations pullout. "But it won't come as a consequence of the Bosnian presidency rejecting negotiations."
A senior State Department official traveling with Secretary of State Warren Christopher in Tokyo said that Mr. Christopher was unaware of any threats by the mediators to the Bosnian Muslims, but that he would consider any effort to pressure them by threatening a withdrawal of relief assistance "a highly unacceptable tactic."
Another senior State Department official, familiar with the matter, suggested that Mr. Stoltenberg and Mr. Owen were in effect indirectly putting pressure on the Bosnian Government.
"My understanding is that they are saying if there is no negotiation soon, the situation will spin out of control and the ability of the peacekeeping and humanitarian operations to operate is about to evaporate," the official said. "By implication one might interpret that as a kind of take-it-or-leave-it proposition."
Another State Department official said that neither Mr. Owen nor Mr. Stoltenberg had informed the United States of any threat to recommend a United Nations withdrawal from Bosnia.
"Any decision to withdraw would have to be made by Security Council," the official said. "We would not favor any such action."
President Clinton, meanwhile, was said to have been so disturbed in Tokyo by television reports on the situation in Sarajevo that his aides had called the State Department on Wednesday to find ways to help provide the city with food, medicine and clean water.
 
 
 
BALKAN UPDATE
 In SARAJEVO yesterday, the Muslim-led Government of BOSNIA said it would reject a Serbian-Croatian plan to divide the country it into three ethnic states. Two Clinton Administration reports say mediators are holding out the threat of seeking the U.N.'s withdrawal from BOSNIA unless its Muslim leaders agree to negotiate on the plan.
In BELGRADE, Vuk Draskovic, an opposition leader, and his wife, Danica, were released from jail on orders from President Slobodan Milosevic of SERBIA.

GRAPHIC: Photo: With little humanitarian aid supplies reaching the besieged city of Sarajevo, a Bosnian family scavenged for food and anything else of use yesterday in a garbage dump near a United Nations barracks. (Associated Press)(pg. 6)

HEADLINE: Health Limbo for Early Retirees

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
The White House is consulting with business and labor groups on measures that would assure medical coverage for millions of workers who retire before they are eligible for Federal Medicare insurance.
Although no decisions have been made on how to pay for care for either active or retired workers under the proposed national health-care plan, Clinton Administration officials are discussing ways of raising money for the program, according to people who attended meetings in the last 10 days with Ira Magaziner, the White House health-care adviser. 
 Some large industries, including auto makers, as well as the A.F.L.-C.I.O., prefer an income-based payroll tax, these people said, while other industries were more receptive to paying a flat premium per employee, and some employers wanted the costs paid from general tax revenues.
 
Other Possibilities
 Ceilings on the tax or premium payments, reduced charges for small businesses and special treatment for low-income employees are also being considered.
Under the Administration plan, people who retire before age 65 could join regional alliances of health-care consumers; these groups presumably could buy health coverage at favorable prices.
With the cost of medical care climbing, many companies are requiring retirees to pay a growing share of their own health costs, which have been rising faster than general inflation for years. Some companies have announced that they will eliminate retiree coverage.
Administration officials and members of Congress said in interviews that protecting retirees would be essential in securing support for the Administration's program of sweeping changes in health care.
"It is critical to include retirees, including those who are eligible for Medicare, in reform of the system," said Dr. Mary Jane England, president of the Washington Business Group on Health, an association of 200 large employers.
Claire Hushbeck, an analyst with the American Association of Retired Persons, said that protecting retirees' benefits was an issue that worried mainstream Americans. "Mom and dad and the next-door neighbors, people who basically did everything right all along the way, are at risk of losing their health benefits," she said.
Indeed, the General Accounting Office, in a report issued yesterday to a House subcommittee on small-business regulation, stated that "retiree health benefits are not secure." It noted that an employer's right to reduce retiree benefits had been upheld in a number of court cases.
The subcommittee chairman, Representative Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, said retiree coverage should be part of a "basic benefits package" that all employers must provide.
 
Variation in Reactions
 Sharon Canner, a health policy expert at the National Association of Manufacturers, said employers' views on the issue varied widely.
"It depends on the industry, high wage or low wage, the markets they are competing in, health costs, geography," she said. "High-tech industries with fewer retirees are more likely to lean toward a flat premium. Autos is likely to favor a payroll tax."
Depending on the financing setup of the Administration plan, costs might be reduced for employers like the auto makers that have many older workers and retirees.
Unions generally favor a payroll tax based on a percentage of income. "It would be one of the fairest ways to get the money," said John J. Sweeney, president of the Service Employees International Union.
 
Rapidly Rising Figure
 Employers currently have a $412 billion liability for retiree medical benefits, the General Accounting Office said, up from $227 billion in 1989. Rising medical costs and the aging population have swelled the total, said Donald C. Snyder, an assistant director of the G.A.O.
At least four million Americans between the ages of 55 and 64 consider themselves retired, and three million retirees under 65 and their spouses are now receiving retiree health benefits. The report said future retirees would have less employer-provided coverage.
Medical expenses are often a problem for people over age 55, who are not eligible for Medicare. Many are rejected by private insurers because of health problems and many cannot afford insurance premiums anyway. "This is a vulnerable age group," said Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan.
Mr. Magaziner discussed the retiree health issue on Thursday with executives of some of the nation's largest companies at the National Association of Manufacturers office in Washington. He met with labor union officials last Friday. Both groups welcomed the Administration's interest in the retiree issue.
"It is to their credit that they are trying to solve the issue," said Karen Ignagni, the head of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. employee benefits department.
Walter B. Maher, a health policy spokesman in Washington for the Chrysler Corporation, said that manufacturers that offer health benefits "are bearing a disproportionate share of American health costs" and that hurts their ability to compete with companies in foreign countries where more health expenses are covered by governments.
Ms. Canner of the National Association of Manufacturers pointed out that while mature industries like autos "were getting the biggest hit" on retiree costs, "eventually all companies are going to be mature."

HEADLINE: Fed Leaned Toward Higher Rates in May

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 9

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve announced today that its main policy-setting committee voted in May to lean toward raising interest rates if inflation did not slow. Many economists said the committee probably maintained that position when it met again on Tuesday and Wednesday.
According to a summary of the May 18 meeting that was issued today, couched in the Fed's typically elliptical prose, the policy-making committee voted 10 to 2 in favor of language that would leave the Fed poised to raise short-term interest rates, but only if there was more bad news about inflation. 
 The central bank's tilt toward tightening monetary policy was a response to an unexpected spurt in inflation early this year, when consumer price inflation rose four-tenths of 1 percent in April, to a 4.3 percent annual rate, from 2.9 percent in 1992. The Fed did not increase interest rates after the May meeting, however, because inflation slowed markedly in May, rising by only one-tenth of 1 percent on the consumer level.
Economists say the policy-setting committee, the Federal Open Market Committee, probably voted this week to keep tilting toward higher rates because many Fed officials fear that inflationary pressures remain stronger than they were last year.
"I think they probably kept their bias toward tightening largely because they don't want to be seen as responding to every little change in economic reports from week to week," said Lyle Gramley, a former Fed governor and chief economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association.
Some Administration officials suggested that the Federal Reserve had maintained its tilt toward tightening because it tends to move slowly, and probably fears that a change would give the impression that it believes inflation has been tamed.
Alicia Munnell, Assistant Treasury Secretary for Economic Policy, expressed confidence that raising rates would not be necessary this year.
"I am confident enough that inflation will remain low for the rest of the year and that raising short-term interest rates will not be an issue," she said.
A leaning toward raising rates normally gives the central bank's chairman some leeway to raise rates without consulting the full committee. The Federal Reserve has pegged its important Federal funds rate -- at which banks lend money to each other overnight -- at 3 percent since last September.
 
Commodity Prices Cited
 At the May meeting, Wayne D. Angell, a Federal Reserve Board member, voted against a slight bias toward tightening on the ground that that was too weak. He favored an immediate increase in short-term rates because he was worried that commodity prices were rising and that the bond markets appeared to fear inflationary pressures.
Edward G. Boehne, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, dissented against the bias toward tightening because he was convinced that there was no fundamental upward shift in inflation. He believed that the economy might weaken further and that "underlying economic conditions did not point toward an extended period of higher inflation."
Mr. Boehne's views appear to have been vindicated by the slight May rise in consumer prices and by the flurry of recent reports pointing to slow growth.
The Federal Open Market Committee includes the Federal Reserve Board's seven members and five presidents of the Fed's 12 regional banks. The central bank traditionally waits six weeks before releasing summaries of open market committee meetings.
Using the Fed's often dense language, the summary of the May meeting said, "In the view of a majority of the members, wage and price developments over recent months were sufficiently worrisome to warrant positioning policy for a move toward restraint should signs of continuing inflation continue to multiply."
But the majority decided that "given the special nature of current inflation and attendant uncertainties," the committee agreed with a proposal from Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, that there should be further consultations "in the event that a tightening move were to be contemplated."
The majority's position was that even "if a policy tightening action were not needed," a tilt toward higher rates "would nonetheless underscore the committee's concern about recent inflation readings."
The debate swirled around the hypertechnical jargon of a Federal Reserve directive. The language that was approved stated that "slightly greater reserve restraint would or slightly lesser reserve restraint might be acceptable." Translators of Fed jargon say this use of "would" is far stronger than this use of "might" and is enough to make bond buyers do somersaults. This language means that the Fed prefers greater reserve restraint; that is, a tilt toward higher rates.

HEADLINE: Yemen's Democracy Gives U.S. the Jitters

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The first true multiparty democracy in Middle Eastern history has emerged in the mountain country of Yemen, despite the best efforts of the United States to abort it. With almost no natural resource base, Yemen has until recently sustained a growth rate rivaling that of the "dragons" of east Asia, more than 6 percent a year from 1970 to 1988. 
 But in the last two years, as a consequence of the Persian Gulf war, Yemen's economy has collapsed. Saudi Arabia, our strategic ally, has made beggaring Yemen a prime foreign policy objective. To this end, and with tacit United States acceptance, Saudi Arabia has forcibly ejected from its soil almost a million Yemenites, most of whom were forced to leave prosperous businesses and properties behind. The Saudis have also funneled money and aid to a fifth column of religious fundamentalists.
As a consequence, more than one-third of the population of Yemen is unemployed, and many are in refugee camps. The Yemeni currency, the riyal, has lost 75 percent of its international value. The economy has been devastated.
The last few years have seen droughts equal to those in Somalia and Ethiopia. Yemen has been visited by a plague of locusts that are destroying crops throughout the land.
Yet starvation has been staved off, and Yemen's refugees have been fed by their own people. The United States, while pumping streams of money or missiles to the region, has avoided offending our petrol partners by acknowledging this little democracy. As a transplanted Yemenite, I ache with pride. But as a first-generation American, I burn with shame.
 
ABDULKADER K. SALEH
Weston, Conn., July 2, 1993

HEADLINE: Guy Noyes, 79, Dies; Economist for Bank And Federal Reserve

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE

 BODY:
Guy Emerson Noyes, an economist who directed research and analyzed trends for the Federal Reserve Board and later for the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, died on Sunday at the Naples Community Hospital in Naples, Fla. He was 79 and lived in Naples.
His wife, Irene, said the cause of death was massive infection. 
 Mr. Noyes joined the Federal Reserve System in 1948 as an adviser to its board of governors and served as director of research and statistics from 1960 to 1965, when he joined Morgan Guaranty as senior vice president and economist.
Reflecting on that move in an interview, he said, "After you have been pushing buttons in Washington for years to get the economy to behave the way you want it to, there's a certain intellectual fascination about wanting to try it on the other side -- to see how policy from Washington affects the private decision-making process."
During his 13 years at Morgan he centralized its various economic analysis units and established the company's economic research unit as one of the strongest on Wall Street.
Mr. Noyes, who was generally known as Jack, was a native of Columbia, Mo., and the son of the dean of the University of Missouri's Medical School. After graduating from Missouri he studied banking as a graduate student at Yale University.
In World War II he served as Army Reserve officer in London. After the war he became a research director at the State Department, where he remained two years before going to the Federal Reserve Board.
His first marriage ended with the death of his wife, the former Patricia Hartnett, in 1972. Besides his wife Irene, he is survived by a son, Guy Jr., of Seattle; a daughter, Pamela, of Great Falls, Va., and a grandchild.

HEADLINE: Talk of German Rate Drop Spurs Dollar Against Mark

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar surged to a 20-month high against the German mark yesterday after a large purchase in Europe set off what traders said was a chain reaction of buying in a thin market. Dealers said the identity of the buyer was unknown.
Meanwhile, gold prices fell. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, the actively traded gold contract for August delivery dropped $3.30 an ounce, to $392.30. A late quote from the Republic National Bank put spot gold at $391.55 an ounce, down $3.20 from Thursday. 
 Talk of further German interest-rate cuts also spurred demand for dollars, dealers said. The talk was rekindled by a statement from the Group of Seven industrial nations meeting in Tokyo calling for lower European interest rates to help stimulate the world economy.
The dollar benefits from lower German interest rates, which make the mark less attractive to investors.
Jitters about the viability of Europe's Exchange Rate Mechanism, which links the currencies of eight European Community nations, also helped the dollar. The fears stemmed from the continued weakness of the French franc, which came under attack Thursday after a weak economic report.
"The dollar is clearly drawing support from renewed tension in the E.R.M. and from all this talk about German interest rates being cut again this month," said David Cocker, currency analyst at Chemical Bank in London.
The dollar also advanced on the yen amid reports that United States and Japanese officials were close to a possible agreement on the framework for a trade pact. Officials were working on the pact as the Group of Seven was wrapping up its meeting in Tokyo.
Progress toward a bilateral agreement has quelled talk that the United States would look to a stronger yen as a tool for paring Japan's huge trade surplus.
In late New York trading, the dollar rose to 1.7210 marks, from 1.7030 marks late Thursday. The dollar was also quoted at 109.96 yen in New York, up from 108.54 yen Thursday.
The British pound, meanwhile, settled at $1.4810 in New York, down from $1.4965 Thursday.
