HEADLINE: Baghdad Journal;
A New Graphic Message From Saddam Hussein

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 9

 BODY:
President Saddam Hussein's latest attempt to get even with the man who forced him out of Kuwait is a larger-than-life mosaic of a snarling George Bush on the floor at the entrance to the Rashid Hotel, the best in Baghdad.
Visitors leave dusty footprints on the image of Mr. Bush, who led the allied coalition in the Persian Gulf war. "Bush Is Criminal," says the legend underneath. 
 It is a futile gesture and, in the view of an Arab ambassador here, "unnecessary and counterproductive." But it illustrates the two-track Iraqi response to nearly three years of trade sanctions and diplomatic isolation.
 
Defiance and Appeals
 On the one hand, foreign diplomats here say, Iraq is making its most serious effort since the war to build bridges to Washington and to get sanctions lifted as the country slides into deepening economic distress.
But the Government is still shouting defiance and trying to rally the people to blame Washington and its allies for all its troubles.
On Thursday the Information Ministry issued a book on the Persian Gulf war. Its triumphant opening sentence says: "The course of the Mother of Battles is a continuation of the holy war of our great ancestors at the dawn of Islam in fighting the atheists and the unjust."
Last summer Iraqi television showed a 52-part serial, "Mirage or Reality," explaining Iraq's historical claim to Kuwait. This summer it is showing a 22-part series on the origins of the Saudi royal family, asserting that King Fahd is descended from Jewish merchants who lived in Basra, in southern Iraq, at the end of the 18th century.
The program can be picked up in Kuwait and parts of Saudi Arabia.
The United States has accused Iraq of masterminding a bomb plot against Mr. Bush when the former President was visiting Kuwait in April. And Iraq is now locked in another standoff with United Nations arms inspectors, who want to install surveillance cameras at what are thought to be missile-testing stations.
Such actions are hard to reconcile with Baghdad's insistence that it wants special relations with the Clinton Administration.
The leadership's reaction to the American missile raid on June 27, which Washington said was in retaliation for the reported plot against Mr. Bush, has been astonishingly conciliatory. President Hussein has not said a word in public since the raid, evidently because he fears being forced to criticize the United States.
In recent months, diplomats say, Baghdad has welcomed industrialists from Japan and Europe and dangled the prospects of big contracts if they can persuade their governments to get sanctions lifted.
Harassment of United Nations personnel, rampant a year ago when the windows of their jeeps were regularly broken and the tires slashed, has virtually ended. Mohammed Zejjari, the United Nations aid coordinator here, says he no longer has difficulty getting relief convoys to Kurds in northern Iraq, whose lands have been blockaded by the Iraqi Army.
Since the Persian Gulf war, in 1991, President Hussein has blamed external forces for the country's economic woes and has used the fear of another attack to rally the people.
From this point of view, the recent American attack played into his hands without doing any discernible damage to his security system.
"Frankly, when I heard the explosions I thought it was a coup, because everything has been so quiet here for months," an Asian ambassador said. "But once I learned what it was, I knew Saddam was safe a while longer."
But other actions are seen as part of an Iraqi campaign to test the Security Council's will to maintain sanctions with the coalition from the war less unified and with poor neighboring countries like Turkey complaining that the embargo costs them billions of dollars in lost trade.
In an attempt to mobilize Islamic opinion in favor of unfreezing its overseas bank accounts, Baghdad recently offered to give $50 million to a Palestinian housing project in the Israeli-occupied West Bank if funds are released and to spend $10 million on Korans for schools there.
Similarly, Iraq opposes installing surveillance cameras at missile-testing sites because it sees this as an attempt by Washington to impose new conditions for ending the embargo.
This is why Baghdad has asked the Council to lay out exactly what Iraq must do to have sanctions lifted. The United States and its allies want Iraq to comply with all relevant Security Council resolutions, in addition to abandoning its weapons of mass destruction, before trade restrictions are eased.
This means Iraq must end its repression of the Kurds in the north and the Shiites in the south and accept the less favorable border with Kuwait that the United Nations has drawn. "That frontier is going to be the most difficult condition of all for Iraq to meet," the Arab ambassador said.
 
Feeling the Pinch
 There is also a widespread feeling here that Iraq is running critically short of resources and may be willing to show greater flexibility.
Both bread and butter have vanished from the restaurants of the Rashid, and the hotel no longer provides soap in the bathrooms or towels at the swimming pool. At meetings with ambassadors, the Foreign Minister no longer gives them note pads; if a diplomat asks for paper, he is offered a single sheet.
Iraq has its cement and fertilizer industries working again, and there is evidence it is exporting both commodities to Iran. But Turkish merchants have complained to their embassy that they can no longer get dollars for the food they bring in.
Last year popular resentment at high prices led President Hussein to execute 43 merchants for profiteering. This year he banned the import and sale of a long list of luxury goods. Foreign cosmetics, beer and electrical items have all disappeared from Baghdad shops.
A year ago the Government-owned foreign currency shop here was stuffed with European goods. Today it stocks virtually nothing but Scotch whisky, which, curiously, has not been banned.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Government of Saddam Hussein is using a two-track response to nearly three years of trade sanctions against Iraq. While the Government is making diplomatic overtures to Washington, in a continuing show of defiance a large caricature of George Bush was installed in the floor of the entrance to the Rashid Hotel in Baghdad. (Agence France-Presse for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Treasury Yield Falls to Low of 6.64%

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Optimism ahead of next week's inflation figures continued to give a lift to long-term Treasury prices yesterday, pushing the yield on the benchmark 30-year bond to a record low for the second straight session.
The price of the Treasury's main 30-year bond rose 1/4 point, or $2.50 for $1,000 in face value. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, fell to a low of 6.64 percent, from 6.65 percent Thursday. 
 Intermediate maturities were 1/32 point to 1/8 point higher. But prices of shorter-term securities retreated slightly by 1/32 point, the Telerate financial information service reported.
Trading was thin, with traders awaiting next week's two June inflation reports: the Producer Price Index, scheduled for Tuesday, and the Consumer Price Index, on Wednesday.
Most economists expect the figures to show a low annual rate of inflation, which would bode favorably for bonds. Higher inflation tends to diminish the value of Treasury securities, particularly bonds that do not mature for many years.
Many economists believe that producer prices will be unchanged to down three-tenths of a percent in June. Consumer prices, meanwhile, are expected to increase by one-tenth to two-tenths of a percent.
With their attention on inflation concerns, participants continued to react positively to a decline in daily commodity prices. Yesterday, the Commodity Research Bureau Index fell 0.7, to 216.05, as grains and precious metals declined in price.
 
'Groping in the Dark'
 The decline in the index, a widely watched indicator of inflation trends, is fueling optimism that inflation reports for the months following June will also show inflation under control, said Robert Brusca, chief economist in the fixed-income department at Nikko Securities International.
"The bond market is sort of groping in the dark, trying to see where it can go," Mr. Brusca said.
A sharp advance in the dollar against key foreign currencies also lent some psychological support to the Treasury market, said Mead Briggs, head of risk trading at Deutsche Bank Government Securities.
Some investors stepping up their purchases of dollars in European trading, which opens before New York's session, decided to funnel the United States currency into Treasury securities, Mr. Briggs said.
Demand for long-term bonds has also benefited from a favorable supply outlook. The Treasury has whittled down the supply of 30-year bonds as part of its new debt management mix. As a result, the Government's auction of long bonds in August is the last until February.
That has lent a favorable undercurrent to prices, since fewer bonds help the value of existing securities.
Yields on three-month Treasury bills were unchanged at 3.07 percent as the discount was steady at 3.01 percent. Six-month yields were up to 3.19 percent as the discount rose 0.02 percentage point, to 3.11 percent. One-year yields were up to 3.38 percent as the discount was up 0.01 point, to 3.26 percent.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 10223/32 , up 1/16 from late Thursday. The average yield to maturity was unchanged at 5.71 percent.

HEADLINE: Stocks Hit Right Notes, Gaining 6.64, to 3,521.06

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET

 BODY:
Like an aging lounge act, the stock market turned in a solid but uninspired performance yesterday.
No trumpets sounded, but no screams were heard, either, as rising bond prices and good results earlier in the day on overseas markets helped lift most leading market indicators. For the first time since June 4, the Dow Jones industrial average finished higher than it did on the previous Friday, gaining 6.64 points, to 3,521.06. For the week, the Dow gained 37.09. 
 "It was pretty good for a Friday," said Lawrence R. Rice, a market strategist for Josephthal, Lyon & Ross. "A nonevent, I'd say."
 
 
Volume Was Surprising
 The one surprise, he said, was that trading on the New York Stock Exchange, was moderately heavy for the start of a summer weekend, at 234 million shares, compared with 284.1 on Thursday. "Figured everybody would be gone," he said.
The markets managed to overcome some profit taking during the morning after two days of solid gains. The exception was among transportation stocks, with the airlines in particular suffering after a rally on Thursday. "They bid them up a little too high," Mr. Rice said. "You continue to have a lack of traffic in the industry, and discounting."
Partly because of the weakened airline stocks, the Dow Jones transportation average finished down 10.09 points at 1,509.16. The American Stock Exchange index was up 1.82, to 434.37, while the Nasdaq composite climbed 3.10, to 705.81. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks lost ground, dropping 0.51 point, to 448.13.
 
 
Auto Makers Gain
 The Big Three auto makers continued a surge that began on Tuesday, when they reported vigorous sales for late June, their best period since late December 1990. "They're coming from a disaster and looking pretty doggone good," said Arvid Jouppi, senior vice president for research for Keane Securities.
General Motors finished the day at 47 1/2, up 5/8. Ford Motor was up 7/8 at 52 1/8, and Chrysler was up 3/8 at 47 1/2.
The upturn for the Big Three may bode well for the economy as a whole. Mr. Jouppi cited the auto makers' performance in 1982, when an August rally in auto stocks presaged the stock market's recovery that fall. For that reason, he said, he expects no more quantum leaps in auto stocks. "There will be other values that will compete for investment dollars in the not-too-distant future," he said.
Among the big gainers yesterday was Best Buy, an electronics retailer. Its shares rose 3 3/8, to 41 1/2, still riding high from its report on Thursday that June same-store sales rose 28 percent from the period in 1992.
Steven M. Ashley, a vice president of Cleary Gull Reiland & McDevitt, attributed the sharp sales improvement to Best Buy's decision to begin carrying personal computers and to a new personnel strategy that relies on clerks paid by the hour. "They have taken aggressive commission salesmen out of the stores," he said. "It is not that used-car-salesman feeling."
In Tokyo, the Nikkei index of 225 issues gained 188.72 points, or 0.96 percent, to 19,877.39. For the week, the Nikkei rose 255.93.

HEADLINE: Henry Hazlitt, 98, a Journalist Who Concentrated on Economics

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Henry Hazlitt, a self-taught economist who popularized the subject as a journalist and wrote a best-selling book about it, died yesterday at the Carolton Chronic Convalescent Hospital in Fairfield, Conn. He was 98 and had lived at the hospital for nearly seven years.
"Economics in One Lesson," the best-known of Mr. Hazlitt's 17 books, was unstinting in its praise of free markets. In the simplest language, rarely citing statistics, he laid out what he called the fallacies of regulating economic activity -- like trying, for example, to raise wage levels through minimum wage laws or union bargaining. 
 And without naming Karl Marx or John Maynard Keynes, whose theories were so prominent in 1946 when the book was published, Mr. Hazlitt rejected their interventionist solutions.
"Fallacies, when they have reached the popular stage, become anonymous anyway," he wrote in his 222-page book, which sold more than 600,000 copies. "The subtleties or obscurities to be found in the authors most responsible for propagating them are washed off."
 
Economics and Some Fiction
 Mainly a journalist, by the time he was 38 years old in 1933 Mr. Hazlitt had written on economics for The Wall Street Journal, served as financial editor for The New York Evening Mail, written editorials for The New York Herald and The New York Sun and, switching specialties, served as literary editor of The Sun and then The Nation.
That brought him to the attention of the writer and critic H. L. Mencken, who asked Mr. Hazlitt in 1933 to succeed him as editor of the American Mercury, a widely read magazine founded by Mr. Mencken and George Jean Nathan, best known for its iconoclastic commentaries on American ways. The following year, Mr. Hazlitt joined The New York Times as an editorial writer specializing in economics, remaining at The Times until 1946. For the next 20 years he wrote a column entitled Business Tides for Newsweek magazine.
Mr. Hazlitt was born on Nov. 28, 1894, in Philadelphia. He had planned to go to Harvard and major in psychology. But "something called a shortage of funds," as he later put it, forced him to go to City College instead, and a few months later he left even that tuition-free school "to go to work to support my mother as well as myself." The Wall Street Journal gave him that first job.
Mr. Hazlitt lived in Wilton, Conn., before entering Carolton. His wife, the former Frances S. Kanes, died in 1991.

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW YORK;
Youths With Potential Honor a Helping Hand

BYLINE: By Felicia R. Lee

 BODY:
IT was the year that both the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. and Robert F. Kennedy were slain, the musical "Hair" enthralled Broadway and defiance marked attitudes. It was also the year that 14 male New Yorkers gathered to consider being young, gifted, black and Catholic in a time of turmoil.
The men will come together a week from today to celebrate the 25th anniversary of the Archbishop's Leadership Project, which began in June 1968 under the Archbishop of New York, Terence Cardinal Cooke. Initially archdiocesan leaders planned to use the group to promote the priesthood as a vocation among blacks, but it quickly became a kind of crucible for personal development. 
 The young men from Catholic high schools were chosen for their academic and personal potential. They spent their two years in the project attending cultural events, debating issues like assimilation versus revolution, listening to guest speakers and going on weekend retreats that were a mix of adolescent shenanigans and soul-searching.
Of the men in that first group, most have gone on to do good things. They are now fathers and husbands, bankers, lawyers, a psychiatrist. And now the first from the leadership project has become a priest.
On a recent sweltering Sunday at St. Mark the Evangelist Church in Harlem, the Rev. Gregory C. Chisholm celebrated a Mass of thanksgiving to mark his ordination.
Ordained in June, Father Chisholm represents a most positive development in a church that has had to contend with dwindling numbers of priests, the loss of many black and Hispanic parishioners and many priests accused of sexual abuse.
That Sunday Father Chisholm looked at the beaming faces squeezed into the pews at St. Mark's, the place where generations of his family have been christened, married and mourned. He grinned.
"I know," he said, "there are many of you who thought you'd never see this." Laughter rang out, bouncing off the walls with the traditional stained-glass renditions of a Jesus with white skin and a large painting of a brown-skinned man on a cross.
Father Chisholm and his friends from the first leadership group credit the project and its coordinator, the Rev. John T. Meehan, an Irish-American priest, as bringing them to a more profound understanding of their role in transforming a society whose barriers had never seemed more fluid.
They learned ways to define manhood that went beyond sexuality and rhetoric, they said. They learned that there is a place where their racial heritage meets their faith. Their hope is that the project -- now coed and led by a laywoman -- can continue to inspire.
"My whole life I owe to it," said Irv Cooke, a tax auditor who grew up in Harlem. "It made me realize my self-worth. Growing up where I did, you never saw the outside world for what it was. I learned that you can be successful by giving it your all."
Gerald Adolph, a management consultant, recalled, "It was taking this group with a bunch of energy and a bunch of mouth and channeling it into something positive. It helped me stand up and formulate some thoughts in an intelligent way."
Father Chisholm was one of the stars of that first group, the men recall. Tall and handsome, he came to the priesthood at age 42 after obtaining a doctorate in mechanical engineering from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, working as an engineer and studying philosophy and theology in London.
On Sunday those various strands came together in a homily that breathed passion and social analysis. Father Chisholm said the Harlem of his youth, the Harlem where professionals and blue-collar workers dwelled side by side and a spirit of collective purpose infused the air, was gone.
What has taken its place, he said, was economic decline, the intrusion of AIDS and crack and a feeling among some of his people that they wanted to distance themselves from "that mess."
"The whiter, more dominant culture will never let any African-American run away from their heritage and their legacy," he said. "Many of us will recognize that the 90's, the last 15 years, represent the worse time in our history."
The Archbishop's Leadership Project reflects some of the changes that make these times terrible ones, Father Chisholm said later. The young people who join these days tend to come from more troubled families and have less understanding of black history, he said. More profoundly, they fail to see themselves as part of a battle waged by their people not simply for economic viability but for human dignity and purpose.
"Those were angry times, but the focus in the group was on our helping, our doing something," Father Chisholm recalled. "We were trained to be self-assured, to be self-aware and to be generous."
So next weekend, between the beers and the back-slapping and the feeling of sustenance that comes from touching one's roots, the men and the women of the project hope to find ways to extend the ladder that they so proudly climbed.

HEADLINE: Muni Funds Provide Hideaway From Taxes

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
President Clinton's pledge to increase the top income tax rate from 31 to 36 percent (39.6 percent for the wealthiest) has many investors scrambling for shelter.
One good place to hide is a municipal bond fund, which invests in the bonds and notes of states and municipalities. The issues, used to finance public projects and services, are backed by the taxing power of issuers or by revenues from toll roads or other projects. 
 The accompanying chart lists the 10 top-performing national muni bond funds ranked by three-year returns, the 9 best muni funds investing in New York and the 10 best for California. The chart excludes funds with annual expenses of more than three-quarters of 1 percent, the average for the group. It also eliminates the most volatile funds and adjusts returns for front-end sales charges.
The chief appeal of these funds, of course, is that their income is free from Federal income taxes (although taxes are owed on any capital gains). In the case of the New York and California funds, which invest in debt issued by those states, their municipalities or agencies, income is free from Federal, state and local taxes for state residents.
So while munis may yield less than taxable funds, investors keep more after taxes are paid.
A fund's "taxable equivalent yield" shows how much a taxable investment would have to pay to match the yield of a tax-free fund. To calculate, divide the actual yield by 1 minus your Federal tax rate expressed in decimals. For a taxpayer in the 28 percent bracket, the taxable equivalent yield for a muni bond fund yielding 4.83 percent -- the average for these funds in June -- is 6.71 percent (after subtracting .28 from 1, then dividing 4.83 by .72).
Also, interest on issues of specific states is free of state taxes for state residents. Funds note this amount on your end-of-year tax statement.
To figure the rough after-tax yield on the single-state funds, divide the fund's yield by one minus your combined Federal and state tax rates, expressed in decimals.
Some national and single-state muni funds own "private purpose" paper, issued by some municipalities to finance nonessential projects like student loans. Interest on private purpose paper is free from Federal income taxes but subject to the alternative minimum tax.
To compensate for the tax liability, private purpose paper normally pays slightly more than regular issues. People who do not expect to owe the alternative minimum tax, or A.M.T., can increase their yields by owning shares in funds that own more A.M.T. paper. Fund companies can provide this information.
While most people view muni funds as solid investments, they carry a serious risk. In general, bond fund prices fall when interest rates rise; the longer the term of the bond, the farther prices fall when rates rise. Most muni funds carry maturities of more than 20 years.
While the top-performing muni funds over time are those with longer maturities, the interim interest-rate risk may be too much for conservative investors. By shortening maturities, investors reduce risk. If interest rates rise 1 percent, an intermediate- term fund's share price should drop only 3 percent, compared with 7 percent for share prices of longer-term funds, said John Rekenthaler, editor of Morningstar Mutual Funds.
Of course what is gained in safety is lost in yield. The 59 muni funds sporting short to intermediate maturities yield about three-quarters of a percentage point less than their longer cousins.
Because of differences in the quality and maturity of bonds held by the funds, yields vary. So it pays to shop around. The average 12-month yield of the long-term New York funds tracked by Morningstar was 5.49 percent in June. But Putnam New York Tax-Exempt Opportunities yields 6.48 percent, while the laggard, the Warburg Pincus New York Municipal Bond Fund yields only 4.45 percent. The long-term California funds yielded an average of 5.53 percent, but Prudential California Municipal Income A yields 6.51 percent and Muir California Tax-Free Bond Fund yields 4.02 percent.
Because of the general erosion in some states' economies, investors in New York and Massachusetts in particular, should keep no more than 40 or 50 percent of their total tax-free portfolio in state bonds, said James F. Lynch, editor of the Lynch Municipal Bond Advisory, a newsletter published in New York. Even in better-managed states, he advised tying up no more than 75 percent of tax-free assets in-state.
One way to minimize risk is to buy funds that invest in insured bonds or regular munis that the fund insures itself. The 1983 default by the Washington Public Power Supply System was a harsh reminder that munis are not risk-free. Yet experts say that defaults on individual issues should not pose a problem for investors in funds, because they have diversified portfolios.
The price for the added security is negligible because the insurance premium is small. As a group, regular munis returned 10.1 percent for the year ended in June, compared with 10.3 percent for the 76 insured muni funds.

HEADLINE: Plotting a Course to a Secure Retirement

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
Saving for retirement has become a critical issue for Americans. Companies are slashing pension benefits; the Federal agency that guarantees corporate pensions, the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, is struggling, and the Social Security system faces the burden of an aging population.
Personal savings will almost certainly have to fill any gap between benefits and needs. But most Americans are in dismal shape. People 25 to 44 are saving at a rate that will provide them with only about a third of what they will need to maintain their current style of living when they retire, a recent study commissioned by Merrill Lynch & Company found. 
 Even the money squirreled away may be placed unwisely. Many investors are choosing conservative investments that will not provide adequately for their retirement. The returns on money stashed for 10 years or more in supposedly safe certificates of deposit or other fixed-rate accounts could be seriously eroded by inflation.
Then again, the stock market could be poised for a fall.
Where's an investor to turn? For guidance, five mutual fund experts were asked how they would invest $50,000 for retirement in 20 years or more. The experts generally adhered to the maxim that stock funds were best for long-term investments.
But several expressed concern about the stock market's lofty prices -- close to a record high -- and chose more conservative portfolios than they would have in years past. Sprinkled among the stock selections are balanced funds, which own stocks and bonds, and growth-and-income and equity-income funds, which own stocks whose high dividends can offset falling share prices.
"All my portfolios have a conservative stance," said Sheldon Jacobs, who edits The No-Load Fund Investor newsletter in Irvington, N.Y. To achieve that goal, he limited the number of aggressive growth and growth funds and opted for some growth-and-income funds.
Eric Kobren, the president of Insight Management, a Wellesley, Mass., investment firm specializing in Fidelity Investment funds and the editor of Fidelity Insight, an independent newsletter, said, "The market is pretty pricey on most fundamental measures, but having some stock market exposure pays off." Besides avoiding the most aggressive types of stock funds, he used bond funds as a buffer in his portfolio.
Despite high stock prices, fund experts recommend that most people move into stock funds as soon as possible. Over time, the market rises more than it falls. And investors will need that portfolio growth.
 The Merrill Lynch study on retirement planning found that the shortfall between retirement needs and savings was greatest among people at high income levels.
Married couples earning more than $100,000 had saved on average only 28 percent of the amount needed to maintain themselves comfortably. Married couples earning $20,000 to $40,000 had saved 49 percent.
How much is enough? People covered by pension plans should accumulate two and a half to six times their annual pre-retirement earnings, said B. Douglas Bernheim, a professor of economics and business policy at Princeton University, who conducted the study. People who do not have pension coverage should aim for four to eight times their peak annual earnings before retirement, he said.
Savers shifting retirement money from C.D.'s and nonequity investments into funds may want to move slowly for psychological reasons, said Harold Evensky, of Evensky & Brown, an investment adviser in Coral Gables, Fla. A gradual shift will help minimize the loss should the market drop suddenly. He advises moving 20 to 30 percent into equities immediately and then dollar-cost averaging monthly over the next 60 months. Dollar-cost averaging means investing a fixed amount regularly; by doing so, you buy more shares when the share price is lower.
For people nearing retirement, several experts suggested modifications of their portfolios. The advice: shift money gradually out of stock funds into bond or money market funds. Start about 10 years before retirement, with a goal of reducing stocks to 60 percent of your portfolio by retirement. One rule of thumb is to subtract your age from 100 to derive a percentage for equities. A 65-year-old would keep 35 percent in stocks, 65 percent in bonds.
Our experts were asked to limit their portfolios to 10 selections and to mutual funds that are open to new investors. Their performance will be tracked periodically in this space, and they will have the opportunity, at quarterly intervals, to make changes.
Mr. Jacobs, who manages private money using no-load mutual funds in addition to editing the newsletter, chose the most funds, at nine, and stayed with an all-equity portfolio. "I believe this extra diversification will provide good growth with less risk than if I were to use fewer funds," he said. Of those, three invest overseas, "allowing me to target the area with the most potential," he said. He would lower the risk of the portfolio for investors nearing retirement by replacing American Heritage and Windsor II with T. Rowe Price Spectrum Income.
Mr. Evensky, who develops portfolios using public and institutional no-load funds, also dedicated his portfolio to stocks because "my primary concern is purchasing power." He struck a balance between large- and small-capitalization stocks, and funds that use various approaches to picking stocks. The SoGen fund is sold no-load through Charles Schwab & Company; otherwise, a 3.75 percent upfront load applies.
For people within 10 years of retiring, Mr. Evensky would reduce the equity portion to about 80 percent.
John Rekenthaler, editor of Morningstar Mutual Funds, Chicago, split his portfolio among five no-load stock funds and the Third Avenue Value, an unusual 5.75 percent load fund specializing in bankruptcies and corporate turnarounds. He would shift the Janus portion into Financial Industrial Income, a more conservative stock fund, within 10 years of retirement.
Jack A. Brill, an investment adviser in San Diego, specializes in socially responsible investing and was co-author of "Investing From the Heart" (Crown Publishers, 1993). To build a portfolio, he made choices from among the 20 or so "social responsibility" funds, which pick securities based on ethical or social criteria. To offset risk, he uses two balanced funds -- Pax World and Working Assets Citizens Balanced -- and an income fund, Working Assets Citizens Income. He would modify this mix for people nearing retirement by reducing the growth funds to 15 percent each, eliminating Progressive Environmental and Pax World, adding Vanguard GNMA (20 percent), Calvert Social Managed Growth (20 percent) and increasing Working Assets Balanced (20 percent).
Mr. Kobren, the Fidelity specialist, constructed an all-Fidelity portfolio with the idea of "being in areas of the market that won't be hurt as much if we hit some bumps." Thus he selected Fidelity Value, a stock fund that owns economically sensitive companies. He balanced that fund's large capitalization bias with a new, quantitatively managed small stock fund, sold with a 3 percent sales load. He reduced risk further by splitting 30 percent of the portfolio between two bond funds. He said he would make no changes for investors within 10 years of retiring.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Same Game, But With New Players

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN

 BODY:
AS major league baseball prepares to celebrate All-Star week, the nation's pastime continues to be haunted by the legacy of segregation, which it formally brought to an end in 1946 with the signing of Jackie Robinson.
This morning, the Baltimore Orioles will hold a breakfast for 25 veterans of the Negro Leagues. Later this afternoon, before a game with Chicago, the Orioles will honor the men who competed in a league that flourished because of segregation, then eventually folded because of integration. 
 On Tuesday, 500 demonstrators are expected to picket Baltimore's Camden Yards during the All-Star Game in a protest organized by the Rainbow Commission on Fairness in Athletics. The purpose of the protest is to call attention to baseball's sluggish minority hiring and its failure to establish ties with black-owned businesses.
Earlier this week, the Center for the Study of Sport in Society, in its annual report card, gave major league baseball a C for its minority hiring record, pointing to the lack of a single black general manager. The center gave pro football a B and for the fourth consecutive year the National Basketball Association received an A.
The report card was issued the same day the Mets announced the hiring of Joe McIlvaine for a second tour of duty with the team. Alexander and Associates, the consulting firm hired by major league baseball in 1987 to improve minority hiring, had advised the Mets to widen their search.
"We suggested to the Mets that they conduct a more adequate inclusionary search," said Clifford Alexander, president of the consulting firm. "They told us the process was too far along."
Alexander is in the unenviable position of having to defend a league that moves at a snail's pace of progress. And it's not just baseball.
The Center for the Study of Sport gave the N.B.A. an A. The Rainbow Commission, however, blasted the N.B.A. recently, releasing statistics showing that despite being 70 percent black on the court, the N.B.A. was woefully underrepresented by African-Americans in key decision-making positions.
"That grade is preposterous," said Charles Grantham, executive director of the N.B.A. Players Association. "You get an A when there is a black commissioner. There is not a black deputy commissioner, no team president who is black, no black team physicians or black comptrollers. You don't get A for effort. Where does the A come from? This is a classic case of grade inflation."
The push for equality in sports has gone beyond fretting over issues that were silly to begin with: Can blacks play quarterback? Can they manage? Can they function in the front office? In fact, numbers are no longer the primary ammunition in the battle for empowerment. The new impetus is forcing professional franchises -- by threat of pickets, boycotts and lawsuits -- to deal with minority-owned enterprises.
There are new players as well. And those conspicuous by their absence are the players -- the athletes -- themselves.
Last week in Baltimore, the Rev. Ben Chavis, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, concluded an unprecedented "fair-share agreement" with a business group in Charlotte being considered for a National Football League expansion franchise. Jerry Richardson, the president and chief executive officer of Flagstar Companies Inc., pledged that if his group is successful in bringing a franchise to Charlotte, N.C., his group will hire 15 to 20 percent minorities in management, spend from 5 to 10 percent of his advertising budget with minority firms and make 10 to 20 percent of purchases through minority vendors.
On Thursday, the Orioles signed an agreement with the African-American Task Force of Professional Sports in Maryland, saying the team would allocate 37 percent of its advertising budget to media outlets with predominantly black readerships and agreeing to deposit $100,000 in a black-owned bank in Baltimore.
In the past, sport franchises rarely worried about having their feet put to the fire. Athletes were too fearful of retribution, and political leaders and community activists in the black community, with other more pressing issues, largely ignored sports.
All of that is changing now. A new group of players are coming to sit at the table -- wise, old veterans of the civil rights movement. They may not be able to shoot jump shots or run off tackle. But they know how to use the courts and mobilize mass support to force change.
The hammer seems to be falling.

HEADLINE: Beethoven's 9 Symphonies in Y Season

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN

 BODY:
The complete Beethoven symphony cycle, played by the New York Chamber Symphony with Gerard Schwarz conducting, is the centerpiece of the 1993-94 music schedule at the Tisch Center for the Arts at the 92d Street Y. Also notable among the center's plans are a traversal of Shostakovich's 24 Preludes and Fugues by the Russian pianist Tatyana Nikolayeva, a Bach series by the pianist Vladimir Feltsman and a three-concert overview of the guitar repertory by John Williams.
After two seasons in which economic pressures led the center to trim its offerings, the Y has reconsidered its balance of orchestral programs, recitals and chamber music. In the new mix, two orchestral performances that were dropped last year have been restored. 
 But the budget for next season is about the same as this year's, roughly $3.5 million.
The Beethoven cycle begins on Oct. 2 with the Fifth Symphony, on a program that also includes a new version of Mendelssohn's "Midsummer Night's Dream" incidental music, with Christopher Plummer narrating his own new text for the work. The only Beethoven concert that will not be performed at the 92d Street Y is the program that brings together the First and Ninth Symphonies; it will take place on Jan. 30 at Carnegie Hall.
 
A Conductor Bows Out
 The New York Chamber Symphony is also continuing its four-concert Baroque music series, which opens with a performance of Handel's "Judas Maccabeus" on Nov. 27 and includes Nadia Salerno-Sonnenberg's debut as a conductor on April 30. Other guest conductors are Dmitry Sitkovetsky and Helmuth Rilling.
Mr. Schwarz is to conduct all seven concerts in the orchestra's main series, including one that was to have been led by Paul Sacher, who is listed in the season's prospectus. The 87-year-old Swiss conductor was advised by his doctors to withdraw from the engagement.
In addition to the Beethoven symphonies, the programs include the premieres of works by David Diamond, the center's resident composer, and Aaron Jay Kernis. Mr. Diamond has also composed a Guitar Quintet for the Y's chamber music series. The Cleveland Quartet and the guitarist Sharon Isbin are to give the work its premiere on Oct. 26. The other concerts in the series feature the center's resident ensemble, the Kalichstein-Laredo-Robinson Trio, with the pianist Leon Fleisher, the bassist Julius Levine and the tenor Paul Groves among their collaborators.
 
A Series of Cycles
 The center has dropped its long-running Distinguished Artists series in favor of two- and three-concert cycles by ensembles and soloists. The Emerson String Quartet, for example, is examining the late quartets of Shostakovich and Beethoven on Oct. 23, Jan. 22 and Feb. 26. Miss Nikolayeva is making her New York debut playing the Shostakovich Preludes and Fugues on Oct. 30 and Nov. 3.
Mr. Feltsman is playing Bach's "Goldberg" Variations on Dec. 19; the "Well-Tempered Clavier," Book I, on Jan. 16, and a program that includes the first two Partitas, the Chromatic Fantasy and Fugue and the Italian Concerto on Feb. 20. And Mr. Williams is presenting a program of Baroque transcriptions on March 10, contemporary works on March 15 and Spanish and Latin works on March 19.
Also on the schedule is a series of performances by young musicians, including Maxim Vengerov, a violinist, and Andreas Haefliger and Christopher O'Riley, pianists. Young Concert Artists will present four programs at the center, and the pianist Jeffrey Siegel will present four of his Keyboard Conversation programs. In addition to classical music, the center is offering a jazz series July 20 to 22 and four cabaret concerts in the fall and winter.

HEADLINE: Muni Funds Provide Hideaway From Taxes

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
President Clinton's pledge to increase the top income tax rate from 31 to 36 percent (39.6 percent for the wealthiest) has many investors scrambling for shelter.
One good place to hide is a municipal bond fund, which invests in the bonds and notes of states and municipalities. The issues, used to finance public projects and services, are backed by the taxing power of issuers or by revenues from toll roads or other projects. 
 The accompanying chart lists the 10 top-performing national muni bond funds ranked by three-year returns, the 9 best muni funds investing in New York and the 10 best for California. The chart excludes funds with annual expenses of more than three-quarters of 1 percent, the average for the group. It also eliminates the most volatile funds and adjusts returns for front-end sales charges.
The chief appeal of these funds, of course, is that their income is free from Federal income taxes (although taxes are owed on any capital gains). In the case of the New York and California funds, which invest in debt issued by those states, their municipalities or agencies, income is free from Federal, state and local taxes for state residents.
So while munis may yield less than taxable funds, investors keep more after taxes are paid.
A fund's "taxable equivalent yield" shows how much a taxable investment would have to pay to match the yield of a tax-free fund. To calculate, divide the actual yield by 1 minus your Federal tax rate expressed in decimals. For a taxpayer in the 28 percent bracket, the taxable equivalent yield for a muni bond fund yielding 4.83 percent -- the average for these funds in June -- is 6.71 percent (after subtracting .28 from 1, then dividing 4.83 by .72).
Also, interest on issues of specific states is free of state taxes for state residents. Funds note this amount on your end-of-year tax statement.
To figure the rough after-tax yield on the single-state funds, divide the fund's yield by one minus your combined Federal and state tax rates, expressed in decimals.
Some national and single-state muni funds own "private purpose" paper, issued by some municipalities to finance nonessential projects like student loans. Interest on private purpose paper is free from Federal income taxes but subject to the alternative minimum tax.
To compensate for the tax liability, private purpose paper normally pays slightly more than regular issues. People who do not expect to owe the alternative minimum tax, or A.M.T., can increase their yields by owning shares in funds that own more A.M.T. paper. Fund companies can provide this information.
While most people view muni funds as solid investments, they carry a serious risk. In general, bond fund prices fall when interest rates rise; the longer the term of the bond, the farther prices fall when rates rise. Most muni funds carry maturities of more than 20 years.
While the top-performing muni funds over time are those with longer maturities, the interim interest-rate risk may be too much for conservative investors. By shortening maturities, investors reduce risk. If interest rates rise 1 percent, an intermediate- term fund's share price should drop only 3 percent, compared with 7 percent for share prices of longer-term funds, said John Rekenthaler, editor of Morningstar Mutual Funds.
Of course what is gained in safety is lost in yield. The 59 muni funds sporting short to intermediate maturities yield about three-quarters of a percentage point less than their longer cousins.
Because of differences in the quality and maturity of bonds held by the funds, yields vary. So it pays to shop around. The average 12-month yield of the long-term New York funds tracked by Morningstar was 5.49 percent in June. But Putnam New York Tax-Exempt Opportunities yields 6.48 percent, while the laggard, the Warburg Pincus New York Municipal Bond Fund yields only 4.45 percent. The long-term California funds yielded an average of 5.53 percent, but Prudential California Municipal Income A yields 6.51 percent and Muir California Tax-Free Bond Fund yields 4.02 percent.
Because of the general erosion in some states' economies, investors in New York and Massachusetts in particular, should keep no more than 40 or 50 percent of their total tax-free portfolio in state bonds, said James F. Lynch, editor of the Lynch Municipal Bond Advisory, a newsletter published in New York. Even in better-managed states, he advised tying up no more than 75 percent of tax-free assets in-state.
One way to minimize risk is to buy funds that invest in insured bonds or regular munis that the fund insures itself. The 1983 default by the Washington Public Power Supply System was a harsh reminder that munis are not risk-free. Yet experts say that defaults on individual issues should not pose a problem for investors in funds, because they have diversified portfolios.
The price for the added security is negligible because the insurance premium is small. As a group, regular munis returned 10.1 percent for the year ended in June, compared with 10.3 percent for the 76 insured muni funds.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 16, 1993, Friday

 CORRECTION:
Tables in the "Your Money" pages on Saturday about the performance of mutual funds misstated the returns for two funds because of calculation errors by Morningstar Inc., which supplied the data. The Scudder California Tax-Free Fund had a return of 3.6 percent in the second quarter and 13.9 percent for the 12 months ended June 30. Its average annual return was 10.8 percent over the last five years. The Scudder New York Tax-Free Fund had a second-quarter return of 3.8 percent and a 12-month return of 13.4 percent. Its five-year average return was 10.5 percent. As a result, neither fund should have appeared on the list of poorest-performing municipal bond funds.

And Bear in Mind
 
(Editor's choices of other recent books of particular interest.)
 
ANGELS & INSECTS: Two Novellas, by A. S. Byatt. (Random House, $21.) Two long novellas, and very clever ones, in which insect life is an analogue of Victorian society and literary immortality is compared to the real thing.
CRUELTY AND SILENCE: War, Tyranny, Uprising, and the Arab World, by Kanan Makiya. (Norton, $22.95.) The cruelty is that of the Saddam Hussein regime in the author's native Iraq; the silence, that of the Arab intellectuals who condone or assist it.
DEAD MAN WALKING: An Eyewitness Account of the Death Penalty in the United States, by Helen Prejean. (Random House, $21.) Governments should stop killing people, says a nun who has often seen death row up close.
DRUMS ALONG THE CONGO: On the Trail of Mokele-Mbembe, the Last Living Dinosaur, by Rory Nugent. (Houghton Mifflin, cloth, $21.95; paper, $10.95.) And was it found? Well, something was, and the trip was loads of fun.
KING LEOPOLD'S DREAM: Travels in the Shadow of the African Elephant, by Jeremy Gavron. (Pantheon, $23.) An Englishman's boundlessly energetic quest finds elephants distinctly less endangered, in some places, than they used to be.
LENIN'S TOMB: The Last Days of the Soviet Empire, by David Remnick. (Random House, $25.) Decline and fall, observed by a Washington Post reporter in the Soviet Union, 1988-91.
THE NIGHT MANAGER, by John le Carre. (Knopf, $24.) Mr. le Carre's solution to the disappearance of the Soviet Union is to create an arms dealer-cum-drug lord as smart as the Devil.
PACK MY BAG: A Self-Portrait, by Henry Green. (New Directions, $18.95.) All of his early life the enigmatic novelist (1905-73) chose to reveal; published in Britain in 1940.
THE PUGILIST AT REST: Stories, by Thom Jones. (Little, Brown, $18.95.) A collection of short stories that portray prizefighters and war heroes surviving, but just barely.
SAVE ME, JOE LOUIS, by Madison Smartt Bell. (Harcourt Brace, $23.95.) The grifters and drifters in this novel think they're pretty good guys, but their actions suggest otherwise.
SPY TRADER: Germany's Devil's Advocate and the Darkest Secrets of the Cold War, by Craig R. Whitney. (Times Books/Random House, $25.) The story of a middleman in the exchange of political prisoners during the cold war.
TINTIN IN THE NEW WORLD: A Romance, by Frederic Tuten. (Morrow, $22.) An American novelist introduces a French comic strip hero to the temptations of the real world.
TSVETAEVA, by Viktoria Schweitzer. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $35.) The life and apocalyptic times (1892-1941) of a great Russian poet, a woman no revolution could contain.
UNITED STATES: Essays 1952-1992, by Gore Vidal. (Random House, $37.50.) In 40 years of essays and articles, the author expounds on sex, politics, literature, himself and other phenomena.

HEADLINE: Protectionism Is Our Most Important Product

BYLINE: By Sylvia Nasar; Sylvia Nasar reports on the economy for The New York Times.

 BODY:

THE MYTH OF FREE TRADE
A Plan for America's Economic Revival.
By Ravi Batra.
274 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $23. 
 WHEN a prophecy fails, propose a little something to make it come true. That seems to have been the spirit animating Ravi Batra as he cranked out his latest wacky wake-up call to America, "The Myth of Free Trade."
Mr. Batra's most recent books -- "The Great Depression of 1990" and its sequel, "Surviving the Great Depression of 1990" -- made him one of the best-selling economists of all time. But, as everyone now knows, the "worst economic crisis in history" never happened. So now the Southern Methodist University professor turned prophet has decided that the United States is well on the way to becoming the basket case of the Western world. The villain this time isn't "the unprecedented concentration of wealth," his bugbear in "The Great Depression of 1990," but the nation's foolish fling with free trade.
His nutty solution: to stop Americans from importing so many Armanis and Toyotas, and American companies from sending their products abroad, erect a 19th-century-style tariff wall around the United States by, among other things, raising existing import levies fivefold.
Hmmm, haven't we tried that before? The Smoot-Hawley Act of 1930 sparked a trade war that helped turn a spreading financial crisis into a full-blown world depression. Instead of merely beggaring our neighbors, which we certainly succeeded in doing, we ended up suffering horribly as well, and there's no reason to think Smoot-Hawley II wouldn't have a similar effect.
Indeed, Mr. Batra himself was saying so a mere book or so ago. "The world is much more interdependent today than in the past," he wrote in "The Great Depression of 1990," "hence, protectionist pressures should be resisted at all costs. If not, the worldwide depression will be much deeper than otherwise." But then, as the professor puts it in "The Myth of Free Trade," "Old ideas become obsolete, creating the need for new thought."
It's not just the notion that the United States should replace the former Soviet Union as the world's biggest autarky that's loony. It's the whole book.
Take the claim that 80 percent of Americans have seen living standards plunge since 1973. It's absurd in light of the fact that consumer spending is half again as high today as in the early 1970's. Besides, though the growth of productivity and living standards slowed in the United States in the 1970's and 1980's, it slowed even more sharply in Europe and Japan.
Or take the assertion that 1973 was a watershed year, in which the United States plunged down the slippery slope of free trade. Lots of things, many unpleasant, like the quadrupling of oil prices, happened in 1973. Just about the only thing that did not happen was a shift in American trade policy. The Nixon Administration did not suddenly sweep away tariffs, quotas and other trade barriers.
True, Americans are importing and exporting more now than they were then, but that trend -- properly measured, as Mr. Batra does not measure it -- got under way around 1960, long before his magical year of 1973, and is anyway the product of millions of private decisions, not Government trade policy.
You'll start to feel positively disoriented by the time you get to Mr. Batra's novel take on our nation's economic history. America's rise to the world's pre-eminent economic power in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, in his view, owes almost nothing to technology, enlightened commercial policy, immigration or natural resources, but everything to protectionism. If that were true, deadbeat nations like Argentina and Burma, with their long histories of high trade barriers, not industrial powerhouses like Korea and Germany, would have much to celebrate.
The author, whose real talent lies not in analyzing the American economy but in tapping into Americans' angst about their economic well-being, says he has no choice but to unburden himself in print: "It is a tremendous burden and responsibility to have information and foresight that you know could shape the destiny of nations. How can you then remain silent?"
Too bad he and the folks at Scribners couldn't figure out a way.

LENGTH: 2796 words

HEADLINE: The Spectacular Boom In Andrea Electronics

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris; Floyd Norris is a financial columnist for The New York Times.

 BODY:
The economist John Maynard Keynes once wrote that the stock market is like a 1930's newspaper contest, in which readers were asked to select the 6 prettiest women from pictures of 100 candidates. The winning entry was the one that most closely matched the overall "favorites."
To win, Keynes noted, you didn't choose the women you deemed the best-looking, or even those you thought the public believed to be the prettiest. Instead, he said, you chose the women the public thought the public believed to be the prettiest. 
 It was that way with stocks, Keynes went on. The winning investor chooses stocks the public is likely to conclude will go up because other investors will buy them. Such stocks may or may not offer real value. What they must have is that appealing something.
Andrea Electronics Corporation has that something: a device to filter out street noise from pay-telephone calls.
On the face of it, a noise-reduction device doesn't sound like much. And Andrea is unfamiliar to most telephone companies. Until this year, it was one of the sleepier defense contractors, a company that hadn't made much of an impact even though it had been around for nearly 60 years. But there are about two million pay telephones in the United States alone, and phone companies are working to get computers to identify voices -- which means extraneous noise needs to be blocked out. Buyers of Andrea stock are therefore betting that phone companies will be showering purchase orders on this tiny, family-controlled New York company based in Long Island City, Queens -- that Andrea will be another example of a new technology's propelling a small company to superstardom.
So hot has Andrea stock become in recent months that an investment of about $700 last November was worth more than $25,000 in June. For the time being, wildly hopeful investors are in control, reinforcing the Keynesian principle that investors can rush into a stock for no better reason than believing other investors will follow. Andrea's rise also illustrates the gravity-defying way in which a stock can become a big winner long before the underlying business succeeds. And it shows how public investors can be left without an easy way to establish the value of a company's stock, despite rules requiring disclosure of material facts to shareholders.
FEW COMPANIES HAVE SEEN A STOCK RUN LIKE ANDREA'S. Last November, with the stock trading at about $7 a share -- or a bit less than in 1960 -- Andrea announced it had demonstrated a device at a convention of pay-telephone operators that could suppress street noise in pay telephones, making it easier for people calling from busy intersections to be heard. The company said it hoped to make sales to "several major telecommunications companies," but didn't name any.
When a company is small, with few outstanding shares, a little buying will push the stock price up, and that movement can attract other investors. Late last year, although Andrea was unknown to all but a select few, any investor looking for unusual activity in a stock could, by tapping into a computer, see the relatively busy trading in Andrea and call up the company's press release announcing the demonstration of the noise-suppression device.
Some of the curious bought the stock, and within a couple of weeks it was trading at $36 a share. Far more amazing was the volume. With only 508,000 shares outstanding, more than half controlled by the Andrea family, the American Stock Exchange reported a volume of 333,000 shares on Nov. 20. The shares available for public trading were being (Continued on page 51)
exchanged at a feverish rate, one that Jules L. Winters, the chief operating officer of the Amex, calls unprecedented. (In 1991, total Andrea volume for the entire year was less than one million shares.)
Things calmed down for a while, but the activity intensified this spring in anticipation of Andrea's annual meeting on May 20, when the company was to show off the device: a computer chip to be inserted in each pay telephone. On the eve of the meeting the shares soared to $93, prompting the Amex to step in and change the rules. No longer could anyone buy the shares on margin -- that is, on borrowed money.
Such a move, which is seldom made, is designed to curb speculation and warn investors of dangerously inflated prices. In Andrea's case, the move brought the stock to the attention of even more investors. The price did slide for a few days, but after dipping to $59 it began another surge. On May 27, the company split the shares five-for-one, which in normal times would cause the price of a single share to decline to one-fifth of its former level. But these are not normal times, and Andrea stock has continued to soar. By early June, the post-split shares were trading at $53 each -- the equivalent of $265 for each old share.
WHY THE FRENZY? Part of the answer lies in the Wall Street dream of finding another Haloid. In the late 1950's, that tiny company had a then questionable technology to photocopy documents. Haloid became Xerox, and early investors in the company realized phenomenal profits. Since then, more money has probably been lost looking for other Haloids than was made on the original one, but hope springs eternal, as any gambler knows.
Andrea's technology cannot be said to be a sure thing; it has yet to announce its first sale to a telephone company. Bellcore, the research arm of the regional Bell companies, has looked at the product, but won't say what it has found, and calls to several Bell companies have shown scant interest in Andrea's device. GTE Corporation, the largest non-Bell operator of pay telephones, says it has not heard from Andrea and is happy with other available products.
Many investors, however, seem to have paid little attention to any of this. To buy the stock at the high prices it has commanded and expect to make money in the long term, one would have to assume a succession of very successful products. Some in the industry, however, say Andrea's system is not compatible with most pay phones. They also say there are other ways to solve the problem of extraneous noise.
"They have some advanced circuitry that reduces the noise level," says David M. Lubensky, a scientist with the Advanced Speech Systems Group of Nynex, the parent company of New York Telephone. "It's a solution. I don't think it is the only solution. There are others that are just as satisfactory."
Noise suppression is highly important, Lubensky says. Phone companies are working on computer technology not only to identify voices but also to recognize whether the speaker is using English or Japanese or any of the dozens of other spoken languages. Much of the work is being done on ways to suppress extraneous noise at the central office rather than at every telephone.
Although phones are designed so that users don't notice it, someone speaking on the phone hears his own voice through the earpiece as well as the voice of the person at the other end of the line. Extraneous noise, like a passing fire engine, is heard both through the ear away from the phone and through the ear pressed to the receiver. At GTE, Terry Fisher, who is a manager of pay-phone operations, says his company has installed some pay telephones with volume controls, enabling a caller to turn up the volume. These pay phones also have circuitry to suppress some extraneous noise, whether from nearby conversations or from passing traffic.
The GTE phones use equipment made by Communications Development Services Corporation, a privately held company based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Weaver Jordan, the company's president, says he talked to Andrea about its technology but concluded its product might be too expensive and could require not only new pay telephones but even redesigned telephone booths. He says Andrea has had problems fitting all the needed circuitry into a pay-telephone box without getting interference from equipment used for tasks like confirming that the caller has deposited coins.
And what do Andrea officials have to say about such criticism? Nothing. Ever since the stock began to soar, they have declined to talk to reporters. Winters, the Amex official, praises the company for not issuing press releases to promote the stock. But the company's lack of public communications has not made it any easier for investors to evaluate a fair price for the stock.
SO FAR, THERE HAVE BEEN NO reports of heavy selling by the company's officials, usually a signal to (Continued on page 56)
observant investors that jumping ship is probably in order. (Federal rules allow disclosures of trading by corporate officials to be delayed for as many as 40 days, but because penalties for late filing are so mild many executives flout those rules.) If the people at Andrea have reservations about the company's future, there are no signs.
Unlike many companies that become overnight stock sensations, Andrea has been around for a while. It began as Andrea Radio in 1934, became a public company in 1960 and has always been controlled by the Andrea family. Frank A. D. Andrea Jr., now 66, is the chairman. He took over the company from his father in 1965, and kept control until last year, when he surrendered the operational responsibility to his sons -- John, 35, and Douglas, 30 -- who are now co-presidents. At the end of 1992, the company had 75 employees, including an engineering staff of 8.
For years, Andrea went mostly nowhere, and the end of the cold war made its future bleaker by depressing military demand for communications apparatus. It stopped earning money in 1989 and stopped paying dividends to shareholders in 1990. In 1991, it lost $490,000 on sales of $2.4 million. Outsiders saw no reason to expect a turnaround. Not that there were many outsiders paying attention.
Nonetheless, a harbinger appeared in the 1991 annual report. In it, Frank Andrea wrote that "new product development is the foundation for future solid growth" and that the company had hired engineers -- experts in "digital signal processing" -- whom he hoped to use to develop new products.
The noise-suppression device is the first such product.
Company officials showed how much potential they saw in that technology. Andrea had gone for many years without issuing stock options to its executives. But on Dec. 31, 1991, its board approved a plan to issue them for up to 200,000 shares, almost 40 percent of the shares outstanding. If the new technology worked, or if Wall Street concluded it did, the holders of those options would reap huge profits. Of course, if the technology failed, they would not have invested a cent.
Andrea has so far reported issuing options for 184,000 shares, or, after the five-for-one split, 920,000 shares. The largest holder is Frank Andrea, the chairman, who has the right to buy 250,000 shares of post-split stock for $313,700. In early June, the market value of those shares was $13.4 million.
Issuing so many options usually dilutes the stake of public shareholders, who controlled 48 percent of the company before the options program began, with the Andrea family controlling the rest. If all the options are exercised, as they will be if the stock price does not collapse, the family and the executives who received the options will have a 65 percent stake in the company, while the public stake will be down to 35 percent.
THE LEAPS AND bounds in the value of Andrea stock have cost some speculators -- the "shorts" -- big money. In fact, "shorts" probably helped push up the stock price.
The legal way to gamble on the probability that a stock price will fall is to borrow shares from someone who owns them and then sell them -- a short sale. Say Stock X is worth $10 today and you believe the price will drop. You borrow 100 shares from a brokerage house and sell them at $10 per share. The brokerage house puts $1,000 into your account, a sum you may not be able to touch until you've made good on your loan. Say the value of Stock X then drops to $5. You buy 100 shares to return to the brokerage house. Your profit: $500 less commissions.
But if the reverse happens, you lose your bet. To make good on shares you've borrowed and to cut your losses, you buy shares before the price goes any higher. Such purchases may drive the price even higher.
In early May, about 10 percent of the publicly held shares of Andrea had been sold short. That was an unusually large proportion, but it was twice as high in early June, just as the price soared. Some speculators leaped in to buy, hoping the short sellers would be forced to pay even higher prices.
Some traders believe there has also been "naked" shorting, or selling a stock without borrowing it, usually because there are no shares available to borrow. Naked shorting is illegal (brokers can do it only under some circumstances), but it is a way for a trader who thinks a stock is flagrantly overvalued to bet the price will fall.
A naked short cannot deliver the stock when the trade is supposed to be settled, usually a week after it is made. If the price has fallen in the meantime, then all is well, and he can quickly buy the stock for a profit. But if the price has soared, the naked short can lose a lot of money very quickly.
Andrea's rapid rise has also prompted talk of "corners," whereby a group of investors buys the available shares. If the stock price soars, the unfortunates who shorted the shares are at the mercy of those who've cornered the stock. When a corner is in place, the price of a stock can rise rapidly and beyond all reason.
Corners are illegal, and in the Andrea case, no evidence has yet been made public that a corner was or is under way. Winters, the Amex official, says the exchange has monitored the trading in Andrea and does not find the buying concentrated among customers of one company or even a small group of companies, as would be expected in a corner. (The Securities and Exchange Commission, which has looked into the Andrea trading, will not say what it has found.)
ANDREA'S SHARE PRICE has not shot straight up. Even on its best days there have been the wild swings that characterize an inefficient market populated by traders with little idea of the stock's real value. Probably the wildest day was Monday, June 7. The previous Friday, an Andrea official, in a rare public comment, had told the Bloomberg Business News service the company was "right on track" to introduce the product before the end of the third quarter. He noted that there are two million pay phones in the United States and another three million outside the country.
That helped push up the stock, and the American Stock Exchange halted trading before the close Friday, citing an imbalance of buy orders. The last trade of the day was at $37.50 per share. On Monday, there was no trading for the first two hours as an Amex specialist -- the broker responsible for maintaining an orderly market -- tried to match orders. Specialists are expected to do limited trading from their own holdings in stocks to balance the inflow of public buy and sell orders. Finally, the stock opened at $51. Within minutes, it fell to $38.50, then bounced back to $50, only to slump and rebound again. It closed the day at $53.75, having more than doubled in just two days. The vast majority of the trades were of a few hundred shares at most, the hallmark of individual investors. Institutions -- pension funds, insurance companies and mutual funds -- have largely stayed clear.
"The activity was extremely orderly," says Winters. By that he means the price did not move by more than a dollar on any one trade, and usually by much smaller amounts. He praises the specialist for doing a good job of maintaining an orderly market.
The total volume of June 4 and June 7 was 1.4 million shares. The number of post-split shares not owned by the Andrea family was 1.2 million. At the $53.75 price reached on June 7, the company's market value was $186 million, counting the shares available to be issued for the management options. From the perspective of last year's balance sheet -- a loss of $691,000 on sales of $3.4 million -- such a valuation is absurd. But if you assume that the device is installed in every one of the two million pay phones and that better devices will follow, then perhaps you could come up with estimates that begin to make the stock price seem reasonable.
Keynes knew it can be more important to figure out what will entrance the public than to ascertain real long-term value. But even he might have been astounded by the fevered clamoring for Andrea stock, whose valuation is based on little more than expectations of success for a product that has yet to find a single buyer.
