HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Divining the Market's Next Big Turn

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
WITH the Dow Jones industrial average bouncing over, then under, 3,500 for the last several weeks, investors may well puzzle over its next big move -- and theirs. Should they avoid a market some call overheated? Or put more money into equities to catch the next big jump others say is ahead?
For guidance, The New York Times turned to eight top-flight mutual fund managers who have run their funds for at least a decade -- in two cases, for nearly a quarter of a century. As a group, they range mostly from neutral to bullish, with just two bears among them, both of whom are bargain hunting among unloved stocks. Here's what the eight had to say: 
 * "We've got an expensive stock market but a good economic outlook, so I think the stock market is fairly priced today," said G. Kenneth Heebner, manager of CGM Capital Development, top performer among 135 growth funds for the decade ended May 31 (up 19.6 percent, according to Morningstar Inc., fund researchers in Chicago; all gains mentioned are annualized averages).
He cites ample manufacturing capacity, a largely recovered banking system and rising industrial productivity. "Admittedly, the strength is in the industrial sector, not the consumer sector. But that's healthy -- we're investing in plant and equipment," he said.
His current strategy: cyclical plays in automobiles, airlines and steel. His biggest holding: Chrysler.
* Shelby M. C. Davis has run the New York Venture Fund for 24 years, winning third place in growth funds for the decade (up 16.8 percent), behind CGM and Fidelity Magellan. He recently also began managing Selected American Shares, a no-load growth-and-income fund. Both funds are fully invested.
"The market crossed 3,000 three years ago, so we're spending a lot of time between 3,000 and 3,500," he said. "We're in a trading range, but there's probably an upside move left when the cyclical stocks have their run and perhaps even the old leaders -- drug companies -- will have another turn." The funds are aiming to profit from "baby boom savings trends," he said, by investing in financial services companies.
* George Vanderheiden, who runs Fidelity Destiny I (up 16.7 percent), says he is "agnostic about the stock market" because the fund must be fully invested by policy. Success comes from moving among the sectors, he said. Autos, energy and industrials have shone. His strategy is unearthing sectors with rising pricing power. Autos are the biggest play; Chrysler is the fund's second-largest holding, after Fannie Mae (the Federal National Mortgage Association). He avoids drugs, tobacco and consumer goods.
* "Call me a 'picky bull,' " said Michael Price, manager of Mutual Qualified, the best-performing growth-and-income fund of the decade (up 15.8 percent). "The Dow is real high, the bond market is real high, and I worry that when the bond market is hit, the equity market will follow." But he specializes in special situations -- "Every day I come in, there's more disasters to pick from," he said -- stocks down because of "worries about the health-care proposals, or the economy, or because they're in California, or the wrong industry, or the wrong sector." He likes Catellus, a large California real estate company, and the Dime Savings Bank.
* A meaner bear is John Neff, manager of the Vanguard Windsor Fund (up 15.4 percent), who has put 20 percent of the fund into cash because he predicts a correction of about 10 to 15 percent. Given that the Standard and Poor's 500 stocks are selling for more than 17 times earnings and yielding less than 3 percent, he said, "we're looking forward to either a great spurt in earnings to justify that valuation -- but I don't think so, because the economy is slow -- or a correction." Looking to buy into weakness, he has been purchasing in particularly hard-hit sectors, especially in food, tobacco and health care. His favorite sector is aluminum.
* Veering up to neutral is Russell E. Thompson, manager of United Income, the decade's top-performing equity-income fund (up 16.2 percent). "The economy is weak," he says, "because there's so much uncertainty in government and no driver for economic growth." Even so, cash accounts for only 5 percent to 7 percent of the portfolio based on his view that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates again, giving a lift to stocks.
* Another neutral-to-mildly bullish manager is Matthew A. Weatherbie, who runs Putnam Voyager A, which took third place among aggressive growth funds (up 14.5 percent) in the decade. "I see a continuation of moderate economic growth with low inflation," he said. While equity prices are high, he said, they are "supportable because of low interest rates." Voyager is roughly 94 percent invested in equities, its usual stance. Of that, 20 percent is in what Mr. Weatherbie calls "opportunity stocks: large companies undergoing positive changes." Two favorites: Primerica and Textron.
* Ralph Wanger, manager of the decade's top-performing small-company fund, the Acorn Fund (up 16.4 percent), for 23 years, views the current landscape with some amusement: "I'm used to small stocks getting wrecked -- it's fun to see the big ones get smashed for a change." He says small companies are priced reasonably today relative to larger ones, but he has gone outside the United States for values, primarily in Europe; Acorn is 22 percent invested abroad. But he's no good at market timing, he says, so "we'll stay fully invested and take whatever comes -- it's like being a Mets fan."

HEADLINE: Cigarettes Can Take A Substantial Tax

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "The Trouble With Punitive Smokers' Tax" (letter, July 2), Robert Tollison claims that a cigarette tax of 35 cents to 40 cents a pack will maximize tax revenues. He is responding to Michael Grossman, who argues in "For Best Revenue, Tax Cigarettes $1.26" (letter, June 18) that the Treasury would lose money if the Federal excise tax exceeded the figure that he prefers.
If Mr. Tollison's tax of 35 cents to 40 cents were revenue maximizing, then how come the Governor and Legislature in Massachusetts are now locked in combat as to how they spend the tens of millions of extra tax dollars that have been generated by that state's recent tax increase from 26 cents to 51 cents a pack? 
 If Mr. Grossman's $1.26 tax were revenue maximizing, then how come the Government of Canada collected billions of extra dollars when it raised provincial and federal taxes to more than $3 a pack (in United States dollars, that is), even in the face of cross-border cigarette smuggling?
Professors Tollison and Grossman both relied upon high-powered statistical studies of notoriously flawed data on state tax-paid cigarette sales. Both of them would be advised to stop citing their favorite econometric research and start looking at the evidence.
 
JEFFREY E. HARRIS
Boston, July 3, 1993

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1149 words

HEADLINE: Clinton Discovers That Even Japan Can Go For a Populist

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
PRESIDENT CLINTON and his Administration kept saying all week that this was a different kind of Group of Seven meeting. The lofty old talk of macroeconomic coordination and stable exchange rates was replaced by the mantras of the 90's: jobs and "structural reform," which means preparing governments, industries and workers geared to cold war prosperity for the new austerity.
"Some have called this a jobs summit," Mr. Clinton said. "And they are right, because the creation of new jobs in the United States and in all the other countries present here was at the center of all of our discussions." 
 But then, as if a ghost was rattling his chains louder the more he was ignored, came a reminder of the past. The final image from the summit was of President Clinton shaking hands with the smiling Japanese Prime Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa over yet another in a decade-long series of agreements to reduce Japan's persistently bloated trade surpluses. President Clinton described it as a new start, full of new ideas; knowing Japanese bureaucrats said it was merely a continuation of the old, incremental negotiation process. Both sides conceded that, as a mere framework for future bargaining, it may take years to produce results.
That tortured, last-minute trade deal underscored the ambiguous character of this "new" summit, as well as the surprisingly strong personal stamp that President Clinton left on it. He seemed to find change an even tougher sell abroad than it has been at home. But among the leaders of the seven wealthiest industrial nations, weary from economic malaise, his personal appeal, energy and ambition to create a sense of momentum permitted him to make the summit agenda his own.
Mr. Clinton played a critical role in shaping the agreements on a major tariff-reduction scheme to spur world trade, a $3 billion package to help Russia change into a capitalist society and a commitment to stimulate faster economic growth. Each is promising but will prove as hollow as the pronouncements from previous summits without the sort of immensely difficult follow-up work that has often eluded these countries.
Nonetheless, a President who had been depicted as too weak at home to lead abroad had stomped onto the world stage with some force.
 
No More Acid and Condescension
 Nowhere was that more evident than in President Clinton's dealings with the Japanese, who before last week had responded to his aggressive trade policy and eagerness for change with a mixture of acid and con descension. For months, senior Japanese officials had been depicting him as a dangerous neophyte because of his insistence on prying open Japanese markets by endorsing market share targets for foreign products and by strengthening the value of the yen against the dollar. Both were considered examples of excessive government interference in the markets.
Speaking of President Clinton and his Cabinet, Mr. Miyazawa had once commented, "It may be that they do not yet understand well the nature of government, since they have just recently come into office." And when Clinton Administration officials had begun talking up the value of the yen, a senior Bank of Japan official abandoned his customary reserve and asserted, "I don't think the top man is receiving sufficient briefings on this."
 
The Personal Touch
 The bash-Clinton campaign collapsed last week. First of all, the President and his wife, Hillary, were treated like personable celebrities, not simply with the awe that American Presidents traditionally command here. In a country where aged political leaders have been seen for years as cogs in a thoroughly corrupt political machine, the Clintons were admired for their youth, sense of purpose and easy manner in public.
In fact, the President clearly sought to capitalize on the disillusionment with the old political order in Japan. A week from today, Japan will hold perhaps its most important parliamentary elections in the postwar era, with most Japanese expecting the governing Liberal Democratic Party to lose its majority for the first time since it was formed in 1955.
One of the things the party still has going for it is the fear among Japanese of disorder. President Clinton sought to alleviate such concerns by stressing in public that political change could improve the lot of the average Japanese by bringing in politicians more inclined to help consumers than producers. Few Japanese missed the message when Mr. Clinton spent the better part of a reception early in the week chatting amiably and at length with several opposition party leaders.
That did not mean President Clinton's ideas were always embraced with the same enthusiasm as his image. "The lecture sounded like a pamphlet appealing for brightness, cleanliness and cheerfulness," said a student after the President spoke at Waseda University. "I could not get a feel for his own character." On the other hand, Mr. Clinton was still an object of fascination for the Japanese media; for them, his image mattered as much if not more than his character.
More important, President Clinton appeared to have moved, if only slightly, the most important constituency in policy-making here: the bureaucrats. His ideas on using measurable targets to open Japanese markets still appall the bureaucrats, who regard this as a heavy-handed attempt to manage Japan. But in light of the President's popularity and strong hand in moving the summit meeting forward, they were not able to dismiss him as a policy lightweight any longer.
"Television was always following Bill and Hillary, and people loved that," said Yukio Okamoto, a business consultant and former official who negotiated several trade deals with the United States. "I think the bureaucracy was moved less than the Japanese people. But they now have a begrudging respect for the President."
Compromise, of course, played as much of a role in President Clinton's successes here as charisma, and that is why, ultimately, it may take a year or more to determine whether the Tokyo meeting produced a change in substance or just in image.
President Clinton, for instance, had sought a $4 billion fund to assist Russia, about half of which was to include cash for grants; he got a $3 billion fund with just $500 million in cash, most of it shuffled from one Russian aid program to this new one. The critical issue now is whether the Group of Seven nations can spend the money effectively and help state-owned Russian companies acquire private owners who know how to run them.
Equally, the question a year from now may be whether the industrial economies, given a blueprint this past week for lifting themselves out of their economic rut, are up to the job of making the changes, or whether that will be too ambitious a goal for these once-a-year gatherings, even when a celebrity President pushes his optimistic agenda.

HEADLINE: The Sheik Will Be Staying Put, for Now

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES

DATELINE: CAIRO

 BODY:
A LITTLE more than a week ago, American officials abruptly informed Egypt that Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman could leave the United States for any country that would accept him unless the Egyptians quickly presented an extradition request, which they reluctantly did. That was the bad news. The good news came a few days later, when the Government here learned that the sheik might spend years locked up as an illegal immigrant while his lawyers fought the extradition request in the American courts.
And the really good news came when American legal experts poring over an 1874 treaty said extradition was not only a long way off, but fraught with so many hurdles that the blind and diabetic cleric might never make it back. 
 Sheik Abdel Rahman, spiritual leader of the Islamic Group, Egypt's main militant opposition, is thought to be the inspiration of the bombing of the World Trade Center last February, of a plot to conduct more bombings and assassinations in New York, and of a wave of attacks in Egypt that have killed 180 people and decimated the tourist industry. Egyptian officials executed seven of his followers last week, but fear chaos if the cleric himself returns for trial. Naturally, they were elated by the obstacles to his return.
"Now," mused an Egyptian official, "if some prison doctor would give him an injection of glucose instead of insulin, we would be rid of the whole mess."
The official was expressing a little-talked-about but nevertheless well-known fact of life here: Even if the sheik threatens Egypt's Government, the Government is not eager to confront him head-on, for in a test of strength, this Government cannot be sure it would win. It has not reduced the burden of poverty, it is known for corruption and inefficiency, and it has not even tried to espouse the kind of romantic ideals that in other places often distract the frustrated masses from such obvious failings in their leaders.
So it would be convenient indeed if a threat like the sheik could be bottled up indefinitely under guard in the United States, no longer able to record fiery sermons for his followers from an obscure New Jersey apartment.
The problem is that this does not address the reasons that the sheik and his teachings have appeal in Egypt in the first place. Even if it can be shown that there are links to outside powers like Iran, "the root cause of the unrest is the poverty and lack of opportunities that plague Egypt," said a Western diplomat. "Until these problems are solved, and until people feel they have a voice in their own destiny, the violence will not only continue, but probably get worse."
The danger to Egypt, many Western diplomats contend, arises not so much from the Islamic militants as from the attitudes and performance of the entrenched, well-fed bureaucrats and military officers who have ruled the country in the 40 years since Gamal Abdel Nasser and other young officers overthrew the monarchy in 1952.
At first, Nasser electrified the Arab world by articulating an idealistic pan-Arabism. His economic nationalization, involvement in Yemen's civil war and defeat in 1967 by Israel later dulled his luster, and when he died in 1970, Egypt was a bankrupt police state. Still, his legacy as the proponent of a grand dream is such, and the paucity of new ideologies is so great, that Saddam Hussein in Iraq, Muammar el-Qaddafi in Libya and Hafez al-Assad in Syria still like to imagine that they have assumed his mantle.
Egypt has never recovered from Nasser. His successor, Anwar el-Sadat, became a darling of the West but never acquired Nasser's popular appeal. When he was assassinated in 1981 by Islamic militants, many Egyptians were ready for something new.
What they got, in President Hosni Mubarak, was a low-key general who eschewed Nasser's rhetoric and Mr. Sadat's pomposity. He set out to loosen censorship, build public works, liberalize the economy and keep Mr. Sadat's close ties with the West.
He has, in fact, proven to be one of the West's best allies in the region, working to further the Arab-Israeli peace talks and leading the Arab coalition against Iraq during the Persian Gulf war. That may be good reason for the United States to cooperate with his Government in containing the threat from the fundamentalists; it is also good reason to confront the weaknesses in the regime itself.
In the fortress-like embassy in Cairo that houses the largest American mission in the world, diplomats worry that Mr. Mubarak is out of touch. Washington has sent $30 billion in aid to Egypt since it agreed to peace with Israel at Camp David in 1978. Only Israel has received more. But diplomats say the ossified political structures, endemic corruption and inefficient state-controlled economy remain largely untouched.
American diplomats have nudged Egyptian officials to improve their human rights record, curb corruption and open up the political system. It is a measure of how deep these problems run, perhaps, that the Egyptians are responding now with bitter talk of betrayal and abandonment, especially since it became public in April that American Embassy employees had been meeting with leaders of the outlawed Islamic Group. "We do not need the Americans to come in here and tell us how to run Egypt," one official said. "Do they want us to treat men who toss nail bombs into crowded cafes, killing children and innocent people, with respect?"
The Americans say that is hardly the point. Criticism of human-rights abuses masks a deeper concern about the fundamental appeal of a regime on which so much strategic interest has been staked. As Egypt's overcrowding and poverty, housing shortages and unemployment persist, the political implications are made worse by the seeming lack of any vision for a better life. Egypt's current leaders have never replaced the Nasserite ideology since it was exposed as nothing more than a fossilized glorification of an Arab ideal that never existed. Nor do they believe it needs replacing.
"This is a one-party state where there is no real political participation by those on the street," said a Western diplomat, "and this has created a political vacuum that the militants are rapidly filling."
This month, President Mubarak will be nominated by Parliament as the only candidate for the presidency, in effect handing him a third six-year term. But no one, even within his Government, expects the next six years to be as stable as the last.
It is an atmosphere in which the heady visions of the Islamic utopians, colliding with the dismissive attitude of the old elite, could well push the country to a flash point.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
The Uninsured: 37 Million and Growing

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM

 BODY:
"WE have met the uninsured, and they are us," is the message from Hillary and Bill Clinton these days as they try to prepare the public for sweeping health-care proposals this fall. They are not arguing for spiritual unity with the downtrodden. Rather, they are drawing on new evidence that startling numbers of even middle-class Americans are finding themselves without the security of health insurance at least temporarily, most often because they have changed or lost their jobs. And still more say they are suffering from "job lock," afraid to move or quit because they fear for their health coverage.
The estimated number of Americans without health insurance -- some 37 million and growing -- has become one of the verities of the health debate and a marker of national disgrace. But this snapshot figure conceals as much as it reveals. 
 Roughly six in 10 of the uninsured at any given time have been without for a year or more, according to Katherine Swartz, an economist at the Harvard School of Public Health. These are mainly lower-wage workers and their families, not poor enough to qualify for Medicaid. Rounding out the total is an ever-changing mix of people who spend months without coverage before regaining it. According to an analysis by Families USA, a nonprofit group in Washington, 2 million people lose their health insurance monthly, though nearly all get it again soon, for a monthly net increase of perhaps 100,000.
And so the White House is seeking to redefine the issue, talking more about the urgent need to safeguard the haves than about the plight of the have-nots.
"If you just focus on the uninsured, you're missing the real problem," said Kenneth E. Thorpe, an economist at the Department of Health and Human Services and an architect of the Clinton plan. "Of all people who have health insurance today, one in four will be uninsured at some point over the next two years. That's the scarier part of the problem."
The shift in emphasis does not mean the President will abandon the have-nots, but that he has made a sensible political calculation.
He is expected to propose that all employers offer health benefits and that all individuals, working or not, be required to carry insurance, with subsidies for companies and families that need help. His plan will mean new taxes as well as controversial cost-cutting measures. But he clearly hopes that a growing sense of vulnerability among the vast middle class -- more and more of whom have had spells without health insurance or know someone who has -- will translate into powerful backing for his overall proposal.
"Security" has become Mrs. Clinton's mantra: "Security is what this debate is about," she says. "Everyone will get a health security card which will guarantee all Americans access to a comprehensive package of benefits, no matter where they work, where they live and whether or not they've ever been sick before."
Critics are seizing on the same data about the uninsured to say the problem has been overstated.
They argue that many who lack coverage do so out of choice, and that compelling everyone to carry comprehensive coverage will waste large public and private sums. John F. Sheils, vice president of Lewin-VHI, a consulting firm in Fairfax, Va., thinks the Clinton plan will force expensive insurance on younger, healthy workers who prefer to pay medical bills out of pocket, gambling that they will not become seriously ill.
"I think the biggest surprise of this whole thing will be the way the uninsured respond to having money taken out of their paychecks," said Mr. Sheils, who believes that simpler measures like changes in insurance rules and targeted assistance to low-income families would suffice.
But Clinton defenders say that universal coverage and the broader restructuring of health care form a seamless whole, and that no one should get a free ride. "I don't think there are that many young healthy people trying to shirk their responsibilities," said Arnold Bennett, a spokesman for Families USA. "They are not just risking their own health care, it's our money," he said, referring to the billions in unpaid hospital bills that are covered by the insured public.
As for the tens of millions of people who find themselves uninsured for months at a time, experts like Dr. Swartz say the perils are greater than ever. It is not just the chance that an ill-timed medical crisis will produce gargantuan bills. Increasingly, insurers are avoiding customers deemed at high risk of illness, and employers are refusing to cover pre-existing conditions. "What worries me," Dr. Swartz said, "is that if somebody develops a medical condition during their time off, it can affect their insurability for the rest of their lives."
The numbers of the long-term uninsured are gradually rising, too. In part it reflects the insurers' efforts to sort the healthy from the sick. More important, the economy is producing more jobs that lack benefits, Dr. Swartz said. Many manufacturing and white-collar jobs have disappeared, while lower-end service jobs, part-time work and independent consulting have risen and many new small businesses do not offer coverage.
 
With Insurance, Expenses Rise

 
 "All these trends add up to a growing sense of unease: 'Yes I'm insured today, but will I be tomorrow?' " said Henry Aaron, an economist at the Brookings Institution. Just how wide and deep that unease is will be tested in the coming year.
The major concern will be the cost of universal coverage. The uninsured do get care now, either paying for it out of pocket or seeking "free" care through hospital emergency rooms. But they also forgo routine care, put off treatment and are less likely to receive costly, advanced procedures. Studies indicate that with insurance their health expenses will rise, and should.
A wild range of numbers, from $30 billion to $150 billion a year, have been floating about as the price of universal coverage. Until Mr. Clinton sorts out just what the required benefits will be, how much companies and individuals will be expected to pay and who will be eligible for subsidies, it is impossible to estimate the cost to society or the Federal budget.
With the cost issue, too, the White House is trying to change the terms of the debate. Instead of focusing on subsidies for the needy, officials prefer to talk about the overall impact of health reform. They say their proposals to reorganize care and cap expenditures will save huge sums compared with existing trends, more than enough to offset the costs of universal coverage.
The trouble is, the savings are unlikely to be visible for several years, while subsidies will require money here and now. Hence the Clinton sales pitch. "If the President can convey the idea that a large proportion of the American work force is in jeopardy, then he can ask voters to make sacrifices," said Dr. Aaron. "That is the price for assured access to health insurance."

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
Black Enterprises Grow and Get Noticed

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
MANY black leaders in Chicago were upset last month when the Johnson Products Company, one of the nation's leading symbols of black enterprise, announced that it would be acquired by the IVAX Corporation, an international conglomerate.
For decades, Chicago-based Johnson Products dominated the market in personal and hair care for blacks with Ultra Sheen, Classy Curl and other products, and its sale means the loss of a very powerful institution, the black leaders lamented. 
 But the Johnson deal is also a measure of the progress that black-owned companies have made over the last 20 years in expanding and diversifying their businesses, so much so that these enterprises have become attractive buys to mainstream companies.
When Joan B. Johnson succeeded her husband as chief executive of Johnson Products in 1989, the company was valued at $11 million. IVAX, a Miami-based pharmaceutical company with skin care, chemical and veterinary businesses, agreed to pay $67 million for Johnson, reflecting the company's long-term growth potential.
Management experts who study black-owned businesses say they anticipate an increase in the number being acquired by large corporations as these enterprises continue to flourish and diversify.
"As black firms become more and more like the traditional business community in terms of expanding their operations and entering technologically advanced fields, we can expect to see more acquisitions like Johnson Products," said Margaret Simms, director of research for the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a research organization in Washington that specializes in minority issues.
While the majority of black enterprises are small and continue to concentrate in traditional areas, the nation's 100 largest black-owned companies posted a 14.1 percent increase in sales last year, bringing their revenue to $9 billion, according to a survey published in last month's issue of Black Enterprise magazine. The increase in 1991 was 10.4 percent.
 
When Motown Was No. 1
 When Black Enterprise first compiled its list of 100 top black businesses 20 years ago, they had annual revenues of $473 million and were dominated by manufacturing companies but included 16 auto dealers, most of whom started their businesses during the 1960's. In the top position that year was Motown Industries, Berry Gordy's recording company.
Black-owned companies have since expanded into areas where they no longer have to rely on black patronage alone. The more recent areas of growth and opportunity have included computer information systems and other technical services, telecommunications, manufacturing and finance.
Among the top 25 on the Black Enterprise list are the Burrell Communications Group of Chicago and the Uniworld Group Inc. of New York City, both advertising agencies; H.J. Russell & Co. of Atlanta, which is in construction and development as well as food services, and Black Entertainment Television Holdings Inc., the Washington-based cable and publishing concern.
"Black business is no longer just food service, hair care, or auto dealerships," said Earl G. Graves, publisher of Black Enterprise. "It's not ethnically skewed anymore. African Americans have moved into the mainstream."
 
Set-Aside Plans
 The growth and diversification has been spurred by a number of factors, in particular the rising number of programs at all levels of government that set aside contracts for minority-owned businesses in such areas as construction and computer and telecommunications services. In addition, there has been an increase in the number of black professionals with management experience who have decided to become entrepreneurs.
Moreover, the experts predict a rise in the number of acquisitions by black entrepreneurs, citing the 1987 purchase of the international operations of the Beatrice Companies by the late Reginald F. Lewis, who was chairman and chief executive of the food-processing and distribution company until his death this year. TLC Beatrice International Holdings is now the nation's largest black-owned business. The company, which is based in Manhattan but operates primarily in Western Europe, had $1.67 billion in revenues last year.
"Just as early black entrepreneurs went into the hair care and restaurant business because it was something they were familiar with, you now have a growing number of blacks who have worked in the computer, high-tech and finance fields and are now launching their own ventures," said Ms. Simms of the Joint Center for Economic and Political Studies.
She said that while minority-owned businesses serve an important role within their communities, providing jobs and economic development, successful entrepreneurs are distinguished from the others by their ability to acquire and build on capital from their enterprise.
David Huggins, chief executive of RMS Technologies Inc. in Marlton, N.J., started the computer and technical services company in 1977 with three employees. Last year, the company had sales of $103 million and ranked sixth on the Black Enterprise list of industrial and service companies.
Mr. Huggins said that his firm had benefited greatly from minority set-aside programs, but that the company had grown so much that it no longer qualifies for most of these programs and often finds itself searching for minority subcontractors to meet government requirements on large contracts.
Perhaps the major obstacle facing black-owned businesses is access to new capital, Mr. Huggins said. "Even when you have a thriving, expanding enterprise, there is still a reluctance and skepticism in taking black-owned firms public," Mr. Huggins said. "Racism is at work here, but you have to see it as a challenge and not a barrier."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Haiti's Future Can Be Undone Before It's Done

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti

 BODY:
FOR many who have followed Haiti's multiple ups and downs since the fall of the Duvalier family dictatorship in 1986, attentions quickly turned -- once the news of a United Nations-brokered settlement of the country's latest political crisis had penetrated -- to speculation over what could go wrong next.
In this proud but star-crossed nation given to coups, countercoups, rampant demagoguery and permanent intrigue, the question seems even natural, given the elaborate choreography called for by the United Nations plan to restore the elected President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, to office on Oct. 30. 
 The United Nations, the Organization of American States and the four countries that have invested most heavily in the diplomatic efforts here -- the United States, Canada, Venezuela and France -- have wagered considerable prestige on making the plan work. But what is most required for its success, many agree, is that rarest commodity in Haitian politics: good will.
No sooner had the ink dried on the agreement between the two principals to Haiti's latest crisis, Father Aristide and the army commander who presided over his overthrow, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, than Haiti's cunning and often cutthroat political class, sensing an end to the military dominion, was galloping off with wildly divergent readings of the painstakingly charted road ahead.
The United Nations-devised settlement calls first for weeding out enemies of the President who were elected to Parliament last January in voting widely denounced as fraudulent and then for the nomination of a new prime minister by Father Aristide. Once his choice is ratified, international sanctions will be lifted and a massive international aid program begun. The effort to build a modern economy and restructure the armed forces involves sending as many as 1,000 experts in development, police, military affairs and other areas.
The senators who had only recently won their places, along with their allies among anti-Aristide legislators, have gone to the airwaves to vow resistance.
"No one on this earth, with the exception of someone armed with a machine gun, will get me to quit -- and even then it would be my cadaver they would drag from here," one senator pledged, his voice trembling, on national television.
Others, like Serge Gilles, a smooth party boss who has wavered fluidly between effective support for the army coup and calls for Father Aristide's return, have chosen audacity over melodrama by suggesting themselves as prime minister rather than the centrist businessman that Father Aristide is believed to favor.
Before any selection can be made, however, the settlement requires a sweeping parliamentary cleanup, and Senator Gilles, like his colleagues who won office early this year, is clinging tenaciously to his seat.
Until Father Aristide's choice of a prime minister is ratified, a crushing embargo that has turned the streets into ghost town sets by blocking Haiti's oil supplies will remain in effect. Many here secretly fear that if basic political questions like this cannot be resolved quickly, tensions rising from growing economic desperation could become explosive.
In order to overcome the parliamentary logjam, the United Nations will convene a meeting of Haitian political leaders and Father Aristide's representatives in New York next week. But for now, as a Creole proverb has it, where everyone is struggling to become somebody, the priority is avoiding becoming a nobody.
If diplomatic suasions can help settle the parliamentary mess, all, including Father Aristide and his closest allies, will anxiously wait to see how committed Haiti's army is to fulfilling the rest of the accord.
Intimates of General Cedras tell reporters nowadays that the army leader is determined to live to the letter of the agreement, which calls for his retirement shortly before Father Aristide's return. But many worry nonetheless that somewhere in the army hierarchy lurks an ambitious officer biding his time, ready to create an incident aimed at derailing the transition.
Haiti's army has wielded power throughout most of the country's rocky 189 years of independence, and an ideology that mixes volatile xenophobia with nationalism is widely thought to be alive and well in the institution.
The United Nations settlement ambitiously calls for Father Aristide's new Government to separate the police from the army and appoint a new commander. These would be only the first steps toward a wholesale renovation of the army that aims to get troops out of the streets, where opportunities for extortion and brutality are rife.
Finally, if all goes well until the transition, there is Father Aristide himself, who diplomats say showed little skill for coalition building or management during his nearly eight months in office, and sometimes appeared to tolerate violence by his supporters.
"We don't want to put Humpty Dumpty back on the wall just have him fall all over again," said one diplomat closely involved in designing the transition. In part for this reason, the settlement calls for a large and varied international presence in Haiti expected to last at least two years, along with copious foreign aid.
Those who have spent time with the Silesian-trained priest say he has grown tremendously in his 21 months of exile. One of the most encouraging signs, they say, is that Father Aristide's expected choice as prime minister, Robert Malval, is a widely respected businessman who is known for his open ear and his pragmatism.
"What we have grown used to in Haiti is extremes," Mr. Malval said in an interview. "A centrist force does not exist yet. What we have to work at is building a middle that would be the meeting place of the moderate wings of each end of the spectrum."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Conversations/Herbert S. Okun;
What Comes After Containment? It May Be Son of Containment

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER

 BODY:
HE was 16 in Brooklyn, the red-haired son of an emigre produce merchant, in the summer of 1947 when he read George F. Kennan's anonymous "Mr. X" article in Foreign Affairs. That essay, "The Sources of Soviet Conduct," recommended and swiftly came to define Western policy toward the Soviet threat for the next four decades as "containment."
Herbert S. Okun recalled: "I read it and said, 'That's what I want to do.' " From James Madison High School he went to Stanford, learned Russian, and applied to join the Foreign Service. The substance of his diplomatic career, ultimately as a United States ambassador, concerned the containment policy of the United States: postings to Moscow and East Berlin and assignments to help negotiate limitations on strategic arms and test bans. 
 Now, with the cold war becoming history, Mr. Okun sits in an office 21 floors above Lexington Avenue contemplating a world whose rules and institutions have virtually broken down in many areas. For 20 months, until May, he watched that collapse from the inside, taking part in the international negotiating efforts to end the fighting in the former Yugoslavia.
With that often-grueling experience under his belt, Mr. Okun ponders what comes after containment. Ponders out loud. Three hours at a stretch with hardly a pause.
"We've got the world's best factory for horseshoes, but the automobile has just been invented," he says. "All of the multilateral organizations, the United Nations, the European Community, NATO, are having big troubles adjusting." He pauses an instant for a sip of coffee from a plastic cup and canters onward: "History helps, but it doesn't give you answers. Knowing history is like a sailor knowing the tides. It doesn't tell you if it is going to rain tomorrow."
Mr. Okun considers his generation "all children of the cold war." It shows when he describes a contemporary in Munich from the mid-1950's and forms with his fingers the initials C, I, A, while mouthing them silently -- although that clandestine identity hardly matters four decades later.
"We have a sense of battle fatigue, cold-war fatigue," he says. "We need to disenthrall ourselves from, what is it Lincoln said? 'the dogmas of the quiet past.' The great horseshoe makers had great achievements -- NATO -- the most successful defense alliance in history. But it is not easy to go from collective defense to collective security."
 
A Country Dissolved
 He left the Foreign Service in early 1991 to help create Financial Services Volunteer Corps, a nonprofit organization set up with Government and private funding to assist countries of the former Soviet bloc in developing banking services, stock exchanges and other financial institutions essential to a market economy. Co-chairmen of the organization are former secretaries of state Cyrus R. Vance and John C. Whitehead.
It was but a short step in October 1991 to accompany Mr. Vance as senior deputy in the initial assignment from the Secretary General of the United Nations to negotiate a cease-fire in the war between Croats and Serbs. In contrast to previous international mediation attempts, that mission was successful. On the basis of a pact signed in Sarajevo, the guns around Dubrovnik and in Slavonia and Krajina fell silent on January 1992. United Nations troops were posted in Serbian-held territories of Croatia to keep the peace. But an even bloodier conflict loomed in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
With that emblematic Yugoslav republic being torn apart in a three-sided ethnic struggle, representatives of 30 governments met in late August in London to have another go at peacemaking. They enlisted Mr. Vance and Mr. Okun for the United Nations and Lord Owen for the European Community to stop the slaughter and redesign Bosnia and Herzegovina as a "multi-ethnic and pluralistic democracy." Mr. Okun, who had explored the region in 1957, paddling the Drina and Neretva rivers in a kayak, soon dubbed it "mission impossible."
Looking back on the tribulations of the Vance-Owen plan, Mr. Okun declines to cast blame, saying only: "What was always necessary was implementation -- sufficient peacekeeping forces or the threat of force. But the international community was not willing to cough up the troops. The international community was not unanimous."
Welcome to Son of Containment. Drawing on the cold war experience, Mr. Okun remarks that carrying out Kennan's containment dictum "took a lot of hard intellectual work" in the 1950's. "Are we doing that in the post-Communist world? We're not. We need the same intellectual vigor and vision." He recalls that the Pentagon spent billions of dollars developing what planners called an "escalatory ladder" of stages of engagement between the West and the Soviet empire.
 
A Ladder Up
 "We don't have the institutions that get at this new cliche called 'preventive diplomacy,' but now everyone says you have to get involved earlier in the Bosnias or in a Nagorno-Karabagh," he says. "We need to design a preventive diplomacy ladder."
With Mr. Vance, Mr. Okun visited the Nagorno-Karabagh enclave last year for the United Nations to view the ethnic conflict that is continuing between Azerbaijan and Armenia. He came away with the impression that it was "worse than Bosnia" partly because both sides were deploying heavy Soviet weapons.
Lacking a coherent plan for dealing with the newest wars, invasions and for the chaos that has descended on countries like Somalia, Mr. Okun sees that inchoate creature called the International Community "edging crabwise, usually unwillingly, into intervention without a visible end."
"WIC's" is his term for these objects of intervention, his acronym for "wards of the international community."
At stake, "roughly speaking," he says, are four principles: sovereignty, territorial integrity, self-determination and human rights. "The problem in former Yugoslavia, for instance, is that these principles bump up against each other. How do you get involved early if they don't want you? That's an infringement of sovereignty. My self-determination is your secession. My freedom fighter is your terrorist. Maybe it is time to start using the World Court. Otherwise, we'll go right back to 1913.
"The lesson for the future from Vance-Owen is that you have got to have the United States directly involved from the beginning," he says. "The United States is the only power that can regulate in the world. It is the Ordnungsmacht (German for the power that creates order). It has to be the policy fountain. That's not arrogance, it's a fact."
Mr. Okun is a reader, in Russian and German as well as English. Turgenev and Lermontov. The novels of Austria's Joseph Roth. And again, George F. Kennan. "Did you see 'The Balkan Crises,' his new essay?" he asks, referring to the July 15 issue of the New York Review of Books. "He draws everything together as only he can do, with the lesson that if you don't use force, you bear the consequences. Diplomacy without force is like baseball without a bat."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Writing New Rules For Criticizing Israel From Afar

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
ISRAEL'S Ambassador in Washington, Itamar Rabinovich, was recently addressing a convention of the America-Israel Public Affairs Committee, the pro-Israel lobby, explaining Israel's peace policies. He said Israel seeks a package of peace and security, based on a compromise with the Arabs, that, at the end of the day, "might also involve some Israeli concessions."
The huge audience of American Jews greeted his remarks with a stony silence, save one solitary soul in the back of the hall who clapped. The resourceful ambassador paused for a moment, took in the sound of one hand clapping, and said: "I understand that it is very difficult to get an applause for the term 'concessions' here. So let us applaud the concessions the Arabs will have to make." 
 That got a rousing ovation.
That scene was no aberration. In recent months the Labor Government of Israel's Prime Minister, Yitzhak Rabin, has increasingly found itself under attack by some prominent American Jews as being too willing to trade land for peace with the Arabs. And some hard-line Jewish intellectuals, who for years argued that it was heresy for any American Jews to criticize any Israeli government's policies, now argue that it is a necessity, indeed a moral imperative, to criticize the Rabin Government in order to save Israel from itself.
The most extreme form of this debate surfaced last week when a vice president of the Aipac lobby, Harvey Friedman, was forced to resign after calling Mr. Rabin's dovish Deputy Foreign Minister, Yossi Beilin, "a little slime ball" while denouncing him for a supposedly excessive willingness to trade land for peace.
Mr. Rabinovich says he has found himself lately in the position, unfamiliar for an Israeli ambassador, of "having at one and the same time to argue our case with the Arab side at the negotiating table, while explaining to a skeptical minority of our own supporters that there is merit to this peace process, even though it is yet unproven."
The chief stirrer of this debate is Norman Podhoretz, the conservative editor of the magazine Commentary. In a long essay in the April issue, he wrote that for many years, and especially from 1977 to 1992, when the right-wing Likud party dominated Israeli politics, he "took the position that American Jews had no moral right to criticize Israel's security policies; only those whose lives were on the line had the standing to participate in the public debate."
 
New Circumstances
 During those Likud years, it was Israeli policy to reject any territorial compromise on the West Bank, Gaza Strip, Golan Heights or Jerusalem.
But in 1993, Mr. Podhoretz argued, "we have an entirely new" political and moral situation that has forced him and others to re-examine their objection to criticizing Israel. The Rabin Government, he said, seems to be walking into a negotiating trap set by Arabs intent on using the peace table, instead of the battlefield, to destroy Israel. Israel is misreading the real intentions of the Arab regimes, Mr. Podhoretz said, and if it does not desist, it may soon be trapped by pressures into creating a Palestinian state or giving up the Golan Heights.
"My basic point," Mr. Podhoretz said in an interview, "is that there is no evidence that either the Syrians or the Palestinians have changed their strategic objective with respect to Israel, which I still believe is the destruction of the state. It seemed to me in listening to statements coming from Israel and the Israeli Embassy in Washington that the Israelis were desperately eager to make a deal and were on the point of making dangerous concessions in order to consummate it."
Mr. Podhoretz admits "that I am being inconsistent on the moral issue of the right of a Jew living outside of Israel to participate in the debate over security." But, he argues, there is a difference "between my kind of criticism and the moral assault on Israel by some Jews, which contributed to the effort to delegitimize Israel in the 1970's and 1980's." He said it was more dangerous to add to that delegitimization than to make the criticisms he is making now, "when the Israeli Government itself is outstripping Washington in its eagerness to make concessions."
 
A Lack of Surprise
 Henry Siegman, executive director of the American Jewish Congress, was one of many Jewish liberals who was denounced by the Jewish right as "anti-Israel" or "self-hating" when he disagreed with the Likud's uncompromising policies during the 1980's. He says he is not surprised that now that the left-of-center Labor Party is in power, Jewish hard-liners say it is all right to criticize. "I just underestimated the speed and shamelessness with which they did it," he said, adding that he wished the Rabin Government would be more aggressive in answering them.
It has not reacted vehemently, Israeli officials say, in part because many in the Labor Government have simply written off some American Jewish groups as irrelevant or irredeemably indoctrinated by the Likud. As Mr. Beilin said: "The firing of Harvey Friedman came on a much more grave background: the transformation of Aipac in recent years into a right-wing Jewish organization." Aipac vehemently denies this.
In part, it is also because Israeli officials are confident that the great majority of American Jews and mainstream Jewish leaders who have been silent in this debate support Mr. Rabin.
And in part it is because many Israeli intellectuals on the left believe the rightist argument rests on a ludicrous assumption that Mr. Rabin approaches the peace talks as a starry-eyed romantic who believes that Israel's Arab enemies have had political therapy and are now ready to reconcile with the Jewish state.
In fact, say Israeli diplomats, Mr. Rabin, whom no one ever called a romantic, bases his whole approach on a sober, functional analysis that there is no transformed Arab psyche, but that political and economic pressures on the Arab governments may make them amenable to a deal that will enable Israel to ease the burden of war with its neighbors -- on terms that will not endanger its security. Maybe, in the end, Israel won't find an Arab partner for such a secure peace, but it certainly has an interest in testing the waters. That, they say, is the deepest form of realism.
"The difference between me and Podhoretz," said the Israeli philosopher David Hartman, "is that when you live on Park Avenue you can afford to be 'worried' about the future of Israel. When you live in Jerusalem with your grandchildren, you can't afford to just worry. You have to believe that the future can in some way be different from the present. It might not be -- but you have an interest in doing everything you can to test that possibility. To be paralyzed by anxiety is a luxury we cannot afford."

HEADLINE: JULY 4-10: Keeping the Pressure On;
A Standoff in Iraq Raises Nervousnessc About New Raids

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL

 BODY:
The air raid sirens that sounded in Baghdad last week proved to be a false alarm, but the Iraqi edginess was only one sign that last month's punitive American missile strike may not be the last.
There was still hope of compromise by week's end in the most serious current standoff between Iraq and the United Nations, which began more than a month ago. But Iraq's steadfast refusal to permit cameras at two missile-test sites moved the dispute closer to confrontation. A U.N. inspection team pulled out in protest. 
 With familiar dexterity, Baghdad masked its intransigence with conciliation. It agreed to destroy chemical wea pons stocks and expressed a new openness to a U.N. plan that would allow it to sell oil provided that the proceeds are used only to buy food for civilians and to support U.N. relief operations.
But with each gesture, Baghdad urged that the United Nations lift the sanctions it imposed after the gulf war; and the line it drew at the installation of the cameras spoke even more directly of its unwillingness to accept long-term Western monitoring. In Tokyo, the leaders attending the economic summit vowed to keep up the pressure on Iraq to accede to the U.N. directives. The view of Western officials in Washington was that such an effort may soon require more military might.

HEADLINE: JULY 4-10;
Mickey Lacks a Soupcon of Charm

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

 BODY:
Battered by a European recession and still bewildered by European habits, Euro Disney put its entire future development under review last week after announcing disastrous summer losses. Being in the red during the cold winter months was predictable, but an April-June loss of $87 million sent the company's stock into a nosedive on the Paris Bourse.
Behind the 20 percent plunge in Euro Disney shares lies a growing uneasiness over whether the Walt Disney magicians may have misjudged more than the economic trends in Europe. Certainly, a recession has hit hotel attendance and spending, and higher-than expected interest rates have made Euro Disney's $3.7 billion of debt very expensive. 
 But the grumbling among Europeans is not just about prices. Euro Disney, through its infamous dress code stipulating what undergarments women employees should use and other kinds of corporate rigidity, has acquired a generally negative image in France.
The French are more irritated by lines than Americans, more insistent on booze with lunch (the company recently gave in and started serving wine at four restaurants), less willing to change their lunch hour -- and a touch more cynical.

HEADLINE: CLINTON, IN SEOUL, TELLS NORTH KOREA TO DROP ARMS PLAN

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Sunday, July 11

 BODY:
Declaring that "no specter hangs over this peninsula or this region more darkly" than North Korea's nuclear-weapons project, President Clinton stepped up pressure Saturday on the Communist Government to abandon the program.
His aides suggested that the United States and South Korea would move swiftly to seek economic sanctions from the United Nations if North Korea failed to back down in coming weeks. 
 Arriving here after the close of the summit meeting of the seven leading industrial democracies in Tokyo, Mr. Clinton assured South Korea's anxious leaders that "our troops will stay here as long as the Korean people want and need us."
 
Two Presidents' Commitments
 Sharpening his own oratory, South Korea's new President, Kim Young Sam, said as Mr. Clinton stood next to him that the international community may soon have to take "appropriate countermeasures" to force North Korea to abandon its nuclear weapons program.
Speaking to the Korean National Assembly in what the White House termed his first major address on Asian security and nuclear non-proliferation, Mr. Clinton insisted that the only way to deter aggression from powers like North Korea and to continue Asia's economic growth is for the United States to remain "an active presence."
"To some in America there is a fear that America's global leadership is an outdated luxury we can no longer afford," said Mr. Clinton, clearly tired after four days of summit sessions. "Well, they are wrong. In truth, our global leadership has never been a more indispensable or a more worthwhile investment for us."
His comments seemed an oblique reference to conflicts within his Administration about the proper scope of United States influence around the world in the cold war's aftermath.
The biggest United States cutback in Asia so far came with the closing last year of the huge air and naval bases in the Philippines. American officials argue that those reductions did not signal any lessening commitment to the region because the bases were closed at the insistence of the Philippine Government, which had demanded a tremendous increase in the rent paid by the United States. The decision to close the air base was also speeded by the eruption of a volcano that buried it in ash.
While the United States has been unable to replicate the two installations, at Subic Bay and Clark Air Base, it has reached agreements for landing rights, refueling and small service sites in several nations in Southeast Asia.
 
The Role of Japan
 Mr. Clinton's speech Saturday came amid growing concern in the Administration that the North Korean nuclear program was already having an unsettling effect throughout the region.
At the talks in Tokyo, for example, Japan was the only country to indicate that it could not yet support an indefinite extension of the Nuclear Non-proliferation Treaty when it expires in 1995.
Japanese officials say that they have no intention of building nuclear weapons but that conservative members of the governing Liberal Democratic Party did not want to forever forgo the right to build them, especially given the threat they felt from North Korea.
Mr. Clinton reserved his harshest comments for the Communist Government of Kim Il Sung, North Korea's 81-year-old "Great Leader." Speaking only four days before the United States and North Korea are to hold another session of talks about the North's refusal to allow international inspectors into its most important nuclear sites, he said that stopping the spread of nuclear weapons would be a top priority of his "Pacific Community" strategy.
Noting that North Korea had recently tested a powerful missile with a range of more than 600 miles -- one that some believe will be capable of carrying nuclear weapons -- he said: "We cannot let the expanding threat of these deadly weapons replace the cold-war nightmare of nuclear annihilation. And today, that policy is too real."
Administration and Korean officials have estimated that North Korea already has enough plutonium for one or two bombs, but that it may not yet have all the technology it needs to detonate one.
Mr. Clinton described at length steps to improve the quality of United States forces in Korea and Japan and told the Korean National Assembly: "These are not signs of disengagement. These are signs that America intends to stay."
The message was quite similar to one that George Bush brought here in January 1992. But South Korea has been nervous about the Clinton Administration, fearing that a combination of budget cuts and the end of Communism's spread in Asia would diminish Washington's interest.
So far, officials say, the United States, Japan and South Korea have worked closely together to present a unified face to the North, dangling what Mr. Clinton Saturday termed "carrots" -- an end to isolation and the prospect of economic aid.
But some internal divisions have become evident in recent months, mostly over the question of whether carrots or sticks should be used first.
Since March, South Korea has veered from one extreme to the other on how the United States, which has no diplomatic relations with the North and had no dealings with it until recently, should play its diplomatic cards. Three months ago, for example, several South Korean leaders said they were concerned that Washington might overreact to North Korea's declaration that it would leave the Nuclear Non-proliferation Treaty.
But in recent weeks, other officials in Seoul have begun to argue that the Americans have gotten little out of their talks with the North, which suspended its withdrawal from the treaty last month. President Kim, for example, suggested in an interview last month that North Korea was simply dragging out the arms negotiations in a bid for time to produce its bomb.
 
Strong Words From Seoul
 President Clinton repeated his warning to North Korea today as he left to visit the demilitarized zone, the fiercely armed no man's land on the border with North Korea, to address American troops stationed near the border. He arrived later than expected because heavy rains forced him to travel to the zone by road instead of helicopter.
The stronger words, though, came from his South Korean hosts.
President Kim, who came to power this year as the first civilian elected President in more than three decades, said that if "North Korea does not demonstrate different attitudes toward the resolution of the nuclear issue, in spite of our sincere efforts, then the international community will inevitably have to come up with appropriate countermeasures to deal with the issue."
Mr. Clinton called that a "very accurate summary of the discussions that we have just held."
A senior Administration official traveling with Mr. Clinton said Saturday that the countermeasures in mind were United Nations economic sanctions. Studies by the United States Air Force and intelligence agencies suggest that a military strike against the nuclear complex at Yongbyon, 100 miles north of the capital, Pyongyang, had a relatively low chance of success because so much of the complex is hidden in hillsides or underground.
"Even if we wiped out everything we saw, we would never know if we got it all," one American official said.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Kim did not describe their talks in detail. But Mr. Clinton brought with him a number of his chief security specialists.
While American and Korean officials are loathe to set a deadline for progress in their talks with the North, for fear it would reduce their negotiating flexibility, several say that their patience will wear out by the end of the summer.
"North Korea must understand our intentions," Mr. Clinton said. "We are seeking to prevent aggression, not to initiate it. And so long as North Korea abides by the United Nations charter and international non-proliferation commitments, it has nothing to fear from America."
The key to making sanctions work is the support -- or at least the abstention -- of China, so it does not use its veto power in the Security Council. South Korean officials seem increasingly confident that if they can demonstrate that North Korea has turned down every chance to find a face-saving way out of the nuclear project, China will go along with sanctions.
"When the United States and South Korea were attempting to discourage North Korea from withdrawing from the NPT, China was quite helpful," Mr. Clinton said, referring to the Non-proliferation Treaty. "I think the Chinese Government is very interested in supporting the position we have taken here."

HEADLINE: 3 Ships Adrift in a Diplomatic Limbo

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, July 10

 BODY:
More than 650 undocumented Chinese men and women remained aboard three rusty tramp steamers about 60 miles west of Mexico's Pacific coast today as the Clinton Administration tried to figure out what to do with the aliens without either abandoning its new get-tough immigration policy or antagonizing the Mexican Government.
On Friday night Mexico turned down a request by the United States for assistance in dealing with the 659 illegal immigrants aboard the three ships. 
 The three are believed to be part of a seven-ship flotilla containing an estimated 1,400 aliens who were planning to illegally enter the United States, probably through Mexico. All seven are sailing under the flag of Taiwan.
When one ship's engine failed, the crew radioed for help on Tuesday. The United States Coast Guard towed it to a point in international waters about 60 miles west of Ensenada, Mexico, which is about 60 miles south of the United States-Mexico border.
The Coast Guard then escorted two other ships to the same point, where it is now providing the aliens with food and medical care while awaiting a decision from Washington about whether to turn the ships back or allow them to land. The other four ships are farther out to sea and still heading east.
 
Governments Still Cooperating
 On Friday, United States officials asked Mexico to allow the Chinese aliens to be brought to a Mexican port, where they could be interviewed by United Nations officials to determine whether they are political refugees, who could ask for asylum, or economic refugees, who would be repatriated.
The United States offered to help Mexico pay for the repatriations.
But on Friday night the Mexican Foreign Ministry, believed to be concerned about the issue of Mexican sovereignty, delicately rejected the request, saying it was "not in a position" to comply.
State Department officials in the United States, and diplomats in Mexico, said today that despite that response, the two governments had continued discussing ways to deal with the aliens.
"When you have interests that touch both countries, you keep on working," said a senior American diplomat involved in the discussions here. The official refused to describe the alternatives being discussed.
 
Stemming Flow of Boat People
 Mexican Government officials were not available today, and a spokeswoman at the foreign ministry said there were no plans to make any statement beyond the one issued Friday night, when Mexico announced it was turning down the United States' request.
The challenge facing both governments is to find a way to handle the aliens humanely while also abiding by Administration plans to try to stem the flow of Chinese boat people.
Last month, at least eight Chinese aliens died when a ship ran aground off a New York City beach. After the New York incident, President Clinton approved a plan aimed at stopping the smuggling of refugees into the United States, and the Administration stepped up its efforts to patrol international waters and seize suspect ships. The effort is similar to that used in the Caribbean for Haitian refugees.
But clearly there is a vast difference between sending leaky vessels a few hundred miles back to Haiti and sending them thousands of miles back across the Pacific to China, although that is an option that may not have been ruled out.
When asked whether the mechanical problems with one of the Chinese ships virtually assured that its occupants would have to be brought ashore and put on jets in order to be repatriated, the American diplomat in Mexico said "disabled boats get fixed, too."
The three ships now being held off the coast of the Mexican state of Baja California are not leaking, but Coast Guard mechanics have not been able to repair the engine of the disabled craft. A Coast Guard spokeswoman at the Long Beach, Calif., station described conditions on the ships as "fair," and said there had been no need to evacuate any of the aliens to a hospital.
The spokeswoman, Petty Officer Elizabeth M. Brannan, said Coast Guard personnel were cooking for the 236 people aboard the disabled vessel, the Sing Li No. 6, and were supplying rice and military-issue meals to those aboard the other two ships.
Petty Officer Brannan said the three ships would be held at the rendezvous point until orders came from an interagency group in Washington consisting of officials of the immigration service, the Justice and State Departments and the National Security Council.
An employee at the Immigration and Naturalization Service office in Long Beach, Calif., who would not give his name, said that contingency preparations were being made there as well as in the San Diego and San Francisco offices to accommodate the aliens should a decision be made to bring them ashore in the United States.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Republicans Forget Clinton; the Big Worry Is Perot

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, July 10

 BODY:
After slashing Ross Perot as "a walking sound bite," "a great hit-and-run artist" and a free agent who can make a splash then "run back to Dallas on his private jet," Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, denied that he harbored any ill feelings.
"I talk to Ross Perot," he said. "I don't want to leave the impression that there's any hostility between myself and Ross Perot." 
 By showing such sensitivity about giving offense, Mr. Dole, never known for making nice to political foes, underscored at a party meeting here just how fearful Republicans are of Mr. Perot's political power.
While Mr. Perot, in his zeal to compete with Mr. Dole as President Clinton's fiercest critic, has neglected the Republicans lately, the party has reason to be more worried about him than the Democrats do: a recent survey by President Clinton's pollster showed that most of the 19 million people who voted for Mr. Perot last year were Republicans, and that they had little interest in returning to the fold.
 
Evidence on a Speedboat
 At the summer meeting here of the Republican National Committee, even the gleeful trading of stories about Mr. Clinton's foibles could not mask an undercurrent of nervousness -- one participant called it panic -- over Mr. Perot. The suspicions escalated recently when Mr. Perot surfaced on his speedboat with David R. Gergen, a onetime adviser to Republican Presidents who now works for Mr. Clinton. The two boaters insisted that they were coincidentally in Bermuda on separate vacations.
"The Democrats' fondest dream is for Perot candidates to run as independents in 1994, splitting the vote and allowing liberal Democrats to slip in the back door with 43 percent of the vote," said Haley Barbour, the Republican chairman. "My Democratic friends have all worn out two sets of knee pads: they're down on their knees praying for the Perot candidates to run as third-party candidates."
Mr. Barbour was not as eager to discuss his own party's even bigger fear: that Mr. Perot will again run as an independent Presidential candidate, siphoning votes from Republicans. Then there is their second-biggest fear: that Mr. Perot will join the Republican Party and run for President, complicating the party's efforts to reclaim the White House and possibly destroying the prospects of veteran Republicans (Mr. Dole comes to mind) who have thirsted for the Presidency.
 
Divided Over a Stand
 Perhaps with his own possible candidacy in mind, Mr. Dole dismissed Mr. Perot as someone who could not win Republican primaries. But he said another independent campaign by Mr. Perot would be worrisome because winning back Perot voters was "going to be very difficult."
Like Mr. Clinton, who has still not figured out whether to cozy up to or attack Mr. Perot, the Republicans are equally ambivalent over how to react. Even as Mr. Dole attacked, Newt Gingrich, the House Republican whip, paid $15 to join Mr. Perot's organization, United We Stand, America.
So did Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison of Texas, who praised Mr. Perot at this conference for making the deficit "a definable, understandable issue." Suggesting that her fellow Republicans were overreacting, Mrs. Hutchison said: "Everyone talks about Ross running against Republicans or possibly running for President. But I've never heard him say that he wants to do that."
And at the luncheon today, Lynn Martin, a former Secretary of Labor, brought up Mr. Perot, telling the Republicans, "He has proven to all of us again that the American people are willing to listen about their future."
 
A Hard-Liner on Perot
 By contrast, William J. Bennett, the former Education Secretary and Federal drug policy coordinator, vociferously argues that the party's uneasy alliance with Mr. Perot is nothing short of pandering. Saying he was distressed at the sight of admiring House Republicans flocking to Mr. Perot's side during a recent foray on Capitol Hill, Mr. Bennett warned at the time, "We could end up making him so big, he'll overshadow us."
These Republicans argue that the party should not be fooled because Mr. Perot has taken only a few swipes at Republicans, now that his longtime nemesis, George Bush, is out of office.
As executive director of the Texas Republican Party, Karen Hughes has watched Mr. Perot for years. And the last thing she wants is for him to run as an independent again in 1996. "The danger," she said, "is that we'd end up with the result that we had in 1992: Bill Clinton as President. That should be our biggest message. People are not going to want that to happen again in 1996."
The challenge for Republicans, Ms. Hughes said, "is to agree with Perot on the issues."
 
Uncomfortable With Views
 The problem, however, is that not all Republicans are comfortable with his stands. They do not like Mr. Perot's opposition to the North American Free Trade Agreement, his proposal (from which he has partly retreated) for tax increases larger than those recommended by Mr. Clinton, and his more liberal views on social issues like abortion.
"I think he's wrong on Nafta," said Don Bain, chairman of the Colorado Republican Party, explaining that he would never vote for Mr. Perot if he ran as a Republican. "His personality, his quasi-military style, is ill-suited to the political process, which is inherently one of principles tempered with negotiation and compromise. But he's worrisome in that he's a potential kingmaker in major races."
(Characteristically, Mr. Perot only grins -- but dodges the question -- when asked whether he will field a slate of Congressional candidates in the 1994 midterm elections.)
 
Forums to Draw Voters
 With no unified strategy over how to deal with Mr. Perot, the Republicans, like the Democrats, have sought to shift the attention to "Perot voters." But there, too, the Republicans are trying to sort out game plans to win them over.
The party, whose meeting ends Sunday, devoted part of its closed session today to discussing its plans for an independent foundation to hold forums around the country. The forums are aimed squarely at drawing Mr. Perot's backers.
Mr. Dole put forth another idea. Citing polling data showing that Perot voters view Congress almost with contempt, he said Republicans should emphasize to Perot voters that "the Democrats have controlled Congress almost completely for the last 40 years" and should be voted out in next year's elections. "No wonder the Perot voters are upset," he said.
 
Still Another Perot View
 There is yet another school of thought: that Republicans should not dwell on wooing Mr. Perot or the people who voted for him.
"The principal reason why Perot was a serious factor was that Republicans felt betrayed by Bush on 'no news taxes,' " said Morton Blackwell, the Republican committeeman from Virginia. "He was a place for people to cast a protest vote. In 1996, we'll reunite the economic conservatives and the social conservatives."
But few other Republicans were willing to predict that Mr. Perot would fade from their political calculations (or their nightmares) any time soon. "In the long run, his message will be subsumed by the major parties and he'll disappear into the role of a caricature," said Mr. Bain, the Colorado chairman. "But that could take four to six years."
