HEADLINE: Clinton in Korea: A Call for a Pacific Community Based on 'Shared Strength'

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Clinton's address to the South Korean National Assembly yesterday in Seoul, as transcribed by the Federal News Service and provided by the Reuters news agency:
When President Truman sent American troops to Korea's defense 43 years ago, he said he aimed to prove that, and I quote, "Free men, under God, can build a community of neighbors working together for the good of all." Our efforts together since then have benefited all our peoples, not only the people of our own countries, but in the Asian-Pacific region, all who seek to live in peace and freedom. Our relationship has made this region more secure, more prosperous, and more free. 
 Now, with the cold war over and profound changes sweeping throughout your country, this whole populous region, and indeed throughout the world, we must create a new vision of how we, as a community of neighbors, can live in peace. I believe the time has come to create a new Pacific community built on shared strength, shared prosperity, and a shared commitment to democratic values.
Today I want to discuss the fundamentals of security for that new Pacific community and the role the United States intends to play. I had the opportunity just a few days ago, at the G-7 summit in Tokyo, to travel to Waseda University to talk about the economic aspects of that new partnership. And I think clearly all the economic reforms that we can make will benefit a great market system like Korea. But we must always remember that Security comes first.
Above all, the United States intends to remain actively engaged in this region. 

 	 	 		. . .	 	To some in America there is a fear that America's global leadership is an outdated luxury we can no longer afford. Well, they are wrong. In truth, our global leadership has never been a more indispensable or a more worthwhile investment for us. So long as we remain bordered by oceans and powered by trade, so long as our flag is the symbol of democracy and hope to a fractious world, the imperative of America's leadership will remain.
I believe there are four priorities for the security of our new Pacific community. First, a continued American military commitment to this region; second, stronger efforts to combat the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction; third, new regional dialogues on the full range of our common security challenges; and last, support for democracy and more open societies throughout this region.
 
Continued U.S. Military Presence

The bedrock of America's security role in the Asian-Pacific must be a continued military presence. In a period of change, we need to preserve what has been reliable. Today we therefore affirm our five bilateral security agreements with Korea, with Japan, with Australia, with the Philippines, and with Thailand. Those agreements work because they serve the interests of each of the states. They enable U.S. armed forces to maintain a substantial forward presence. At the same time, they have enabled Asia to focus less energy on an arms race and more energy on the peaceful race toward economic development and opportunity for the peoples of this region.
The contribution Japan and Korea make to defray the costs of stationing our forces underscores the importance of that presence to both of those countries. There is no better example of that commitment than our alliance with your nation. As the cold war recedes into history, a divided Korea remains one of its most bitter legacies. Our nation has always joined yours in believing that one day Korea's artificial division will end.
We support Korea's peaceful unification on terms acceptable to the Korean people. And when the re-unification comes, we will stand beside you in making the transition on the terms that you have outlined. But that day has not yet arrived. The demilitarized zone still traces a stark line between safety and danger.

 	 	 		. . .	 	So, let me say clearly, our commitment to Korea's security remains undiminished. The Korean peninsula remains a vital American interest. Our troops will stay here as long as the Korean people want and need us here.
We lost tens of thousands of America's best in Korea's mountains and mud and sky. But Korea lost millions. That sacrifice affirms some old truths; vulnerability invites aggression, peace depends upon deterrence. We cannot forget those lessons again. And so it is throughout the region. Our commitment to an active military presence remains. Our mutual agreement with the Philippines to close our bases there should not be cause for Asian alarm. The larger picture tells a different story.
We have obtained increased access for our forces throughout Southeast Asia, to facilitate our presence and, if necessary, to project our forces beyond the region. Here in Korea we have frozen American troop withdrawals and are modernizing Korean and American forces on the peninsula. We have deployed to Japan the Belleau Wood amphibious group and the U.S.S. Independence battle group, the largest and most modern in the world. These are not signs of disengagement. These are signs that America intends to stay.
 
The Threat of Nuclear Arms
 The second security priority for our new Pacific community is to combat the spread of weapons of mass destruction and their means of delivery. We cannot let the expanding threat of these deadly weapons replace the cold war nightmare of nuclear annihilation. Today that possibility is too real. North Korea appears committed to indiscriminate sales of the Scud missiles that were such a source of terror and destruction in the Persian Gulf. Now it is developing, testing and looking to export a more powerful missile with a range of 600 miles or more; enough for North Korea to threaten Osaka, or for Iran to threaten Tel Aviv.
We have serious concerns as well about China's compliance with international standards against missile proliferation. And, since both you and we are attempting to engage China in a more extensive trade relationship, I hope together we can have a positive influence against that development.
The Pacific nations simply must develop new ways to combat the spread of biological, chemical and missile technologies. And, in the coming weeks, the U.S. will propose new efforts aimed at that goal. But no specter hangs over this peninsula or this region more darkly than the danger of nuclear proliferation. Nearly 160 nations have now joined to resist that threat through the nuclear nonproliferation treaty, the most universally supported treaty in all history.
Now, for the first time since that treaty was opened for signatures, one of its members has threatened to withdraw. Our goal has remained firm. We seek a nonnuclear Korean peninsula and robust global rules against proliferation. That is why we urge North Korea to reaffirm its commitment to the nonproliferation treaty, to fulfill scope safeguards obligations to the International Atomic Energy Agency, including I.A.E.A. inspections of undeclared nuclear sites, and to implement bilateral inspections under the South-North nuclear accord.
Our goal is not endless discussions, but certifiable compliance. North Korea must understand our intentions. We are seeking to prevent aggression, not to initiate it, and so long as North Korea abides by the U.N. charter and international nonproliferation commitments, it has nothing to fear from America.

 	 	 		. . .	 	The many economic discussions within the region also can play a role. . . .
The goal of all these efforts is to integrate, not isolate, the region's powers. China is a key example. We believe China cannot be a full partner in the world community until it respects human rights and international agreements on trade and weapons sales, but we also are prepared to involve China in building this region's new security and economic architecture. We need an involved and engaged China, not an isolated China.
Some in the U.S. have been reluctant to enter in to a regional security dialogue in Asia. They fear it would seem a pretext for American withdrawal from the area, but I see this as a way to supplement our alliances and forward military presence, not to supplant them. These dialogues can ensure that the end of the cold war does not provide an opening for regional rivalry, chaos, and arms races. They can build a foundation for our shared security well into the 21st century.
Ultimately, the guarantee of our security must rest in the character and the intentions of the region's nations themselves.

HEADLINE: Prostrate Haiti Looking to Foreign Aid for a Lift

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, July 9

 BODY:
The economic data pieced together here by foreign experts in recent weeks read like those of a country emerging from a devastating war: unemployment of more than 40 percent, uncontrolled inflation and a poverty line cutting off 70 percent or more of the population.
But even these figures do not give a full picture of the damage wrought not by armed conflict, but by nearly two years of political strife and mismanagement as well as international sanctions intended to help force the restoration of democracy after a coup by the Haitian military in September 1991. 
 Already the poorest country in the hemisphere before the overthrow of its first democratically elected President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, Haiti has been turned into an economic wasteland whose resurrection, experts say, will require hundreds of millions in aid and years of the kind of determined and judicious management that Haiti has rarely experienced in the past.
The settlement signed a week ago by Father Aristide and the Haitian military commander has lent momentum to international plans for economic aid, which revolve around creating 75,000 or more jobs in the country in the first year after Father Aristide's scheduled return to office on Oct. 30. Many of those jobs will involve unskilled labor in basic public works projects in neglected areas like sanitation and road repair.
 
U.S. Pledges $37.5 Million
 In its first year, the aid program will require more than $170 million from international donors. The United States recently pledged $37.5 million, and is expected to give more.
Over the longer term, experts say their hope is not just to put money in empty pockets, but to build a new Haitian economy.
The damage to Haiti's existing economy is visible everywhere. At an industrial park on the edge of the capital that blossomed in the 1980's to become the country's largest foreign exchange earner, only silence emanates from row after row of the hangarlike buildings where clothing was stitched and electronic components were soldered a few years ago.
On downtown streets that once bustled with vendors and chaotic traffic, cars are few and the trade is gone.
"My father died because I couldn't buy him medicine; now I can't feed my children because there is no more business," said Marceline Dukens, a produce vendor who has been trying to save up enough money for car fare to reach her village. "Please give me something so that I can take my family out of town."
 
Thousands Leave Capital
 Her appeal is a common one these days. With inflation running over 60 percent and business virtually dead, thousands of people have left the capital in recent months in the hope of eking out a subsistence in the countryside, where farming and barter have mostly replaced commerce.
The most immediate explanation for Haiti's current suffering is an international oil embargo imposed only last month by the United Nations. Although it forced the army to accept a political accord providing for Father Aristide's return, it has also had a crushing effect on almost everyone.
The flow of electricity in the capital, which depends on oil, is now down to less than 12 hours a day in most areas. Under a strict rationing program, cars lining up at gas stations snake around city blocks or, as is often the case where discipline breaks down, turn entire streets into helter-skelter parking lots.
"We will be lucky if our factory can make it through the end of next week," said a producer of fertilizers of the effect of the oil embargo. He requested anonymity so as "not to scare off foreign customers."
But if the oil sanctions are the most visible symbol of the country's woes, they are perhaps the most easily settled. They are to be lifted once Haiti's Parliament purges lawmakers who were elected in a fraudulent vote in January and then ratifies Father Aristide's choice of a new Prime Minister.
 
Economy in Stagnation
 "What you have is an economy that has been in stagnation since 1987," said Alberto Favilla, an economist and former World Bank official who has led efforts to put together an international recovery package for Haiti. "Virtually every sector has suffered severe damage, from agriculture and export industry to infrastructure. Government has done nothing to take care of the country, not so much as maintain roads or irrigation canals."
At the root of the economic crisis, economists say, is a sharply divided class system in Haiti that allows the wealthy few to thrive almost regardless of the plight of the rest of the population. The elite relies on rigged markets to preserve longstanding monopolies, the lack of tax collection and an institutionalized corruption that allows big importers to bring their goods into the country without paying duties or even standard port fees.
"Haiti has what you could call a franchise economy, where members of the elite have carved out their own niches and in effect employ the Government and the army to protect their holdings," said one expert on the Haitian economy, speaking on condition that he not be identified.
The system, which has evolved over decades, is so entrenched that ordinary public services, from schools and hospitals to fire stations and drinking water, have never been created for the general population.
Experts involved in planning the aid package for Haiti say it will seek not only to create new economic activity quickly and ease suffering, but also to redress the imbalances in the hope of creating a more stable and just political climate.
"What we are talking about is making a viable country where there was none before," said a diplomat who has been closely involved in the aid planning. "That means not only short-term aid, but longer term things like helping rebuild government ministries and developing Haitian expertise."
As prospects of Father Aristide's return to power have improved in recent months, diplomats say, so has the involvement of the President's aides in shaping policy decisions and economic planning in ways they hope will allow the program to get off the ground quickly.
 
Miami Meeting Planned
 Father Aristide, a populist priest viewed by many in the Haitian elite as an enemy, has been reaching out to some of the country's most conservative business leaders, inviting many of them to a meeting planned in Miami later this month aimed at allaying their fears.
"The President wants to tell them that he wants to work with them, not go after them," said Robert Malval, a businessman who is expected to be Father Aristide's choice for Prime Minister. "If we are going to rebuild this country, the President has said that everyone who rejects crime and corruption will have a place."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Already the poorest country in the hemisphere before the overthrow of its first democratically elected President, Haiti has been turned into an economic wasteland by nearly two years of strife, mismanagement and sanctions. A charcoal wholesaler waited for customers in Port-au-Prince. (Daniel Morel for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: IRAQ SEEKS TO KEEP MISSILE SITES OPEN

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 10

 BODY:
Saddam Hussein faces a new confrontation with the Security Council this weekend over the elimination of Iraq's weapons of mass destruction unless he allows United Nations inspectors to seal two missile-testing stations close to the capital, rendering them useless.
Today the Government made a counteroffer, saying it would give the inspectors constant access to the sites if they did not place seals on the buildings and equipment there, officials here said. 
 The United Nations special commission charged with eliminating Iraq's weapons of mass destruction tonight debated how to react to the Iraqi proposal. But it told its inspectors to visit the sites Sunday in any case.
Earlier today, the chief United Nations inspector expressed optimism that Iraq was ready to comply and let the sites be closed on Sunday.
"I have every confidence they will allow us to install the seals," said the team's leader, Mark Silver of the United States, adding that he had "no reason to believe" the Iraqis would block his mission. The two sites are about 40 miles south of Baghdad.
Other United Nations officials were similarly optimistic. They argued that any attempt to thwart the inspectors now would jeopardize plans for a United Nations review of Iraq's compliance with the terms of the cease-fire that ended the Persian Gulf war. Among the terms is the destruction of Iraq's most dangerous weapons.
 
Review Sought by Iraq
 Baghdad has asked for such a review as part of talks now under way in New York on easing the embargo on oil sales by Iraq so it can raise money for imports of food and medicine.
The United Nations special commission has demanded that the two missile-testing stations be neutralized until Iraq agrees to install surveillance cameras to insure it does not try to develop long-range missiles, which it is banned from doing under the terms of the cease-fire.
In South Korea, President Clinton warned that any further Iraqi defiance could lead to a new United States attack. In late June, the United States fired cruise missiles at an Iraqi intelligence compound in retaliation for Iraq's reported involvement in what Washington said was a bomb plot against George Bush during his visit to Kuwait in April.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher also warned that any further Iraqi obstruction would provoke a severe reaction. If Iraq refuses to cooperate, he told an American television interviewer, the special commission will order Baghdad to destroy both testing stations. "If that isn't done, the United Nations will have to react," he said, clearly hinting of another possible strike.
Since the end of the gulf war, Iraq has been striving to re-equip its forces and rebuild its military industry. United Nations officials here say Baghdad needs the two testing stations for development of a new surface-to-surface missile; the missile would have a range of about 50 miles, well below the 100-mile limit set by the cease-fire agreement.
But after three years of an increasingly debilitating economic embargo, Baghdad is also making an earnest effort to convince the Security Council that it is complying with the main terms of the cease-fire, the elimination of its most dangerous weapons, and should be rewarded by some easing of the sanctions.
 
Some Conciliatory Gestures
 Baghdad has made conciliatory gestures in other fields. It has reopened the talks with the United Nations that it broke off on partly lifting the ban on oil sales, and some days ago it ended its intermittent jamming of the Arabic broadcasts by the Voice of America, the BBC and Radio Monte Carlo.
In the dispute over the missile-testing sites, Baghdad has been careful not to reject outright the installation of surveillance cameras. Instead it asked the special commission first to review its compliance record and to explain what more Baghdad must do to meet all the terms of the cease-fire.
The commission responded by saying that if the sites were sealed by Sunday, it would invite an Iraqi team to New York to review compliance and prepare for further high-level talks in Baghdad later this month.
The commission remains dissatisfied with Baghdad's position on several other issues. It wants Iraq to provide a full list of all foreign companies that provided sensitive technology for weapons, and wants a full account of how these programs were organized and run. Finally, it wants Iraq to accept a plan for the long-term monitoring of its military industries.
But even if Iraq meets all these conditions, the Security Council seems unlikely to agree soon to any easing in sanctions, beyond possibly permitting some oil sales to allow Iraq to buy some essential goods, diplomats here say.
This is because the United States and its allies say the sanctions cannot be lifted fully until Iraq has complied with all other relevant Security Council resolutions.
Such compliance would mean that Iraq must accept the new and unfavorable frontier with Kuwait that the United Nations surveyed after the gulf war. It would also have to lift its economic blockade of the Kurds in the north and end harassment of Shiite dissidents in the south.

HEADLINE: Haven in Rio Quite Hostile For Angolans

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 10

 BODY:
Keeping one step ahead of Angola's political police, Manuel Neto dreamed only six months ago of escaping across the South Atlantic to Brazil.
"The Brazilians I worked with in Angola were nice," the Angolan refugee reminisced of managers of Angolan diamond mines. "We spoke the same language, Portuguese. I thought we were from one family." 
 But after arriving here in February, the 28-year-old business graduate quickly discovered that Rio de Janeiro's reputed open-arms welcome does not necessarily extend to Africans.
In April, Rio's Mayor, Cesar Maia, complained in a letter to Brazil's Foreign Ministry that the Angolan war refugees were bringing a new strain of the AIDS virus to Brazil, posing "a serious epidemiological risk."
 
The Mayor's Demands
 Mr. Maia, who lived as a political exile in Chile only 20 years ago, demanded that fewer tourist visas be issued to Angolans, that visa applicants be tested for AIDS in Angola, and that Angolan tourists who apply for political asylum in Rio be more "fairly" distributed among Brazilian cities.
"The sudden arrival of thousands of foreigners causes a real and negative impact," wrote the Mayor, whose beachfront city annually welcomes thousands of tourists from Europe and the United States.
Mr. Maia backtracked after the Foreign Ministry retorted that there was no medical evidence that the Angolan refugees carried H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. As many as a million Brazilians are infected with the virus.
But the Mayor's outburst reflects the widespread hostility here against the Angolans, who are easily identified by their tightly cropped hair.
"The Brazilians curse at us a lot," said Mr. Neto, who lives here with his wife, Maimona Dosimao. "One day I was walking with three other refugees, and a man pulled out a pistol and started shouting at us."
 
Racism and Desperation
 Rio's cold shoulder seems to result from centuries-old racism and from desperation linked to a deep recession.
"Some man shouted at me, 'We are going to kill you -- you are living off the Government,' " said another refugee, Agostinho Modizo.
In the last three months, one African was shot in the leg and another was stabbed in the stomach.
The recent surge in Angolan refugees began after Angola's main opposition group, Unita, the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, refused to accept its loss in elections last September and resumed its 18-year guerrilla war.
"A truckload of Government police raped my mother, father and brothers and then killed them all," said Mr. Neto, whose father directed Unita's election propaganda in the Angolan capital, Luanda. After they were killed, he said, a family friend obtained a Brazilian visa for him and bribed airport officials to let him board the once-a-week flight from Luanda to Rio.
Since November, about 1,500 Angolans have sought refuge in Rio, the Angolan consulate here estimates, and about half have formally applied for political asylum with the United Nations High Commissioner on Refugees.
 
Restrictions on Visas
 Several refugees interviewed here said the Brazilian Embassy had been the only one in Luanda issuing tourist visas. Brazil was the first country to establish relations with Angola after the West African country gained independence from Portugal in 1975. It has also cultivated trade and investment links with Angola, which is rich in oil.
But after issuing 1,506 visas to Angolans last December, Brazil tightened restrictions, reducing the number of visas issued in March to 170.
Using $70,000 a month from the United Nations High Commissioner on Refugees, the Roman Catholic charity Caritas provides each registered refugee with two meals a day and lodging in a $1.60-a-night boardinghouse. Contrary to a common perception here, Brazil's Government does not provide aid.
"By the end of the year, most of the refugees will have working papers," said Heloisa Santos Nunes, a Caritas social worker.
Although about half of Brazil's 155 million people trace all or part of their ancestry back to West Africa, Brazil barred non-European refugees from settling here until 1989. Judging from the hostility that Angolans have encountered, many Brazilians apparently would like to return to the racially exclusive policy.
 
Shifts in Immigration
 A nation molded by immigrants, Brazil stopped attracting emigres from Europe and Japan about 30 years ago. In the 1980's, Brazil reversed roles and started to export people. Today, an estimated one million Brazilians live overseas, fleeing a country in which population growth has outpaced economic growth and inflation is running at 30 percent a month.
Bleak as it may seem to Brazilians, life here is a step up for refugees from Angola, a country where the civil war grinds on without end.
So far, few people have offered to help the Angolans.
For example, Rio's black groups have long stressed their cultural links to Angola, since most of Rio's large black population is descended from Africans imported from Angola as slaves in the 18th and 19th centuries. . But Candido Feliciano da Ponte Neto, the director here of Caritas, said not one group has contacted the refugees.
"Frankly, we don't have anything to offer other than words of solidarity," said Amaury Mendes Pereira, president of the Institute for the Research of Black Cultures. "Our own movement is very precarious."

HEADLINE: Detroit's Papers Under Fire At Trial of Officers in Beating

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 9

 BODY:
The court and the news media were at odds again this week in the trial of three white former police officers accused of beating an unemployed black steelworker to death on Nov. 5.
Judge George W. Crockett 3d, who has made no secret of his mistrust of the local newspapers, threatened to hold a photographer and editor in contempt of court after their newspaper published a photograph of a prosecution witness standing outside the courthouse. 
 Cameras have been permitted in the courtroom throughout the trial, but when one witness asked that he not be photographed, Judge Crockett granted the request. The judge's order did not specify time or place.
Richard Lee, a photographer with The Detroit Free Press, took a picture of the witness outside the courthouse after he finished testifying, and the newspaper published the photo on Wednesday. The witness, Byron Gibbs, had reported to two of the defendants that his car, which was similar to the victim's car, was missing.
The prosecution sought a contempt ruling against Mr. Lee, saying he had violated the judge's order. The court cited both Mr. Lee and the newspaper's city editor, Carole Leigh Hutton.
Lawyers for The Free Press said Mr. Lee had not disobeyed the order because he had taken no photographs of the witness inside the courthouse. Barring photographs in public places would violate First Amendment press freedoms, they said.
Ms. Hutton, they added, should be dropped from the citation because she had no role in deciding to publish the photo.
With Mr. Lee and Ms. Hutton in the courtroom on Friday, the judge demanded that a newspaper lawyer, Michael Gruskin, identify the editor responsible for publishing the photo. Mr. Gruskin, after consulting with the editor and the photographer, said he was unable to name the person who made the final decision.
"How does one get a paper that has something in it if nobody's responsible for what gets in there?" the judge asked. "Does it grow like Topsy?"
At yesterday's court hearing, which was originally to have been on the contempt charges, Judge Crockett granted the newspaper's request to transfer the case to another judge. The contempt citation is now scheduled to be heard by Judge Dalton A. Roberson on Sept. 22. Judge Roberson agreed to drop Ms. Hutton from the case on the condition that The Free Press identify the responsible editor.
Earlier in the trial, Judge Crockett found an intern with The Detroit News in contempt for telephoning a juror at home. He sentenced the 23-year-old intern to five days in jail and ordered him to spend part of that time in the courtroom, dressed in prison garb. The sentence was stayed by the Michigan Court of Appeals until a review is done.
 
Years of Mistrust
 During the earlier contempt proceedings, Judge Crockett voiced his desire to hold editors accountable for the intern's actions. He also said he had mistrusted The Detroit News since age 9 because of the newspaper's coverage of his father, former Representative George Crockett Jr. In 1952, The News printed, then retracted, a headline implying that the elder Crockett belonged to the Communist Party.
The trial in the fatal beating of Malice Green, which began last month, has attracted considerable attention, in part because of its echoes of the Rodney G. King beating case in Los Angeles last year.
The three officers were dismissed after Mr. Green's death. Two, Walter Budzyn and Larry Nevers, now face second-degree murder charges, while the third, Robert Lessnau, is charged with assault.
Earlier this week, a sergeant in the Police Department's homicide division testified that police officers had altered evidence at the scene of the beating and failed to provide complete details about the case to investigators.
Mr. Green was beaten inside and outside his car as the officers questioned him outside a house in which crack cocaine was used.
Sgt. Kenneth Day testified Thursday that he had become angry with the officer who had arrived to take charge while Mr. Green was being beaten. He said the officer, Sgt. Freddie Douglas, failed to tell him that blood had been wiped from the officers' flashlights and from the inside of Mr. Green's car, and that Mr. Green's car had been moved.
A charge of involuntary manslaughter against Sergeant Douglas was dismissed, but he still faces a lesser charge of willful neglect of duty. He was also dismissed from the police force, and awaits a separate trial.

HEADLINE: UConn Plans Tuition Rise And Layoffs

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: GROTON, Conn., July 10

 BODY:
Tuition at the University of Connecticut will rise 10 percent in 1994-95 and some part-time faculty members will lose their jobs this fall, the school's trustees have decided.
This is the sixth consecutive year that the university has called for a double-digit tuition increase. Over five years, tuition has doubled and the university has trimmed about one-fifth of its faculty and staff. 
 At a meeting at the university's Avery Point campus on Friday, trustees said they hoped for an end to the university's financial crisis and set a goal of not increasing tuition more than the cost-of-living index.
The trustees adopted a $281 million operating budget for 1993-94, almost 2 percent higher than last year's budget. The state will pay $136 million of the new operating budget, up about 10 percent from last year's figure but less than what the state spent five years earlier.
In addition to the tuition increase, the school increased room and board 6.7 percent for undergraduates.
Counting room, board, tuition and university fees, an in-state undergraduate on the Storrs campus will pay $9,784 to attend the university in 1994-95, up from $9,168 this fall.
Despite the increase, the university expects to make more budget cuts, including laying off some part-time faculty members who would have taught about 150 class sections during the 1993-94 school year.
A slumping state economy and rising inflation have been a painful combination for the university.
"It's impacting us every time we turn around," said Peter Isidro-Cloudas, a graduate student who is to join the board of trustees later this year. "Students feel they're paying more and more and getting less and less."
Michael Taylor, a student trustee from Hartford, said the board should do all it can to limit future tuition increases.
"We can't just assume students can continue to pay a 10 percent increase and another 10 percent increase," Mr. Taylor said. "Eventually the money is not going to be there."

HEADLINE: Beyond Budget Demagoguery

 BODY:
Anti-tax rhetoric poses a threat to common sense when Congressional conferees meet this week to begin the arduous task of reconciling the House and Senate budget bills.
Each bill would trim about $500 billion from projected deficits over the next five years primarily by cutting defense spending and raising taxes on families with taxable income over $100,000. But the House would tax and spend about $30 billion more than the Senate. 
 No matter how the conferees try to slice this difference, they risk losing Congressional approval because each budget bill passed by a razor-thin margin. Worse yet, a demagogic anti-tax campaign waged by the Republican National Committee is poisoning the atmosphere for compromise.
To hear Bob Dole, the Senate minority leader, tell it, tax hikes wound the economy but spending cuts heal. Never mind that some economists say spending cuts hurt the economy more in the short run than do tax hikes. Or that in the long run, no one could measure the difference.
The Republicans, to measure the worth of a budget plan, have nevertheless seized upon the ratio of spending cuts to tax hikes. Their implication is that, if spending cuts don't at least equal tax hikes, the economy will suffer. Yet the ratio is arbitrarily measured -- much of what the G.O.P. calls spending cuts are really tax hikes. Even so, the scare tactics are taking their toll -- warping policy because the conferees are afraid to face voters in the face of Mr. Dole's attacks.
There are honorable ways to close the gap between liberal Democrats in the House, who are demanding higher taxes to pay for programs targeted at the poor and urban ghettos, and conservatives in the Senate, who want lower taxes and less spending. If the conferees artfully set an energy tax about halfway between the Senate and House bills, they can accommodate the liberals without running roughshod over the conservatives.
The House passed a $70 billion B.T.U. energy tax. But Senate Democrats from oil-producing states rejected that option in favor of a far smaller $20 billion tax on transportation fuels, primarily gasoline. To make up for the $50 billion in lost revenue, the Senate took money out of Medicare, urban enterprise zones, subsidies for low-paid workers, food stamps and other programs targeted at the poor. These are programs that the Black Caucus and other liberals in the House say must be included or else they will reject the budget plan.
One way out of the morass is to start with the Senate gas tax and raise another $20 billion through a small sales tax on electricity and home heating oil sold to consumers. That tax combination would be less painful than the B.T.U. tax because it would not fall on employers and would hit Americans across the country by about the same amount.
About $16 billion of the extra money so raised could reinstate the House's programs for the poor: tax credits for low-paid workers, food stamps, child immunizations and foster care. These programs are needed if Congress is to deliver on President Clinton's noble pledge to make work pay -- by making sure families with at least one full-time worker no longer live in poverty.
Another $4 billion could reinstate Mr. Clinton's proposal to create a small number of urban enterprise zones -- blighted areas where businesses would qualify for subsidies if they created jobs for residents. States have experimented with enterprise zones without notable success. But Mr. Clinton proposes to create what amounts to a small demonstration to see whether Federal zones could work better; the experiment is worth trying.
Not worth trying are the extra tax breaks for small businesses and real estate investors passed by the House. They amount to little more than a $10 billion giveaway.
These changes would skew the ratio of spending cuts to tax hikes toward the latter. But the true measure of a budget is not whether it meets a meaningless ratio; it is whether it provides for economic growth while caring for the poor. That goal is within the conferees' grasp.

HEADLINE: A Stealthy, Evasive Confession

 BODY:
When the White House was getting ready to fire all seven employees of its travel office, why was notice sent to Hillary Rodham Clinton and not her husband the President? And why, even after the public had learned how Clinton friends engineered the travel office flushout, did the staff feed President Clinton the discredited line that the firings were simply economy measures?
These are among many questions that remain unanswered after the White House release of what it styles as a "management review" of the travel office fiasco that unraveled in May. Thomas McLarty, the chief of staff, hoping to contain the scandal, calls his report "complete and thorough." 
 But his accounting is replete with the "mistakes were made" format of White House dodges of the past. The mistakes, the report insists, were simply bad judgment and inexperience, nothing venal. The report's confessions were delivered almost by stealth on July 2, presumably in hopes that anyone interested in its contents would be safely at the beach. In any event, more than mistakes were made: Misstatements were made and wrongs were committed.
The report commendably concludes that the travel office employees were cashiered without "sensitivity and decency," that assigning a Clinton cousin to replace them "fed the appearance of favoritism" in dishing out a White House perk, and that it was "not a good practice" to give Clinton friend Harry Thomason roaming privileges in the White House and not cut off his interventions for his business associates. But surely more than appearances were involved here. Mr. Clinton's friends and relatives abused their White House access to gain advantages for themselves or for their cronies.
The White House also acquits itself of anything much worse than bad appearances in the abuse of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The staff summoned an F.B.I. official to bolster insinuations that the travel office, instead of being reshuffled for friends, was under investigation for possible criminality. That maneuver, along with suggestions that the Internal Revenue Service might be called in, didn't just look bad. It was bad.
The White House management study says the First Lady inquired about the travel office and was sent a copy of a memo about the impending firings. No one seems to have asked the nature of her interest. The study also says that Bernard Nussbaum, the White House counsel, and two members of his legal staff attended that key meeting with the F.B.I. official. No one asked why Mr. Nussbaum, the in-house ethical watchdog, didn't intervene to stop the obvious pressure on the bureau to make the travel office look crooked as well as inefficient.
The management study concludes that it was wrong to tell reporters that the F.B.I. was probing for criminality but doesn't repent the rest of the White House tale: that the probe of the travel office began as a routine part of Vice President Al Gore's efficiency survey. President Clinton's staff kept giving him that line to sell to the public long after the public had rejected it.
Attorney General Janet Reno may not find criminal abuse of office when she reads this management review. But the Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole, however partisan his impulses, is on the right track to call for a Congressional look at this catalogue of mistakes and deception.

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
Globe-Trotting Clinton Faces Trip's Side Effects

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEOUL, Korea, July 10

 BODY:
If you are the President of the United States, traveling the world has its benefits. There are big planes to fly in, large crowds to cheer and police-escorted motorcades that whisk you through dizzying rush-hour traffic.
But there are side effects that even a President cannot avoid. For Mr. Clinton and the White House officials armed with briefing books and draft communiques, the chief enemy has been jet lag. Tokyo and Seoul are seven time zones away from San Francisco. 
 With Mr. Clinton, who has confessed that he makes his worst mistakes when he is overtired, the first few days of his trip to Asia were a fatigue test. But by Friday, when his advisers in Tokyo were still walking into walls after a week of virtually round-the-clock trade negotiations, the President declared he had conquered his weariness.
He spoke too soon. Today, after taping his weekly radio address in the wee hours and staying up even later, past 2 A.M., to work on a trade agreement with Japan, Mr. Clinton's eyes were puffy and his voice betrayed his exhaustion.
A portion of the radio address broadcast in error tonight in the traveling White House press room showed a punchy Mr. Clinton telling part of an incomprehensible joke into the open microphone, apparently about someone losing a job at a Bridgestone tire plant in Arkansas. Laughing, he was heard saying "It was funny as hell."
 
A Few Social Gaffes
 It is little wonder that the President was feeling silly when you consider his schedule today.
Mr. Clinton shuttled from a breakfast and news conference with President Boris N. Yeltsin to an announcement with Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa. By midafternoon he was in South Korea, where he met with President Kim Young Sam and appeared before reporters for the third time today.
By this evening, he and his wife, Hillary, were toasting their hosts at a state dinner at Blue House, the presidential residence.
A faux pas at the dinner might have been attributable to tiredness. Mr. Clinton referred to the First Lady of South Korea as "Mrs. Kim," The Associated Press reported, instead of using her own name, Sohn Myong Suk, or Mrs. Sohn, as is the custom here.
And, trying to correct some translating awkwardness earlier in the day, the President asked his translator to stand between him and President Kim, The A.P. added, a bit of logistics that the Koreans took as a slight, however unintentional, of their leader.
Aside from the protocol blunders, more evident to the Koreans than to the Americans, the dinner for 90 people appeared otherwise successful.
"All of you would agree that this room is full of warmth and friendship," President Kim told his guests.
Mr. and Mrs. Clinton are planning to meet their daughter, Chelsea, on Monday in Hawaii for a short family vacation. But even then, the two do not plan to rest immediately. Unable to resist the chance to shake another few hands, Mr. Clinton has scheduled a rally in Honolulu for Sunday afternoon.
 
Mrs. Clinton to Break Silence
 Hillary Rodham Clinton, who has been the curiously quiet spouse during much of the Asia trip, is apparently going to break her silence almost as soon as she returns to American soil, at a health-care forum Tuesday in Hawaii.
Mrs. Clinton has been the model of a 1960's retro wife this week as she and her husband and mother have traveled in Asia. She is popular everywhere she goes, whether traveling by rail to a Buddhist temple or sitting and nodding as her husband delivers a speech.
As she has traveled, however, reporters have been explicitly warned to ask her no questions. When a few hardy souls tried, they received scarcely an acknowledgement.
No White House official will say why Mrs. Clinton has kept her profile so low, but they were chagrined earlier this week when Mr. Clinton's reaction to a question about her upstaged a weighty speech the President had just delivered.
And when the President was asked point blank whether his wife was being kept under wraps as he worked to establish his reputation on the world stage, he insisted that "she did what she wanted to do."
Could be. But while Mr. Clinton met with President Kim at Blue House today, Mrs. Clinton met with Mrs. Sohn, the President's wife. Local television showed her repeatedly smiling, waving and, at one point, walking several steps behind her husband.
And when she finally spoke, it was to say, "I'm having a wonderful time. I'm so pleased to be here with Mrs. Kim in this beautiful house."
 
Gergen's High Profile
 For a man who has claimed to be interested in keeping his head down, David R. Gergen, the Presidential counselor who was recruited with great spectacle to help get the White House on track, was certainly on track for overexposure.
Mr. Gergen was responsible for a dizzying amount of political spin this week. To hear him tell it, Mr. Clinton was responsible for every victory at the economic summit conference in Tokyo and was aware of no setbacks.
Day after day, he assembled groups of Administration officials to tell the hundreds of reporters working in a hotel ballroom in Tokyo how wonderfully the President was doing.
And minutes after the White House announced a successful conclusion to the trade talks with Japan, Mr. Gergen pulled reporters aside to tell them a story about how the Japanese negotiators had been so divided that they had resorted to fisticuffs in a hotel lobby.
Mr. Gergen's constant televised presence and gravelly voice shoved the usual spokesmen -- the press secretary Dee Dee Myers and the communications director Mark Gearan -- into the shadows.
On the theory that a good offense is the best defense, Mr. Gergen often leapt into his spin control at times when no one had any questions they particularly wanted answered.
As the President was preparing to hold a news conference that was broadcast live on some morning television news shows, Mr. Gergen scrambled to the lectern to "clear the decks." That is, he wanted to ferret out questions he hoped the President would not have to answer on the air. Unfortunately for him, the line of questioning turned to whether Mr. Clinton had made a decision on lifting the ban on homosexuals in the military. Mr. Gergen quickly cut off questioning and introduced another official to talk about aid to Russia instead.
But it is hard to take issue with a strategy that works. Mr. Clinton's visits to Tokyo and Seoul were generally well received both in Asia and in the newspaper and television reports of his visit that reached voters back home.
"Thank you," Mr. Gergen said at the end of one late-night briefing that dragged on much longer than was warranted by the information it contained. "I'll be back sooner than you'll probably appreciate."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL'S KING OF THE ROAD;
Jack Lazorko Doesn't Pitch Here Anymore

BYLINE: By IRA BERKOW, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROCKWALL, Tex.

 BODY:
Maybe you've never heard of Jack Lazorko, the 37-year-old right-handed pitcher who is as compact as a tugboat and is called "Il Bulldog" in Italy, "El Bulldog" in Latin America and "Zork" in the States.
Maybe you've never seen him play, his dark brows over intense hazel eyes, armed with an assortment of pitches from forkballs to knuckle curves to sliders to fastballs that dip and fastballs that rise -- none of which will blow anyone away, as he describes it, but all of which are invariably around the plate and always carry a purpose. 
 While he is hardly a household name, fans in hundreds of the most unlikely towns around the world plus a legion of people in baseball -- from players to executives -- knows him, or of him. After all, he played for or with or against many of those in baseball. Maybe most of them.
"Sometimes," he said, "it feels like all of them."
Few baseball careers have been anything like Jack Lazorko's, who was born in Hoboken, N.J., and grew up in River Edge to the north, and who has called so many places home since then that, he says, he has single-handedly kept map makers in business.
Maybe you haven't followed his career for the past 16 years, as he played for nine major league organizations and 17 of their teams, and maybe a dozen more teams in the Caribbean and Mexico and South America and Europe. This year alone, he has worn the uniform of the Yankees (in spring training) and of the Norfolk Tides, the Mets' Class AAA team. When a call was made recently to the Tides' executive office, it was asked whether Jack Lazorko was there.
"Not anymore," came the reply. Gone after seven games.
It is, in a nutshell, the story of Jack Thomas Lazorko's baseball life.
"I've been released by more teams in more leagues in more countries and in more languages than anyone in the history of baseball," Lazorko said one day last week. "And I'm the only man to have been released by both the Mets and the Yankees in the same year -- within four months!" He shakes his head and smiles wryly. "Unbelievable."
Unbelievable because, as he said recently at his home here, "I always seem to be the 11th man on a 10-man pitching staff."
He is currently unemployed. Again. But that could change tomorrow. Or the next day. He is ready. He says he has learned to pack in 10 minutes, and that's for a six-month trip, if necessary. He asks two questions of his new team: "What color spikes do you wear?" And "what color sleeves?" He has in his closet piles of various colored baseball shoes and piles of sweatshirts. In his attic above the garage are several dozen suitcases, hanging bags and equipment bags. One day last May his wife and children drove into the garage, and the 7-year-old, Mitch, noticing that the foldable stairs to the attic had been pulled down, said, "Oh, Daddy's got a job."
"But this year might be the turning point, when I start to think of something else, a normal job, maybe like coaching," said Lazorko. "It's come to that."
Lazorko has played at all levels of amateur and professional baseball, from rookie league to the major leagues. He has played in the United States and Canada and Mexico and Latin America and Europe, for teams ranging from the El Paso Diablos to the Tulsa Drillers to the Phoenix Fire Birds to the Wichita Aeros to the Asheville Tourists to the Sun City Rays (in the Senior League) and on to, among others, the Calgary Cannons, Edmonton Trappers, Los Mochis (Mexico) Caneros, Santurce (P.R.) Crabbers, Valencia (Venezuela) Magallenes and Parma (Italy) Angels. Just recently he joined a team called the Hollywood Legends, which played and won a weeklong European tournament in Belgium.
Maybe you weren't aware of Jack Lazorko's brief pitching stints in the major leagues in parts of five years in the 1980's with Milwaukee, Seattle, Detroit and California (twice) as a spot starter, middle reliever and infrequent closer -- and that it took him three years to notch his first victory in the big leagues (he has five victories against eight losses, two saves and a 4.22 earned run average in 69 games.) The last time he appeared in the major leagues was in 1988, with the Angels.
Maybe you didn't see him pitching with his customary aggressiveness in the dead heat of Managua, Nicaragua, where he and his teammates were protected from antsy local fans by soldiers bearing machine guns, or hurling in the midnight sun in Skelleftea, Sweden, just a three-hour bus ride from the North Pole.
And maybe you haven't seen him throwing in recent days at a screen with a roped-off strike zone in his small backyard here, in this bedroom community just northeast of Dallas, hoping for one more chance at the big leagues, or Japan, or somewhere.
"Every year we say, 'This year, this year won't be crazy like the last one,' " said Brenda, his wife of 15 years. "And every year turns out to be crazy, like the last one, only more so."
"Every year we start out with a plan," Lazorko said. "We have Plan A, Plan B. . . . This year we're on Plan Double Z, and the summer has only just started."
"A lot of people think ball players have it made," said Brenda. "They don't realize that only a relative handful do. And they don't realize the stress involved. Jack has played for 16 one-year contracts. Every time he pitches, his livelihood is on the line. It's got to a point when I'm at a game where I hate to hear the organ play. I know Jack's coming into the game and my stomach starts to churn."
Brenda is a petite blonde with an even disposition, which she has needed, and with the inner strength of a tiger, something that has also been required.
 
2 Christmas Trees And One Suitcase
 "Oh, the times we've had," she said. "Like twice we've bought Christmas trees in places, once in Puerto Rico, once in the Dominican, and we've been sent somewhere else, and we had to sell the trees. Then there was the time we were on a road trip in Hawaii with the Edmonton team and Jack got the call to the big leagues for the first time, to go immediately to play for the Brewers in Baltimore. Well, we had one suitcase, and Jack took it. I had to buy another suitcase to get home with the kids."
Brenda Nanney and Jack Lazorko met when they were in college together at Mississippi State in 1978. He graduated that year with a degree in business administration. The next year Brenda, who got a degree in fashion merchandising, went to visit Jack in Sarasota, Fla., where he was playing in his second professional season.
"As soon as I got there, he was sold to Asheville," she said, speaking of his move from the Houston Astros organization to that of the Texas Rangers. "Right then I should have known."
In the first five or six years of their marriage, they moved 50 or 60 times. "Then we just started to lose count," she said. "It seems that every time I unpacked everything, we were traded or sold. It was like a bad omen. Even when we were in one place for a while -- like we were in Tulsa for a full year -- I still kept all my cosmetics in the bag."
This spring training Lazorko snared a tryout with the Yankees, after many appeals, including some to his former teammate at Mississippi State, Yankee Manager Buck Showalter. "Jack," said Showalter, "is a survivor."
Reggie Jackson came by the clubhouse and noticed the name taped to the locker. "This can't be the same Lazorko who pitched for Seattle years ago," he said. "Yeah, Reggie, that's me," said Lazorko, from behind Jackson. Lazorko was released by the Yankees in March.
 
'Hit the Road, Jack,' Again and Again
 In April, he sent letters and visited teams and called managers and general managers and player personnel directors nationwide and in foreign lands looking for a job. His phone bill for the month was $249. At the end of May he caught on with the Mets and was sent to pitch for the Norfolk Tides. After two games, he was released.
"I got belted a little in the first game, where I gave up two runs in two-thirds of an inning," he said, "but I was a little rusty, not having pitched in a game in two months. But Clint Hurdle, the manager, threw me in the next day and I gave up just one hit. The next thing I know, it's hit the road, Jack."
He is always so close, he feels. So close to reaching his dream of having a fulfilling career as a major league pitcher. This, he says, is more important even than the big bucks he would receive. He sees players he played with in the minor leagues, pitchers like Tom Henke and Ron Darling and Tom Candiotti, among others, making millions of dollars.
The most he ever made was $125,000, when he pitched for Edmonton on a major league contract. In contrast, in his early years in the minors, his first contract was for $500 a month in A ball, around $1,500 in AA ball, but as much as $15,000 a month in Class AAA. But in his lean years, "to make ends meet," he said, he had to pitch winter ball and, on the side, sell radio advertising, storm windows and meat from the back of a truck.
In recent years, though, he has earned a regular, if generally modest, living (especially when you factor the expenses for his peripatetic existence) for Brenda and their three children, 11-year-old Jake, 7-year-old Mitch and 3-year-old Nicky -- all of whom travel with him.
 
An M.V.P. in Italy
 The Lazorkos lived in Italy last season, renting a fourth-floor walk-up in Parma, where he made $90,000 and was named the most valuable player in the Italian League as well as in the championships, which Parma won. He pitched and won the last two games on the same day.
"Traveling the way we have, the kids have got an education you wouldn't believe," said Brenda.
Back in Texas, where Brenda was raised and where, Lazorko said, one can conveniently catch nonstop flights to almost anywhere in the world, the Lazorkos live in a nicely appointed two-story brick house on a street appropriately named "Meandering Way."
Lazorko has been careful with the money he has earned, and has been able to buy the house as well as keep up a college fund for his children. "And we've managed to save some -- not a lot," said Lazorko. "But I'm going to have to find a job soon. These kids drink a lot of milk."
 
Pitching His Talents
 So Lazorko was on the telephone trying to sell himself and his pitching arm to a rather reluctant clientele.
"Oh, he's not in?" said Lazorko, in the kitchen, the American League Red Book and the National League Green Book, loaded with team phone numbers, on the table before him. "Well, could you tell him Jack Lazorko called? Would he mind calling me back? He'll know what it's about it. Thank you."
Lazorko shrugs, checks another number.
"We want to go with younger guys," he hears from some people he calls. Or: "We're full right now." Or: "We don't have any spots open." Or: "I'll take your number and I'll call if somebody goes down."
That's exactly why the Mets called in May. "To be brutally honest, we just needed an arm," said Gerry Hunsicker, the Mets' director of player personnel. "Some guys went down with injury, we had a few other things happen, and Jack had been calling me, so I told him, 'O.K., but it might not be for very long.'
"Jack's a good guy to have on a ball club. He gives you everything he's got. I knew him when he was in college. I coached against him, when I was at Florida International University. That was 20 years ago. I remember him as a kid with a strong arm. A pretty good-looking pitcher with above average fastball and definitely major league potential.
"But the realities now are that we got kids we're developing. Kids with a future ahead."
Said Buck Showalter: "At this stage for Jack, he needs pinpoint location where he can throw the breaking ball for strikes at will, and he just has to be a cut above the others. I like Jack, and I've always loved his attitude. But I felt his stuff came up just a little short."
Lazorko said: "If I get lit up whenever I go out there, that's one thing. Then I know it would be time to hang 'em up. But that doesn't happen. I keep guys in the ball park, I keep runners on base, and I'm one of the best fielding pitchers in the game."
Brenda does not discourage her husband in his pursuit. And the kids, apparently, have not suffered. Jack tutored them in Italy, and Jake spent his ninth birthday climbing the Matterhorn with his folks and his 10th birthday climbing one of the pyramids in Egypt, until a security guard told him it wasn't allowed.
"Everyone has his level of frustration," said Lazorko. "Some guys who play 15 years in the big leagues are frustrated that they haven't made the Hall of Fame. Some guys who played 10 years never got in a World Series. We had a great college team and eight guys were drafted by big league teams, but only one of us ever made the Show. How do you think those other guys felt? And me? I still love the challenge of setting up the batters, and getting them out."
But something else gnaws at him. "I just want a little more, just to prove that I was a real, contributing big-league player, and not a fringe guy."
 
Between Jobs, Still Pursuing the Dream
 It is nighttime, and warm. The black Texas sky is sugared with stars. Crickets are in harmony. Jack Lazorko has switched on the garage lights and they throw a gentle glow on his backyard.
Diagonally, the yard, from the corner of where the red-brick garage meets the house, to the now-shadowed gray picket fence and the roses that line it, is just a little more than 60 feet 6 inches, the distance from the pitcher's mound to home plate.
At the far end is the screen, a backstop, and just below the roped strike zone is a large netted bag that catches most of the balls that he throws. "What's great about this is that I can keep my arm in shape, and don't need a catcher," said Lazorko.
He is wearing a dark-blue Yankee T-shirt and gray Yankee shorts and rubber-soled cleats. He is standing on the concrete walk in the corner, where he has placed a pitching slab. Behind him is his living room, and through a picture window his wife can be seen sitting in a leather chair watching television. A leather bag of some 125 baseballs lies on the patio table near him.
He begins to throw, slowly at first, stretching his stocky body. Then he begins to throw harder, testing his assortment of pitches, almost but not quite skinning his knuckles on the bricks of the garage wall.
This is his routine when he is, as he says, "between jobs." He pitches to batters in his imagination, batters he is familiar with, like most of the lineup of, say, the Oakland A's, whom he had been watching earlier on television. And he throws in what he calls "situations." "Otherwise," he said, "you're just throwing and not thinking."
He's pitching now to Rickey Henderson with a man on, and going inside with a fastball and low and away with his slider. Next, Mark McGwire is up. Lazorko throws a curve. "Uh, oh," he said, "I hung that one. Home run." And he grunts. He is sweating now, plucking up one ball, deciding what to pitch, and letting go. This is work. This is pleasure. This is Jack Lazorko's life.
"If I were called up, I could pitch tomorrow," he said, breathing deeply after throwing a high hard one. "Tomorrow."
He took another ball from his bag, and looked down to get the sign, with, maybe, Ruben Sierra at bat in his mind's eye.
"I just need the opportunity, is all," he said. He wound up and threw. The ball thumped against the shadowed screen -- for a strike.

HEADLINE: NOTEBOOK;
Athletics and Twins Playing Their Way Into a Strange Situation

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
The two teams that between them have won the American League West championship the past six seasons reach the All-Star Game break occupying the last two spots in the division standing. Their location, however, does not exclude them from the race that will ensue after the break.
That development, bizarre though it may be for the Oakland Athletics and the Minnesota Twins, can be viewed from different perspectives. For the Athletics, for example, their status as a possible contender creates a dilemma of economic proportion. 
 As the general manager of another American League club put it, if the Athletics were as far out of the race as a sixth-place team should be, they could begin lowering their $36 million payroll by trading some of the high-priced players they are prepared to play without. Rickey Henderson, for example. But they can't very well concede at this stage.
 
'Worst-Case Situation'
 "They have a payroll the market can't sustain," the general manager said. "If they were out of the race, making some moves would be more understandable. But now they're handcuffed. And they're not drawing. They're in a worst-case situation. It's like being in hell. They don't have an opportunity to do what's in their best interest."
Sandy Alderson, the Athletics' general manager, declined to look at his position from that perspective.
"That's the negative side of a more positive situation," he said. "I certainly am not sitting here wishing we were out of it so I could trade some players. We're happy to be back in the race. But we still have lots of room for improvement."
Economics aside, Alderson put his team's and the Twins' status in perspective. Thanks to the inability of any of the other A.L. West members, particularly the Chicago White Sox, to pull away, the sixth and seventh-place teams remains close enough to challenge for the championship, but they have to play better than they have until now if they are to be serious contenders.
The Athletics, entering yesterday's games, were six games under .500, the Twins 11 under. Only two teams in the division, the White Sox and the Kansas City Royals, were over .500.
 
'Hard to Understand'
 "Through no fault of our own, we find ourselves still in the middle of the race," Andy MacPhail, the Twins' general manager, said, viewing his team's position realistically. "It's hard to understand. Two years ago, nobody was under .500 in the division. The nature of the game is more volatile than it has ever been, and our division is proof of that. Injuries or guys having off-years can make a major change."
In the Twins' case, the pitching staff is one of the major reasons they have fallen. Among the top three staffs in earned run average each of the past two seasons, the Twins have the league's only team e.r.a. over 5.00. The top two starters, Kevin Tapani and Scott Erickson, are the biggest culprits, each with an e.r.a. well over 5.00 and with a combined 8-20 record, compared with their collective 65-40 the past two seasons.
"To get back in the race requires only that our players play up to their accustomed level of peformance," MacPhail said. "It's not like we need a rookie to come up in the second half and win 14 games."
 
'Looking for Improvement'
 Alderson, too, called for improved performances from his veteran players.
"We're looking for improvement from within," the Athletics' executive said. "I think we can be better. We're going to see how well we perform through the month of July. Our starting pitching hasn't been consistently good. I think we can get more out of Bob Welch and Ron Darling. Our bullpen is rounding into shape. Some of our position players have been performing better."
A major factor in the Athletics' chances of recovering from a poor start will be the condition of Mark McGwire, who has played only 25 games and continues a nearly two-month stay on the disabled list with a tear in his left heel.
"It can take a few weeks to a few months to heal," Alderson said. "The cast is off. We're hoping he'll be ready by the end of the month, but that's speculative."
Neither general manager will trade his young players for veteran help for the second half.
"We could have traded Brent Gates and Craig Paquette," Alderson said of the Athletics' two rookie infielders. "We have similar players in the minors we could've traded, but we're not prepared to do that."
MacPhail, whose payroll is three-fourths of Alderson's, said: "There will be no shortage of opportunities and temptations to pick up high-salaried guys facing free agency this year or next at the cost of a couple of prospects. But what are you trying to accomplish?
"What really matters is winning the division. Whether you finish third or sixth really doesn't matter in the final analysis. To expend resources to upgrade your team from 70 wins to 80 makes no sense. You would be doing it only to take heat off you. It wouldn't make sense from the standpoint of money and young players."
 
Slashing Upward
 When St. Louis sliced Philadelphia's lead to five games Thursday night, it marked the Phillies' smallest margin over the second-place team in the National League East since May 22, a span of nearly seven weeks. The Cardinals slashed six and a half games off their deficit in 24 days.
On May 30, the Baltimore Orioles were in sixth place in the A.L. East, 10 1/2 games from first. A 26-11 record between then and yesterday catapulted the Orioles only two and a half games from the top spot.
With the exception of one day, the Mets have been 10 or more games behind the expansion Florida Marlins since June 17. The Marlins have maintained that kind of lead even though they went into last night's game with Atlanta with a seven-game losing streak. But now check out the other expansion team, the thought-to-be hapless Colorado Rockies. Their fourth consecutive victory Friday night boosted their record to six games better than the Mets' mark.
 
The Mets' Missing Three
 The Mets arrive at the All-Star break having failed to win three games in a row this season. The last team to display such ineptitude was the 1985 Pittsburgh Pirates, who won two in a row seven times before the break but couldn't win a third straight. The Mets have won two straight only four times.
The Pirates reached the break that season with a 29-56 record, in last place, 23 games from first. They finished 57-104, in last, 43 1/2 games behind. They did manage to win three in a row once, with two weeks left in the season, the third victory coming in 11 innings at the expense of the Mets, who were in a sprint for the division championship with St. Louis. The Pirates won two games of the three-game series, knocking the Mets from one game back to three, the Cardinals' eventual winning margin.
The Mets' futility is even worse than other teams that had the worst starts of recent seasons. Last year Kansas City lost 16 of its first 17 games but wound up winning three or more games in a row three times before the break. In 1988, Baltimore lost its first 21 games but managed to win three straight once, and Atlanta recorded a pair of three-game winning streaks after losing its first 10.
 
Home-Run Tales
 The Boston Red Sox, entering the weekend, had hit 25 home runs in their last 18 games. It took them 56 games to hit their previous 25 home runs (they had only 30 over all in their first 66 games). The Red Sox record in the 56 games was 23-33; it was 13-5 in the 18 games.
Brett Butler and Jose Offerman, 1-2 in the Los Angeles lineup, also are 1-2 in the race to have the most at-bats without a home run. Butler took his perfect record of 339 at-bats into yesterday's game with the Mets, while Offerman stood at 315. Two members of the top 10 dropped out of the race last week. Felix Fermin of Cleveland hit his first home run last Monday night on his 252d time at bat. The following night, Chuck Knoblauch of Minnesota succeeded on his 292d at-bat, the most attempts anyone has had this season before hitting a home run.
 
Henderson Feats
 Rickey Henderson is a special player, the best leadoff man in baseball history, so it should come as no surprise that he has created one of the most unusual statistics in history. Of his 211 career home runs, Henderson has hit 61, or a shade under 30 percent, leading off the first inning.
Adding a remarkable touch to an already remarkable record, Henderson led off the first inning of both games of a doubleheader against Cleveland last week with home runs. He hit the first against Paul Abbott, the second against Mark Clark.
Knowing Henderson's penchant for first-inning home runs, Abbott was asked, how does he approach the confrontation?
"I don't really prepare to pitch to him any different than I would to anybody," Abbott said before returning to the minor leagues. "I try to keep the ball down, throws strikes and not get behind, like with any good hitter."
What happened on No. 60?
"I got to a full count," the 25-year-old right-hander related. "I was ahead of him 0-2, then I threw three balls. Leading off the game, you don't want to walk him. I grooved a fastball, and he cranked it."
Having seen Henderson's act up close, what did Clark do wrong in the second game?
"I don't think he did anything wrong," Abbott said. "It was a good pitch. Rickey Henderson was just hot. He threw a good pitch, and Rickey cranked it."
And what would Abbott do differently the next time he meets Henderson in the first?
"I'd probably try not to get to 3-2 on him," Abbott said. "You have to remember: He is Rickey Henderson."

HEADLINE: For Business Lobbyists in Albany, Little to Cheer About

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 9

 BODY:
The anger in the terse, two-sentence news release was palpable.
"To the Governor and the Senate, thank you for your efforts to improve New York's dismal economy," it read. "To the Assembly, thanks for nothing." 
 The statement, issued Thursday, by the Business Council of New York State, a lobbying group, seemed to sum up the attitudes of the business community about the losses it sustained in the waning hours of the 1993 legislative session, which sputtered out Thursday morning after a full night of lawmaking.
Several bills supported by business groups that had been proposed earlier in the session never made it out of the Legislature. Indeed, virtually the only sector of the business community that had something good to say about the closing days of the session was the real-estate industry, which lobbied successfully for a measure limiting rent stabilization and then helped kill bills that would have raised wages at private construction sites and regulate workers who remove lead paint.
Over all, business lobbyists were bemoaning Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's failure to win approval of bills he proposed that would have held down employers' costs for workers' compensation insurance and would have curbed product liability lawsuits.
In addition, the Assembly and Senate could not reach agreement on other legislation that business groups had supported, including bills to permit privately owned businesses and partnerships to organize as limited liability companies and to restrict lawsuits filed by stockholders.
 
'A Big Goose Egg'
 "It was a big goose egg for the business community," said Mark P. Alesse, state director of the National Federation of Independent Business, an advocacy group for small companies. "It's shocking in light of the condition of the economy."
Governor Cuomo had proposed a measure that would allow large employers to contract with health maintenance organizations, among other providers of managed care, to treat their employees' work-related injuries, rather than allowing employees to chose their own providers. Employers favored the proposal as a way to cut costs, particularly because the New York Compensation Insurance Rating Board has asked state regulators for an 18.7 percent increase in the workers' compensation premiums paid by businesses. The State Insurance Department is expected to rule on the rate request next week.
But unions, in particular the A.F.L.-C.I.O., opposed the bill, saying it went too far too fast and was not in the best interests of injured workers. The measure passed the Republican-led Senate, which traditionally supports the business community, but it was not acted on in the Democrat-controlled Assembly.
Another proposal by the Governor would have placed some curbs on product liability lawsuits. Manufacturers have contended that the lack of constraints on such suits is driving up costs, particularly on liability insurance. But the plan was opposed by trial lawyers, among others. Neither house brought the bill to a vote.
 
Special Companies Sought
 The Senate and Assembly were also unable to agree on two other measures that business groups have pushed, without success, in recent years. The first would have created limited liability companies, hybrid entities in which partnerships and family businesses are treated like corporations, with the insulation of the assets of individuals who make up the company or partnership. Such special companies are permitted in dozens of other states, prompting the fear that businesses barred from forming them will move elsewhere.
As an incentive to lure businesses from other states, the Senate bill would have exempted such companies from some taxes. But the Assembly bill would not have exempted the companies from all the taxes the Senate proposed, because, sponsors argued, the state stood to lose significant tax revenue if corporations transformed themselves into the new limited liability companies.
The second measure that the Senate and Assembly were unable to agree on was a measure that could have curtailed shareholder derivative actions, in which investors sue a company's individual directors because they are displeased with the company's handling of an issue. The business community has argued that such suits are often meritless and extremely costly.
 
Real-Estate Gains
 Thanks in part to strong lobbying, the housing and construction industries fared better than the business community as a whole. Apartment building owners in New York City and surrounding counties, for example, won what they considered a moral victory when rent limitations were removed from the wealthiest tenants in the most expensive apartments.
Landlords clashed with the environmental lobby on a measure that would have established training standards for workers who remove lead paint from buildings.
Real-estate lobbyists contended that such a program, which would have included licensing and certification of workers, would have driven up costs, unnecessarily burdening smaller owners. Environmentalists countered that the measure, by setting guidelines for safe lead removal, would protect the health of children.
The bill was passed by the Assembly but was not voted on in the Senate. A second bill, which would have imposed strict constraints on the removal of lead paint from bridges and other large municipal structures, also died in the Senate.
In other action, the construction industry had strongly opposed a measure that would have required contractors to pay "prevailing" wages -- union rates -- on private projects awarded public funds, such as loans from industrial development agencies. The bill passed the Senate but was not voted on in the Assembly.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 15, 1993, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sunday about the reaction of business lobbyists to the 1993 legislative session in Albany referred imprecisely to the position of people in the construction industry on a bill that would have required contractors to pay union rates on private projects awarded public money. While construction companies generally oppose the measure, construction unions generally support it.
