HEADLINE: Boards Protect Shareholders, Right?

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn.

 BODY:
LEONARD TOW was in many ways an ideal choice for the board of the Citizens Utilities Company, a consistently profitable business based here. An impressive career in the cable-television business made him one of the world's wealthiest businessmen. He knows important people. He thinks big. To his fans, no one better understands the jumble of changes transforming the communications business.
But once he joined the board in 1989, Mr. Tow quickly began to act less like a mere director and more like a man who wouldn't mind running the company. Soon he was. The way he reached the top and what he has done since then are a good study for the current debate about whether boards of directors are always up to their sole task: to protect shareholders. 
 After Mr. Tow joined the board, holdover directors were offered a variety of opportunities to increase their compensation, and directors who left the board were replaced by longtime associates of Mr. Tow. In the process, his critics say, Mr. Tow effectively gained control of the company without paying public shareholders a penny and without triggering the scrutiny of government regulators who typically examine changes of control at utilities.
Soon the board elected Mr. Tow as chairman, and he found it easy to win board approval for a pay package worth millions of dollars more than that of any other utility executive in the nation. He also found little resistance when he proposed deals that tended to shift costs to Citizens, a cash-rich company in which he has a negligible stake, and shift fees to Century Communications, a cash-poor company in which he owns a big stake.
In addition to Mr. Tow, Citizens' 11-person board now includes Mr. Tow's wife, Claire, and four directors who have financial ties to the company above and beyond the fees directors customarily receive for serving as the shareholders' watchdog. The smorgasbord includes bargain-priced stock options, and fees for legal, consulting and advisory work.
At least one arrangement, involving a 77-year-old director whom Mr. Tow's predecessor had tried to remove, was not disclosed to Citizens' shareholders. In that instance, Mr. Tow let the director stay put, placed him on several important committees that lifted his pay, and granted penny-a-share options that produced a quick $123,000 paper profit. Unbeknownst to Citizens' shareholders, he also appointed the director to the board of Executive Re, an insurance concern in which Citizens was a founding investor. That pays $12,000 a year in cash plus $12,000 in stock whose value could soar if the company, as expected, goes public.
Should the Rules Be Changed?
Many companies have directors who serve the business in ways other than their board seat. But Citizens stands out for the number of such instances, raising questions about whether the board is sufficiently conflict-free to step up when tough calls must be made.
Directors are the linchpins of the corporate governance system. But current standards -- a threadbare patchwork of state laws and listing requirements by the various stock exchanges -- allow companies to nominate directors who have financial arrangements, business dealings or personal relationships with the managers they are supposed to monitor.
Paying board members substantial sums beyond their directors' fees "is what the average person would call theft, but what passes for accepted practice in the modern corporate board room in far too many situations," said Gregg A. Jarrell, a former chief economist for the Securities and Exchange Commission who teaches at the Simon School of business in Rochester.
If the Citizens directors "are embarrassed, they have reason to be," said Joseph A. Grundfest, a former S.E.C. commissioner who teaches at Stanford law school. "To be polite, this board will not be a case studyof how a modern corporation should be governed."
Asked in interviews about the many ways he and his directors are paid, Mr. Tow bristled and said, "We're all grossly underpaid for all the guff we get for it." Of his board, he said, "It's beholden to nobody."
Mr. Tow admitted that neglecting to mention in the annual proxy statement that he had put forward the director for the Executive Re board was a "fault -- we'll correct it."
Some people shrug about Citizens' situation, arguing that coziness in the nation's boardrooms is endemic and hard to prevent.
But others, like the Council of Institutional Investors, a Washington group of pension funds, say that outside directors should have no links to the companies they govern other than their board seats. "What that means is the person has never worked at the company, is not related to someone who has worked at that company, and does not provide services to that company like a lawyer or vendor might," said Anne S. Hansen, deputy director of the council. Her organization's tests for outside directors would disqualify at least four of the 10 people who serve with Mr. Tow on Citizens' board and all but one of the nine members of Century's board.
Citizens Utilities shareholders have filed three separate suits against Citizens' directors in recent weeks over the manner in which Mr. Tow gained control of the company, which they view as clandestine; over Mr. Tow's pay, which they consider excessive, and over disclosure documents they think are incomplete.
The California Public Employees Retirement System, which owns 381,000 Citizens shares and is considering joining one of the suits, recently sent the company's directors a scorching letter, comparing them to "pigs at the trough" for having allowed Mr. Tow such free rein.
Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts and chairman of the House subcommittee on telecommunications and finance, plans hearings this fall on the adequacy of the modern board, and the panel is interested in Citizens.
Some longtime Citizens shareholders are particularly disturbed. "This may be the American way of doing business," said Thomas King, whose family has owned shares since the 1940's, "but this hasn't been the history of this company."
 
The Citizens Story
 For much of its 57-year history, Citizens Utilities was Richard L. Rosenthal. A Depression-era boy wonder who attended New York University on scholarship, he waged and won a 1946 proxy fight for what was then a shaky company in the electric, telephone, gas and water business. It was the start of a 43-year reign. Through acquisitions, Mr. Rosenthal transformed the business from the "mighty midget" that Forbes magazine called it in 1955 into a hefty company with about $340 million in revenues and the highest of debt ratings when he left. Investors who stuck with him until his retirement in 1989 enjoyed a 17 percent compounded annual return, and many became millionaires.
Today, Citizens Utilities, with 1992 earnings of $115 million on revenues of $589 million, provides electric, gas, telecommunications, water and wastewater services to more than 800,000 customers in 13 states, most west of the Rockies or in the Midwest.
 
The Leonard Tow Story
 Leonard Tow, now 65 years old, entered the scene in 1989. The son of Russian immigrants whose last name is derived from the Hebrew word for "good," he grew up in Brooklyn. He earned his doctoral degree in economic geography in 1960 from Columbia University, traveled to southern Africa to research the region's potential for economic development, and flirted with academia until he decided that universities had "too many people fighting over tiny anthills."
His quest for a more rewarding career led him to a job at the Teleprompter Corporation, a cable company, and he rose to the No. 3 job there. The company ran into trouble when his former boss, Irving Kahn, was convicted in 1971 of bribing city officials of Johnstown, Pa., to win a franchise. Mr. Tow left to start his own cable venture in 1973.
Century, the company he started, became a way for Mr. Tow to take television, as he put it, to the "television deprived." The company went public in 1986 at $3 a share, adjusting for splits, and three years later Mr. Tow's stake hit $315 million and higher, landing him on Forbes's list of the world's 400 richest people. (Now that Washington is reregulating the cable business, Century's shares are trading at $7.50, well below their 1989 peak of $13, and Mr. Tow's stake is worth $280 million or so.)
Mr. Tow's entree to Citizens Utilities came through Drexel Burnham Lambert, the now-defunct investment firm, which was marketing a 2 percent stake that belonged to Mr. Rosenthal and two board members.
The asking price was high. But this was no ordinary opportunity: this was the single biggest chunk of stock in the company. One Rosenthal confidant who asked not to be identified said that Mr. Rosenthal hinted that the buyer could expect to assume his place on the board and replace enough departing members so that 2 percent would yield control. (Mr. Rosenthal declined to comment for this article.)
While Mr. Tow sought representation on the Citizens board, he denies that he was promised or expected control. He remembers thinking that here was a chance for a tried-and-true cable veteran to learn more about the telephone business and spot opportunities where the two companies could collaborate. And who better to rouse Citizens, which had not made a major acquisition in years, than a proven dealmaker?
For his investment, Mr. Tow received two board seats; a month later, his candidates for two new openings were accepted. He also gained considerable power when he took a seat on the executive committee, which oversees the company between board meetings.
When Mr. Rosenthal commanded $48 million from Century for his group's shares of Citizens, 27 percent above the market price, shareholders were miffed at having been left out.
Citizens' board didn't take well to Mr. Tow either, at least at first. A former Citizens officer who asked not to be identified said that John L. Schroeder, one of three directors whom Mr. Tow inherited from the existing board, fought Mr. Tow's first attempt to be named chief executive in 1989 -- one year before his actual appointment. Mr. Schroeder, a veteran money manager, did not return calls for this article. But the former officer said Mr. Schroeder feared that handing over the reins to Mr. Tow and Century could constitute a change in control and subject the business to burdensome regulations.
The board also sided with Hampton D. Graham, the chief financial officer in early 1990, when Mr. Tow proposed teaming Citizens and Century to bid on some cellular-telephone properties. The board members agreed with Mr. Graham that the proposal was unfair to Citizens, and the terms were significantly altered when a similar deal was introduced a year later.
 
Changes at the Board
 With Mr. Rosenthal gone in 1989, his longtime No. 2, Ishier Jacobson, acted as chairman of Citizens. But once he had negotiated a $5.3 million severance package with Mr. Tow's support, Mr. Jacobson announced his retirement, effective July 1990, from the executive ranks and from what was at that time an eight-man board. Suddenly, with only seven directors left, Mr. Tow was in the catbird seat. He had introduced three of the other six directors to the company, and at least two of the holdovers were warming to him. That month he was named Citizens' chief executive and chairman.
Among the holdovers was Norman I. Botwinik, the 77-year-old director who avoided being pushed off the board and was granted, among other things, the profitable options. Another was Andrew N. Heine, a lawyer, received $51,705 for advising Citizens on its 1989 acquisition of Louisiana General, a gas company, and options in a cellular-phone subsidiary that yielded the same $123,000 paper profit that Mr. Botwinik received. (Mr. Heine and Mr. Botwinik were granted the options for serving on a board committee.)
Mr. Schroeder remains the only board holdover who has no apparent attachments to the company beyond his directorial duties.
The board newcomers whom Mr. Tow had a hand in bringing aboard in 1989 included Robert D. Siff, a commercial banker who is also on Century's board and who received $261,400 in consulting fees from Citizens in 1990 and $258,800 in 1991. Another was Aaron I. Fleischman, who has done an undisclosed amount of legal work for Citizens and Century.
Last year, Citizens expanded its board to 10 members. And in May it was expanded again. Mr. Tow's wife joined, a decision Mr. Tow said he was not behind. "They wanted a woman," he said.
Eric Roth, a lawyer for Citizens' directors (except the Tows), said his clients would have no comment because of the pending litigation. But one new director, Stanley Harfenist, commented anyway: "There's no one on the board who's going to roll over for Leonard Tow," he said, describing his colleagues as wealthy people. "They don't roll over for anybody."
Mr. Tow chased off some executives who challenged him. One who left in October 1991 was Mr. Graham, the chief financial officer whose outspokenness had given him trouble the previous year. Mr. Graham declined comment. Mr. Tow chose to act as his own chief financial officer rather than hire a new one.
 
The Pay Package
 Citizens' newly constituted board approved for Mr. Tow an employment contract that entitled him to $800,000 a year in base salary with automatic cost-of-living increases, a $50,000 expense allowance, a $3 million life insurance policy and an annual pension equal to two-thirds of his best 12 months' compensation. On top of the guaranteed payments, the Citizens board last year approved for Mr. Tow a $330,000 cash bonus, $7 million of restricted stock and $10.4 million of options above and beyond the guaranteed sums. Recently it has also changed the company's former policy to allow him to collect $33,500 to serve on his own board.
One outside compensation expert, Graef Crystal, valued Mr. Tow's 1992 pay package at $21 million last year, eight times the compensation of the next-highest utility executive in his survey and higher than that of all 17 of Mr. Tow's counterparts combined.
Mr. Tow also succeeded in winning board approval for deals that tended to shift fees to Century and costs to Citizens. In two joint ventures between the companies, one involving cellular-phone properties and the other cable-television systems, Century is assured of management fees.
In another instance, Citizens used $12 million of its own cash to buy Century shares from a company close to Mr. Tow; in its public filings, Citizens has never identified the seller: Sentry Insurance, his partner when he founded Century.
"It is an incestuous relationship," said Merle Thorpe Jr., a Washington lawyer and longtime Citizens investor who is suing the company, upon learning the seller's identity. "It is a transaction I would not let any client engage in without making disclosure."
Mr. Tow disputes that the transactions are anything but proper, citing as an example three fairness opinions Century and Citizens got from investment bankers when they merged their cellular-telephone properties. "Every inter-relationship between these companies is handled the same way," he said. "We've been exceedingly careful to not cross lines and stay away from situations that might cause us headaches."
Mr. Tow was also asked about other instances where Citizens and Century appeared less than upfront with shareholders about relevant facts -- for example, that Century expects to be paid management fees in the cable-television venture with Citizens. He said there was no need to report the fees until a contract was signed.
The two companies' affairs are so tangled at this point that some employees of Citizens are not quite sure when Mr. Tow, his wife and other shared personnel are working for one company or the other. And they are still buzzing about the proud day last year when Citizens Utilities began trading on the New York Stock Exchange: more Century people than Citizens people turned out on the floor of the Big Board for the event.
To be sure, Citizens shareholders have fared well during Mr. Tow's three years at the top. Citizens' stock has climbed 20.2 percent compounded annually in those years, versus 11.2 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500. Looking aggressively for acquisitions, Citizens has bought two gas companies and has pursued deals that tilt the company toward the fast-growing telecommunications business, including a tentative agreement to buy many of GTE's rural telephone properties for $1.1 billion.
But Mr. Jarrell of the Simon School, for one, is not impressed. "The most egregious cases of self-dealing and boards of directors asleep at the switch almost uniformly come at companies that are performing well," he said, "because those are the conditions where boards of directors will justify what otherwise would be considered shady practices."
What most worries Citizens' shareholders, rating agencies and employees these days is a fear that Mr. Tow really wants Citizens to buy his other company, Century, at a premium price -- something Mr. Tow vigorously denies. Of course, Citizens' board would have something to say about that. Then again. . . .
 
Mr. Tow's Other Dealings
 IF the board of Citizens Utilities had wanted a hint of what to expect from letting Leonard Tow come aboard, its members simply had to look at Century Communications, the company he founded 20 years ago and continues to run. There, he helped himself to millions of dollars of interest-free loans; put his wife, Claire, and son Andrew on the board, and bought from and sold to Century millions of dollars worth of properties.
December 1986 was a busy month for such deals. Mr. and Mrs. Tow sold to Century for $18 million a cable television system that they had acquired three years earlier for $3.7 million. (Mr. Tow says he could have gotten $25 million.) That month, Century also paid the Tows $7.7 million to buy back two radio stations it had been forced to divest two years earlier. The couple had bought the stations with a $3 million promissary note. (Mr. Tow says he "bent over backwards" to reach a fair price.)
Now, Mrs. Tow is selling Century a recently acquired license to operate a Kentucky radio station for what the proxy says is her cost: $450,000. According to her husband, the Government favors women and minorities in the granting of licenses, and never would have given Century the license.
Nearly always, when one of these "related party" transactions has to be disclosed, the company explains that "a majority of the company's disinterested and independent directors" approved it. But it's difficult to figure out exactly who the independent directors are at Century.
For starters, there are Leonard, Claire and Andrew Tow, all of whom work for the company. (Claire heads human resources; Andrew, 33, runs the cable company.)
Then there is David Z. Rosensweig, Mr. Tow's personal attorney, who negotiated his employment agreements at Citizens and Century, even as his law firm has grossed nearly $5 million in fees since 1986 as Century's general counsel. Now, he is one-half of Century's compensation committee.
There is Robert D. Siff, a banker who helped Mr. Tow when he was at Teleprompter and whose Citibank connections helped put Century on the map. Mr. Tow brought him to the Citizens board in 1989 to represent Century's 2 percent stake. Mr. Siff soon had a consulting deal with Citizens that put more than $500,000 in his pocket in two years.
Next come Peter J. Solomon, an investment banker who was to be paid a $25,000 advisory fee, according to the 1991 proxy, and William M. Kraus, who is described in Century's filings simply as a publisher with experience in state government. In fact, he is the former executive of Sentry Insurance who persuaded his company to bankroll Century in 1973. And though it is not disclosed in recent proxies, Mr. Kraus is also paid by Century to handle investor relations.
Mr. Tow said in an interview that he was not sure to whom the passages on "disinterested and independent directors" referred, except for Mr. Solomon. He went on to say that all his board members were independent, later allowing that he, his wife and son might not be.

HEADLINE: Your Own Account;
Learning the Lessons of a Layoff

SERIES: First of two articles on losing a job.

BYLINE: By Mary Rowland
CONSULTANTS are beginning to worry that many people thrown out of work by a decade of corporate change will never find jobs again, a class of people who are "terminally unemployable."
If you have been out of work for months -- or even years -- and you are waiting for economic recovery to put things right again, you are almost certain to be disappointed. The recession only masked changes in the economy that have eliminated forever whole categories of jobs.

 BODY:
 Even when the economy picks up steam, many companies that reduced their work forces will continue to "downsize" to become more competitive. "There is a whole group of people who cannot expect to insert themselves back into Corporate America, because there is no place for them," said Sharon Coleman, a psychotherapist and management consultant in New York.
Perhaps you were told that it was not your fault when you were laid off, that the layoffs were unrelated to your job performance. That was not necessarily a favor if it kept you from making the changes you must make to become employable again.
"Some years ago, a lot of downsizing was done based on seniority," said John J. Parkington, director of organization research and development in the San Francisco office of the Wyatt Company, a benefits consultant. "That's pretty rare now. Now they try to ferret out people who are less productive."
As American companies change to become more competitive in a global economy, those who do not understand the new structure -- or fit in -- are let go. "A layoff is related to a person's job performance," Ms. Coleman said. "The person who is cut is not as good a fit for the job."
If you are one of them, you must make some changes of your own, to your expectations and your skills. Losing a job is often just a piece in the larger puzzle of a life askew, said Nancy Hutchens, a human resources consultant in Ossining, N.Y., who works with large corporations to help identify departing employees who need special help.
An employee who is going through a divorce, a crisis with an aging parent, a shift in personal values or some other type of transition may not focus on work. And he or she may not notice how the work place is changing and what must be done to change with it. A layoff should be "a very strong message that the way you are doing things isn't working," Ms. Hutchens said.
Looking desperately for another job just to put bread on the table is not a long-term solution. Without an understanding of what went wrong -- and what it takes to survive in the new environment -- you may well fail again.
A survey by Battalia Winston International, a New York executive recruiter, provides some evidence of this. Battalia Winston receives 700 to 1,000 resumes a month. In May, the company decided to analyze the job histories of those who were looking for work and found most candidates had bounced from job to job for several years.
"One of the frightening statistics we found was that an enormous percentage of people had spent a long time at a company, perhaps 10 years or more, and then they'd had five jobs in a row lasting no more than a year or so," said Dale Winston, the company president. In fact, 55 percent of the job candidates fell into that category, Ms. Winston said.
This indicates that these people do not understand how the workplace has changed. They are laid off from one job, race out to find another and get laid off again. "I've seen people go right back to the same thing and fail again," said Ms. Coleman, the psychotherapist. "They will resist breaking out of that box and thinking in new ways."
If your industry is changing, you must be realistic about your chances of finding a position similar to the one you lost. "Too many people won't give up until they see their industry die," said Ms. Hutchens, the consultant. "People in publishing are a perfect example. They will not take a step to retrain themselves to do something different until they are told they don't have a job anymore."
Many of those who held high-paying positions have unrealistic expectations about what to expect in a job. "I run across a lot of folks who just have not taken a hard look in the mirror," said Craig E. Schneier, a management consultant in Princeton, N.J. "It's painful to see them barking up a tree that they have no chance of climbing."
Most companies are not looking for someone to manage people. They are looking for someone to make a contribution. "The key word today is individual contributor," Ms. Winston said. "No one today is paid to simply manage the activity of others. Companies cannot afford to do that."
Delineations between jobs are no longer clear. Titles are not important. Companies are looking for people who pitch in and do whatever is necessary. "You can't see work in terms of turf, but in terms of the job that needs to be done," Ms. Hutchens said. Many of those who are unsuccessful in today's workplace have not learned to work in that type of environment. "They don't deal with ambiguity well," Ms. Hutchens said. "Rather than seeing it as an opportunity they see it as a threat. They like things to be very clear. That is suicidal these days."
When you join a new company, observe carefully how things work. "You must go in and develop relationships that will enable you to become a part of that organization," Ms. Winston said. "You really have to figure out what drives that organization and its culture." For that reason, she often recommends that people make lateral moves.
 
'Retooling' Yourself for a New Job
 NO one is truly unemployable if they are willing to change their behavior, gain new skills and "retool" themselves for a new work environment.
"Anyone can be employed at something," said Jane King, a financial planner in Wellesley, Mass. "But many families have to come to grips with the fact that they will not have an income of $150,000 any more."
If you are still employed but see the writing on the wall, use your company's employee assistance program.
"Most of them provide both career counseling and personal counseling," said John J. Parkington, a consultant at the Wyatt Company in San Francisco.
There is much to be gained by taking control of the situation. "People can come out the other end of this process much better prepared to deal with life," said William P. Brittain, an industrial psychologist in New York. "The reason is that they have learned something about having control over career decisions. Once you've been through this, you'll never be scared of being fired again because you will know exactly what to do."

HEADLINE: Warehouse Club, County's First, to Open

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
AS the economy softens, interest heightens in warehouse purchasing clubs, which sell household goods and food products at wholesale prices to members. This Friday, Pace, the first membership warehouse in Westchester, is scheduled to open for business in Elmsford.
"We already have 3,000 business members and 1,000 household members signed up," said Greg Mowery, the director of the Pace warehouse, which is at 333 Saw Mill River Road, Route 9A. 
 The yearly membership fee for those joining the warehouse club before the opening is $25, he said, while those joining after the opening will pay $30 a year.
 
The Attraction: Price
 Business members, who make up 60 percent of the membership, are likely to be the owners of small retail stores, doctors, dentists and entrepreneurs, Mr. Mowery said. He said they would be able to buy merchandise for business resale and personal needs at the special hours of 9 A.M. to 11 A.M. daily.
"A local merchant, such as a mom-and-pop deli, is a typical business member," he said. "The attraction is price. Our wholesale price makes it easy on their pocketbooks because they are able to buy smaller quantities of products for resale than are available from other sources. An example: a dozen pounds of shortening can be had at the same wholesale price that they'd pay for a carload of the stuff elsewhere."
Individual householders who are club members can buy even smaller quantities, he said, like a package of two heads of lettuce or a package of three U.S. Choice steaks.
What else is available? Everything from fresh foods to fax machines, with brand-name items in over 250 product categories, Douglas Hock, a Pace spokesman, said.
"We have extremely low markups because our profits are derived almost entirely from membership fees, not markups on merchandise," he said. "We work on a markup of 8 to 9 percent compared with 25 percent markup for discounters and 40 percent for retailers."
 
An Untapped Market
 The cost of doing business in Westchester, together with the lack of available sites to build a warehouse, slowed the growth of warehouse clubs in the county, Mr. Hock said. "But now," he said, "with the recession and the economy in the doldrums, we feel the environment is right. Westchester, with its population density, is a huge untapped market. The demographics are good. We expect to generate $45 million in sales."
Pace, with headquarters in Englewood, Colo., operates 125 warehouses in 29 states and Puerto Rico. The company, which was founded in 1983, was acquired by Kmart Corporation in 1989 and operates as a wholly owned subsidiary.
Studies of the Westchester market began several years ago when Pace was approached by Martin S. Berger, president of the Robert Martin Company, a major developer in Elmsford.
"We had what we thought was a prime location for a warehouse club building, which was 13 acres of land on Route 9A in Elmsford," Mr. Berger said. The site was the old Elmsford drive-in theater, which had been vacant for 14 years and "was a real eyesore," he said.
 
One Union Objects
 "Pace, which is a regionally diverse warehouse club with stores as spread out as Alaska and Puerto Rico, was looking at new markets and we thought the demand for warehouse clubs was strong here so it would be a good fit," Mr. Berger said. Negotiations began between Robert Martin, Pace representatives and the Town of Greenburgh.
"The only hostility came from a union in Queens that represents supermarket employees," Mr. Berger recalled. "They sent people to attend every hearing. But almost everyone else -- Town of Greenburgh officials, construction unions, people in the neighborhood -- were in favor of the project."
Building the 110,000-square-foot warehouse building, which is the size of two large supermarkets, created more than 150 construction jobs, he said. "And that was at a time when construction in the county was absolutely flat."
The development will bring other substantial benefits to the area, Mr. Berger said, including revenues of approximately $250,000 a year in taxes.
"And 150 Westchesterites will find new jobs at Pace," he said. "People will have the opportunity to buy what they need at lower prices and what's more, improvement of the property, which has been an eyesore for years, will upgrade the 9A corridor and generate additional activity for local businesses."
When asked about the new competition local supermarkets will face, Mr. Berger said he did not think a warehouse club would put supermarkets out of business.
"Unlike the supermarkets, warehouse clubs stock only 50 percent of food products," he said. "People don't go to a warehouse club for a quart of milk. They go to stock up on such things as paper goods."
The economic downturn has spurred the growth of warehouse clubs nationally, Mr. Hock said.
"Our operation is based on the premise that today especially, more people are looking for the best bang for the buck, plus the convenience of one-stop shopping," he said. "We're the fourth-largest warehouse club company in the industry and our size gives us the ability to offer consumers about 4,000 items in 250 different product categories of merchandise under one roof.
"We sell bakery goods, but we also sell electronic equipment and automotive supplies. And we keep our overhead low and we don't do any mass media advertising, so we pass the savings on to members."
Pace, he said, is able to buy name-brand products in large quantities directly from manufacturers. In addition, the company carries some products under its own label.
The merchandise in the warehouse stores is geared to the business needs and way of life of the communities they serve, Mr. Mowery said. "What's popular in Alaska would bomb in Puerto Rico. Each warehouse carries a line of local products, which include ethnic and gourmet preferences."
 
$3 Million in Phone Business
 Other services are available to members, including optical departments, mail-order pharmacies, a film- developing-process service, and discounted long-distance telephone service from M.C.I.
"Pace members did $3 million of business with M.C.I. in the first quarter of the year," Mr. Mowery said.
Paul J. Feiner, Supervisor of the Town of Greenburgh, said that the Pace warehouse will not only generate revenue for the Town of Greenburgh but will also give consumers an alternative shopping choice.
"There was some supermarket opposition but none of the supermarkets mounted a major campaign against the warehouse," Mr. Feiner said. "In tough times, warehouses offer a way to help people save money, and that's a good thing."

HEADLINE: Will the Zebra Mussels Invade L.I.?

BYLINE: By LINDA SASLOW

 BODY:
A SMALL European freshwater mollusk, the zebra mussel, has invaded the lakes, rivers and streams of North America. Originally seen as a problem confined to the Great Lakes, the zebra mussels, so named for their dark brown stripes on a light tannish shell, have been found in the Hudson River, 25 miles from the Long Island Sound.
The mussels have not been sighted in Long Island waters and pose less of a threat to the region, because the Island is surrounded by saltwater. But marine experts are concerned about species of zebra mussels found in 1990 that tolerate saltwater and may be able to thrive in Long Island waters. 
 A 30-minute documentary produced by WLIW-TV and the New York Sea Grant Institute, "Zebra Mussels," to be broadcast on Channel 21 on Tuesday at 7:30 P.M. and Saturday at 5:30 P.M., investigates the tiny pest and its potential problems for business, industry and government.
Their prolific reproduction makes them a major economic and environmental danger, said the writer and co-producer of the documentary, Avery Klauber of South Setauket. Each female can produce up to one million eggs, he said.
Mr. Klauber said he had been following the problem since the mussels were found in the Great Lakes in 1988. "There were indications that they were migrating south and that this would eventually become a problem for us in the New York area," he said. "But we had no idea how long it would take for them to move. They've moved faster than was expected, and this means that power systems will have to take cleanup and control measures, and the costs will indirectly have a ripple effect on every citizen."
Mr. Klauber said zebra mussels worried many people because they can attach themselves to anything hard with water flowing through it and clog intakes of power stations and water systems, river locks and boat engines. The mussels can disrupt industry, alter ecosystems and restrict recreational water, he said, adding that many freshwater beaches had become littered with stretches of dead and rotting mussels, which have sharp shells and a horrible odor.
"If left untouched, they can cost the country billions of dollars over the next decade," Mr. Klauber said.
A curator at the New York Aquarium, Dennis Thoney, said although zebra mussels had spread quickly through New York State, their threat was not as great on Long Island because they cannot travel too far in saltwater. Unless they are delivered on the Island by people, Mr. Thoney said, they have no way of going to Long Island.
 
Adaptability to Saltwater
 But the director, co-author and co-producer of the documentary, William Shine of East Northport, said new species of zebra mussels had been found that can survive in brackish water and may be able to survive and proliferate in saltwater.
In 1990 the mussels were spotted in the Hudson, and species were found that were able to tolerate brackish water and different temperatures. If those other species can adapt to saltwater, Mr. Shine said, then the Island will be in danger.
Zebra mussels, native to the Caspian Sea, were noticed in the United States in 1988 in Lake St. Clair, east of Detroit. Experts say they believe that the mussels arrived when ships traveling Europe through the St. Lawrence Seaway and dumped their ballast water. The mussels attached themselves to the hulls of commercial and recreational boats, navigational buoys, docks, ladders, plastic bottles and intake pipes.
Large numbers of the mussels spread from recreational boats used in one body of water and taken to another. They have also hitchhiked on aquatic plants, the feathers of migrating birds and ducks and animals' fur.
Knowing where the mussels have spread is vital to monitor where they are going, Mr. Klauber said. New York City, with the largest water system in the world, has a $16 million plan to avert a catastrophe.
The controls -- scraping the mussels, spraying them with high-pressure water, chemicals or heat -- are costly. In 1990 the Federal Government allocated $37 million to combat zebra mussels, but no state has a long-range plan, which is necessary to obtain matching funds from the Federal Government.
 
With $40,000 From N.O.A.A.
 The documentary was financed by a $40,000 grant from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The film was shot in the Great Lakes, the Mississippi River and other waterways in seven states. The documentary focuses on Monroe, Mich., whose 40,000 residents lost their water supply for two days, because of an infestation of zebra mussels.
Most people, Mr. Shine said, have never heard of zebra mussels and do not realize the potential problems. The biggest concern for the New York region, he added, is to keep the mussels out of upstate reservoirs.
"So much about zebra mussels is still a mystery," he said. "But it's no mystery that the financial burden of the cleanup will fall on everyone nationwide. We need to coordinate our efforts with advanced planning and monitoring, because the zebra mussels are heading our way."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A new hardier strain of zebra mussel, top, and the older strain, bottom. (Chris Hildreth/Cornell University)

HEADLINE: Shades of Lincoln-Douglas: Spano vs. Brodsky

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: OSSINING

 BODY:
INVOKING the spirit of the Lincoln-Douglas debates, which took place in parks in Illinois during the summer of 1858, the Westchester chapter of the League of Women Voters last week sponsored an Independence Day dialogue between two Democratic primary candidates for County Executive.
Before the holiday concert and traditional July Fourth fireworks at Louis Engel Waterfront Park here, County Clerk Andrew J. Spano and State Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, who represents the 86th District, sparred on issues involving the environment, housing and property reassessment -- at times, generating their own fireworks display. 
 Mr. Spano, County Clerk since 1980, was chosen in May by the party organization to challenge County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, a four-term Republican seeking re-election. Mr. Brodsky, a former member of the County Board of Legislators and six-term State Assemblyman, was the Democrats' choice four years ago to run against the incumbent, but he lost in a relatively close race, 52 percent to 48 percent, to Mr. O'Rourke.
Mr. Spano -- who also sought the party's nomination in 1989 to challenge Mr. O'Rourke but stepped aside then to allow Mr. Brodsky to run -- vowed to come back to fight another day if the Assemblyman was unsuccessful.
 
Allegations Against O'Rourke
 Going into the debate, there were some hard feelings on the part of Mr. Spano and party leaders, who believe that Mr. Brodsky should not be dividing Democrats at a time when a united front is important to their effort to unseat Mr. O'Rourke.
The incumbent has been troubled by allegations in recent months that he sought jobs and favors for friends and family members. The matter is still being investigated by the District Attorney's office.
In 1989, when Mr. Brodsky ran against Mr. O'Rourke, the alleged misdeeds focused on Playland, the county-run amusement park in Rye, where concessionaires claimed that they were obliged to contribute to the county Republican Party to win contracts and where some county employees were given Republican Party administrative tasks to perform during their work hours. The Playland issue faded when its former director, E. Richard Keeler, a Republican appointee was convicted only of minor charges.
Because Mr. Brodsky announced in May that he was aiming this year, too, to take down Mr. O'Rourke -- saying there was never a formal agreement that he would not run again for the county executive position -- the two Democrats are to face each other on Sept. 14.
Last week, as the sun made its way around to the west and temperatures hovered above the 90-degree mark in the waterfront park, Mr. Brodsky and Mr. Spano debated the issues, attracting a crowd of more than 300 holiday revelers, who took an hour out to listen to the candidates' impassioned dialogue over the noise of passing trains and boats.
"It may not be known to all of you, but from where we stand today, Abraham Lincoln twice passed, once on his way to Washington to become President, and four years and two months later as a martyred President to be buried in Springfield, Ill.," the 47-year-old Mr. Brodsky, a Harvard Law School graduate, told the crowd.
 
'Important for the Future'
 The issues that Abraham Lincoln, 49 and a former Congressman running for the Senate, and Stephen A. Douglas, 45 and a two-term Senator, debated 135 years ago eventually led to the Civil War, with the Democratic incumbent winning the 1858 Senate race and Lincoln becoming the 16th President three years later.
"The issues we face today are, thank goodness, not as elevated, not as passion stricken, but they may be at least as important for the future of our county and our people," said Mr. Brodsky, who lives in Greenburgh.
For his part, Mr. Spano, who lives in Yorktown Heights, called upon more recent history for his opening comments, drawing an analogy between big business and the county government. "Five years ago, I.B.M. had to make a decision, and the decision it made gave it its destiny into the future," the former social studies and history teacher said. Later, in an interview, he explained that he meant that I.B.M. had lost its competitive edge by resting on its laurels and not looking ahead.
Westchester is in much the same position as I.B.M. was five years ago, said Mr. Spano, a 57-year-old graduate of Fordham University who was named Clerk of the Year last month by the New York State Association of County Clerks. "We are heading into a whole new society, a society that will be dealing with a world economy, a concern for the environment, a whole information revolution based on new technologies," he said. "And it will require the foresight of the next county executive to see that future and guide this county into the 21st century."
In the first of three questions that the League of Women Voters had prepared for the primary candidates, the moderator, Nancy Basset, a director of the Westchester League of Women Voters and the State League, asked, "Without destroying home rule, what role should the county play in developing regional plans to protect the watersheds and air quality?"
Mr. Brodsky, seizing the moment to refer to questions about Mr. O'Rourke's integrity in office, said, "The government has become a sewer of corruption and patronage, and the county's ability to speak credibly to issues of environment, tax policy, housing and the rest have become fundamentally eroded."
 
Environmental Issues
 Referring also to his role as chairman of the State Assembly's Environmental Conservation Committee, Mr. Brodsky said that the county should treat open space as parkland, stop county employees from selling the right to dump toxic water into county sewers and "look to this great river again as a resource that unites the county."
Mr. Spano spoke about the problems of polychlorinated biphenyls in the Hudson River and excessive nitrogen in Long Island Sound and said that if he became county executive he would establish a Department of the Environment to address those issues.
When the County Clerk suggested that the State Environmental Review Act be restructured because it has "stopped development" and did not, in fact, benefit the environment, the Assemblyman lashed back.
"That law has been the single most effective protection for environmental concerns in this state," said Mr. Brodsky, who called his opponent's comment "a profoundly dangerous idea."
The second question of the debate was: "What role should the county play in meeting the need for affordable housing in Westchester? How should the burden of meeting the need be allocated to each municipality?"
Mr. Spano called for an "eclectic and comprehensive housing policy" and suggested using existing space in shopping centers, storefronts, abandoned buildings and other commercial sites to develop housing for the elderly, the homeless and civil service workers, among others.
Again, calling for a government that is not "patronage ridden, corruption ridden," Mr. Brodsky said the county must build a consensus with local leaders in order to locate more affordable housing in communities throughout Westchester.
 
Housing Plans
 But the two tangled over the issue of who would have the final say if the county and local governments disagreed on housing plans. Mr. Brodsky said he would work in a "collegial and cooperative manner" with local government officials. And while Mr. Spano said he, too, believed in building a consensus -- "I'm very good at it. It's one of the reasons for my success in my present office," he said -- the County Clerk added that if a consensus was not reached, he was willing to make tough decisions.
"Would you make them over the objections of local governments?" Mr. Brodsky asked.
Mr. Spano answered, "If it was in the best interest of the people of Westchester County, yes."
Mr. Brodsky called his opponent's position on the matter "a blueprint for disaster."
The final question -- "Where do you stand on the question of tax reassessment?" -- provoked yet more disagreement during the debate, again about the balance of power between county and local government.
Mr. Brodsky, linking Mr. Spano with the current administration in White Plains, said, "The message is clear: the Spano-O'Rourke philosophy of a county government coming in and telling you what to do, coming in and telling you you've got to reassess, coming in and telling you you've got to build housing without a process of consultation -- my goodness, it's anti-democratic."
In response, Mr. Spano, said, "All I'm telling you is that this is a major problem that is not going to be solved very easily."
Mr. Spano got the last word in his closing remarks, criticizing Mr. Brodsky for saying he backed no increase in taxes, but supporting measures in Albany that would in fact raise taxes. "My grandfather used to say, 'Guarda le mani, non ascoltare la bocca' or 'Watch the hands, don't listen to the mouth,' " he said.
The two candidates did agree on the answer to one question raised by a member of the audience about the future of the Indian Point 3 nuclear power plant in Buchanan, which has been temporarily shut down by the New York Power Authority, which owns it, because of management and operational problems.
 
Encouraging Business
 Both men said the plant should eventually be phased out. Mr. Spano, though, took the opportunity to chastise Mr. Brodsky, who was chairman of the Assembly's Subcommittee on Air Quality and Nuclear Issues, for allowing the problems to develop.
After each candidate was asked how he would encourage business for Westchester, Mr. Brodsky suggested restructuring the state capital gains tax to help owners of commercial buildings (a process the Legislature began a month ago), retraining white-collar workers and holding down taxes.
Mr. Spano, who has written an economic development plan for the county, encouraged audience members to ask his office for copies of the plan.
The League of Women Voters is planning more debates between candidates for county posts but has yet to announce the schedule.

Cablevision Channel 34 will play the hourlong tape next Saturday at noon and July 20 at 9 P.M. for subscribers in Mount Kisco, Bedford, Yorktown, Somers and Putnam County.

HEADLINE: Viewpoints;
Health Reform Runs Antitrust Risk

BYLINE: By LEONARD ORLAND; Leonard Orland is a professor of law at the University of Connecticut in Hartford.

 BODY:
UNWANTED side effects are the bane of medicine, and they may bedevil the Clinton health reform effort, too. As policy makers cure health care's inaccessibility and high cost, they may unwittingly create new ailments in the area of antitrust.
These risks are real. While the specifics of the "managed competition" reforms are unknown, the Administration has embraced general principles that may dangerously increase the economic concentration of the health-care industry. There will be fewer, and bigger, buyers of health care, sellers of health care, and insurers: 

Item. The reforms will organize individuals and all but the largest employers into hug purchasing cooperatives that, in theory, will force insurers to compete hard for business.
The notion sounds good -- although the performance of such volume buyers as the United States Government and Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield hasn't exactly proven the proposition. But what about the vastness of these cooperatives, which sometimes will cover a whole state and include millions of people? These single buyers -- monopsonies -- can be as economically dangerous as the more familiar monopolies, or single sellers.
 
Item. Only big sellers can meet the needs of big buyers. For this reason, under reform most of the multibillion-dollar health insurance market will go to the biggest insurers -- Aetna, Cigna, Metropolitan Life, Prudential and Travelers.
Known as the "Gang of Five," these huge companies have formed an alliance to promote managed competition. Why? The companies' annual reports explain.
Managed competition is "one of our most attractive [profit] opportunities," says the Travelers report. Cigna's report sees prospects for "improved revenue growth and better margins" in light of the "new Administration's health care policy." These and the other big insurers are optimistic because they know that in the world of reform many smaller insurers, unable to service the big buyers, will fail. This will leave the large insurers with a powerful oligopoly.

THE reforms will concentrate health-care power in many other ways. To become more efficient and more able to handle large buyers of insurance, for instance, doctors and hospitals will form provider networks. In turn, many of these networks will link up with the large insurers, thus forming even larger entities. (Indeed, Cigna is already assembling a network in the New York area.) Finally, for administrative services, many purchasing cooperatives and big corporate insurance buyers will turn to the big insurers -- and create still-larger groups.
In short, under reform big and few will replace small and many.
The Administration is not unaware of this dangerous convergence of power. In mid-June, it recommended that health insurers be stripped of antitrust immunity, something they have enjoyed since passage of the McCarran-Ferguson Act in 1945. Also, the Administration thus far has rebuffed doctors, hospitals and pharmaceutical companies who have requested similar immunities.
But policy makers must be even more sensitive to the antitrust dangers of health reform. First, they must realize that economic concentration is dangerous even if antitrust immunities are not granted. Such concentration is inherently dangerous because, "like all power, it is laden with the possibility of abuse," in the words of Irving Kaufman, the eminent Federal judge.
Second, as they focus on cutting health costs and raising accessibility to health care, policy makers must closely examine their proposals' antitrust effects. Are there equally effective reforms that avoid dangerous concentrations of power? Are there safeguards that can put in place? How, in detail, will this brave new world of health care be regulated? Who will oversee the regulators?
For example, the purchasing cooperatives may well receive some form of antitrust immunity because, as single sellers in a defined area, they can hardly function without immunity. If so, policy makers must be aware that the giant insurers are likely to become the cooperatives' administrators. As such, the insurers may benefit from this immunity even if their own has been stripped away.
If health reformers are vigilant, perhaps they can steer clear of the dangers that so justifiably worried Senator John Sherman when he drafted the nation's basic antitrust law more than 100 years ago. Health reform should not be a cure that creates another disease.

LENGTH: 1566 words

HEADLINE: THE MIDWEST FLOODING;
Flood Leaves 250,000 Without Water to Drink

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DES MOINES, July 11

 BODY:
After several days of hope that this city might escape the fate of so many others in the Mississippi River watershed this sodden summer, the Des Moines and Raccoon Rivers overflowed today, ruining the fresh-water supply of 250,000 people, cutting off the electricity to thousands of homes and businesses and forcing hundreds of people to flee before dawn.
The rivers merge near the center of Des Moines, and early this morning they flooded the plant that supplies water to the city and several suburbs. The disruption of the drinking water supply could last up to a month, officials said this evening. And as some residents scrambled to obtain emergency water brought in by truck, long lines formed elsewhere when residents flocked to stores to buy bottled water. 
 The flooding closed downtown bridges that link the east and west sides of the city and prompted city leaders to urge downtown workers not to go to their jobs on Monday.
 
The Rising Toll
 Des Moines is the latest crisis site in a siege of Midwestern floods along the Mississippi and its tributaries that has forced more than 30,000 people from their homes and caused 22 deaths since late last month. Damage to crops and property is estimated at more than $2 billion in Illinois, Iowa, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska, South Dakota and Wisconsin.
Vice President Al Gore said today that he would visit the flooded areas of Missouri on Monday.
The ultimate scope of the destruction depends on the weather, and forecasters said today that there were signs that the stubborn system causing unrelenting rain in the Upper Midwest, along with the leaden heat on the East Coast, was about to break up.
 
Drying Out Is in Sight
 Daniel Graf, a meteorologist at Pennsylvania State University, said that there was a chance for heavy rain in the next two days but that after Wednesday the probability of rain would decrease and a drying-out period would begin.
Estimates of the economic toll from the flooding will not be possible for some time.
"It's difficult to give an exact damage estimate until the water starts going down, when you'll see you'll have sewer lines, water treatment plants, streets, roads, bridges, people's homes, businesses -- all have damages," James Lee Witt, the new director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, said today on the CBS News program "Face the Nation."
 
Price Effects Unknown
 Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy said he had visited flooded farms and added, "It's the worst disaster, agricultural disaster, that I've seen in quite a while."
But Mr. Espy, who appeared today on the ABC News program "This Week," said it was too soon to know whether the flood would have a substantial effect on food prices.
In Des Moines the concern was not food, but water. Mayor John Dorrian said that while water for sprinkler systems and fire hydrants would probably be available in a week, the drinking water supply could probably not be restored for a month.
The Des Moines Water Works is adjacent to the Raccoon River, from which it draws the city's water supply. While the plant is surrounded by a system of levees to protect it from the river's periodic floods, this one was too high.
Mayor Dorrian said that a second night of heavy rain pushed the river over the sandbag dikes and earthen barriers about 3:30 A.M. today, submerging not only the plant's pumps and generators in eight to nine feet of water, but also contaminating the complex filtration and purification system.
The pumps that supply water to Des Moines were turned off so the taps in the city did not flow. In the suburbs, which receive water from Des Moines but have their own pumping systems, faucets would run but residents were warned not to drink the water.
Arrangements are being made for trucking in millions of gallons of drinking water from nearby towns and grocery warehouses and distributing it at dozens of locations around the city.
But many people did not wait for the emergency supplies. At one grocery store, 200 to 300 people were in a line that snaked through the parking lot at 7 A.M.
The Mayor said water would be strictly rationed to about two gallons a person. "The water is for drinking only," he said. "It's not for bathing or anything else. But we're still in pretty good shape. It's not a panic situation."
 
Evacuations in a Suburb
 The day before, the area's residents got a preview of how unpredictable the rivers can be. In West Des Moines on Saturday, the Raccoon River broke a sandbag dike and flooded the historic Valley Junction business district of the 37,000-resident suburb.
The police and National Guard, sometimes using boats, evacuated 3,500 people. Today, much of the district, with its antique shops and art shops, was under five feet of water.
The Des Moines River, which is much bigger than the Raccoon, runs through the heart of the state's largest city, and when it rose to inundate a power substation early today, it threw much of the central part of the city into darkness. Traffic lights stopped signaling and elevators went dead.
The Des Moines Register, the state's largest newspaper, could not run its computers or presses and was forced to move its operations to makeshift offices in a suburb. With the help of two other Iowa newspapers, The Register struggled to publish an eight-page special edition for distribution on Monday. It faxed articles to a paper in Indianola to be laid out and then had the pages flown to Iowa City to be printed.
Evelyn Fincher, a spokeswoman for the Army Corps of Engineers, said the Des Moines River was not the major source of the city's problems. Flood-control dams and reservoirs, although severely taxed, were working as designed, she said.
The problem, she said, was with the Raccoon River, which merges with the Des Moines at the edge of downtown. That river has no control systems and the two nights of rain overfilled it earlier than officials had expected. If there had been time to plan, the officials could have reduced the flow of the Des Moines River from the Saylorville Dam upstream to help take more water from the Raccoon, but "we did not anticipate it cresting right now," Ms. Fincher said.
 
Volunteers at the Library
 Carolyn Greufe, who works in the fine arts department of the Des Moines Public Library, said several inches of water had seeped into the basement of the old building, which sits just a few feet from the Des Moines River levee. She said 50 volunteers had moved 10,000 to 20,000 books upstairs between 3 A.M. and 6 A.M. today.
"It was so dark, you couldn't even see people's faces," she said. "We formed a human chain and moved the books upstairs. There were flashlights and candles to guide us, that's it."
One volunteer she did recognize was a homeless man, one of the many people who have been fighting the rivers here all weekend. There were lawyers and doctors. There was a retired Air Force pilot and students. There was a homemaker who lives on high ground but said she "wanted to help out because people helped me so much when my first husband died of cancer."
Mayor Dorrian termed the flooding a shock. "No one could have planned for this," he said. "We had the levee system in place and we thought it was more than adequate, but it was not."
 
Crest Delayed at St. Louis
 As levees collapsed along the Mississippi River, giving the water a wider space in which to spread, officials with the Army Corps of Engineers in St. Louis moved the projected date of the river's crest to Saturday from Wednesday. The river, at 42.8 feet today, is expected to crest at 45 feet.
Floods chased people from two more towns along the Mississippi over the weekend. In Winfield, Mo., just north of St. Louis, and in Grafton, Ill., a rush of sandbagging failed to hold back the water, and the homes of more than 1,000 people were flooded.
In St. Louis, some raw sewage was allowed to flow into the river to prevent water from backing into homes. "This is nothing unusual," said Gary Dyhouse, a spokesman for the Army Corps in St. Louis. "No one should drink from the river water."
He said the city had released sewage into the river during heavy floods "several times in the last 20 years." He said the sewage had been diluted by the heavy volume of water, and he noted that all river water was treated before getting into the drinking supplies of communities downstream.
Water from the creeks and rivers that overflowed in Kansas City on Saturday night receded today, the Fire Department reported, leaving the streets largely free of water. The authorities found the body of a man, thought to be a transient, along Southwest Boulevard, and he is believed to have drowned.
The business and manufacturing plants along Southwest Boulevard were under as much as six feet of water on Saturday, and rescuers had to help people trapped in buildings along the boulevard escape.
The Blue and Kaw Rivers, and Brush and Turkey Creeks, tributaries of the Missouri River, were responsible for Saturday's flooding. Kansas City is under no immediate threat from the Missouri River itself, said Phillip Wall, chief dispatcher for the Kansas City Fire Department. A levee system protects the city to a river height of 45 feet, and the river crested at 40 feet Saturday. It would take another week of heavy rainfall for Kansas City to be seriously threatened, Mr. Wall said.

LENGTH: 2040 words

HEADLINE: Mexicans Fear for Corn, Imperiled by Free Trade

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN MATEO TEPOPULA, Mexico

 BODY:
Before they plant even one kernel of corn, the Perez Rueda brothers always follow the timeless Mexican custom of using the first 12 days of the year to predict the weather of the coming 12 months. It rained here last Jan. 5 so they planted in May, the fifth month, and their corn is almost three feet high.
Joel and Benjamin Perez Rueda firmly believe that abiding by the old tradition has brought them success, the proof being that in 13 years they have moved up from two mule teams to three tractors, including one they bought just last year because it was such an "ano maicero" -- a good corn year. 
 But they are worried about next year. They know the custom won't help them handle the big changes that will come if the United States Congress approves the North American Free Trade Agreement and Mexico is flooded with cheap corn from the north.
"Look at what happens when other products are allowed in and the local market gets wiped out," said Benjamin Perez Rueda, 36, jumping off his new Ford tractor on a misty morning in the Chalco Valley, about 25 miles east of Mexico City. "The truth is, the treaty is not going to help us at all."
 
Farmers in Trouble
 Even with a 15-year shelter that protects Mexican corn longer than any other products covered by the trade agreement, people here are worried. While many Mexicans would benefit from the new jobs that are expected to be created, corn farmers like the Perez Ruedas would be hard pressed to survive the fierce new competition. Peasant farmers could be hurt even more, and thousands could be left with few choices but to abandon their land and head either to Mexico's already crippled cities or to the United States.
The trade agreement still faces a tough fight in Congress. And a Federal judge in Washington recently increased the uncertainty by ordering the United States Government to assess the environmental impact of the agreement, a process that could take several months. But most people here believe it is inevitable, just as inevitable as the cultural changes that are already under way as Mexico tries to modernize.
As people become more well-to-do, they generally consume less corn, the food of the poor. Bread replaces tortillas, steak replaces tamales, Ford tractors replace mule teams. Mexico City now has Jenny Craig Weight Loss Centers and Denny's restaurants, but whether such changes represent improvements in the quality of life or a long slide toward cultural obscurity is unclear.
"Corn still connects the Mexicans of today with Mexicans from before the conquest, but when you don't get a good tortilla in a restaurant, it's a very good indication of a deterioration of the quality of life," said Homero Aridjis, a Mexico City poet and environmentalist who is constantly tested by the sweet, long-ago memory of his grandmother's handmade tortillas. "It's just like when the French do not find a good baguette in their restaurants. It shows something serious has happened."
 
The Indian Heritage
Corn and Mexico Evolve Together
 At last the rains have come, and the dark volcanic fields of the Chalco Valley are erupting with an ancient variety of cream-colored corn.
But here and there in the jagged rows tended by Leopoldo Neria Rodriguez and his black and white mules Aguacate and Paloma sprouts an even older type of corn called teosinte, a reminder of the Aztec people who lived in these misty hills half a millennium ago.
In some Indian tribes the word for meals refers only to corn. But corn represents far more than food. Since Indian wanderers first decided to save gnarled kernels of a tiny ear of corn 7,000 years ago and plant them the next season, Mexico and corn -- here it is called maiz -- have evolved together.
Corn cannot grow without man and man cannot survive without corn -- from the earliest times, Mexicans have interpreted this as a lesson for a life of self-sacrifice. Growing corn is a national obsession, even though this is a nation cruelly unsuited for agriculture. More than half of Mexico is arid, and more than half of all land is too steep for cultivation. Yet corn is grown in all 31 states by nearly three million farmers, mostly peasants working small, inefficient fields without irrigation and at the mercy of the rains. With their families, they represent nearly a quarter of all Mexicans.
Because corn comes from the land, land too is an important part of Mexican life, and was a big factor in the violent 1910 revolution. Rambling haciendas were seized from their Spanish owners and the land was redistributed to peasants, who used it to grow corn.
But no green revolution ever followed because corn grows most productively on large flat fields, the kind found in Iowa, not Oaxaca. Average yields in Mexico are one-third those in the United States. Many Mexican farmers either cannot afford or stubbornly resist improvements like tractors, fertilizer or improved hybrids.
Even though cultural changes are reducing the middle class's reliance on corn, Mexico's young population keeps growing by 2 percent a year, increasing the demand for corn and turning self-sufficiency into a matter of national security. A complex system of subsidies has evolved, accompanied by inefficiency and corruption. At a cost of almost $2 billion a year, the Government buys all the corn that Mexicans produce, at nearly $200 a metric ton, almost twice the world price. Then it has to subsidize tortillas, to bring the price back down.
Even so, Mexico often must import corn from the United States to satisfy demand. The corn is dyed green or pink at the border so it cannot be sold back to the Government at a profit.
The price of local corn has gone so high, while other subsidies have shrunk or disappeared, that many farmers who once grew other crops have switched to corn. The production of rice, cotton and sorghum in Mexico has dropped, while corn production, and corn subsidies, have soared. Even without a treaty such a system is unsustainable, and Mexican officials have studied alternatives, including direct payments to farmers who grow corn and other crops, and subsidies based on income.
Whichever is chosen, many who live by corn face an uncertain future. Big farmers can simply switch to some other crop. Peasants who grow only the corn they eat can continue as they always have. But those in the middle, like the Perez Ruedas, stand to be squeezed out by the new competition and the loss of subsidies. According to the World Bank, in the first five years of the treaty, from 145,000 to 300,000 farmers could abandon their land and head for the cities.
When they leave, they will take with them an unwritten encyclopedia of knowledge about hundreds of varieties of corn that have been cultivated for generations until they became ideally suited to their own weather and soil conditions. Scientists are concerned that the genetic stock that is lost may never be recovered.
To Americans used to supermarket yellow corn, the variety of corn grown here -- from stubby cobs like pine cones to those with red, white and speckled black kernels -- is staggering. Mauricio R. Bellon, a scientist at the National Autonomous University of Mexico who has studied this biological diversity, worries that important gene strains could be lost under the coming economic and cultural changes.
The International Maize and Wheat Improvement Center in Texcoco, near here, has already set up the world's largest corn seed bank with nearly 13,000 samples. But its directors fear they might not be able to keep up with the rate of abandonment if the economy is transformed.
 
The Staff of Life
For Mexico's Poor, Corn Is Everything
 In one swift, easy motion, Graciano Palma Mancilla splits open the soil with his coa, a three-foot-long digging stick. Except for its wide steel blade, made from a discarded tractor part, the coa is a replica of the planting tool used by his Aztec ancestors.
"We planted 15 days ago," he said, "but it was just too dry. Look." He jabbed his coa into the ground near a spindly seedling. Then he dipped his left hand into a plaid pouch on his waist and took out a small handful of dried corn kernels, which he flipped into the hole.
For roughly $10 a day, Mr. Palma Mancilla will repeat the same motions up and down long rows on the San Juan farm in Temamatla, also in the Chalco Valley. He has his own field of corn to tend, but it is too small and he is too poor not to have to work for someone else. That, he says, is life in Mexico.
For him, there isn't much more to life than corn. He lives with his wife and three children, and the corn they grow provides them with food every day: corn porridge in the morning, tortillas and beans for lunch, a stew with tortillas at night.
"Without corn," he said, "what are we going to eat?"
For the poor, the answer is little else. Per capita consumption of corn in Mexico exceeds 260 pounds a year, which is roughly 3,600 tortillas, or 10 tortillas a day. Almost none of Mexico's harvest goes to feed animals. Here they say an ear of corn fed to a pig is a meal taken from a peasant.
Besides tortillas, corn is turned into soups and tamales -- ground corn steamed in a corn husk. Pushcarts sell corn on the cob, rolled in a crumbly white cheese, and cups of corn kernels doused in atomic chile. At midday, practically every construction crew makes a small fire on which to cook tortillas. A rare fungus that grows on some corn husks is saved and turned into a delicacy called huitlacoche.
But even without free trade, many Mexicans have already changed the way they feel about the crop. In a modern supermarket, pasty tortillas in plastic bags are displayed across the aisle from pasty white bread in plastic bags. In wealthier states near the United States border, people prefer more expensive tortillas made of wheat.
It could be just that the northerners eat more beef, and wheat tortillas taste better with beef than do those made of corn. But to many traditional Mexicans in the center and south of the country, that preference aligns the northerners more with wheat-eating Europeans than with the corn-eating Indians of their past.
 
The Mighty Tortilla
Corn Loses Its Hold On Many Mexicans
 Walls once yellow are stained a greasy gray. A conveyor belt runs ceaselessly and the gas-fired flames of the oven, exhausted into the garage-sized room, give the Marta Elena Tortilleria in the mountain village of Tenango del Aire all the charm of a bus terminal.
Mario Sanchez, 18, figures that on an average day he makes and sells about 12,000 tortillas at the Marta Elena, one of about 24,000 small tortilla-making shops in Mexico. On a special day like the recent celebration of Tenango del Aire's patron saint, John the Baptist, he could go through 35,000 tortillas, especially if they are blue ones made from black corn.
The corn he uses comes from the Chalco Valley, from the fields of Mr. Neria Rodriguez and the Perez Rueda brothers and the farm where Mr. Palma Mancilla works. The shop on Tenango del Aire's main street thus completes an ancient cycle of planting, harvesting and tortilla-making that Cortes found in 1519 when he landed on the coast of Mexico.
Outside the open counter, hoping to rush home before the rains started again, Emma Chong bought a kilogram (2.2 pounds) of tortillas, about 35 of them at a cost of one peso -- 33 cents. Mrs. Chong said she, her husband and their 6-year-old son, Carlos Antonio, would not finish them for a week; they much prefer bread.
Her mother, Concepcion Varela, also bought a kilo, but she and her husband will finish them in two days. She said that in her 66 years she had never gone a day without eating corn, and if for some reason a day should come when she couldn't find a tortilla, she supposed she would eat bread, but she wouldn't like it.
"You see how my children like bread now," she said, clearly concerned with the way her family and Mexico were changing right before her eyes, how their roots seemed no longer to run so deep, and how corn for many no longer was so important. All so different. "But I'll tell you," she said, defiantly, proudly, "for me and for my husband, the tortilla still is everything."
