HEADLINE: Free Trade Pact Is Still a Mystery To Many in U.S.

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 11

 BODY:
Only four months before Congress is expected to vote on the sweeping package of economic changes known as the North American Free Trade Agreement, a New York Times/CBS News poll finds that nearly half of Americans say they have not heard anything about the agreement.
Although President Clinton has often spoken of the consumer benefits of global trade, as he did in Tokyo last week, the White House seems to be letting other parties set the agenda for the national debate on the North American pact. In recent months, Mexican officials and business executives have criss-crossed the United States promoting the agreement, which would create a single free trade zone encompassing Canada, Mexico and the United States. Meanwhile, Ross Perot and some American labor groups and environmentalists have been opposing it with increasing vehemence.
 
A Stalled Campaign
 Administration officials say they cannot begin a sales campaign until side agreements about environmental and labor issues are completed and until Congress ends work on the budget. But the poll charts the problems ahead in selling Congress on the pact, which within the next 15 years would eliminate tariffs and other trade barriers among the three nations. 
 If adopted, the agreement would eventually create a single market of 370 million people, producing and consuming $6 trillion a year in goods and services. Supporters say the pact would create high-technology jobs in the United States, allow a more prosperous Mexico to spend more money on environmental protection and insure political stability in the region.
But detractors contend that the trade agreement would cause the wholesale flight of American factories and jobs to Mexico, increasing pollution in a country known for lax enforcement of environmental laws.
Both sides agree that the pact would cost the United States billions of dollars in forgone tariff revenues, in the cost of retraining workers who lose their jobs to imports and in payments for the environmental cleanup of the United States-Mexican border.
With only about a quarter of Americans in favor of the pact and about a quarter against it, according to the poll, the fate of the trade agreement will depend on whether the Administration can make a compelling case in the coming weeks.
The nationwide poll by The New York Times and CBS News was conducted by telephone with 1,363 adults from June 21 to 24, and has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3 percentage points. The poll found that only 51 percent said they had read or heard something "about the recent proposal to create something called a 'North American free trade zone' composed of Canada, the United States and Mexico." Another 44 percent said they had not read or heard anything, while an additional 5 percent said they were not sure whether they had or not.
 
An Advantage Seen
 Some Administration officials view the poll results as an opportunity and see the public's ignorance of the agreement as an advantage. "Given the intense activity of the opposition, and that we haven't made a full-court press, that indicates that people are open to the arguments for Nafta," said a senior trade official who asked not to be identified.
Some Democrats agree. The lack of understanding "is definitely to Clinton's advantage, because he still has an opportunity to frame the issue for people," Geoffrey D. Garin, a Democratic pollster, said. "The danger is that this ultimately gets framed as a treaty that ships jobs to Mexico."
President Clinton promised in early January to appoint an inter-agency coordinator, whose job it would be to sell the trade pact to Congress and the American people. The search for such a person is now in the final days, people involved in the process said.
Polltakers and members of Congress on both sides of the issue say that the biggest challenge for whomever the President appoints will lie in convincing the American people that the agreement would create jobs in the United States. The poll found that people who have heard of the agreement tend to think, by a margin of nearly three to two, that the pact would result in fewer jobs.
Representative Sherrod Brown, a freshman Democrat from Ohio who is leading opposition among House freshmen to the pact, said he recently visited a concrete factory in his district and found workers there "scared to death" of the agreement. Mr. Brown and several other members of Congress expressed surprise at the poll's results, saying that it contrasted with their mail, which was lopsidedly against the agreement.
"Mail that I'm getting, and everyone else is getting, shows Nafta is going down like the Pizza Hut blimp," Mr. Brown said.
Labor unions and some consumer, religious and environmental groups have been organizing letter-writing campaigns against the free-trade pact. During a paid half-hour commercial on network television a month ago, Ross Perot, the former Presidential candidate, urged Americans to send postcards to Congress condemning the pact.
 
Lobbying Congress, Not Public
 President Clinton has mentioned the agreement at several news conferences and in a handful of speeches. But since the campaign he has not delivered a speech spelling out in detail why he favors the pact. Instead, the Administration has pursued a campaign of lobbying members of Congress and holding small news conferences for print reporters in an effort to influence opinion makers rather than the general public.
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, said the Administration's low-visibility advocacy of the pact is unavoidable since three supplemental agreements are still being negotiated. The latest round of talks ended Saturday near Mexico City. The agreements are intended to protect worker rights and the environment and limit sudden surges in imports as the main agreement lowers tariffs across North America.
Mr. Kantor and other Administration officials have also said that they intend to win majorities in both houses of Congress to put the trade pact into effect as planned on Jan. 1.
Some Democratic politicians suggest that the agreement is a political albatross that will cost the Administration precious political capital that might better be spent on issues closer to President Clinton's heart.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who heads the Finance Committee, said he doubted that a majority of senators supported the pact. "Our party has become a protectionist party," he said.
 
Excuse for Delay
 A Federal judge's ruling that the Administration must conduct a time-consuming environmental impact statement on the pact may prove to be a lucky break for President Clinton, by giving him an excuse to postpone action, Mr. Moynihan added.
Administration officials are instead appealing the decision by United States District Judge Charles R. Richey. They have concluded that delay would run the risk of making the agreement more of an issue in the 1994 Congressional elections, while killing the pact would contradict the President's emphasis on making America compete in the global economy instead of retreat from it.
The poll shows that opponents and advocates of the agreement were evenly split, with 22 percent of the respondents in favor and 23 percent opposed, a difference considered statistically insignificant. Another 6 percent said they had no opionion on the pact. Only respondents who had heard of the plan were asked for their opinions of the pact.
As their chief reasons for opposing the agreement, respondents familiar with the pact most frequently cited: loss of American jobs (17 percent); cheap labor in Mexico (8 percent) and the pact's perceived unfairness to the United States (6 percent).
As their main arguments for favoring the agreement, respondents most frequently cited: the help it would give to all three countries (11 percent); a stimulus to the United States economy (10 percent) and the principle of free trade (7 percent).
The view in Washington has been that the Administration would at some point have to appeal to the American people, as well as lobby Congress. When told the poll results, some politicians and pollsters suggested that public apathy might let the Administration pursue a more narrow campaign restricted to Capitol Hill.

HEADLINE: New Accents for Old Ritual: Vacationing in the Catskills

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SWAN LAKE, N.Y.

 BODY:
The generations who came here to escape New York City's sultry streets called the Catskills "the Mountains," as if no other mountains existed or mattered. More often than not, their comments were flavored with Yiddish.
The crisp air and cool shade of the area are still ambrosia to vacationers. But now many of the voices are Korean and Russian, people flocking to places like Swan Lake because the landscapes remind them of summer places in the mountains near Seoul or in the Urals. The Yiddish that is spoken comes from the Hasidim who have replaced more secular Jews as the mainstay of the area's bungalow colonies. 
 As the Catskills grow more diverse, the region is showing signs of stemming the economic slide that over the years forced many of its resorts to close.
In the region's glory days, the 1940's, 50's, and early 60's, Jewish, Italian and Irish city dwellers would flock north for an inexpensive retreat from the summer heat. The area was close, about two and a half hours from Manhattan, and relatively inexpensive and it welcomed immigrant ethnic groups. The vacationers kept returning, as faithful as the Capistrano swallows. But their sons and daughters are more likely to seek out the Berkshires than the Borscht Belt.
 
Returning, Like Salmon
 Although a handful of big-name resort hotels, like the Concord and Kutsher's, still hold their attraction, many smaller hotels and bungalow colonies have closed. Others have been converted into New Age religious retreats, drug-rehabilitation centers and Orthodox yeshivas.
And at others, the bungalows have been converted into condominiums or co-ops and sold to former New Yorkers who raised their children on Catskills summers before they retired. Now these vacationers, known as the Floridians, have returned to share memories and the natural air-conditioning with summertime companions of old.
"It's like salmon," said Willie Weinberg, 79, who winters in Florida and spends summers in nearby Monticello. "They grow up in the river and then they're going to the sea and after five years they're coming back. That's how it happened to me."
But probably the most startling presence is the Koreans, whose arrival was trumpeted in mid-April when Soung Kiy Min, a businessman, purchased Grossinger's. Once the elegant dowager of a legion of Catskills resorts, Grossinger's went bankrupt and closed in 1986. Its once-majestic lawns grew chaotic with weeds.
Mr. Min hopes to use Grossinger's golf course as the nucleus on which to resurrect the hotel, starting with a 42-room building and indoor pool that he plans to open in September.
People of Korean background have bought at least three other hotels here in surrounding Sullivan County. For owners like Hak Men Kim, whose family bought the dilapidated Golden Swan, a motel boasting one of the lake's best vistas, the experience has been a struggle.
 
Vacation at a Fast Pace
 The Kims have found to their chagrin that most Koreans have yet to adopt the American habit of two- and three-week-vacations.
Instead the Korean-Americans, who constitute 10 percent of the Kims's guests, come up for two or three days to plunder this lake's fabled bass and barbecue their catch on the small beach, then return to their fruit stores or coin-operated laundries. Even the weekends they take are not restful.
"There's not enough time to enjoy here so they don't sleep," said Hak Men Kim. "All night they fish and they eat."
Mr. Kim and his wife, Young, left Korea 13 years ago, labored in the South's tobacco farms and mills, then bought a Bronx fish store. They fell in love with the Catskills on a skiing trip in 1985.
"My country is the same as here," said Mr. Kim. "It's mountains. It's up and down. Big trees. Lake. It's beautiful."
Working virtually round the clock, Mr. Kim has spruced up the 28 rooms and cleared the beaches of debris while Mrs. Kim has run a small restaurant and their twin daughters, Karan and Kayeon, 17, have straightened rooms. The daughters attend high school in nearby Liberty with only a handful of other Korean students.
 
Praise God, Have Some Fun
 Besides the hotels, there is also a Korean-American bungalow colony -- the Catskills word for clusters of white cottages with a handball court and a pool that is always advertised as Olympic-sized even when its no bigger than a hot tub.
Ye Shik Choi, a Presbyterian elder in Flushing, Queens, has turned a nine-bungalow colony into a combination guest house and religious retreat called Bethel Mission Village. He fills bungalows with families or groups of teen-agers from congregations in New York City.
Along with enjoying the pool, his guests study the Bible and pray in the chapel, once the colony's "casino."
During the 1950's and 1960's, "casino" was a somewhat inflated Riviera-flavored name for a game room with battered sofas and a tiny stage that was the social center of each colony. The women played mah-jongg, the men played pinochle and smoked cigars, and their teen-age sons and daughters went through their first awkward romantic gropings.
This week, three young men with guitars and drums were using the former casino to rehearse a rock 'n' roll spiritual. Outside, Korean-American boys and girls played volleyball.
"We came here to pray, praise God and have a little fun," said Brian Son, 14, a student at Brooklyn's Midwood High School.
Although Russian-Americans have yet to buy any of the resort hotels, they have established a strong presence. Paula Yeager, a local real-estate agent, said some Russian community groups from New York City rent entire bungalow colonies for the summer and parcel them out to their members.
With their Slavic accents, working-class origins and Old World habits, the Russian-Americans remind year-round residents of the Jewish war refugees who filled many bungalows in the 1950's and 1960's. But, though most of the new Russian visitors are Jewish, few speak Yiddish or were raised with Jewish traditions.
 
Reminders of Home
 Like the Koreans, many Russians are attracted by the area's resemblance to their homeland.
On the day Leah Borodova, 71, of Brooklyn, arrived at Willow Acres colony here, she made a syrupy juice out of green apples she had picked. She is also eager to hunt for ripe mushrooms in the woods behind the colony, then dry them for winter storage, just as she did in the Urals.
"The air, the weather, the quietness," she said. "I think I'm there at home."
Mrs. Borodova came here for two weeks with two grandchildren, Anna Beylin, 9, and her cousin Alex Beylin, 15, and Alex's mother, all for $400, about the cost of two days in Martha's Vineyard. Anna's parents, computer programmers, were expected for the weekend, squeezing their own cots into the two-room bungalow in the manner of bungalow dwellers of the past.
Once there were more than 400 bungalow colonies, said Al Bard, a longtime owner. Now the Yellow Pages list 175, but residents are skeptical that that many are in operation.
Many of the rest of the colonies have sold off individual bungalows as co-ops or condominiums for about $15,000 each, with Jewish retirees often the purchasers.
Willie Weinberg, a retired food shop owner, helped turn Silbert's Resort Community near Monticello Raceway into co-ops. When he was younger, Mr. Weinberg and his wife, Lola, would take their son, Marty, and daughter, Marilyn, out of Queens to now-defunct colonies like Zager's in Swan Lake. In the mid-1980's, after years of trying other vacation spots, they returned.
One-third of the resort's 57 bungalows are owned by Holocaust survivors who try to rekindle some of the atmosphere of their younger days when Catskills camaraderie had to substitute for the families they lost in Europe. They could breathe air reminiscent of their Polish towns, learn American dances and card games and give their children a respite from the clamorous streets.
"When we came to the mountains, we found our friends," Mr. Weinberg remembered. "Between survivors, it's one, two, three. You go to the casino Saturday night and the next day you're friends."
"And a week later you're enemies," added Mrs. Weinberg.
 
Fathers Arrive on Weekends
 Mrs. Yeager, the real-estate agent, estimates that 75 percent of the remaining bungalow colonies are held by Hasidic groups. Decades ago, when the Weinbergs began coming to the region, the Hasidim were a small presence. But now, with their large families and distinctive garb, they now give the Catskills the look of the European shtetls.
The women at one colony with the business-like name of Nel Education Center cluster in lawn chairs encircled by baby carriages and small children. They replace their customary wigs with cooler turbans and play board games like Othello or dip in a pool enclosed with a high fence to safeguard their modesty.
The men drive up on weekends or brief vacations and spend much of their days inside, in a study hall. "Studying is one thing you never take a vacation from," said David Weiss, a Satmar Hasid from Brooklyn's Williamsburg who learned enough plumbing to manage the colony.
Mr. Weiss, who charges $1,200 for the summer, is not impressed with the arrival of the Korean- and Russian-Americans, predicting that they, too, will one day become upwardly mobile and forsake the Catskills.
"They won't last," he said. "The Hasidim have no choice. You can't take 10 children and go off to Europe."

HEADLINE: Clinton Ends Asia Trip at Korea's Demilitarized Zone

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PANMUNJOM, Korea, July 11

 BODY:
Seeking to underscore the economic and security concerns that now define the relationship between the United States and its Pacific allies, President Clinton ended a six-day trip to Asia today by visiting one of the most menacing vestiges of the cold war -- the demilitarized zone between North and South Korea.
Mr. Clinton's visit to Japan and South Korea, which revolved around last week's meeting of the leaders of the seven richest industrialized democracies, was part economics primer and part military maneuver for a President who won election by emphasizing his country's domestic needs.
Mr. Clinton used the occasion to address some of the 36,000 American troops stationed in South Korea in a speech intended to build the President's stature by demonstrating through words and pictures that he can be an able Commander in Chief even though he never served in uniform.
 
Tough Talk and a Saxophone
 He courted the soldiers with tough talk about American security and patriotism, and then performed an impromptu riff on a saxophone borrowed from a member of the Army band. He drew his biggest cheer when he mentioned his decision last month to order a missile attack on Iraq in retaliation for what the White House said was a plot to assassinate President Bush. 
 President Clinton's two-day visit to South Korea was devoted almost entirely to demonstrating to Seoul and Tokyo that Washington was committed to stopping North Korea from building nuclear weapons.
"When you examine the nature of the American security commitment to Korea, to Japan, to this region, it is pointless for them to try to develop nuclear weapons," Mr. Clinton said today. "Because if they ever use them, it would be the end of their country."
In several speeches during his trip, Mr. Clinton has talked about the creation of a new Pacific community that will link American economic and security interests. The Administration has offered no specifics on this proposal, but it seems to be aimed, at least in part, at building a bridge of good intentions between Asia and North America and the European Community.
 
Tough Stance on Nuclear Treaty
 At the demilitarized zone, Mr. Clinton stared across the border into North Korea and pledged to "stay strong" on his insistence that North Korea not go through with its threat to withdraw from the the treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons.
"Some day this will all be one country again," he said.
"I hope someday they'll just be able to walk on over here, in peace," he said of the North Korean soldiers.
Later, at Camp Casey, an Army base near the demilitarized zone, Mr. Clinton was cheered by thousands of soldiers of the Second Infantry Division when he praised them for serving "on the frontier of freedom." His remarks were delivered in a hangar decorated with hundreds of yards of camouflage netting, flags and two signs reading: "The Warrior Division welcomes the Commander in Chief."
The only soldiers allowed to talk to reporters were selected by base commanders in an apparent effort at public relations control that was missing when Mr. Clinton toured the aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt off the coast of Norfolk, Va., last year. Then, he was openly criticized by a number of military people who were unhappy about his opposition to the Vietnam War and his pledge to lift the ban on homosexuals in the armed forces.
 
G.I.'s Advised to Behave
 The soldiers who gathered for Mr. Clinton's visit today were advised on how to behave in advance. "Anytime during this speech, it's all right to drown out this microphone," Sgt. Maj. Robert Hall announced before the President arrived. "It's O.K. to raise the roof on this building."
It is the monsoon season here, and Mr. Clinton's trip to the border was hampered by torrential rain that forced him to travel to Panmunjom by motorcade instead of by helicopter.
The rain, however, did not diminish the theatricality of the President's visit. Passing rice paddies and saluting guards, Mr. Clinton stepped onto the short concrete bridge that is blocked off at North Korea's end by a six-foot cinderblock wall as North Korean sentries stood on the other side.
"I looked at them and they were looking at us," Mr. Clinton said afterward. The North Koreans, he added, "have been rather calm in response to my trip here, and that is rather encouraging."
 
'Bridge of No Return'
 Mr. Clinton walked to the middle of the "Bridge of No Return." As he stopped about 30 yards from the North Korean border, Army officials said he became the only American President to come so close to the enemy territory, where North Korean sentries watched his every move.
President Reagan visited the demilitarized zone in 1983 and President Bush came last year. Today, Mr. Clinton combined Mr. Reagan's talent for the compelling backdrop and Mr. Bush's taste in music. Dozens of soldiers dressed in camouflage sat in camera range behind Mr. Clinton during his speech. And beforehand, a soldier sang the Bush campaign standard, "I'm Proud to Be an American."
North Korea alarmed many countries in March when it announced that it would withdraw from the treaty banning the spread of nuclear weapons. North Korea has since "suspended" its withdrawal, and is to continue talks with the United States. But Japan has indicated that it could not yet support the indefinite extension of the treaty, which expires in 1995.
American officials have said on Mr. Clinton's trip that the United States is prepared to lead its allies -- and perhaps China -- into imposing economic sanctions on North Korea. But Mr. Clinton also talked with South Korea's President, Kim Young Sam, about the pace of the negotiations with the North. South Korea has a robust trade relationship with China, established only last August, that could be influenced by the nuclear weapons issue, illustrating the related nature of the concerns Mr. Clinton must address in coordinating his policies on Asia.

 HONOLULU, July 11 (Special to The New York Times) -- After leaving South Korea, President Clinton arrived here today for a brief vacation that began with a visit to the U.S.S. Mr. Clinton and his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, were greeted when they landed here by their daughter, Chelsea, who presented her parents with leis as they stepped off Air Force One. The Clintons are expected to remain here until early Wednesday.

HEADLINE: 2 Who Split on Clinton Budget Find Neither Won

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SALT LAKE CITY, July 10

 BODY:
When Representative Bill Orton broke with his party and voted against President Clinton's budget package, he became an instant hero in the canyons and deserts of his rural district in eastern Utah. But his hopes of winning a choice committee assignment on Capitol Hill plummeted.
When Representative Karen Shepherd of Salt Lake City cast aside her doubts and voted with the President, she faced a barrage of angry constituent phone calls and letters. While she may well have committed political suicide, she became the darling of the House leadership by providing a critical vote for the budget bill, which passed with only a six-vote margin. 
 Like dozens of other Congressional Democrats, Mr. Orton and Ms. Shepherd must once again walk a political high wire. As they consider how to vote for whatever deficit-reduction package emerges from the House-Senate conference in coming weeks, Democratic lawmakers from conservative states like Utah face a difficult choice.
They can embarrass their President, sink an effort to cut $500 billion in deficit spending over the next five years and face retribution from White House and Congressional leaders. Or they can endanger their own political survival by voting for $250 billion in tax increases.
 
Doubts and Fears
 "Members feel isolated," Ms. Shepherd said. "You have this sense when we go back to the districts of going to get beat up."
In a separate interview, Mr. Orton said, "All I want is to be on the Ways and Means Committee, and the leaders have made it clear that I can only be on Ways and Means if I vote with them. But if I vote with them, I won't be in Washington, because my constituents will throw me out of office."
Over the weeklong Fourth of July recess, the two junior Utah lawmakers took to the stump and met with constituent groups, hoping to muffle the political tremors that will come no matter how they vote on the final deficit package.
At some stops, Ms. Shepherd, 53, distanced herself from Mr. Clinton and promised that she would endorse the final version of the economic package only if it included caps on spending for automatic benefits and a deficit-reduction trust fund. Borrowing pages from Ross Perot's book, she displayed charts and trumpeted her "800" telephone number as she called for term limits and more spending cuts.
 
Learning From Perot
 "Never let it be said I didn't learn from Ross Perot," she said at a Harvard Club luncheon here. At another point she joked, "I thought I'd have to wear a sack over my head because President Clinton seemed to be heading for the 'Guinness Book of World Records' for the number of gaffes over the number of weeks."
If Ms. Shepherd sounds like something less than a true-blue Democrat, it is because of the political realities in her strongly Republican Second Congressional District. A former English teacher and magazine publisher, she eked out a victory last year in a district that had not voted for a Democratic Presidential candidate since 1964, largely because she faced a weak opponent whose strident style offended the sensibilities of this Mormon area.
Ms. Shepherd's campaign was highlighted by a television commercial in which she pledged to vote against any tax increase until the nation's health-care system was overhauled.
Since her election, Ms. Shepherd has emerged as a star of the 114-member freshman class in the House. Her fellow Democratic backbenchers elected her as a leader of their effort to revamp House rules, and the House leadership has selected her to help marshal votes for the President's health-care plan when it is introduced.
 
Winning a Reputation
 By leading an effort to slash spending in the legislative branch, as well as the benefits for former Presidents and House Speakers, Ms. Shepherd has acquired a reputation as a deficit hawk in Washington. But in this district, her votes for abortion rights and the Clinton economic package draped her in the politically untenable cloak of liberalism.
National Republicans have already begun working for her defeat in 1994 by financing radio commercials castigating her for her votes.
At a town hall meeting on Thursday night in Riverton, a staunchly Republican suburb of Salt Lake City, Ms. Shepherd could barely put two sentences together before she was interrupted by angry constituents.
"You promised in the campaign you wouldn't raise taxes," said Michael Zufelt, a 34-year-old tire salesman. "You broke your promise."
Ms. Shepherd responded a hint of contriteness: "Yes, I did. Now I have the opportunity to explain."
 
'You're Wasting Your Time'
 But before she could flip through her flow charts, she was interrupted by Russ Sorenson, the 41-year-old owner of a construction supply company. "If you are here to sell the President's plan, you're wasting your time," he said.
Mr. Orton represents an even more conservative district, the Third, but his string of votes opposing abortion rights and Mr. Clinton's packages to stimulate the economy and reduce the deficit may have inoculated him from political harm.
He has received hundreds of congratulatory telephone calls and letters in recent weeks, and at meetings he has received nothing but approving nods when he explains that he cannot vote for energy taxes that he says are unfair to Westerners who must drive long distances.
The former tax lawyer is among three conservative Democrats who are trying to galvanize the 38 House Democrats who voted against the President's economic package into a bloc that would support the package if Democratic leaders drop all energy taxes, make more spending cuts and attach a modified line-item veto to the bill.
 
Courted by Republicans
 Mr. Orton faces an entirely different political equation than Ms. Shepherd. Since he was elected over a stumbling Republican opponent in 1990, he has retained strong approval ratings, and he has been invited by the Republican Party to switch his allegiance.
Mr. Orton, 44, insists that the Democratic Party needs conservative voices, and he is considering a 1994 challenge to Senator Orrin G. Hatch, a Republican. But to run for the Senate he needs to attract contributions, a difficult task because most state and national Democratic groups view him with suspicion.
His slim hopes appear to be based on satisfying Democrats by voting for final passage of the President's package, while protecting his base. He said he could do that as long as the final package excluded the energy taxes and included enough new spending cuts.
Mr. Orton practiced his tightrope act on Friday night at a town hall meeting in Orem, where he said the economic package was being unfairly attacked as simply a tax increase.
The Congressman strongly objected when Lowell H. Christensen, a 70-year-old retired real estate agent, complained that the Democratic Party was deceiving the people by "using words like investment and contribution" to sell the deficit-reduction bill.
"Remember," Mr. Orton responded, "Ronald Reagan coined the term revenue enhancement because he didn't like to use the word 'taxes.' "

HEADLINE: Unions Hammer Out Offer To Try to Revive The Post

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON

 BODY:
The labor unions at The New York Post last night put together a package of the financial concessions demanded by Rupert Murdoch when he shut the newspaper on Friday, but it was not clear whether The Post would be able to move away from the edge of extinction.
In a new round of talks prompted by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, the unions said they had reached Mr. Murdoch's goal of saving $6.2 million of The Post's annual losses of some $12 million to $15 million. Mr. Murdoch threatened to close the newspaper if the savings were not agreed to, and then carried through on his threat Friday afternoon, while the unions were $1.2 million short of the goal. 
 Early this morning, in what seemed to be a tangible step toward reviving the newspaper, representatives of the drivers union said they had reached an agreement with negotiators for Mr. Murdoch that included savings of $2.2 million.
About 2 A.M., Frank Sparacino, the president of the drivers union, said the agreement was being drawn up but declined to give details, saying only that the union had given up some overtime.
Mr. Sparacino had been optimistic yesterday afternoon. "If there is any agreement, even just verbally, with the 6.2, they will definitely open the paper," he said then.
 
Separate Standoff With Guild
 But as the talks wore on last night, Mr. Murdoch's representatives said they were not sure that the union package added up to the concessions Mr. Murdoch demanded. And a separate standoff with the New York Newspaper Guild, which represents some 290 news, advertising and circulation employees, appeared unresolved. If the 9 production unions besides the drivers reached an agreement and the guild did not, yet another crisis could threaten the newspaper.
Both sides credited Governor Cuomo for pushing them to try again to reach an accord. With midnight calls from the Executive Mansion in Albany to Mr. Murdoch's executives over the weekend and 6 A.M. calls to union leaders yesterday, the Governor orchestrated a complex series of meetings through the afternoon and into the night.
Governor Cuomo said a pact at The Post would require the unions to give Mr. Murdoch the savings he requested while recognizing that Mr. Murdoch would continue to shoulder heavy losses to keep the newspaper functioning.
"I think if it happens," Governor Cuomo said in a telephone interview, "what it will be is a kind of model demonstration of shared sacrifice of a kind, frankly, that is needed in many different places in this country in the middle of this post-recession period."
The leaders of the newspaper's 11 unions met at noon yesterday at the Sheraton New York Hotel and Towers on Seventh Avenue in Manhattan. There they worked on the package to try to satisfy Mr. Murdoch. Although Mr. Murdoch's goal of a $6.2 million savings was a clear one, the union's proposals about how to satisfy it were subject to interpretation.
 
Complex Issues
 The complex issues involved changes in such things as work rules governing the number of employees required for various production tasks and rules for computing overtime payments. At 4 P.M. yesterday, Mr. Murdoch's representatives began meeting with the leaders of the unions separately to discuss whether the union proposals met the target set by Mr. Murdoch.
The talks continued into this morning. Howard J. Rubenstein, Mr. Murdoch's spokesman, said that management representatives had believed earlier in the day that that they had achieved the savings Mr. Murdoch demanded. "We thought there would be a paper tomorrow," he said.
But he said that Mr. Murdoch's representatives were unsure as they began to meet with the union leaders individually that the packages the leaders were offering came to the total savings Mr. Murdoch required.
At one point yesterday evening, Mr. Murdoch's representatives told leaders of the newspaper's pressmen's union that the pressmen's package of proposed savings was inadequate and asked them to return with a better offer. When they returned, the second offer was rejected, prompting high-level talks among union leaders and with Governor Cuomo.
Although it has been common in the past for New York newspapers to insist on "me too" agreements after the unions give one city newspaper concessions, the unusual situation at The Post made it unclear whether that pattern would apply now.
Much of the effort yesterday involved the newspaper's 10 production unions, because Mr. Murdoch's financial demands were aimed at them. But underlying all the maneuvering was a growing uncertainty about the other union, the New York Newspaper Guild.
Mr. Murdoch has demanded that that union grant him broad powers to dismiss employees for a four-month period and to use nonunion subcontractors. He also said he would not honor existing severance obligations. Mr. Murdoch has said those demands are not negotiable.
 
Strike Authorized
 In June, the guild authorized its leaders to call a strike, and guild leaders have said they have assurances from the other unions that they would honor guild picket lines.
Last night, Barry F. Lipton, the guild's citywide president, said there had been no progress on the issues affecting the guild. Despite the narrowing of the financial differences between Mr. Murdoch and the other unions, Mr. Lipton warned that those unions could be drawn into yet another crisis.
"They have indicated they are supporting us," Mr. Lipton said. "As you know, we have a strike vote here which we'd use if we absolutely had to."
It was not clear whether the guild would precipitate a crisis at The Post immediately if it did not reach some settlement.
The guild has appeared divided over whether to fight its own battle with Mr. Murdoch immediately if the other unions reach accords on the financial dispute. Mr. Murdoch would eventually be positioned to try to impose his conditions on the guild. But he would not be able to do so now because he is not formally the newspaper's owner.
If Mr. Murdoch were to reach agreements with the other unions, he could then negotiate with the newspaper's creditors on a purchase plan that would have to be approved by the judge who is overseeing the newspaper's bankruptcy proceeding.
When a purchase was finally completed, perhaps several months from now, Mr. Murdoch could seek to force a confrontation with the guild, which is often described as dependent on newspaper production unions to enforce a strike.

HEADLINE: THE MIDWEST FLOODING;
Dams and Levees: Restraint on Nature or Talisman for Flood-Prone Areas?

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 11

 BODY:
The calamitous flooding in the Midwest has rekindled the old debate over whether the United States Corps of Engineers can fool Mother Nature.
Has the $25 billion spent by the Corps through the better part of this century to build 500 dams and 10,000 miles of levees nationwide been a huge pork-barrel boondoggle that fooled only the taxpayers? 
 Given that the current flooding on the Mississippi and Missouri Rivers may turn out to be the worst in memory, would the nation have been better off with a less costly approach, like tougher building and insurance regulations in flood-prone areas?
There are no easy answers to these questions about a system of dams and levees whose construction is sometimes likened to the building of China's Great Wall and Egypt's Pyramids. Nobody is suggesting that the system be abandoned because it is periodically overwhelmed. Nor is anybody suggesting a ban on settlement in flood-prone places, especially since many have been occupied as far back as colonial days, when rivers were the primary means of transportation.
 
Some Second Thoughts
 Still, in spite of all the construction, flooding continues to be the most destructive and costly type of natural disaster in the country, according to the United States Geological Survey, and in the last 10 years or so some experts have begun to have second thoughts about dams and levees.
Part of the hesitancy reflects concern over the Federal budget deficit. It is also partly in response to arguments by environmentalists that the projects inevitably fail to control floods as they are intended to, yet still deface or destroy natural areas.
As a result, Congress now gives the Corps of Engineers more money to maintain old dams and levees than to construct new ones. Last year, Congress took the added step of cutting the agency's budget for its staff by almost 10 percent.
Congress now also requires that communities pay a quarter of the cost of new flood control structures, a major inhibiting factor.
 
Controlling Settlement
 Closer to the flood-prone areas themselves, there is a slow but steady growth in the use of building and insurance regulations to control settlement. And questions are being raised about whether property owners who receive Government disaster aid once should be given a grant after a second flood if they fail to take protective action in the interim.
Even before the current flooding, Congress had begun to look at strengthening ways to prevent flood damage. Representative Doug Bereuter, Republican of Nebraska, suggested that Federal incentives be developed to encourage development away from flood-prone areas and encourage property owners already in such areas to buy flood insurance.
President Clinton apparently favors the new direction in flood control policy. In an early budget proposal he called for barge operators on major rivers to share more of the cost of maintaining channels, which are frequently as important to flood control as to navigation.
One notable measure of the evolving view of flood control is that in the current crisis there have been only one or two calls for new dams and levees. More typical of the new thinking was a comment by John Elmore, the chief of operations and readiness for the Corps of Engineers, when he was asked the other day at a Washington news conference if his agency would respond to the flooding with a burst of new building.
"I would caution against a precept that says that we're going to line the banks of all of our streams with levees," he said, "because that's not going to happen and it shouldn't happen."
 
New Centers of Attention
 Until a few years ago, members of Congress and officials of the Corps tended to talk more about the engineering marvels of flood control than the economic and environmental aspects.
But that was when the budget deficit was smaller and environmentalists were less vocal.
"There's been a genuine change for the better in flood control policy," said David Conrad, a water resources specialist for the National Wildlife Federation, which is concerned with the effect of dams and levees on wildlife habitats. "The pace of construction has slowed significantly. But the fight is not over. The pressure to start building again somewhere, some place, never stops. A lot of people still think they can fool Mother Nature. They don't acknowledge that a dam can destroy a habitat or that a levee can end up causing flood damage if it constricts a river to the point that it just bursts free."
The Corps of Engineers argues that no water control system can be perfect. "As long as we have rains, we're going to have some floods," said Jimmy F. Bates, the agency's chief of policy and planning.
Still, Corps officials say the $25 billion spent so far on flood control represents a solid investment. They say their control system has prevented at least $250 billion in flood damage over the years, which works out to a 10 to 1 return on investment.
 
Calculations Challenged
 Opponents of dams and levees question that calculation. "It's nothing but rank speculation because who can say what a river that hadn't been tampered with might have done or might not have done," countered Brent Blackwelder of Friends of the Earth, an environmental group.
Last year when a Federal task force took a detailed look at the nation's flood control efforts, it found that while the efforts had worked in many places, there had been no reduction in the average number of flood deaths each year and flood damage had cost the average American more than twice as much a year going into the 1990's as in the years before World War II, even when adjusted for inflation.
"Overall vulnerability," the report concluded, "has either increased or stayed the same, probably because of the large amount of vulnerable development already in place, numerous exceptions to the state and local policies that would reduce that development, and the fact that population growth, movement and urbanization sometimes take place so quickly or in such unexpected ways that adequate planning and regulation simply cannot be established soon enough to prevent unwise use of flood plain areas."


GRAPHIC: Levees are dams made out of earth and sand, built parallel to a river bank to prevent flooding.
Diagram: "Holding Back the River"
 As early as 2000 B.C., the Egyptians built levees along the banks of the Nile. The levee system for the Mississippi, begun in New Orleans in 1718, is the most extensive in the world, consisting of almost 3,600 miles of main-river and auxiliary levees.
 The higher the levee, the greater the flood protection, at least in theory. But some engineers protest that high levees enclose a river to such a great degree that its water level rises high above the level of the bank.
 This has been the case on the Mississippi, where the extensive levee system has raised the overall level of the river, forcing higher and higher levees to be built. Some embankments now reach 50 feet or more.
 Currently, the system is failing as floodwaters spill over or break through the levees, inundating the farms and communities they were designed to protect. (Sources: Encyclopedia Americana, Army Corps of Engineers)

HEADLINE: Already Shaky Area Losing Key Pillar: Mrs. Paul's

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, July 11

 BODY:
Crescentville looks like a neighborhood from the 1950's, except for all the "For Sale" signs. This blue-collar section of northeast Philadelphia is filled with rows of tidy, two-story brick homes with metal awnings and an occasional ceramic squirrel. Children spin Hula-Hoops on the street and run through the misty rainbows of lawn sprinklers.
But the troubles of the 1990's have arrived within the ill-defined boundaries of Crescentville, where the residential neighborhood bumps against a ghostly industrial area with empty warehouses, closed manufacturing plants and a boarded-up supermarket. 
 Of all the corporate closings, the one with the most emotional punch is coming at the end of this month, when Mrs. Paul's Kitchens, the frozen-seafood company that has been a Philadelphia institution for decades, will shut its doors and take 504 jobs to Omaha.
"It feels bad," said Thomas Matthew, a 49-year-old city employee who lives in Crescentville, noting that many of his neighbors had spent their entire working lives at Mrs. Paul's and felt betrayed.
 
One Blow After Another
 In recent years, the recession and corporate consolidations have cost several thousand Crescentville residents their jobs at the Pathmark supermarket, Sealtest Foods dairy-processing plant, the 3M Company plant, Sears, Roebuck & Company and Exide Battery. And the neighborhood got a bad scare earlier this year when the Pentagon recommended that a naval supply depot at the northern edge of the community be shut down. But the Federal base-closing commission recently gave the station and its 4,500 workers a reprieve.
Philadelphia has seen its once-strong manufacturing base shrink as the city's economy has become more dependent on service industries, including health services. In 1950, 1 in 3 workers held manufacturing jobs; now that ratio is 1 in 10 and dropping.
The closings in Crescentville have rocked the neighborhood, shuttered some nearby shops and encouraged urban blight, which is creeping inexorably closer to Philadelphia's outlying neighborhoods from the inner city. Even city services are declining, said the Rev. Peter D. Burke, pastor of St. Ambrose Roman Catholic Church.
"Trash collectors don't always come," he said, "and people who are moving in aren't voters, so they don't call their council people and complain." Each month, he said, about 25 families of Irish and German heritage leave his parish and are replaced by Asian and Hispanic families, who, he added, are less likely to complain about the decline in services.
 
Confronting the Unexpected
 He said widespread unemployment and an increase in the number of minimum-wage jobs had cast a "whole depression" over the people of Crescentville.
Residents say they never thought that Mrs. Paul's would close, especially since the plant was refurbished just last fall after a fire.
The frozen-seafood business grew from a concession in a local bar into a national brand name, and, in the process, the company and its founder, Edward J. Piszek, became Philadelphia institutions.
Mr. Piszek, who sold the business to the Campbell Soup Company in 1980, said in an interview last week that he started out in 1946 with $350 and a recipe for deviled crab cakes. He soon discovered that fried fish kept its taste after freezing, so, by 1980, he had expanded into a national company that in one year sold more than $100 million worth of frozen fried fish sticks and fillets.
"I called it Mrs. Paul's Kitchens because we tried to prepare the fish like a fussy old lady," Mr. Piszek said. "We referred to the business as 'the Old Lady.' "
 
Polish Philanthropy
 Over the years, Mr. Piszek became a local legend for spreading his fish profits around the world, especially in Poland, his ancestral home. Among other things, he sent Poland a $1 million fleet of vehicles with chest X-ray machines in the 1940's; a dozen years ago, he sent 10 million pounds of codfish cakes to a flood-stricken area of Poland. He also endowed two foundations with a total of $7 million to encourage the teaching of English worldwide "so more people can communicate with each other for world peace and prosperity," he said.
But Mr. Piszek said he had lost $100 million in a bad investment in 1980 and had sold Mrs. Paul's to Campbell's.
Sales for what Mrs. Paul's advertising calls its "crispy, crunchy, breaded" fish products peaked in 1985, then declined 5 percent to 10 percent each year as diet-conscious consumers began eating less fried food, said Elizabeth Hanlin, a spokeswoman for Campbell's.
In February the company announced that it would close the Philadelphia plant and move its operations to Omaha as part of a consolidation program that would cost the company $300 million. The company does not need to be close to a seaport because it deals with frozen fish.
Mr. Piszek resisted the opportunity to criticize Campbell Soup. "I want to be a decent human being, therefore, I don't want to be an angry old man," he said.
Workers say that Campbell Soup pays a good wage, $8 to $14 an hour, and -- until it announced the closing of Mrs. Paul's -- was a good employer.
 
Fear of the Future
 Anxiety, tinged with anger, was palpable among employees as they streamed from the one-story factory after a recent afternoon shift change.
An employee who has worked for Mrs. Paul's for 28 years but who asked that his name be withheld, said: "When we heard about the closing, everybody was talking about taking a $1-an-hour cut in pay, but it turned out to be a done deal. There was no chance to change the minds of the big corporate millionaires."
The closing is worrying John and Nancy McGlynn, who work at the plant and live a few blocks away. They work different shifts so they do not have to hire a baby sitter for their three small children.
"I've worked there 13 years, since I got out of high school," said Mr. McGlynn, who is 31 and operates a packaging machine. "We live from check to check, and the couple thousand in severance pay won't last long. I don't know how we will pay the mortgage with minimum-wage jobs."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "We live from check to check, and the couple thousand in severance pay won't last long," said John McGlynn, right, who has worked at Mrs. Paul's Kitchens in Philadelphia for 13 years. The plant, which also employs his wife, Nancy, left, is set to close this month. The McGlynns have three children, Paul, left, and the twins, John Jr. and Jillian. (Bill Cramer for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Protecting A Fragile Recovery

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 11

 BODY:
Discouraged by recent weak economic reports, Administration officials are nervous that President Clinton's deficit-reduction plan could slow the economy further. But they see no need for an emergency stimulus package because they are confident that growth will pick up in the second half of this year.
Reluctant to start a new battle over economic stimulus after losing one in April -- and not convinced that stimulus is needed now -- the Administration appears resigned to tinkering around the edges of the budget package to insure that any near-damage it causes to the economy will be minimal. 
 Administration officials said they would urge House and Senate negotiators, when hammering out a compromise budget plan, to pay attention to how leaving in or lopping out certain provisions, like investment incentives, would affect growth.
"I would hope that in the process of reconciliation some thought would be given to the signals the economy is giving out," Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chairwoman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said in an interview.
Ms. Tyson said the Administration would soon lower its growth forecast for this year to about 2.5 percent, down from the 3.1 percent prediction it made in January. But she predicted that the economy would grow at a rate of more than 2.5 percent in the second half of this year, a forecast consistent with those of many private-sector economists. That would be considerably more than the sluggish 1.5 percent growth rate that many economists estimate for the first half.
She said that once President Clinton's budget package wins Congressional approval, growth should accelerate because most of the uncertainties nagging at business would disappear.
Many corporate executives say -- and Republicans are quick to echo them -- that the uncertainties surrounding President Clinton's budget package and the forthcoming health plan are undermining business confidence and causing companies to hold off on hiring and new investments.
To help protect the fragile economy, some Administration officials want to urge Congressional conferees to delay the increase in personal income taxes to July 1, the date the Senate has approved, from last Jan. 1, the date the House approved. The theory is that this delay would make consumers feel richer and thus more willing to buy new homes and cars. But some officials argue against such a delay, saying it will deprive the Government of revenues and probably do nothing to lift the economy.
The Administration is also considering whether to stretch out the phase-in period for proposed energy taxes.
Administration officials admit to feeling gun-shy about proposing a new stimulus plan after Senate Republicans defeated the President's $19 billion jobs plan last April. Nonetheless, the President is eager not to be viewed the way many Americans viewed President George Bush: as someone who sat on his hands while the economy floundered.
Administration officials point to Mr. Clinton's strenuous efforts at the Tokyo summit meeting to get Europe and Japan to stimulate their economies and help American exports. Unfortunately for Mr. Clinton, growth in those economies is not expected to pick up until next year.
The Administration's view is that President Clinton, by proposing his jobs plan and his $500 billion deficit-reduction package, has demonstrated that he is far more aggressive than his predecessor in seeking to nurse the economy back to health. But some liberal Democrats say that after he campaigned to turn the economy around, the President is not being aggressive enough -- and should not have given up his fight for a stimulus package so soon.
Of course, if the economy stumbles for several more months and Mr. Clinton does not take vigorous action to set things right, he might start hearing complaints that he is being as feckless on the economy as Mr. Bush was often perceived to be.
Historically, deficit-reduction plans bite into economic growth by increasing taxes and cutting Government spending. But this time around, Administration officials are optimistic that Mr. Clinton's package will result in faster growth by pushing down interest rates.
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen has often said that the drop in long-term interest rates of a full percentage point since last November will give the economy a stimulus equivalent to that of $100 billion in extra Government spending.
Ms. Tyson said most of the benefits of lower rates had still not percolated through the economy. Some of the Administration's economic models show that only 30 percent of the benefits of falling interest rates are felt in the first year, with the remaining 70 percent felt in the subsequent years.
The Republicans are not as sanguine about the effects of the President's budget package, asserting that its $250 billion in tax increases will pull the economy back toward recession. They see the tax increases as ammunition they can use in the 1994 Congressional elections.
Appearing today on CNN's "Newsmaker Sunday," Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich acknowledged that taking $500 billion out of the economy through tax increases and spending cuts could hurt the fragile recovery.
 
 
'Legitimate Question
 "If we're taking that much out of the economy in terms of trying to reduce the budget deficit, at the same time we're trying to come out of the gravitational pull of the recession, are we taking out too much too soon?" he asked. "That is a legitimate question."
Ms. Tyson also acknowledged that deficit-reduction plans often slow growth, but she said the drop in interest rates would more than offset this. She said such "fiscal drag" would not become substantial for several years, if at all.
One White House official said it would be inappropriate to float a stimulus proposal now because the Administration is focusing on getting the budget package passed and does not want to see itself -- or Congress -- sidetracked by controversial new economic issues.
In the view of one senior official, the Administration might consider some special stimulus measures if there are several more months of disappointing economic news.
The consensus among Administration officials is that a few weeks of bad economic reports -- coming after huge jumps in employment in April and May -- are not enough to send them scrambling to put together a new stimulus package.
"There's been a tendency to overreact to the June employment figures," when the number of jobs rose by just 13,000, one Administration official said. "We need a clearer picture of what's going on. Once we get the budget package behind us and get some more reliable statistics, then we'll have a better sense of where we are."
Many officials say the economy's recent stumbles demonstrate that the Republicans were misguided to kill President Clinton's $19 billion jobs plan. For their part, Republicans respond that the stimulus package was larded with pork-barrel projects and that the recent economic softness has been caused by Mr. Clinton's proposed tax increases and the uncertainties surrounding his budget package.
With the economy stumbling along, one thing many Administration officials do not want is for the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates. Alicia Munnell, Assistant Treasury Secretary for Economic Policy, said she was confident that inflation would remain in control this year and that as a result, a rate increase would not be needed.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
UNIONS AT POST READY CONCESSIONS
The labor unions at The New York Post have put together a package of the financial concessions demanded by Rupert Murdoch when he shut the newspaper on Friday, but it was not clear whether The Post would be able to move away from the edge of extinction. In the new round of talks, which were prompted by Governor Cuomo, the unions said they had reached Mr. Murdoch's goal of saving $6.2 million of The Post's annual losses of about $12 million to $15 million. The unions were $1.2 million short of the target when Mr. Murdoch closed the paper. But Mr. Murdoch's representatives said they were not convinced that the union package added up to the concessions Mr. Murdoch demanded. And a separate standoff with the New York Newspaper Guild, which represents about 290 news, advertising and circulation employees, appeared unresolved. B3.
 
NEW SEX ASSAULT AT CITY POOL
A group of teen-age boys surrounded a 16-year-old girl in an upper Manhattan swimming pool, tore off her bathing suit and fondled her, the police said. Three men were arrested after the incident at Highbridge Park pool in Washington Heights, which the police said was the fifth such attack reported in a New York City pool in less than a week. B3.
 

ELDERLY MAN KILLED IN PURSE-SNATCHING
A 72-year-old man was run over in a parking lot in Bayside, Queens, as he tried to stop a driver from stealing his wife's purse, the police said. The couple was heading toward a Waldbaum's Supermarket in Bayside to buy some groceries when a man pulled up beside them and grabbed the bag. When the husband resisted, the driver reversed, knocking the couple down, and then drove forward, striking the husband, the police said. He died shortly afterward. B3.
 
WHEN PRIVATE SECTOR SERVES BEST
Privatizing government by using contractors is relatively common in New York City, with about $1 in every $10 of the expense budget already going to private companies and organizations under contracts to provide services. But for the most part, it's still bureaucracy-as-usual at City Hall. So for advocates of "city-competitive contracts," the fight is on. Metro Matters, B3.
 
THE THRIVING BUSINESS OF BEAUTY
Students go to the Learning Institute of Beauty Sciences for a variety of reasons. But what they share above all else is the knowledge that the skills they are learning in the seven-month, $6,000 course are in hot demand. Indeed, at a time when employment in many blue- and white-collar fields continues to sputter, there are persistent calls for cosmetologists. Currently, some 40,000 jobs across the nation are estimated to be unfilled. Strictly Business, B6.
 
REGION
 
NEW VOICES IN THE CATSKILLS
The crisp air and cool shade of the Catskills are still ambrosia to vacationers, but in the former Borscht Belt, many of the voices are now Korean and Russian, people flocking to places like Swan Lake because the landscapes remind them of the mountains near Seoul or in the Urals. The Yiddish is spoken by Hasidim who have replaced more secular Jews as the mainstay of the area's bungalow colonies. As the Catskills grow more diverse, the region is showing signs of stemming the economic slide that over the years forced many of its resorts to close. A1.
 
NEW LINE OF COMICS HAS HIP-HOP HEROES
From his cramped office in Edison, N.J., Roland Laird has created a line of comic books that feature young black men who sport flattop haircuts and frequent dance clubs and face real-life problems like police harassment and street violence. Mr. Laird, 32, is the owner of Posro Komics, the only black-owned comic-book company in New Jersey and one of about 20 nationwide. B5.
 
TENTATIVE DEAL IN GARBAGE STRIKE
Union officials and representatives of 39 trash haulers in New Jersey reached a tentative agreement that may lead to the end of an 11-day walkout that has disrupted garbage collection in 14 counties. The tentative contract calls for a 5 percent wage increase over each of three years, and the continuation of employer health-care contributions at their current level, said John Tesauro, executive director of the state Board of Mediation. B5.

HEADLINE: Even as Heat Eases Slightly, Its Toll Rises

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
Like an oven turned down from broil to bake, the New York region cooled oh-so-slightly yesterday from the oppressive, triple-digit heat wave that has left the area simmering, the first sign of a more bearable week to come.
But with temperatures remaining in the mid-90's, the drop from last week's 100-plus temperatures was too little, too late. New York City emergency workers recorded the city's second heat-related death, and businesses tallied up another devastatingly slow day in a week that has seen few customers venture onto sizzling sidewalks. 
 The city's emergency medical workers were still working in overdrive, with more than 2,200 calls logged by mid-afternoon, said Robert Leonard, an Emergency Medical Service spokesman.
 
Elderly Woman Dies
 Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the city's Medical Examiner, reported yesterday that a 96-year-old woman had died on Friday from the heat. The woman, whose name was not released, died early Friday evening at Coler Memorial Hospital of hypothermia and exposure to heat, Ms. Borakove said.
A hospital spokeswoman said the elderly woman, a longterm patient at the hospital, died in the garden, where she was sitting in her wheelchair. It was not clear whether she was attended at the time. "We're still investigating," said Phyllis Daniels, the spokeswoman for the hospital, which is run by the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation.
The death of a 37-year-old Brooklyn man on Friday was also attributed to the heat, as was the death on Thursday of a 40-year-old man in Brooklawn, N.J.
Despite yesterday's high of 97 degrees, after three straight days of 100 degrees or more, weather forecasters expect the heat wave to subside over the next several days as a cool front moves into the area.
 
Effect on Businesses
 Such news is likely to cheer many business owners whose sales have withered in the searing heat. Throughout the region sidewalk cafes were deserted and laundromats were distinctly unpopular. And despite air-conditioning, some retail giants like Macy's saw a drop in traffic.
Georgia Young, Macy's weekend manager, said that while the store was busy there were fewer customers yesterday than on a typical summer weekend. And slow traffic at Macy's, the anchor store in Herald Square, put a crimp in business nearby.
The Florsheim shoe shop, across Broadway from Macy's, was nearly empty most of the day.
"We have seen a $3,000 drop in business since Tuesday," said Morris Foli, a salesmen who was sitting on a bank of seats that customers usually occupy.
 
Air-Conditioner Gave Out
 Lisa Grande, the manager of International Haircutters on West 66th Street in Manhattan, said the salon had lost about $1,000 in business since the air-conditioning system gave out on Wednesday.
"It was about 110 degrees in here from Wednesday until Saturday afternoon," she said. "Almost no one came in."
The few customers who did arrive were mostly men who just wanted hair cuts. Almost everyone passed on the blow-dryer.
Sunny skies and warm temperatures usually draw crowds to the South Street Seaport. But some businesses there said the weekend's warmth was too much of a good thing.
At the Liberty Cafe, a restaurant on the south side of Pier 17, business was off by 50 percent. Nelson Tejada, the manager, said the number of meals served dropped from 300 to about 150 a day. And he said a drop in temperatures to the 90's would not bring customers back.
"We need a breeze," he said, "and a drop to the mid-80's."
In the stifling heat, customers were passing on the free miniature golf on the roof of Casey O'Toole's Tavern in Fairfield, N.J. The manager and part-owner, Walter Kaminski, said business at the bar had been steady but people were not eating as much.
"Fifteen to 20 percent more beer is being sold," said Mr. Kaminski, noting that even hard-liquor drinkers were choosing beer.
 
The Bottom Line
 It was too early to determine yesterday how extensive the losses to businesses would be, and Wallace L. Ford 2d, New York City's Commissioner of Business Services, said his office had not received reports of serious problems caused by the heat.
"Typically," he said, "there is a connection between weather and business. Some small businesses are particularly vulnerable to weather conditions. So far we have heard of no unusual problems. But if next Sunday we are still looking at temperatures in the high 90's, or going past the 100-degree mark, we may start hearing about some serious problems from people trying to cope with the impact on their businesses."
But for some store owners, the impact is already real enough. Michael Rezay, the manager of the First Look, a women's clothing store on Seventh Avenue one block north of Macy's, said customers do not want want to try on clothes in the heat.
"We have not had a strong day since the July 4th weekend," he said.
 
Ice Skating, Anyone?
 Still, what was a curse for some was a blessing for others.
Movie theaters and appliance stores, for example, saw a predictable upturn in sales as people slipped into the cool, dark cinemas or into stores to buy fans and air-conditioners. On Saturday, Sky Rink, the indoor ice-skating rink on West 33d Street, saw its business triple as skaters sought refreshment on the ice.
John Sheridan, one of the managers, said the most frequently asked question there yesterday was: "Can I borrow a sweater or sweatshirt from the lost-and-found?"
At the Manufacturers Surplus Outlet Furniture Store in Fairfield, N.J., wicker and rattan furniture was selling well this week, said Chris DeLisa, 19, whose father owns the store.
But the store's supply of fans had sold out. "If we had them now we'd be millionaires," said Mr. DeLisa.
 
Relief in Sight
 Some businesses, like Tavern on the Green, the popular restaurant in Central Park, seem immune to forces of nature. Thomas Monetti, managing director of the restaurant, said business was up for the week despite the closing of the garden on Friday and Saturday. But in order to keep customers cool the restaurant had to increase its air-conditioning by 35 percent.
Mr. Monetti might be able to cut back the air-conditioners in the next couple of days, however. "The worst is over," said Daniel Graf, a meteorologist with the Weather Communications Group, consultants based at Penn State who monitor weather patterns throughout the country.
A front from the Midwest is expected to move in late today, bringing the temperatures slightly down, to the mid-80's by tomorrow. A second front, pushing down from Canada and the Great Lakes, should move into the region by Thursday, forcing the thermometers as low as 80 degrees.
Mr. Graf said that the intense heat in the region had been caused by a high-pressure zone that has stalled about 20,000 feet over the Southeast and mid-Atlantic states. To the west, a trough of low-pressure at about the same level has caused extreme flooding in the Mississippi and Missouri River valleys. The normal flow of the jet-stream, which carries weather systems from west to east, had been blocked until recently by a large high pressure area that had stalled near Greenland.
Any relief this week will be more than welcome, said Michele McClary, a 32-year-old secretary, who was at the South Street Seaport enjoying the East River breeze with her fiance Andre Joyner. She said the couple, both from Jersey City, had spent the last week lying naked under a fan. "This weekend we came here to get a breeze," she said. "And we want to be near the water more next weekend, if it cools off."

HEADLINE: A Trade Agreement Born of Political Necessity;
A New Approach To Old Problems

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 11

 BODY:
The trade agreement announced by the United States and Japan on Saturday is supposed to set a new course for economic relations between the world's two largest economies.
The so-called framework is aimed at reducing Japan's huge trade surplus with the United States and the rest of the world as well as soothing trade tensions between the American and Japanese Governments. 
 But the framework, a vaguely worded document developed through hasty but arduous negotiations last week, only sets the stage for more negotiations -- and probably, more arguments. Almost as soon as the new agreement was announced, Japan and the United States were differing over interpretation.
Following are basic questions about the agreement and the answers, based on a reading of the document and the assessment of trade officials:
Q. What is the framework?
A. The framework is a statement of directions and principles for negotiations over more specific negotiations to open Japan's markets for particular products or alter its economy.
It also sets up a mechanism for continued consultations over the next two years or more, including twice-a-year meetings between the President and the Prime Minister.
In addition, the framework contains a commitment by Japan to take steps to bring about a "highly significant" reduction in its current-account surplus "over the medium term" and for the United States to reduce its budget deficit.
Q. What are the principles governing future negotiations?
A. Trade agreements negotiated under the framework are to include "objective criteria" to measure progress in improving market access. The indicators will be determined through negotiation for each specific treaty, but they could include things like the share of Japan's market held by foreign products or the number of foreigners on standards-setting committees.
Q. How is the framework different from previous American approaches to trade with Japan?
A. In the past, the United States has pursued two separate approaches. One has been to push for opening markets in specific sectors, like semiconductors or glass. The other has been to push for structural changes in Japan's economy, like eliminating cartels, that could lead to increased sales of many different kinds of foreign products. The framework combines these approaches.
Another big difference, American officials say, is that the specific agreements negotiated under the rules of the framework will be more "results oriented" than past agreements because progress will be measured.
"What you have is something that goes far, far further toward explicitness and clarity and deadlines and schedules than anything you have ever seen before," said W. Bowman Cutter, chief American negotiator and deputy director of the White House's National Economic Council.
While that may be true in general, there have been specific agreements in the past, like the semiconductor trade accord, that were more explicit in terms of targets or deadlines than the new framework.
Q. What areas will be subject to negotiation?
A. The framework talks will cover five categories. One category will be talks aimed at increasing Japanese Government procurement of foreign products, particularly computers, satellites, medical technology and telecommunications. United States Government procurement practices will also be discussed.
Another is changing regulations that impede market access, like in financial services. A third, called "other major sectors," will aim at increasing sales in Japan of foreign autos and auto parts. A fourth, economic harmonization, will address issues that make it difficult for foreign concerns to buy land or companies in Japan. The fifth is implementation of existing trade accords.
Q. What is the timetable?
A. The United States and Japan are to forge specific agreements covering Government procurement, the insurance market, automobiles and other high-priority areas in six months. Other trade agreements are expected to be finished in a year. After two years, both Governments will decide whether to extend consultations in the framework beyond the fall of 1995.
Q. Does the framework set targets for Japan?
A. The framework does not mention targets, though it does not rule them out. The objective criteria are meant to provide an agreed-upon way for both sides to measure progress. But, according to Japan's interpretation at least, the agreements negotiated under the framework will not contain goals on how much progress should be made. The United States might try to include such language in the specific agreements.
Q. Won't that lead to arguments?
A. There is a danger of this. While the two nations have agreed on a way to measure progress, they seem likely to argue over whether the progress has been sufficient.
Q. What will happen if the United States is not satisfied with Japan's progress in a particular area?
A. The agreement says both nations will exercise "utmost efforts" to resolve disputes through negotiations or through multilateral forums like the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. But the United States has not given up the right to impose sanctions on Japan under Section 301 of American trade law. In a side letter to the agreement that has not been made public, Japan says it reserves the right to drop out of any negotiations if faced with a threat of sanctions, according to Japanese officials.
Q. Will this agreement work to increase sales of American products in Japan or to reduce Japan's trade surplus with America?
A. There is reason for optimism and pessimism. There have been a series of trade treaties over the years. Many work to some extent in increasing Japan's imports of particular products. Agreements with targets, like the semiconductor agreement and the private-sector auto parts agreement, have increased sales of American products in Japan. It is not clear how well agreements will work that contain measures of results but not targets.
Despite the success of some individual trade agreements, however, Japan's trade surplus over all has not gone down. Similarly, pledges by the United States to reduce its budget deficit have not been fulfilled.
Q. How will the agreement affect other countries?
A. The agreement stipulates that the benefits of Japan's market-opening measures will accrue to all nations, not only the United States.
But this has not calmed European complaints that Japanese procurement under United States-Japan trade agreements favor American products. That is partly because it is the United States that is putting the pressure on Japan. In addition, in the new framework, the sectors chosen as targets for market opening, like supercomputers and telecommunications, are ones in which the United States is particularly strong.
There are other concerns, as well. To the extent this bilateral approach catches on, it could undermine efforts to forge worldwide agreements, like the GATT talks. And some rapidly developing nations in East Asia have expressed fears that the United States might try to negotiate similar agreements with them.
