HEADLINE: Recalling July '36, When Streets and Dentures Melted

BYLINE: By EMILY M. BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
The biggest difference between the current heat wave and the one that held New York City in its grip 57 years ago is air-conditioning.
When the temperature in Central Park hit 106 degrees on July 9, 1936 -- an all-time record -- methods of staying cool were short on technology, and sometimes long on moxie. In one case, the heat got so bad for 20 unemployed men and women that they staged a protest at the Home Relief Bureau to demand ice. 
 Before air-conditioning, it was not unusual for businesses to shut down in a heat wave, for workers to faint on the job and for people to sleep on their roofs. And no other heat wave in the United States was ever hotter or deadlier than the one in July 1936.
"That still stands as the great heat wave of the whole nation," said Paul Knight, a meteorologist at Pennsylvania State University. "People were dying because they were losing their common sense."
Nationwide, 997 people died in the 10-day heat wave, 76 in the New York area. Twenty-one of the deaths in New York were drownings, as children and adults who could not swim jumped into the water anyway seeking relief. Other city residents tried to stick to their normal routines, and collapsed on their roofs, in their apartments, even on commuter trains. A 29-year-old janitor died next to the hot-water boiler in his building.
 
She Remembers It Well
 "People had to get out of the streets, but the subway was smothering, withering," said Pearl Levy, now 95 years old, who lived in the Bronx at the time. Mrs. Levy said she remembers the heat wave's devastating effect on the city, even if she can't remember the exact year.
"I remember distinctly that when I walked out on the street, it was like the street was full of hot steam," she said. "The heat came up from the sidewalk and it would envelop your whole body and face."
The 1936 heat wave began in early July over the northwestern plains and lingered over the Middle West, making a severe drought in many states even worse. By the time the front reached New York on July 8, much of the country was blanketed by hot, sweltering air.
New York was by no means the state hardest hit by the 1936 heat wave. It was the only time temperatures of 120 degrees were recorded outside the desert Southwest, in places like Arkansas, Kansas and North and South Dakota. Fifteen states, including New Jersey and Pennsylvania, set records for high temperatures that have yet to be broken. Canada also suffered under the heat, with Ontario alone reporting more than 500 deaths.
But the blazing sun took a special revenge on the pavement of New York. People who remember it say the heat was overwhelming. But not being accustomed to air-conditioning then, they were also more prepared to sweat it out than people are now.
Nonetheless, anyone who could leave New York did. The roads out of the city were packed with refugees from the baking pavement.
Mayor Fiorello H. LaGuardia, who was spending the summer in his country home, tried to accommodate the sweltering masses left in the city. After about a dozen people were arrested for sleeping on public beaches, he ordered them released and said there would be no more arrests for the duration of the heat wave. The Parks Department kept the city's pools open until midnight.
Many stories of that heat wave and its effects resemble the ones being told by New Yorkers this week. City dwellers crowded the local beaches and parks. Firefighters traveled through their neighborhoods shutting fire hydrants. Officials warned of water shortages and asked people not to use their sprinklers.
But some of the tales are from another era. Women lost their shoe heels in asphalt, and tar melted under the sun. Police officers in Brooklyn tried to revive a horse that collapsed in an intersection. Three Harlem River drawbridges swelled by the heat could not close properly after opening for a tugboat.
And The New York Times entertained its readers with the following report: "In Syracuse, on one of the main streets, a housewife fried an egg on the pavement; at Perry, N.Y., an absent-minded man who left his false teeth on the window sill returned within an hour to find them melted away."

HEADLINE: Savings Bond Sales Off

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 11

 BODY:
Sales of United States savings bonds declined 13 percent in June, to $798 million, from $919 million in June 1992, reflecting lower interest rates offered to savers. The Treasury lowered the guaranteed minimum rate on the savings bonds to 4 percent from 6 percent on March 1.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Magazines;
The Lessons of Recession Help Magazines Lure New Readers and Advertisers

BYLINE: By Deirdre Carmody

 BODY:
As anxiety about the second half of 1993 replaces the optimism that swept the magazine industry earlier this year, publishers are fundamentally altering the way they woo advertisers and readers.
The recession taught magazines that advertisers were fair-weather friends, quick to pull out when things got tough. It was a bitter lesson for the publishers, who depended on advertising for most of their revenue, and led many of them to court readers as fervently as advertisers. 
 Five years ago, for instance, 60 percent of the revenues from Time Inc.'s magazines came from advertising and the rest from circulation. Today it is an even split.
But reading habits have changed so drastically in recent years that magazines have had to find new ways to lure readers. Increasingly, they have turned to so-called niche publications, narrowly targeted to readers with special interests.
Some have originated as one-shot issues in response to news events, like People magazine's special issue on Audrey Hepburn, which was published almost immediately after the actress died on Jan. 20. Others, like "Find the Real You," first published last year by YM, a magazine for teen-agers, have proved so successful that they are repeated annually.
Some have come about simply because an opportunity was so tantalizing that publishers abandoned normal publication procedures. The University of Alabama's victory over the University of Miami in the Sugar Bowl on Jan. 1 was one.
Sports Illustrated wrote about the game but did not feature the story on the cover. When local distributors in Alabama said they could sell out the issue if the Sugar Bowl was on the cover, the magazine reprinted 200,000 copies with a new cover and shipped them to Alabama within 24 hours where they sold out immediately. Sports Illustrated then produced a 96-page commemorative issue that highlighted Alabama's entire season.
"If you know anything about Alabama football fans, you know that Alabama football is only slightly more important than God," said Roger Jackson, the publicity director for the magazine. "Within 24 hours, 550,000 copies sold out."
Ladies' Home Journal plans to produce seven or eight special publications in the next 12 months. Four will be part of a so-called Leading Lady series, which will focus on a celebrity and have advertising from a single sponsor. The first, which will appear on July 27 on newsstands, will be devoted to Katharine Hepburn and will be sponsored by Cover Girl Cosmetics.
Like most special magazines, it is a relatively inexpensive venture, relying on pages of pictures that have already appeared and an interview with Myrna Blyth, the editor-in-chief of Ladies' Home Journal. Four hundred thousand copies will be printed.
"The magazine industry is changing," said Michael T. Carr, the president and chief executive of Weider Publications Inc., which is based in Woodland Hills, Calif., and publishes Muscle & Fitness and Shape. "Leisure time is at a premium. The four-day week was a myth of the 50's. Mass media was in vogue in the 60's, but now everything is special interest."
Shape magazine was started in 1981 in response to demand from women who had found that fitness was a good way to combat stress. Shape's circulation has grown to more than 800,000 and it is now spawning spinoff magazines.
On May 27 Weider published 250,000 copies of Shape's Guide to a Fit Pregnancy. Mr. Carr said the magazine sold out in 6 of the 10 major United States markets. He said he planned to put out 500,000 copies of a second issue next spring. He is also planning another Shape special for readers over 35 who are looking for a different exercise regimen than the magazine's core younger readers.
Then there are the spinoffs of the spinoffs. Next week Shape will introduce its "Do It Right" videos, which will be available in supermarkets, large retail stores and video stores. A line of Shape clothing, which was started last year, has generated $10 million in sales, Mr. Carr said.
"All that did not exist 18 months ago, and I have just begun," he said. "The bottom line is anywhere our readers consume information, we will supply it -- interactive software, videos, magazines, specials and clothing."
The time appears ripe for imaginative new ways of acquiring revenue, as magazine advertising continues to be erratic. After a strong first quarter this year, advertising pages dipped in April. Pages were up slightly for May and down again for June.
While some magazines are doing well, publishers say ad spending for the second half of the year may be lower than predicted. Marketers are trimming ads, renegotiating deals and delaying commitments. Fourth-quarter spending is uncertain.
"In the last quarter of 1992 and the first quarter of 1993, I could sense an uptick of consumer confidence, volume and ad spending," said Jack Kliger, the publisher of Glamour. "But the Clinton Presidency has sort of settled into its rough waters and the economy has resultingly slowed down. When things get tight, advertisers and marketers resort to promotional short-term fixes like spot TV and couponing, and ad budgets get rearranged."
Francis Pandolfi, the publisher of Times Mirror Magazines, said he thought magazines would have to change the way they did business to compete. For instance, he said, Times Mirror publishes outdoor magazines and stages events for advertisers like ski races that other magazine companies are unable to match.
"We have hundreds of assets, and we have to present them more effectively than we ever have before," he said. "You have to go back and offer more than a page of space. If I present a package that is one-fifth advertising, the advertiser may say to me, 'I can get a better deal at Hearst.' "
He added: "Today, what you have is a lot of added value -- if you buy my page, I'll give tickets for the ball game or a page of space in my trade magazines -- and generally that's given away. We have to change from added value to a genuine marketing- value approach. And then, we have to charge for it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: To lure readers in recent years, magazines have turned out niche publications narrowly focused on audiences with special interests. (Naum Kazhdan/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A Possible OPEC Price War Threatens Oil Company Prospects.

BYLINE: By Agis Salpukas

 BODY:
JUST as things were looking up for the oil industry, talk of a huge surplus has raised the specter of falling prices for crude -- and a grim turn in the fortunes of the big oil companies.
The leaders have sprung back to life this year after low demand for their products had depressed earnings and forced huge write-offs. The 22 largest American oil companies showed profits of $4.1 billion in the first quarter, in contrast to a loss of about $900 million in the 1992 quarter. 
 But last month's meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries left a sword of Damocles hanging over the industry. It became clear that Kuwait was not willing to abide by its production quota, setting up fears of price wars that could pull a barrel of oil below the current $18. Some OPEC nations are already exceeding quotas.
Further promoting the uncertainty were comments by the United States delegate to the United Nations, Madeleine K. Albright, that the United States would not object to Iraq's beginning to export oil if it met certain conditions.
The price of crude has continued to drop, mostly because of the possibility of Iraq's putting about 400,000 barrels a day on the export market if its talks with the United Nations to ease sanctions succeed.
Michael Mayer, an oil analyst for Wertheim Schroder, predicts that the Iraqi production could cause the price to drop by another $1 to $2 a barrel. A decline of that size could significantly erode profits of the big oil companies, whose stock prices as a group have fallen faster in the last six weeks than has the overall market.
Mr. Mayer estimated that the shares of the 15 largest companies could lose about 10 percent of their value, though not much more than that. "Over the years, as the market has watched the price of oil go up and down, it has built in the expectation that OPEC will react," he said.
The three major companies most vulnerable to the fall in crude prices are British Petroleum, ARCO and Amerada Hess. That is because their stock prices are high and they are heavily weighted toward producing crude oil.
Over all, the industry is better prepared now for price instability. It has been phasing out old refineries, reducing capacity in the last year by 600,000 barrels a day out of total capacity of about 15 million. It has cut jobs, spun off marginal subsidiaries and tightened spending on exploration.
But Michael Young, an oil analyst for Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, does not believe this is enough to protect the industry.
In the past, he said, the oil companies could cushion such a fall by getting higher prices for refined products like gasoline, jet fuel and heating oil. Margins on those products benefit from the low prices of crude oil.
But such a strategy can work only if demand for those products is high, which is not the current case. While motorists are shaking off the effects of the recession and driving more, the price of gasoline has remained low in the face of rising demand.
"Demand is growing," Mr. Mayer said, "but it is growing slowly."
One encouraging prospect remains. The OPEC producers are expected to pull back if they see that cheating on quotas is leading to big price drops.
Since 1986, when the price of oil fell to $10 a barrel, from $27 a barrel the previous year, Mr. Mayer said, OPEC has taken corrective measures when prices reached $15 to $16. Emergency meetings were called and production cutbacks were able to stem the huge drops of the past.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Alternatives to Treasuries Grow

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
With interest rates on Treasury securities at the lowest levels in 20 years or more, investors who rely on bonds are continuing to seek higher yields. For individuals, the primary alternatives are municipal bonds, on which the interest payments are exempt from Federal income tax and the state and local income taxes of the issuing state.
For middle-income taxpayers paying a 31 percent Federal income tax, yields on high-quality tax-exempt bonds are well above those on Treasury and investment-grade corporate issues of similar maturity. 
 On Friday, yields on Treasury issues ranged from 3.96 percent for two-year notes to 4.99 percent for a five-year issue, 5.73 percent for a 10- year bond and 6.64 percent for 30-year bonds. Assuming a Federal income tax burden of 31 percent, the yield comes to only 2.73 percent for two-year notes, 3.44 percent for five years, 3.95 percent for 10 years and 4.58 percent for the 30-year bond.
 
 
Shorter Maturity Favored
 In comparison, tax-exempt bonds rated triple A carry yields of about 3.40 percent for two years, 4.25 percent for five years, 4.9 percent for 10 years and 5.65 percent for 30 years. This means that a five-year tax-exempt issue that is rated triple A yields more than a 10-year Treasury issue, after taxes. The shorter maturity on the tax-exempt issue is preferable to many investors, because if interest rates rise, the price of the five-year issue will fall only two-thirds as much as that of the 10-year issue.
But even with the yield advantage of top-quality municipals, compared with Treasury securities, the desire for still higher yields is leading many investors to seek lower-rated municipal issues. Medium-grade municipal bonds rated Baa by Moody's Investors Service carry yields ranging from about 4.75 percent for bonds due in five years to 5.45 percent for 10-year issues and 6 percent for 20-year maturities, according to Municipal Market Data in Boston.
Douglas Casey, a managing director at the Gates Capital Corporation, notes that the combination of strong demand for Baa issues and the heavy supply of triple-A issues has caused the yield spread between those categories to decline from about six-tenths of a percentage point last year to approximately four-tenths of a point.
The extra yield for buying the lower-quality issues may not be worth it, he said, since prices of those issues tend to weaken more when interest rates rise and investors are not so avidly seeking higher yields. Gates Capital is a New York firm that specializes in advising investment managers on bonds.
 
 
Pre-Refunded Issues
 Among triple-A-rated bonds, a category that has never before been in such ample supply, Mr. Casey recommends pre-refunded issues to investors who seek the same safety as with Treasury issues, but want a higher yield. Pre-refunded bonds are those that local governments have refunded with a new bond issue. The old bonds, however, cannot be retired because they have been protected from retirement for a specified period: usually 10 years from the date of issuance. Until the retirement date comes, the bonds are backed by a pool of Treasury securities, guaranteeing interest and principal payments.
The supply of triple-A-rated bonds is at a record level because about 40 percent of new municipal bonds issued this year have been sold with insurance, according to the Municipal Bond Investors Assurance Corporation, the largest such insurer. According to David H. Elliott, the corporation's chairman, insurance is up from 30 percent of the market in 1991 and 16 percent in 1986, because "it is very popular with the individual investors who dominate that market and who want high quality."
Another alternative for institutional investors seeking higher yields has been mortgage-backed securities. These are sold with an indicated range of likely maturities and yields, with the exact level depending on how rapidly mortgages are repaid.
The uncertainties are enough to deter many institutional buyers, which is one reason why the securities offer yields that exceed those of Treasury securities by six-tenths of a percentage point to more than two percentage points, depending on the issue.
 
New Risks in Mortgage Market
 The uncertainty of maturity is not new to the mortgage market. But with interest rates so low, the risks of the mortgage market are changing, noted Andrew Kowalczyk, a vice president at Descap Securities in New York.
"Now there is a growing concern that investors are vulnerable to unexpected extension of maturities on the securities they own," Mr. Kowalczyk said. If interest rates rise, and the rate at which homeowners are refinancing their mortgages slows, securities sold with an expected life of only a few years may endure for 10 years or more, he noted.
Although securities dealers promote planned amortization class mortgage securities -- or PAC's -- as a solution to the uncertain maturity and cash flow of mortgage issues, there are still risks.
One recent PAC issue of securities backed by the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, was recently sold on the assumption that the rate of prepayments on the backing mortgages would range from 135 percent PSA to 247 percent PSA. PSA is a standard measure of prepayments, with a 100 percent rate corresponding to an average life of mortgages of about 15 years, which was standard in the mid-1980's, when the rating system was developed.
Should the rate of prepayment on the 7.5 percent mortgages backing this PAC issue slow to 100 PSA -- "not an unreasonable assumption at all," said Philip H. Engel, vice president at Descap -- the average life of the issue would rise to 15.25 years from the initial estimate of 3.4 years.
 
Pools of Old Mortgages
 Curiously, while mortgages with rates as low as 8.5 to 9.5 percent are being repaid at record rates -- repayments in June rose to an annual rate of more than 52 percent on some pools of 8.5 percent mortgages -- there are pass-through securities backed by pools of old mortgages of 13 to 15 percent, which are being repaid at much slower rates. The remaining mortgages may exist because the homeowners are unaware that lower rates are available, cannot afford the closing costs on a new loan, or cannot qualify for one.
Mr. Kowalczyk noted that a 14 3/4 percent issue of Fannie Mae was now worth about 119, to yield 6.93 percent if prepayments were fast enough to produce a three-year average life or 8.44 percent if prepayments are slower and produce a four-year average life. In either case, the return is far higher than Treasury securities.
Mr. Kowalczyk warned that buying a single issue of high coupon pass-throughs would be risky, because the prepayment of a few mortgages in a much shrunken pool of securities could drastically reduce the security's yield. But for large buyers, like banks or mutual funds, a portfolio consisting of the tiny remaining pieces from several dozen different pools is diversified enough that prepayments of a few mortgages in a single pool will not be a serious blow.

HEADLINE: Bill Clinton, Emerging Asia Hand

 BODY:
Maybe President Clinton should travel abroad more often. He has left the country only twice in his first six months in office, but both trips -- April's Vancouver summit meeting with Boris Yeltsin and the just completed journey to Tokyo and Seoul -- have burnished Mr. Clinton's Presidential image and advanced American interests in important parts of the world.
The Asia-Pacific region, which includes the Americas, now accounts for 60 percent of world output, and 40 percent of U.S. trade is trans-Pacific. Yet changing political and security forces in the region pose a challenge to American policy. The cold war is over, the old political order has crumbled in countries like Japan, South Korea and Taiwan, and China stands poised between a bright future of market-oriented growth and the serious risk of political convulsions when Deng Xiaoping passes on. 
 On both immediate and longer-term problems, Mr. Clinton showed a sure hand.
Take, for example, Japan's critical July 18 election, in which Washington's longtime favorite, the Liberal Democratic Party, faces its first real defeat since it was formed in 1955. While treating his Liberal Democratic host, Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa, with respect, Mr. Clinton also met with two of Mr. Miyazawa's challengers.
In his public remarks, he declined to endorse any particular party, but spoke in favor of "change," particularly the kind of change that would take more account of Japanese consumers, and, of course, of American exporters who want to compete for their yen. That neatly reflects America's real interest: a more competitive politics that responds better to the needs of ordinary Japanese, not just those of big business and rice farmers. In Korea, the immediate problem is North Korea's rejection of international nuclear inspections. Both the Clinton Administration and the South Korean Government of President Kim Young Sam favor a carrot-and-stick approach, putting diplomacy first so long as North Korea remains within international agreements.
But both leaders face pressure from more hawkish elements. By visiting Seoul, by traveling to the bristling North-South frontier at Panmunjom and by reaffirming America's commitment to maintain troops in South Korea, Mr. Clinton reassures nervous South Koreans and buys time for continued diplomacy.
More broadly, Mr. Clinton endorsed new Asian moves toward regional collective security, an approach previous American Administrations opposed. Traditional cold war alliances like those with Tokyo, Seoul and Manila should be maintained. But Moscow is no longer the main threat. American guarantees would have little relevance in a hypothetical conflict between, say, Japan and Korea. Broad regional pacts, similar to NATO, can provide added insurance against local conflicts.
On economic issues, new region-wide organizations also need to be strengthened. Mr. Clinton gave a strong endorsement to the 15-member forum on Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation. The United States holds the forum's rotating chairmanship this year and will host its annual meeting, scheduled for Seattle in November. Mr. Clinton will attend and invites other heads of state to join him.
For a President not known for interest in foreign policy, Mr. Clinton is off to a promising start in Asia.

HEADLINE: At Home Abroad;
Mr. Clinton Abroad

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: HONG KONG

 BODY:
The G-7 meeting in Tokyo, however lasting its achievements, was a political triumph for Bill Clinton. A President who has so often stumbled in the White House was sure-footed in a tricky foreign environment.
Aside from the big surprise -- agreement on a framework to correct the trade imbalance with Japan -- Mr. Clinton was impressive in gestures outside the G-7 forum. When he met President Suharto of Indonesia, for example, he raised human rights abuses in East Timor, which Indonesia occupies. The situation there cries out for attention, but few American Presidents have been ready to deal with it. 
 The personal success of the Tokyo trip is a fair peg for an early assessment of Mr. Clinton in foreign affairs. Foreign issues have inevitably pressed on him, despite his efforts to stick to his domestic last.
To start with the credits, one Clinton action was an outstanding example of Presidential courage and wisdom. That was his decision, announced over the Fourth of July weekend, to extend the current moratorium on U.S. nuclear tests for at least 15 months -- and longer if no other countries test.
It was a difficult decision, made against the urgings of the nuclear weapons laboratories and the advice of the Secretaries of State and Defense. Why Defense Secretary Les Aspin, who knows about these things, should have supported the feeble arguments of the laboratories is a mystery. But he did, and it took backbone for the President to say no.
With negotiating skill and luck, Mr. Clinton's decision could mean the permanent end of nuclear tests. The President called for early negotiations on a comprehensive test ban -- which would help greatly to discourage the spread of nuclear weapons.
After a hesitant start, President Clinton grasped the issue of aid to Boris Yeltsin's Russia and led the effort that ended in Tokyo with an agreed aid package. The Administration handled the perennial problem of most-favored-nation trade status for China with skill, extending M.F.N. but with a serious demand for human rights improvements by next year.
The most spectacular Clinton act abroad, the missile attack on Baghdad, can hardly be rated a success by either hawks or doves. Lopping two floors off an intelligence headquarters will not make Saddam Hussein tremble. And the claimed legal basis for unilateral action was dubious.
The Baghdad raid had the air of something urged by David Gergen to boost Mr. Clinton's domestic poll ratings. It did that, but in the rest of the world the reaction was mostly negative -- and not only from the left. In South Africa, where I was, the newspaper Business Day spoke contemptuously of "Rambo Clinton."
The great foreign-policy failure of Mr. Clinton's first six months is not in doubt. After much huffing and puffing about the need for stronger measures to stop Serbian aggression in Bosnia, Mr. Clinton did nothing that mattered. To this day the horror continues. In Sarajevo water and electricity supplies have failed. The World Health Organization warns of "catastrophe" on a scale unseen in Europe since World War II.
The non-policy in Bosnia is more than a human disaster. It signals Mr. Clinton's unwillingness or inability to do what George Bush funked: supply the vision of a security system for Europe and the Atlantic after the cold war.
To use the word vision is to identify a major reason for its felt lack in President Clinton's foreign policy. His Secretary of State, Warren Christopher, is a superb lawyer. He did the country great service in his dogged negotiations to end the Iran hostage crisis in 1980. But he has no larger sense of strategy, no strength as a policy maker.
Mr. Christopher did himself mortal damage when he said all sides in Bosnia were guilty of human rights violations, thus ignoring the role of Serbian leaders as inciters of genocide. But the problem Mr. Christopher presents to the President is broader. The Times of London put it last month:
"Mr. Christopher may have qualities, but dynamism, creativity, vision and leadership are not among them. If the Clinton Mark II Presidency, launched at home, is to take shape abroad, the search must start for a secretary of state worthy of the name."

HEADLINE: PULSE: The Port of New York and New Jersey

 BODY:
Dredging was completed last week at the Newark/Port Elizabeth Marine Terminal, which handles more than 90 percent of general cargo at the Port of New York and New Jersey. The removal of 465,000 cubic yards of silt and sludge reopens the terminal's 62 berths to the largest container ships, some of which had been diverted to other ports because of inadequate depths in these berths. Even so, general cargo tonnage was up 6.3 percent last year over 1991. Bulk cargoes, which are handled at other terminals, fell 18.3 percent. Through May 1993, traffic is down 1.4 million long tons from the previous year.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 13, 1993, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
A Pulse chart yesterday in The Metro Section about the Port of New York and New Jersey mislabeled one component in the breakdown of the port's regional economic impact. The category that generates $2.1 billion in annual business through the port is trade-related services, not travel-related services.

HEADLINE: Kantor Insists on Sanctions

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 12

 BODY:
The United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, denied today that the Clinton Administration had backed away from plans to require sanctions to enforce side deals to the proposed North American Free Trade Agreement.
"That is an inaccurate report," he said at a news briefing when asked about press accounts saying that officials had withdrawn their call for sanctions during negotiations last week in Mexico. "We have not changed our position at all. We want real teeth, real enforcement." 
 Later, before an audience of steelworkers opposed to the accord, Mr. Kantor reiterated this view. "We will not -- I repeat, we will not send Nafta to the Congress, unless we have effective side agreements," he said.
United States negotiators were quoted last week as saying that commissions on labor, the environment and import surges would not have the authority to impose sanctions, fines or penalties.
The United States has maintained that those commissions should have enforcement powers, a stance that has been resisted by Mexico and Canada.
Today, Mr. Kantor also repeated statements by the negotiators that important progress had been made at last week's talks.
Members of Congress -- notably Senator Max S. Baucus, Democrat of Montana, chairman of the Environment Committee and of an international trade subcommittee -- have said they would vote for the broad accord only if it were sent to Congress with strong side agreements, particularly an agreement on the environment. They argue that enforcement will be impossible if it is left in the hands of each nation.
Critics express particular concern about the prospects of increased pollution along the Mexican border, where many American companies have moved to take advantage of low-paid labor and more are expected to relocate if the accord is approved.
The Canadian Parliament has approved the North American accord, and its passage in Mexico is considered assured.
Negotiators have said that they expect to work out a common text for an environmental side agreement when they meet again next week in Ottawa.

HEADLINE: In Baghdad, Panic and Defiance Over Standoff

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 12

 BODY:
A mixture of panic, anger and defiance gripped this city today as Iraqis woke to find themselves back in an all-too-familiar world in which President Saddam Hussein is quarreling with the United Nations and their country faces the threat of another American-led air attack.
Only three weeks ago spirits here were lifted after the Government unexpectedly announced that it was reopening the talks it had broken off with the United Nations last year on partly lifting the embargo on Iraq's oil sales so it could buy more essential goods. 
 But hopes that the rigors of daily life might ease after three years of economic blockade have faded under the impact of two more recent crises pitting President Hussein against President Clinton, who came to office saying he wanted to "depersonalize" Washington's quarrel with the Iraqi leader.
First came the June 27 cruise missile strike on an intelligence base here in retaliation for what the White House described as Iraq's plot to assassinate George Bush during the former President's visit to Kuwait in April. Iraq said the raid killed six civilians.
Now Iraqis find their Government involved in a new standoff with the United Nations over carrying out the Persian Gulf war cease-fire, which includes monitoring of Iraq's weapons industry. A weapons inspection team left Iraq on July 5 after being denied permission to install cameras at two missile-testing sites, and another inspection team left the country on Sunday when it was refused permission to seal equipment at the sites.
 
Fear of Another Attack
 "I listened to Voice of America this morning," said a worried Iraqi woman working in a reception center for foreign businessmen who gave her name only as Mary. "They are not really going to attack us again, are they?"
Sipping tea in a cafe near Baghdad's souk, a retired civil servant calling himself Abu Husseini said: "It's the uncertainty I don't like. It's like Russian roulette. You don't know where the attack will come. You don't know where you are safe."
Deputy Health Minister Chawky Sabri Morcos, who described himself in an interview today as "a doctor, not a politician," asked angrily, "Haven't they killed enough people already with their embargo without any more attacks?"
His ministry calculates that 285,556 people have died unnecessarily as a result of the trade embargo imposed on Iraq after its defeat in the gulf war. The embargo has shut down what once was the world's second leading oil exporter, leaving it without funds to import medicines it needs.
The Government-controlled press is venting its anger on the United Nations, which Baghdad sees as the tool of an American-led conspiracy to weaken and humiliate Iraq by forcing it to accept terms for lifting the trade blockade that are ever more onerous.
According to this view, sealing the missile-test sites would only have encouraged the United Nations to start shutting down other Iraqi industries, saying they could be used for manufacturing prohibited weapons.
In a sign of the jitters sweeping through this city, the price of food and other goods on the free market rose amid indications that people with the money to do so were hoarding in anticipation of trouble.

HEADLINE: Mexican Official Rebukes U.S. on Chinese Aliens

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, July 12

 BODY:
With unusual sharpness, a senior official in the Mexican foreign ministry told the United States today that the fate of 659 undocumented Chinese aliens aboard three ships off Mexico is up to the United States, and that Mexico's rejection of a request by the United States for assistance still stands.
"Mexico is not going to accept these people," said the official, who spoke on condition that he not be identified. "This is the responsibility of the United States." 
 The official said Mexico had made it clear in a letter to Ambassador John D. Negroponte on Saturday that it "was not in position" to accept the United States' request to allow the three ships to dock in Mexico, where the passengers could be interviewed and then either allowed to enter the United States or returned to China.
The official disputed the accuracy of a statement by the State Department over the weekend that negotiations were continuing on possible solutions. Moreover, he contended that the United States had made an unreasonable request because the Chinese had no desire to go to Mexico and because, he said, United States immigration law so often worked against Mexican citizens trying to enter the United States.
 
Policy Change Suggested
 "Why would we do this as a favor to the United States when our own people are victims of the same policy?" the official asked. He also said the United States seemed to be trying to change an immigration policy that for last 12 years had allowed Chinese citizens to seek asylum in the United States.
The Mexicans denied that further negotiations had taken place. They said officials from both countries had met, but only to share information.
In Washington, however, the State Department said that talks were continuing "with some intensity" but that there was no sign of resolving what is becoming an embarrassing international dilemma.
The dubious conditions on board the ships added to the urgency of the negotiations. The Coast Guard said today that conditions on the three aging commercial vessels crammed with Chinese were "fair" at best. In the last few days the Coast Guard has ferried out hundreds of pounds of rice and military meals, as well as life jackets and an electric generator for a ship whose engine had failed.
But a State Department spokesman gave a harsher assessment. "Conditions on these ships are truly appalling," said the spokesman, Michael McCurry. "That's one more reason that requires us to deal quickly and accurately with the threat that is presented to those on board."
The origin of the ships has not yet been disclosed, but officials in the United States and Mexico said they appeared to be part of international smuggling rings.
Mexican immigration officials backed off earlier reports that four other ships carrying more than 700 Chinese were heading toward the coast. And Coast Guard officials said their air patrols had not sighted them.
Thirteen employees of the Immigration and Naturalization Service have boarded the three ships, but officials said today that they were sent mainly as interpreters, not as part of any resolution to the diplomatic standoff between the United States and Mexico.
Verne Jervis, a spokesman for the immigration agency in Washington, said the Chinese-speaking interpreters were helping United States Coast Guard personnel who have been caring for the aliens since the ships, which were heading east, were intercepted last week and brought to a point in international waters 64 miles west of Ensenada, Mexico.
While Coast Guard medics have treated several passengers for minor injuries, only one person, a 19-year-old woman, has required hospitalization.
Immigration officials in San Diego said the woman, Zhou Shiuyun, of Fuzhou province in China, was airlifted Sunday afternoon to the University of California at San Diego Medical Center, where she underwent emergency surgery for a tubal pregnancy. She was in good condition today, said Eileen Callahan, a hospital spokeswoman.
Ms. Zhou spoke to The San Diego Union-Tribune on Sunday but has declined further interviews, Ms. Callahan said. "She's under a lot of medication," the spokeswoman added.
 
'I Hate the System'
 Immigration officials said they suspected that she was going to the East Coast because she was carrying a New York-area telephone number.
"It's not just an economic problem," Ms. Zhou said in the Union-Tribune article. "I hate the system in China. There's no justice. I'll be punished severely, too, if the Americans send me back. That will be the end of me."
In the same interview she said it was a smuggler's promises of opening her own business that led her to borrow half of the $20,000 fee to be smuggled to the United States.
Immigration officials said Ms. Zhou was allowed into the United States under a medical parole permit and would be returned to the boat as soon as her condition improved. But an I.N.S. spokesman, Rudy Murillo, predicted that Ms. Zhou would ask for political asylum to buy time in the United States.
"She's talking like she's very well versed, very well coached," he said. "It's hard to reconcile the entire story."

HEADLINE: U.S. Fears a Sharp Rise In Balkan Refugee Flow

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 12

 BODY:
The partition of Bosnia into three ethnic areas could require the resettlement of 1.5 million to 2 million people, a classified State Department report says.
The brief report, prepared early this month by the intelligence bureau of the State Department and based on a map drawn by President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia, draws no conclusions about the desirability of carving up the country but assumes that masses of Serbs, Croats and Muslims will move, either through coercion or by choice, State Department officials said. 
 This would require an extraordinary new commitment of outside assistance, senior State Department officials and officials from international relief agencies said.
 
'Waves of People'
 "Partition is not going to solve the humanitarian problems of Bosnia," a senior State Department official said. "We're talking about enormous waves of people. Things could get much worse than they are now if you don't have access to people and enough resources to provide food and shelter."
Another problem, one senior State Department official said, is that partition could disrupt most of the Bosnian families with mixed ethnic backgrounds.
Senior State Department officials and relief agency officials stressed that the Milosevic map, which international mediators are using as a basis for negotiation, is by no means inevitable. On Sunday, the Muslim-led Bosnian Government rejected the partition proposal, which was advanced last month by Mr. Milosevic and President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia.
The report coincides with a worsening of the humanitarian crisis in Sarajevo and the five other regions in Bosnia that the United Nations has designated "safe areas." The capital now lacks fresh water and is low on food and fuel, and United Nations relief convoys are stalled at Serbian roadblocks.
 
Doing the Numbers
 At a hearing before a subcommittee of the Senate Appropriations Committee, Warren Zimmerman, director of the Bureau for Refugee Programs and the last United States Ambassador to Yugoslavia, called Bosnia "a humanitarian crisis of a scale we have not seen in Europe" since World War II.
The State Department report estimates that with partition, 600,000 Muslims would have to move, half of them from areas of Bosnia that would no longer be controlled by the Government, the other half expelled from Croatia.
Between 275,000 and 300,000 Croats would have to move, most displaced from towns like Vitez and Travnik that would be Muslim controlled area, the report estimates. Half a million Serbs would be expected to move, about 350,000 from Serbia back home to newly Serb-controlled territory, the rest from places that would come under Muslim or Croatian control.
There are now 3.8 million people displaced by the war, compared with 2.4 million last December. As partition becomes more likely, European countries are making it more difficult for people from the remnants of Yugoslavia to settle in their countries.
 
Who Gets What
 Under the Milosevic map, the Serbs would receive 60 percent of Bosnia, the Muslims 35 percent and the Croats 15 percent. But the Croats are demanding more territory, and some State Department officials are convinced that if they prevail, it will be at the expense of the Muslims.
"If you use the Milosevic map. the Muslims get a raw deal," said Frederick C. Cuny, an American relief consultant who returned from Bosnia last weekend. "Even though the Croats get a small area, they get far more than the Bosnians in terms of industrial and hydroelectrical potential. The Serbs, of course, benefit the most and, in effect, the Bosnians would become economically dependent on Serbia."
The Muslims would get 20 percent of the arable land, 19 percent of forest reserves and 30 percent of Bosnia's overall export potential, Mr. Cuny said. Although the Muslims would receive 53 percent of the coal reserves, the coal is of low quality; since they would not get any steel mills, the coal would be of little use.
 
Threat by the U.N.
 Bill Frelick, a senior analyst for the United States Committee for Refugees, said there would be three consequences of partition: "genocidal-type killing," whose scale would depend on the response of the outside world; a mass exodus, which would depend on the willingness of the West to accept refugees, and the creation of a combination "Indian reservation/Palestinian refugee camp in which people with no political power, held in closed areas, become an international welfare case."
Sadako Ogata, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, has become increasingly frustrated by her agency's inability to deliver aid to Bosnia and is threatening to pull out.
In unusually blunt remarks on Friday, she condemned the use of relief aid as a weapon of war and accused donor countries of failing to provide enough aid.
Nicholas Morris, Mrs. Ogata's new representative in Bosnia, is said to be eager for a complete withdrawal of the agency from the country.
Lionel Rosenblatt, president of Refugees International, a private aid agency, said: "At a time when maximum pressure is being put on the Bosnians, we are finding that donors are not engaged and almost deliberately turning away and the United Nations seems to be giving up. One can surmise that this is part of an indirect pressure campaign to force the Bosnians to accept partition."

HEADLINE: English Retirement Resort Is a Model for Europe

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEXHILL-ON-SEA, England

 BODY:
Down at the police station, where the usual crime wave involves con artists preying on the elderly, constables have begun a program to install door chains free of charge.
At the whitewashed De La Warr Pavilion, on the seafront, promoters are hoping to lure sellout audiences of retirees with a summer program of big-band revivals and light musicals like "The Dancing Years," one of London's most popular prewar shows. 
 Government officials are also busy encouraging elderly people to apply for grants of as much as $1,500 each to reinsulate their houses before cold weather sets in again.
 
Proving Ground for Changes
 This well-manicured seaside resort in East Sussex is a retirement mecca where pensioners make up more than 42 percent of the population of 39,000. It is also a kind of proving ground for solutions to the social and governmental challenges that much of Europe faces as its population grows older.
As in the United States and Japan, declining birth rates and rising life expectancy have forged a powerful demographic reality across Western Europe. By the year 2020 more than one in every four people in the 12 countries of the European Community will be over 60, compared with fewer than one in five now. More critically, over 12 percent of the population is forecast to be older than 75, double the current percentage.
From recreation programs to health care, officials in Bexhill, about 30 miles east of Brighton, and in the administrative county of East Sussex, are already looking for ways to stretch limited public resources.
Down at the Charter Center, for example, the county and a consortium of volunteer groups and private contractors have pooled resources to offer a kind of senior citizens' drop-in center, aimed at helping sustain elderly people as long as possible in their own homes rather than force them into nursing homes or residential housing.
 
'Such Nice Company'
 One regular client, Ivy Wheeler, comes by bus four times a week for lunch, visits that provide her access to medical care and other services and social contact but still allow her to stay on in her own apartment.
"There's always such nice company, and a good home-cooked meal, too," said Mrs. Wheeler, a jovial woman who describes herself to visitors as "one of the local Bexhill ruins."
The degree of increase in the aged population across Europe is not expected to be anywhere as sharp as it will be in the United States and Japan, which have relatively young populations. By 2040, the over-65 segment of the population in the United States is expected to grow by about 75 percent, and in Japan by 149 percent.
Still, the rate is steep enough to insure that Europe's overall population remains older than that of any other continent. This led the European Community to designate 1993 as the European Year of Older People and to initiate seminars, conferences and studies examining everything from age discrimination to more efficient management of long-term health care.
In Europe's capitals, the looming burden of sustaining pension and health-care programs for the growing number of elderly is already forcing choices on governments that had until recently prided themselves on their social welfare programs.
Like the United States, which made changes in its Social Security system in 1983 by increasing taxes and curbing benefits, Germany, Italy, France and Britain have enacted or are considering similar changes of their own, including plans to raise the age at which retirees will qualify for pensions.
Many people would have to work longer to qualify for benefits, not only so the Government could limit the flow from social security budgets, but also to increase contributions to pension funds. The ratio of working people to retired people -- between those whose contributions sustain the pension funds and those who draw on them -- is projected to decline sharply.
In 1980, for example, there were 4.3 people of working age in Britain for every person over 65. By 2040, that ratio is expected to decline to 3 to 1.
Britain is studying a proposal that would raise the retirement age for women from 60 to 65, the same as it is for men, and thereby save the social security budget an estimated $6 billion in annual payments.
At the same time, nearly every European country is looking at ways to shift a larger share of the burden for care and service to the private sector and voluntary charities.
"It is a painful adjustment for Europe, where the idea was always for governments to take care of people, to actively intervene on their behalf," said Mervyn Kohler of Help the Aged, a private British charity that works with the elderly. "And it is especially hard on the generation now in their 50's and 60's, who are being told by politicians that, whoops, you aren't going to get all you thought you were."
 
Paying for Nursing Care
 In Germany, which has already agreed to lift the age for pension eligibility for men and women to 65 by 2012, the Government is close to adopting a plan for Government health insurance to cover nursing care for the elderly by increasing monthly contributions from workers and employers by 1.7 percent.
But to increase the employers' contribution, workers would be required to forfeit the first two days of pay for sick leave, which in turn would be contributed to the health fund. The proposal has stirred wide opposition.
In France, which reduced the eligibility age for pensions 13 years ago, the new conservative Government recently introduced legislation to increase taxpayer contributions to its social security fund by 1.3 percent and impose new taxes on some beverages.
The Government stopped short of changing the retirement age from 60, but it increased the period that an employee must work to qualify for a full pension from 37.5 years to 40 years. It also diluted the income on which the pension is calculated, from an employee's 10 highest-earning years to his or her 25 highest-earning years.
In Italy, where the working population is projected to shrink 15 percent by 2040 while the number of elderly grows by 35 percent, the Government intends to raise the retirement age for men and women to 65, increase contributions and, as in France, use a longer span of earnings to calculate pension entitlements.
 
Politically Volatile Issue
 All the initiatives are politically volatile. Some older people assert that they are being cheated out of benefits, because they must now work longer before they can begin drawing their pensions.
But many advocates for the elderly say there is no reason older people cannot work longer. On the whole, older people are healthier and more fit, and much more culturally and socially adept, than earlier generations.
"I think the picture of the little old frail lady living in a nursing home on the coast is a vanishing image," said Mr. Kohler of Help the Aged. "Generations that will be coming into retirement 20 years from now will have completely different life experiences, and expectations, than their parents or grandparents."
At the same time, deferring retirement may mean that older people will be competing with younger people for jobs. In a recent letter to The Times of London, a writer complained that such a measure would "increase unemployment among younger people, since jobs that would have become available through retirement would continue to be filled."
Another way that governments are looking to reduce expenditures is by shifting some responsibility for care to local administrations and asking them to take a stronger role in managing the providing of services.
 
'Community Care' Preferred
 The strategy reflects a philosophical commitment across the Continent to what is broadly described as community care, or trying whenever possible to keep people in their own homes rather than in institutions.
Ken Saunders, a team manager for the Sussex County Social Services Department, said his department had already begun shopping for services from private companies and help from charities because the money allocated to the county by the national Government had remained nearly static over the last decade while its elderly population continued to grow.
Organized by the county, the resource center that Mrs. Wheeler and some 80 other elderly people visit daily in Bexhill represents an amalgam of private and public sector cooperation.
The podiatrist and hairdresser are provided by a local charity, and the people who deliver meals to the center are volunteers, although the county pays the cook and buys the food. Mr. Saunders and the center's manager, Linda Phillips, are working more closely with private concerns that offer everything from transportation to home care.
For her part, Mrs. Wheeler says she wants to avoid a nursing home.
"I don't want to leave my apartment," she said. "That's what's so nice about coming here. Every day I go back home."

It is also a kind of testing ground for solutions to the social and governmental challenges that much of Europe faces as its population grows older. HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Bond Yields Hit 16-Year Low

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond inched down to another 16-year low yesterday as traders and investors awaited reports today and tomorrow on inflation in June.
The data on inflation, which many analysts expect will show that prices were restrained or even declined, could help continue a summer rally that has shown how quickly the mood can change in the bond market. 
 The move to new lows in 30-year bond yields, which got going in the last week of June, came after a market selloff in May that was prompted by fears of rising inflation and the threat of tightening interest rates by the Federal Reserve. In the May selloff, the 30-year bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, jumped to 7.04 percent on May 21.
 
 
Secondary Trading
 In secondary trading yesterday, the price of the 30-year bond due in February 2023 rose 6/32 point as the yield fell to 6.62 percent, the lowest since the Treasury began to issue 30-year bonds regularly in May 1977. The yield on Friday was 6.63 percent.
The prices of Treasury notes were unchanged or slightly higher in light trading. At the weekly auction of three- and six-month Treasury bills, the average discount rates were slightly higher.
The Producer Price Index for finished goods, which will be released today, is expected to show a decline of two-tenths of 1 percent, according to analysts' consensus figures gathered by Bloomberg Business News. Salomon Brothers is predicting a decline of five-tenths of 1 percent. The index was unchanged in May.
The consensus on the Consumer Price Index, which will be released tomorrow, is for an increase of just one-tenth of 1 percent. Salomon Brothers is expecting it to be unchanged. The index rose one-tenth of a percent in May.
A one-tenth of 1 percent rise in the Consumer Price Index would put the annualized rate of inflation for the first half of the year at just over 3 percent, which would bring it back closer to the 2.9 percent increase for all of 1992.
If these predictions prove to be right, they will also help ease some of the concerns about inflation raised by the recent sharp rise in commodity prices and the upward spurt in the price of gold. In trading yesterday, the price of gold for August delivery on the Commodity Exchange in New York was up $2.60, to $394.90 an ounce. The Commodity Research Bureau index of commodities prices was down 0.83, to 215.18.
Another positive for the bond market is the recent rally of the dollar, which closed yesterday at 1.7290 marks and 109.45 yen. In the last three weeks, the value of the dollar has jumped 3 percent against the German mark.
The dollar rally is likely to continue attracting foreign investors into dollar-denominated investments in the United States in an effort to profit on the rising value of the currency. And a lot of the securities that are bought will be bonds.
There are still some road blocks ahead, however. One is the uncertainty over the negotiations on the deficit-reduction package in Washington. Another is the pace of economic growth.
On deficit reduction, the House and Senate still have to work out the differences between their two proposals, and that could lead to delays that could worry investors.
On the economy, much of the bond rally has come on recent reports that economic growth did not pick up much in the second quarter after a very sluggish pace in the first three months of the year, when the gross domestic product grew at an annual rate of only seven-tenths of 1 percent. This sluggishness was emphasized a week ago, with a report that nonfarm payroll jobs rose a meager 13,000 in June.
But it is possible that the economy will begin to show some signs of a pickup soon. Salomon Brothers is predicting a three-tenths of 1 percent increase in retail sales in June, after an increase of just one-tenth of 1 percent in May. While still moderate, such a June pickup would be a signal that consumers are still buying. The retail sales data will be released tomorrow along with the Consumer Price Index report.
John Lipsky, the chief economist at Salomon Brothers, said that while the inflation news is likely to be positive, it is essential that investors and traders think it can continue.
That judgment will depend on the pace at which the economy is growing. If it is moderate -- in the 3 percent annual range -- then the good inflation news can help long-term interest rates fall even further, Mr. Lipsky said. If the economy is much stronger, then fears about future inflation pressures will revive, and that could stop the decline in long-term rates.

HEADLINE: San Diego Sees Too Much of Success In Building Hotels to House the Poor

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO

 BODY:
Over the last six years, this city has proved unusually adept at building inexpensive housing for the poor.
Too adept, it now seems, for its own taste. 
 A few years ago, city planners were winning national awards for replenishing San Diego's stock of single-room-occupancy hotels, the inexpensive quarters for the down and out that have been vanishing in many other cities amid lawsuits and angry civic clashes.
 
Turning Policy Around
 As advocates for the poor in other cities fought simply to preserve such hotels from demolition, San Diego coaxed private developers into building dozens of new ones.
But after aggressively promoting their policies around the country, San Diego officials have now made it virtually impossible to build any more of the hotels downtown.
The shift, which began quietly more than a year ago through changes to the zoning and building codes, came after some downtown businesses and residents complained that the hotels attracted too many undesirable people.
"There was a feeling the downtown already has more than its share," said Myles Pomeroy of the San Diego Planning Department. The critics, he said, feared that a further concentration of inexpensive hotels would scare off middle-class housing and destroy the drive for a varied downtown.
The changes close, for now at least, a celebrated chapter of urban development, one that mixed profit motives with social goals and added a dollop of architectural innovation. What began as some tinkering with the city's building codes inspired tens of millions of dollars of new investment, two academic case studies and a handful of national awards for architecture and government.
 
City 'Deserves High Marks'
 Although advocates for the poor have expressed regret over the recent change, they say the city has gone farther than most to promote low-income housing.
"All in all, I think San Diego deserves high marks for what they did," said Andy Raubeson, who heads a not-for-profit development organization in Los Angeles that specializes in single-room occupancy hotels, or S.R.O.'s. "It was urban pioneering to make the changes, which gave them what they wanted -- a substantial increase in the housing stock."
Alan Altshuler, dean of the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University, praised San Diego's talent for getting private enterprise to address a public problem. "It's really quite a remarkable accomplishment," he said of the building boom.
Mr. Altshuler said the San Diego experience showed that local codes could be changed to make housing less expensive without compromising safety. The direct relevance of the San Diego example to other cities varies, of course, with local circumstances. High land prices in New York, for example, would make it extremely difficult for the city to make S.R.O.'s profitable for downtown developers just by adjusting building codes.
Single-room-occupancy hotels sprang up in the early part of the century to house transient workers. But over time, many turned into slum housing for alcoholics, drifters and the mentally ill. Beginning in the 1960's, urban renewal destroyed as many as one million such rooms across the country, as developers put prime downtown sites to more expensive uses.
But many of the displaced people had nowhere else to go, and cities began looking for ways to preserve the hotels.
In 1985, San Diego put a moratorium on hotel destruction, after redevelopment had cost the city a quarter of its 4,600 S.R.O. units. But the hotel owners protested that this illegally deprived them of their rights, and some simply closed their properties.
Chris Mortenson, a local developer, stepped forward with an unconventional idea: He would build a new S.R.O., one of the nation's first in 50 years.
To proceed, however, Mr. Mortenson had to find ways around zoning and building codes that he said discriminated against S.R.O.'s and needlessly added to their cost. "We wouldn't do it if it wasn't profitable," he said.
He won permission, for instance, to install thinner fire doors in exchange for putting sprinklers in the ceiling. He was also allowed to install toilets that were closer to kitchen sinks than the code normally allowed.
Mr. Mortenson's building is called the Baltic Inn, named for the cheapest property on a Monopoly board. The rooms are simple and small, with a bed, a toilet and a sink. Showers are off the hall. Residents can cook with microwave ovens in their rooms, and they use common lounge and laundry areas.
 
Helped by 27 Code Changes

When the Baltic opened to immediate success, other developers wanted to follow. To encourage them, the City Council in 1987 adopted a package of 27 changes to the zoning and building codes. The changes were designed to accommodate S.R.O.'s as a unique form of housing, somewhere between an apartment and a hotel. By waiving expensive requirements to provide parking, for instance, the code recognized that most S.R.O. residents do not have cars.
A building boom followed, adding about 2,700 S.R.O. units to the city, few of them publicly subsidized.
Among the intriguing byproducts of the experiment was the work of the Baltic Inn's designer, Rob Wellington Quigley, an architect with a prominent reputation but little experience in low-income housing.
Mr. Mortenson said, "We wanted to do it with a name architect, so everybody wouldn't say we're building a ghetto."
Intrigued by the challenge of giving inexpensive buildings what he calls "emotional content," Mr. Quigley took on the work at a greatly reduced fee. Although economy required the Baltic to take on a boxlike shape, for instance, Mr. Quigley arranged a striking V-shaped color contrast on its exterior to destroy the monotony.
 
Enlivened by Alternating Colors
 Mr. Quigley designed three subsequent S.R.O.'s, expanding on his base of knowledge as he went. Efficiency requires the buildings to have long, monotonous corridors, but Mr. Quigley learned to alternate colors on the plastic baseboards: navy blue, then turquoise, then maroon.
His work has earned Mr. Quigley a fistful of architectural awards, and in 1988 the city won a $100,000 award from the Ford Foundation for offering, through the code changes, an example of government innovation. Planning officials used the prize money to proselytize among other cities, and the Kennedy School produced two case studies of the city's experience.
Most of the San Diego hotels cater more to the working class than to those living on welfare or disability checks. Only about 500 of the 2,700 new units rent for less than $280 a month, with most renting in the $400 range and some costing as much as $525 a month. The Baltic, where rooms rent for under $300 a month, mixes healthy young workers with the aging alumni of homeless shelters. Richard Ulmer was living in a shelter in Tucson, Ariz., but moved to San Diego after learning of its plentiful S.R.O. hotels.
"I read the want ads, and I kind of gathered what the S.R.O. situation was," he said.
At the age of 59, Mr. Ulmer, a recovering alcoholic, suffers from bone cancer and multiple sclerosis, requiring him to use crutches and making walking painful. He gets by on a $683 monthly disability check and says that without the Baltic he would "probably be on the streets."
Mr. Pomeroy, the city planner, said the hotels had not caused a surge of crime or disorder. "I certainly wouldn't say San Diego regrets having done it," he said, calling the latest changes in codes a brake, not a backtrack.
The recent changes began in 1991, when the city adopted a parking plan that requires new S.R.O.'s to provide one parking space for every five rooms, driving up the hotels' cost. And a redevelopment plan adopted by the City Council last year designates several blocks for residential use but classifies S.R.O.'s as commercial.
Mr. Raubeson, the housing advocate, calls the changes an example of the not-in-my-backyard attitude that hampers low-income housing everywhere. "It's just the feeling that there's too many poor people," he said, "which is sad."

HEADLINE: Reich Assails Price Increases

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 12

 BODY:
Secretary of Labor Robert B. Reich criticized some American companies today for raising prices rather than using now-advantageous foreign-exchange rates to increase their share of markets against foreign competitors.
In remarks at a Congressional seminar, Mr. Reich accused some business leaders of short-term thinking, using as an example their response to exchange rates that are making imported goods more expensive and United States goods more attractive. 
 "Look at what has happened now that the dollar is low, that is relative to the yen and some other currencies," he said.
"American manufacturers could use this opportunity to increase market share," he said, adding that instead they are raising prices.
Mr. Reich declined to specify which industries he alluded to, and did not respond to a question whether he meant the auto companies.
"There have been some discussions" between Cabinet members and industry leaders about the situation, he said.
