HEADLINE: Economic Recovery Spreads But the Gains Vary by Region

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
For two years, the fitful economic recovery has been a fact in only half the country. In the heartland -- the Midwest, Southeast, Texas and the surrounding states -- sales and jobs started to come back after a quarter or two of relatively mild recession. In coastal regions like the Pacific Southwest, the Middle Atlantic States and New England, the worst layoffs and losses since the Great Depression continued for quarter after quarter.
But now, recent signs of weakness notwithstanding, the recovery that began in the nation's center seems to be fanning out to the rest of the country. Exports to Latin America and tourists from Europe are helping to revive Florida and the rest of the Southeast. Stronger car sales have given a lift to parts of the Midwest, although recent floods could cause a temporary setback. In Texas and other South Central states, service businesses and high-technology manufacturing are expanding. A few Western states have been growing so fast that businesses are running out of people to hire.
 
Higher Employment

 In deeply depressed California and the rest of the Pacific Southwest, sales and income tax collections have stopped shrinking and business people say the economy may have touched bottom. The northern New England states are growing again, and there are signs of life even in Connecticut, which is still reeling from military cutbacks. And New Jersey has started to regain some of the jobs it lost. 
 The extent of the spreading recovery is mirrored in a variety of broad economic statistics. Employment -- though still shrinking in a few states -- is higher this year in all but one region, the South Central states, than it was in the first half of last year. Help-wanted advertising, a sensitive indicator of changes in the job market, has turned up in seven of the nine regions in the last three months, though it is still far below its pre-recession peak.
And while factory employment, historically a source of good jobs, has dropped to its lowest point since the mid-1960's, in most regions industrial production has recovered to pre-recession levels. This means more profits and wages for manufacturers and workers.
Income has also recovered in most areas of the country, although many people have been left behind, either with no jobs or lower-paying jobs. New England is the only region where total real personal income (excluding the effects of inflation) has not yet climbed to a record high, though it is only marginally below its previous peak.
"The recovery is finally spreading," said Sara Johnson, who heads a team of regional economists at DRI/McGraw-Hill, a forecasting firm.
In another sign that the recovery is reaching across the country, revenues from state income and sales taxes have grown. Every region reported higher revenues in the first quarter, compared with a year ago, according to the Center for the Study of States in Albany. John Liscio, the editor of a financial newsletter, also notes that the majority of large states have been reaching or exceeding their revenue targets in recent months, even though many have recently raised those targets.
Business people in most parts of the country also say they detect signs of growth, though it is often slow growth. In some of the most depressed states and regions, like the Southwest, executives say they see indications that the slide has stopped.
To be sure, it is difficult to measure with precision how well various regions are doing. The statistical evidence is mixed and sometimes contradictory. State tallies of business payrolls, for example, have shown virtually no growth in recent months, even though the Department of Labor's nationwide employment survey shows that business has added half a million new jobs in each of the last two quarters.
 
 
A National Pattern
 As a rule, regional data are less trustworthy than national indicators, which are based on bigger samples. But taken together, the economic statistics and business reports suggest a pattern of recovery that is clearly becoming more national in scope.
Even as the recovery spreads, economists are remarking on how long the process has taken. In the past, most regions sank into recession at about the same time, and started to come out again within a quarter or two of one another.
"This was the most regionally concentrated recession in postwar history," said Brian Cromwell, a regional economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco. "That disparate performance during recession turned into unbalanced recovery."
Economists say that growth is likely to remain extremely uneven, with some regions growing two or three times as fast as others. The slow, on-again, off-again pace of the recovery itself is likely to make those disparities feel larger as well.
"All recoveries are uneven," said Lawrence Katz, chief economist at the Department of Labor. "Boom or recession, there are some areas that grow faster than others. The mountain states are going to grow faster than New England or the Midwest."
 
 
Effects of Military Cuts
 Indeed, the recovery's increasingly national scope does not mean that it will necessarily shift into high gear. It is apt to take several more years for the regions hit hardest, particularly New England, the Middle Atlantic and the Pacific Southwest, to recoup the jobs lost in recent years. And Ms. Johnson of DRI/McGraw-Hill says she still expects some states, including California and Connecticut, to lose more jobs as Washington continues to pare the military payroll.
"Job growth is going to be a lot slower in the 1990's than the 1980's," said Steven Gold, director of the Center for the Study of States in Albany. "If overall growth is below average, that means some states are actually stagnating or even shrinking."
The broadening of the economic expansion reflects two developments. In the areas of the country where the recession turned out to be relatively short and shallow, the number of jobs started to grow at a faster clip in the first half of the year. Utah, Idaho and other mountain states, where help-wanted ads have jumped nearly 11 percent since February, have been attracting migrants from other states, as well as new businesses -- from credit card operations to software companies.
Texas, Louisiana and President Clinton's own Arkansas, where payroll jobs are 2 to 6 percent above levels a year ago, are reaping the rewards of expanding trade with Latin America and rebounding housing markets. The oil patch went through hard times in the late 1980's -- ahead of the rest of the country -- after oil prices, real estate and much of the Texas banking system collapsed.
 
 
Growth for Southeast
 In the Southeast, a swelling population, a revival of home building and the growth of new high-tech and service companies are contributing to some of the fastest job growth in the country -- well over 2 percent a year in populous states like Georgia, North Carolina and South Carolina. Economists expect job growth to stay strong despite pockets of weakness likely to be caused by military cutbacks. And a surge in tourism and solid gains in exports to Latin America, says Erdal Donmez, an economist for the City of Miami, are keeping Florida's economy going.
Job growth in the Midwest, which has been swept by torrential rains and floods, is being tempered by the recent weakness in manufacturing and a continuing effort to raise productivity on the factory floor. But thanks to higher car and truck production, Michigan has been a leader in payroll job growth in the last six months or so, though its unemployment rate ticked up a bit -- to 7.3 percent -- in June. The next few months may look better, however, since American auto makers are to turn out 2.5 million cars and trucks this summer, 17 percent more than last summer.
Other industrial states are also showing gains. The latest Labor Department employment report on large industrial states showed that unemployment fell in June in Illinois, Ohio and Pennsylvania.
"We had a good year last year, but our business has been on a definite upsweep since last August," said Tim Dressing, president of Dressing Chevrolet, Buick and Pontiac in Jacksonville, Ill., a town whose farming and food processing industries have not been threatened by the widespread flooding in other parts of the state. In Jacksonville, light manufacturers are investing heavily in new plants and equipment, and construction is on the rebound.
 
Good Signs for Weak Regions
 In contrast, the economy is still depressed in some other areas, but there are signs that these regions may be touching bottom.
Job losses have started to taper off in New York State and the rest of the mid-Atlantic region, as well as in New England and the Southwest. Some states in these regions have already seen the beginnings of spotty job growth and an upturn in job ads. And some industries -- especially retailing, health and services -- are adding to payrolls.
The weakest regions are getting help from the rest of the country, which is buying more of their goods and services. For example, northern New England is getting a lift from tourism. Upstate New York, where factories produce everything from headlights to auto air-conditioners, is benefiting from stronger nationwide car and truck sales.
Many state and local governments -- California's not included -- are in better shape than they were in 1990 and 1991. As a result, they are spending more, which is stimulating their economies. Even as Federal payrolls are shrinking, states and localities have added more than 100,000 jobs in the last five months.
In New England and the Middle Atlantic States, home building is reviving as a glut of unsold houses and empty apartments has started to ease after a four- or five-year hiatus in building.
 
A Low Point for California?
 Even in California, where more military cuts loom and business executives are willing to venture only that the economy may be flattening out after its steep fall, the unemployment rate has drifted down to 9.1 percent from 10 percent and the number of Californians with jobs is up 1.6 percent from a year ago. In addition, said Brad Williams, executive director of the California Commission of State Finance, tax collections -- an indirect measure of employment -- have leveled off in recent quarters after falling sharply for two years.
"It feels as if the last three months are the low point," said Steve Compodonico, comptroller of the Collins Electrical Company, a large electrical contractor in Stockton, Calif.
That is not to say that improvement will be continuous everywhere. The Pacific Northwest, for example, which has had the nation's fastest-growing job market for five years, is being threatened with tens of thousands of layoffs at Boeing and further cuts in its troubled lumber industry. And in a few states, including Nebraska, the unemployment rate has tumbled so far that labor shortages are actually threatening to choke off what growth there has been.
Despite the shortcomings in some of the state-by-state job figures, which are often sharply revised, there are reasons to think that the picture of stabilizing job markets in most of the country is reasonably accurate, since the numbers are supported by data on tax revenues and other indicators.
If anything, said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the Bureau of Labor Statistics commissioner for the New York region, the count of payroll jobs in, say, the New York metropolitan area makes the job market look weaker than it is. That is because it does not capture all of the new small businesses that people are starting, something that tends to happen when the economy is switching from recession to recovery. It takes Government data collectors a while to find the start-ups and include them in regular surveys.

HEADLINE: Police List Items From Search Of Home of Suspect in Killings

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., July 12

 BODY:
Nassau County prosecutors today released a chilling inventory of items they said had been found in searches of Joel Rifkin's bedroom, garage and pickup trucks. The list included books about serial murders and tying knots and 75 pieces of women's jewelry.
The six-page list was released on the same day that prosecutors gave a grand jury evidence in the death of Tiffany Bresciani, 22, whose body was found in the back of Mr. Rifkin's pickup truck when two state police troopers arrested him on June 28. 
 Though the police say Mr. Rifkin, 34, an unemployed gardener, has confessed to killing 17 women, and credit cards taken from his bedroom last week linked him to an 18th death, the Nassau County grand jury will consider only Ms. Bresciani's death because she was the only victim found in Nassau County.
The grand jury is expected to indict Mr. Rifkin tomorrow, with arraignment likely later this week, said Ed Grilli, a spokesman for prosecutor's office.
 
Pink Sock and a Hair Curler
 Listed today among the things found in Mr. Rifkin's room was "The Green River Killings," a book about what remains the nation's lengthiest string of unsolved murders, in which the bodies of 49 prostitutes were dumped along the Green River south of Seattle in the 1980's. Most of Mr. Rifkin's victims have been identified as prostitutes.
Other books were "Ropes and Knots" and Shere Hite's "Women and Love: A Cultural Revolution in Progress." The 1987 book, a controversial report on marital infidelity, concluded that 70 percent of women married for more than five years were having affairs.
And there was more: heavy and thin ropes, a bag of unidentified "boney matter," 17 rolls of film, videotapes and legal pads crammed with personal writings. A blue metal safe held 48 pieces of women's jewelry, and the police found another cache of 27 baubles. They found women's clothes: a pair of gray stretch tights with one pink sock still attached, a black sweater with white balls, a pair of black suede pants, a blue Lycra skirt, shoes and a hair curler.
The first search of Mr. Rifkin's house, garage and one truck in East Meadow was done the same night the troopers stopped him for driving without license plates.
While investigators had earlier mentioned several items taken from Mr. Rifkin's home -- including a blood-soaked orange wheelbarrow and women's underclothes -- today's list was the first thorough accounting of the items seized in that first search. The inventory did not include items taken in a far more extensive search of the home and surrounding grounds that the police conducted with specially trained dogs last Thursday.
The sheer array of women's belongings raised questions about how Mr. Rifkin collected such a pile of personal effects -- much of it left in plain sight in his cluttered room -- without arousing the suspicion of his sister, Jan, 31, or his mother, Jeanne, 71, with whom he lived.
 
Some of Story Doubtful
 Mr. Rifkin's lawyer, Robert Sale, has challenged the propriety of the June 28 search and last week asked the Nassau County District Attorney to investigate the way it was conducted. While Mr. Sale would not disclose the results of the inquiry, Mr. Grilli said the prosecutor had found "nothing to corroborate Mr. Sale's allegations."
Of the 18 killings, the police have so far identified 10 women by name, either through Mr. Rifkin's confession or through evidence found at his home and in his pickup trucks.
Another four bodies recovered by the police in the region are believed linked to Mr. Rifkin, though the remains have not been identified by name. The bodies of four more women the police believe Mr. Rifkin strangled have yet to be found.

HEADLINE: Dow Inches Up 3.32 in Seesaw Trading

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET

 BODY:
Billions of dollars sloshed to and fro in the stock market yesterday, as prices fluctuated with the news, the weather or somebody's mood. But at the end of the day, analysts said, it all signified very little.
"It's a ho-hum market," said Rao Chalasani, chief investment strategist for Kemper Securities in Chicago. 
 After a roller-coaster ride, the Dow Jones Industrial average closed the day up 3.32 at 3,524.38. Other indexes were similarly up slightly. Traders passed 202 million shares back and forth on the New York Stock Exchange, down from 234 million Friday.
Some analysts said investors were hanging back, waiting for the release of the June inflation figures today and tomorrow, but Mr. Chalasani dismissed that view, saying the market was simply stalled.
"I don't think the market is marking time," he said. "Today's market is telling us the rally that started last week can't be carried to any appreciable heights." The Dow gained 37.09 last week.
 
Transportation Stocks Change
 The only sizable change yesterday came among transporation stocks. Weighed down by aviation and railroad issues, the Dow transportation average sank 13.44 points, to 1,495.72. Delta Air Lines lost a point to close at 46 7/8. USAir also dropped one point, to 13 3/4.
Federal Express helped lower the transportation average, falling 1 1/8 points, to 45 7/8, probably because the company plans to release its second-quarter earnings today, said James Winchester, a senior equities analyst at Lazard Freres.
"People may be a little nervous about holding it going into the earnings report," he said.
Mr. Winchester said that like other transportation stocks, Federal Express was suffering because of pessimism about the economy in the second half of the year. A weak economy "obviously has an impact on such premium product services as the overnight and express services," he said.
Other leading market indicators edged up yesterday, drowsily. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 0.85, to 448.98. The Nasdaq composite gained 1.86, to 707.67, and the American Stock Exchange composite rose 3.73, to 438.10.
Reversing a week's worth of uniform gains among the Big Three auto makers, Ford Motor was one of yesterday's big decliners, shedding 2 points to finish at 50 1/8. Jack V. Kirnan, a Salamon Brothers auto analyst, lowered his opinion of the company yesterday from "buy" to "hold."
Mr. Kirnan said that he was alarmed to discover that a high proportion of Ford car and truck sales were for commercial and rental fleets and for leasing, which are less profitable than straight retail sales. That sales strategy, rather than weakness in the European market, is behind the company's low profitability, he said.
"Our call on Ford today really reflects what we now feel is a rather serious deterioration in the company's product mix in North America," he said.
General Motors and Chrysler both slipped 5/8, to 46 7/8.
Among the blue chips, I.B.M. had a particularly strong day. After the company reported that it was shipping a new microprocessor to compete with Intel chips that control computer disk drives, its stock rose 1 1/2 points, to 48 1/8. That gain alone accounted for 3.32 points of the Dow's increase -- equal to the total rise on the day.

HEADLINE: Northeast Incomes Remain Relatively High

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
New England and the Middle Atlantic States, which boomed in the 1980's only to crash hard, have seen their troubles drag on for two years after growth revived in America's great middle. But even as the pain continues, economists offer one bit of solace: the two regions are still more prosperous than most other parts of the country.
The Northeast was hit with the worst job losses in the nation. Together with California, it accounted for two-thirds of the jobs lost in the recession, and neither the Northeast nor California has yet reached its pre-recession employment levels. 
 But income figures tell another story. "The rich stayed rich," said Nicholas S. Perna, chief economist at Shawmut Bank in Hartford. "After the havoc wreaked by the worst recession since the Great Depression, the Northeast is still affluent."
Just how affluent may come as a surprise. During the 1980's, Massachusetts vaulted into third place in per capita income, up from 13th. Even after 10 percent of the jobs in New England disappeared, Massachusetts still ranks third. Total purchasing power in the state -- as measured by the personal income of all residents -- is still 45 percent higher than in 1979. And despite the real estate bloodbath, houses are selling for two and a half times what they fetched at the start of the 1980's.
New York, which lagged far behind neighboring Connecticut at the end of the 1970's, moved closer in the 1980's, advancing from ninth in per capita income among the 50 states to fourth now. New Jersey, which had been fifth, is right behind Connecticut, the top-ranked state, today.
Connecticut displaced Alaska in the 1980's as the state with the highest average per capita income, but it has been one of the states most bruised by the recession. Still, it has hung on to its top status despite deep military cutbacks, white-collar layoffs and corporate defections. Per capita income was just a hair below $27,000 a year in 1992, roughly $9,000 ahead of, say, Ohio or Texas -- two states that weathered the recession quite well.
The Northeast's real losers in the recession, of course, are the factory workers, bank officers and engineers who ended up on the unemployment line. "The people who are still working are still making good money," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner for the Bureau of Labor Statistics. "And their pay increases have kept pace with other regions."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Rate Cut Prospects in France And Germany Raise Dollar

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar rallied against the German mark and French franc yesterday amid mounting speculation that German and French interest rates would soon be cut.
Meanwhile, gold prices rose. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, the actively traded gold contract for August delivery gained $2.60 an ounce, to $394.90. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted spot gold at $393.90 an ounce, up $2.35. 
 The dollar's allure grew as speculation intensified during the weekend that France must soon cut interest rates to stop its economic recession from turning into a depression.
 
Interventions Overwhelmed
Heavy dumping of the French franc depressed the currency to around 3.41 per mark, well below its central parity level in the European Monetary System's Exchange Rate Mechanism. This prompted several rounds of coordinated French franc purchases by the Bank of France and Germany's central bank, the Bundesbank, but the waves of selling were overwhelming.
The failed interventions fueled talk that the Bundesbank, in a show of solidarity, would cut German rates soon to make French franc-based investments relatively more attractive.
This was reinforced by the French Economy Minister, Edmond Alphandery, who said maintaining the current mark-franc parity was an "absolute imperative" for France. Moreover, the German Finance Minister, Theo Waigel, said further cuts in German interest rates were both possible and desirable.
"Speculation is rife the Bundesbank will bail out the French by cutting rates before its summer recess," said Howard Archer, research manager at NatWest Bank in London.
The dollar was quoted at 1.7300 marks in late New York trading, up from 1.7210 marks late Friday. It was also quoted at 5.9065 French francs, up from 5.8540 francs on Friday.
 
Dollar Falls Against Yen
Still, the dollar fell against the Japanese yen, sliding to 109.45 yen in late New York trading, from 109.96 yen Friday. Dealers took profits made over the weekend on an American-Japanese trade framework reached at the Group of Seven summit meeting in Tokyo. The framework reduces chances that the United States will talk up the yen in the near future to cut Japan's huge trade surplus, dealers said.
The British pound settled at $1.4769 in New York, down from $1.4810 Friday. Earlier in London, the pound fell to $1.4780, from $1.4822 Friday.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
A Commercial By Nike Raises Concerns About Hispanic Stereotypes.

BYLINE: By Michael Janofsky

 BODY:
SOMETIME during Major League Baseball's All Star Game tonight in Baltimore, television screens around the country will be filled for 30 seconds with visions of bright-eyed boys in tattered clothes, playing baseball in La Tierra de Mediocampistas (the Land of Shortstops), a.k.a. the Dominican Republic.
The dusty setting was chosen by Nike, the athletic apparel company, but not so much to sell shoes or equipment, Scott Bedbury, Nike's director of advertising, said. Rather, Nike wanted a vehicle to reflect the pure joy of the game that would strip away the crass commercialism of the major leagues -- even if it meant spotlighting players who could scarcely afford a Nike T-shirt, let alone $60 baseball cleats. 
 Still, the hardscrabble setting contributes to the mood of the commercial and so does the voice-over. It's entirely in Spanish, making the spot perhaps the first Spanish-language commercial ever broadcast in prime time over a major network in the United States. Subtitles in English appear at the bottom of the screen.
"It's a powerful message of hope for kids that through baseball they can dream," Mr. Bedbury said from his office in Beaverton, Ore. "It shows that people of any age, any culture can participate, and it is particularly moving in that in the Dominican Republic, which has so little, baseball provides so much for them."
From that environment, more than 70 Dominicans have made it onto major league rosters, including a stream of well-known shortstops, like Tony Fernandez of the Toronto Blue Jays and Rafael Belliard of the Atlanta Braves.
Yet however well meaning Nike's intentions -- a bouquet to the vast audience of Spanish-speaking baseball fans -- not all of them appreciate the effort. Some, in fact, might find it downright condescending and, worse, a possible means of perpetuating stereotypes about Spanish-speaking citizens of the United States.
Tony Bonilla, chairman of the National Hispanic Leadership Conference in Corpus Christi, Tex., a group dedicated to enhancing Hispanic participation in mainstream American society, commended Nike for at least acknowledging "the huge economic potential impact" of the Hispanic community by directing a commercial to its members.
But he expressed deep concerns that a Spanish-language commercial viewed by an audience that could reach 20 million people might deepen cultural divides, further isolating the Hispanic population from English-speaking people or those with another first language.
"A large percentage of the Hispanic population might find it insulting," said Mr. Bonilla, who had not seen the Nike ad. "The commercial perpetuates and promotes the idea that Hispanics don't want to assimilate, that they're isolated, clinging to the Spanish language without caring to learn English. That's just not so. A majority of the Spanish-speaking population does speak English. Hispanics are proud of their culture and they do encourage multilingualism. They recognize it as an advantage."
Mr. Bonilla criticized corporate America for its limited use in commercials of Hispanic Americans, who by some accounts will be the largest minority in the United States by the end of the decade. Beyond the work of Ricardo Montalban, an actor once prominent in Chrysler advertisements, and Lee Trevino, the golfer, as Toyota salesman, Mr. Bonilla could cite no other well-known Hispanic American as a corporate spokesman.
Nike has "some relationship" with about half the current 700 major league baseball players, Hispanic players among them, Mr. Bedbury said. But none hawks Nike products in the high-profile manner of Bo Jackson or Deion Sanders, black players who will be seen in other Nike commercials during the All Star Game.
Mr. Bedbury said that when Nike and Wieden & Kennedy, its Portland, Ore., agency, conceived the Dominican baseball commercial, concerns were raised that the theme would celebrate only a minor aspect of the Hispanic culture. But they decided that what they found during several days of shooting reflected enough positive aspects of the culture to compensate for any missing elements.
"We captured what is honestly there," Mr. Bedbury said, "hope, joy, inspiration, baseball and the sense of community that baseball provides. In this ad, we're not trying to sell shoes."

HEADLINE: Tariff Deal Called the Bigger Success

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 12

 BODY:
President Clinton's agreement with the Japanese on a process for trade talks was a political victory, but it will not mean as much for American businesses and workers as the global tariff reduction deal struck a few days earlier, business executives, economists, legislators and officials said today.
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, described the agreement reached in Tokyo on Saturday as a rule book for negotiations in coming months on specific industries, not a trade agreement. 
 "The game hasn't started," he said at a news conference. "You write the rules, then you take the playing field."
Japan agreed to reduce its trade surplus "significantly" over the next few years, but did not yield to American demands for a specific numerical target. The two nations also agreed to organize their trade talks into five broad categories, and to use unspecified qualitative or quantitative criteria for measuring success.
 
Applause From Congressman
 Congressional Democrats expressed enthusiasm today about the deal with Tokyo. "Politically, the Japan agreement is probably the most important, given the fact that most of the attention has been on Japan," said Representative Robert T. Matsui, Democrat of California, who wants to lower American trade barriers.
But there was acknowledgment that the tariff-reduction agreement reached last Wednesday by Japan, Canada, the United States and the European Community was more important. The agreement reinvigorated the long-stalled Uruguay Round talks of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
"The real breakthrough was the Uruguay Round," said Gary C. Hufbauer, an economist at the Institute for International Economics here. "That's why I would give Clinton a B-plus or an A-minus" for his summit performance.
Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr., a trade official in the Carter and Reagan Administrations, said the deal with Japan was more important for how it was accomplished than for any immediate commercial effects. "These negotiations were being handled by office directors," he said, "and now it's at the head-of-state level."
Harold A. Poling, the Ford Motor Company's chairman and chief executive, said in a speech today in Cleveland that while he was pleased that the tariff-reduction deal had been achieved, he thought that specific targets should be set for reducing the Japanese trade surplus.
Among big beneficiaries of last week's tariff agreement may be chemical companies. K. James O'Conner Jr., associate director of international trade for the Chemical Manufacturers Association, said that the deal, if approved by other GATT nations, would mean higher profits for American producers. Chemical companies tend to locate their factories all over the world, depending on where it is cheapest to make a product.
"The chemical industry is already a multinational industry that ships back and forth to itself," Mr. O'Conner said. "The more freedom it has to do that, the more efficient we can be."
 
U.S. Approach Discussed
 Mr. Kantor noted that tariff reductions would be further negotiated, in the hope of expanding and broadening them, this fall in Geneva. In theory, a broader GATT agreement cannot take effect until the organization's 114 nations agree on other issues before them, including limits on unilateral trade sanctions and new rules for trade in services like banking and insurance.
Mr. Kantor said that the Clinton Administration was offering fewer concessions on textiles and apparel than the Bush Administration did. It wants to avoid tariff cuts on goods mainly made in China and Taiwan, which are low-cost producers. The Administration also wants strict rules to prevent large textile and apparel producers from evading quotas on their shipments, he said.
Mr. Clinton has been reluctant to antagonize members of Congress from textile-producing states or textile makers, something Mr. Kantor attributed in part to the industry's employment of many women and minorities.

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
On the Many Splendors Of Long-Lasting Love

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
Five love stories are told in "For Better or for Worse," tonight's cheerfully melancholy offering in the "P.O.V." documentary series. David Collier brings to the screen couples who are more like his grandparents, who have been married for 67 years, than his parents, who were divorced when he was 5. He chose wisely, and his work serves both his subjects and his viewers well.
Three of the couples, all of whom have been together for more than half a century, are white and heterosexual, one is black and one is homosexual. Yet these 10 people are very much alike in their feelings for the person who is never referred to as the significant other. (Yes, kids, there is love after 30, and after 80, too.) 
 As the camera catches hints of their economic and social class (upper to lower middle), their milieus (urban and suburban) and their quirks, they talk about their lives.
How they have managed to stay together all these years: The glue of one union seems to be incessant arguing, particularly over the relationship of chicken legs to drumsticks.
High points: The homosexual couple is seen being celebrated in a New York City Gay Pride parade as "the two oldest gay men in America." And low ones: The black couple recalls the early deaths of two sons.
Sex: One wife, evoking attitudes of another era, says that women don't "get as much out of it" as men, but that she was pleased to be pleasing her husband all these years. Another seems to have been something of a sexual adventurer who deduced, correctly, that her virginal suitor needed some help in that line. Hearing aged men and women admit they have never slept with anyone other than their spouses may strike one as quaint, particularly on television, where promiscuity is a commandment, but whatever they may have lost in sexual variety seems trivial compared to what they have built and sustained.
And the prospect of separation: One partner, who has Alzheimer's, has already been institutionalized. And the others have the end in mind. One man speaks for all when he says, "If she should go first, I won't be long about it."
Despite the shadow of the inevitable, this is far from a gloomy hour. These people don't go in much for self-pity. Old photographs show the couples in earlier years (how demure she looks, how fit he looks, how romantic they look together). When they are seen strolling, it is often hand in hand. Their answers to Mr. Collier's off-camera questions are like duets.
"We're hanging in there with good humor," one says, and the hour, which has a lot of tunes in it, ends on a perfect note with Billie Holiday's delivery of "Our Love Is Here to Stay."
 
P.O.V.
For Better or for Worse
PBS, tonight at 10 (Channel 13 in New York)

David Collier, producer, director and director of photography; Betsy Thompson, co-producer; Marcia Jarmel, associate producer; David Collier and Ms. Jarmel, editors; Ellen Schneider, executive producer for P.O.V.; Ward Chamberlin, executive director of P.O.V.
 
 WITH: Dan and Sophie Trupin, Paul and Inez Jones, Chet and Vi Loucks, Bruhs Mero and Gean Harwood, Howard and Cecil Waite.

HEADLINE: Observer;
Nouveau Riche Guys

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER

 BODY:
My Baltimore sisters who don't know beans about baseball came by the other night and right away started fuming about the players being scandalously overpaid. Their ire had been fomented, if I may lapse into crossword-puzzle talk, by the imminent All-Star Game to be played today in their town.
Like everybody else who hates to see a ballplayer have a big payday, they started in on the shame of a society that pays a schoolteacher only $15 a week, or whatever the current shameful figure is, yet pays millions to Cal Ripken Jr. 
 They specifically cited Mr. Ripken, who plays for their hometown team, the Orioles, as an example of nearly utter worthlessness. Whether this was because he is having a terrible year with the bat seems doubtful, since their interest in R.B.I. statistics is nil.
Most likely it was simply because Mr. Ripken is as prominent a piece of the Baltimore landscape as the Bromo-Seltzer tower or the statue of George Washington in Mount Vernon Place, both of which Mr. Ripken has closely resembled this season when batting with runners on base.
I hate talking baseball with people who know absolutely nothing about it, even when they are my sisters and I love them. I also hate talking baseball with people who know practically everything about it because they make me feel so ignorant.
For instance, I have been itching to ask this question of Thomas Boswell, baseball wizard of The Washington Post whose eye is always on the Orioles: Is there a law that says you can't walk Frank Thomas when he comes to bat with two men on base?
Mr. Thomas, who plays for the Chicago White Sox, comes to bat against the Orioles every few days with two men on base and usually hits a three-run homer. Being pathetically unlearned about baseball, however, I hesitate to ask baseball-wise Mr. Boswell why the opposing team doesn't simply walk Mr. Thomas in this situation.
Is it because they yearn to be three runs behind? Is it bad sportsmanship to deny Mr. Thomas his regular three-run homer by walking him? I'm so certain that this question shows I am completely stupid about baseball that you will never catch me asking it of a master.
I'm not so shy, however, about asking why so many people abuse baseball players for earning princely salaries. You rarely hear anybody say it's shameful that America throws millions at Barbra Streisand, Frank Sinatra, David Letterman, Madonna or Robert Redford while treating teachers like dirt.
Corporate lawyers and investment bankers aren't constantly abused because they happen to be egregiously overpaid, or at least considerably better paid than the schoolteacher my sisters fret about.
For years top corporate bosses have regularly been receiving huge pay boosts while running their businesses into the ground. Since the whole economy finally hit the rocks public hostility, to be sure, has been rising against them, but the overpaid, incompetent C.E.O. still doesn't provoke the kind of bile reserved for baseball players, many of whom are actually quite competent.
Part of it is probably that baseball is blue-collar work widely thought of as entertainment for blue-collar guys. Its long association with beer tells the story. Millionaires are the wine classes. Real guys drink beer.
There may be some mean-spirited streak of envy in Americans which makes them hate seeing a blue-collar worker being paid on the champagne scale along with show-biz stars, lawyers, bankers and corporate bosses. As evidence that the ballplayer doesn't deserve champagne living, note the TV scenes in the winner's locker room at season's end when baseball players use champagne bottles as water pistols.
In any case, you never hear anybody -- except maybe schoolteachers -- say it's disgraceful that movie, TV, rock, legal, banking and corporate stars are paid so much better than schoolteachers.
This concern for schoolteachers, though doubtless sincere with my sisters, is probably just gassy discharge from the population at large. Americans' readiness to let the public school system go right on decaying if money is the price of stopping it is illustrated in election after election.
Ignore the humbug, Mr. Ripken. Get your money every Friday.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Electric Boat Laying Off 800; 1993 Total May Reach 2,000

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON

 BODY:
The Electric Boat Company said yesterday that it was laying off 800 people at its submarine yard in Groton, Conn., and other plants at the end of the month and that layoffs and jobs lost to attrition this year might reach 2,000, not the 1,500 that had been expected.
A company spokesman, Neil D. Ruenzel, said that Electric Boat's workload was declining faster than had been projected as submarines are completed and the company's backlog of orders from the Navy shrinks. The company said last fall that it would cut 1,500 jobs in 1993. The 800 layoff notices to be distributed among salaried and union employees between July 26 and Aug. 9 are part of that reduction. 
 "We're rapidly working off our backlog, which currently consists of three Los Angeles-class attack submarines, four Tridents and two Seawolfs," Mr. Ruenzel said. "We just this month delivered a Trident and a Los Angeles-class submarine, and bear in mind that there have been no new contracts awarded since May of 1991."
The company said it did not know how many jobs would be lost at the Groton yard, which employs nearly 13,000 of Electric Boat's 19,000 employees. A second yard in nearby Quonset Point, R.I., employs 4,000.
Mr. Ruenzel said that the company's original projection of employment at the end of 1993 was 17,500, as more submarines were completed but that the number now could drop as low as 17,000.
If no new contracts are received, Electric Boat has said, its employment at all plants will fall to 7,500 by 1996.
 
Base Is a Factor
 The U.S.S. Nebraska, the 14th of 18 Trident submarines being built, joined the Navy on Saturday at a commissioning ceremony at the Navy's submarine base across the Thames River from Groton in New London. The 18,750-ton submarine was built by Electric Boat over the last six years.
Just last week the Groton area received some good news when it learned that the New London base would not be closed as part of the nationwide cutback in military installations.
But William D. Moore, president of the Chamber of Commerce of Southeastern Connecticut, said that even with the Navy base staying open, economic projections for the region forecast the loss of 21,000 more jobs in New London County by the end of the decade because of military cutbacks.
"It's an unfortunate byproduct of the so-called peace dividend, and when you're in the nation's most heavily defense-dependent region, you feel it," Mr. Moore said. "It's a fact of life in this region that as the contracts go away, so do the jobs."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 14, 1993, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about layoffs at the Electric Boat Company in Groton, Conn., misstated the location of the nearby Navy submarine base. It is also in Groton, not New London.

HEADLINE: Ocean Pioneer Mines Energy That Is Cool, Clean and Free

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

DATELINE: KEAHOLE POINT, Hawaii

 BODY:
DR. JOHN P. CRAVEN has made a living by taming a part of the planet that few people think much about and almost no one visits: the bottom of the deep blue sea.
As head of the Navy's Deep Submergence Systems Project in the 1960's, he pioneered new technologies to plumb the ocean's depths, developing the world's most advanced vehicles for deep-ocean search, rescue and salvage. He also developed an abiding faith in what he saw as the sea's untapped economic potential. 
 In the 1970's he came to this promontory of ancient lava on the big island of Hawaii with the dream of bringing the deep ocean onto dry land, pumping cold water from the Pacific's depths to study the development of new industries and life support systems for the human race. From that vision has flowed discoveries great and small.
"Oh, wow!" Dr. Craven, now 68 years old, said recently as he showed a visitor a lush garden here watered in a novel method using seawater. "Holy smoke! Look at the size of that zucchini."
The 870-acre laboratory and commercial park that developed around his original idea has become the world leader in developing the remarkable potential of cold seawater for such disparate things as growing strawberries, air-conditioning buildings, raising lobsters and making electricity.
Pipes that are 12, 18 and 40 inches in diameter run through the breakwater here and plunge far beneath the waves to haul up deep water as cool as 45 degrees Fahrenheit, about the same as a refrigerator. Other pipes collect warm surface water, typically a tepid 80 degrees. The temperature difference between the two is crucial to much of the magic that goes on here.
Once on land the ocean water flows through a four-story melange of concrete and machinery that cranks out 210 kilowatts of electricity in the newest and largest generator of its kind in the world. In other parts of the laboratory cold water goes though heat exchangers to air-condition a handful of buildings, and in the near future will circulate through the nearby Keahole airport to cool it as well.
Perhaps most impressively, the cool water flows down the road in buried pipelines to nourish a host of small companies that have sprung up over the years to exploit the nutrient-rich seawater for aquaculture. The concerns are raising lobsters, a type of flounder highly prized by the Japanese for sashimi, such sea vegetables as ogo, nori and ele ele, and a kind of microalgae rich in protein known as spirulina, which is sold as a dietary supplement in health food stores.
Most recently, the cool water has been run through a welter of pipes that sustain a large vegetable garden here. The pipes cause water vapor in the humid air to condense and drip onto the soil and root systems, producing an Eden-like profusion of crops that turn out to be exceptionally large and sweet.
"All the other things that came along turn out to be more important than the electricity," said Dr. Craven while munching a carrot from his seawater garden. "You bring up that cold water and you've got it made."
He recently founded the Common Heritage Corporation, based in Honolulu, to commercialize the cold-water techniques, including the emerging ones for agriculture. So far his small research team has tested them on 79 kinds of fruits and vegetables.
"We're doing something so off the wall that most people laugh," said Kevin Sue Rohan, a tan, athletic woman in her 30's who oversees the experimental garden, often with three small children in tow. "But we're doing it successfully."
Dr. Craven sees the mix of cold water electrical production, air-conditioning, aquaculture and agriculture as a boon to the developing world, much of which lies in the equatorial band of the planet where strong sunlight generates big temperature differences between the ocean's upper and lower reaches.
"Deep ocean water is a resource that can, today, provide environmentally sustainable economic self-sufficiency and independence for tropical island and coastal nations around the world," he wrote last year in The Marine Technology Society Journal.
Dr. Thomas H. Daniel, the laboratory's chief scientist, called Dr. Craven a gifted visionary.
"He saw before many other people that the ocean is a very large potential resource," Dr. Daniel said. "We can get 10 terawatts of electricity out of the oceans continuously, which is about man's usage right now."
Dr. Craven was born in Brooklyn in the shadow of the Williamsburg Bridge and joined the Navy during World War II, serving in Hawaii and earning two battle stars before being sent to Cornell University for advanced education. After the war, under the G.I. Bill, he studied at the California Institute of Technology and the University of Iowa, where he met his wife of 42 years, Dorothy, and received a doctorate in mechanics and hydraulics.
 
Important Navy Projects
 In 1951 he began working for the Navy as a civilian, studying how to improve ships and submarines. He was promoted quickly after correctly predicting and helping solve a structural problem with the Navy's first nuclear-powered submarine, the Nautilus.
After serving as chief scientist to the Navy's special project's office, where he helped develop the Polaris missile, Dr. Craven in 1963 became head of the Navy's Deep Submergence Systems Project. There he pioneered advanced vehicles for deep-ocean search, rescue and salvage. He and his team played important roles in major political crises. In 1966 he helped find an American hydrogen bomb that had been lost off the coast of Spain and in 1968 helped locate the twisted wreckage of a nuclear-powered attack submarine, the Scorpion, in waters nearly two miles deep.
The fleet of underwater vehicles that he helped develop included the Navy's NR-1, a deep-diving nuclear submarine with crab-like claws for picking up objects; the Deep Submergence Rescue Vehicle, a cylindrical craft that could save up to 24 people at a time from a sunken submarine; and the bathyscaph Trieste, a deep diving vessel that his team improved to increase its operational range. It investigated the sunken Scorpion.
Dr. Craven was lured to Hawaii in 1970 by the state's governor, becoming dean of marine programs at the University of Hawaii and the state's marine affairs coordinator.
 
Impetus From Oil Embargo
 A major challenge arose in 1973 when the Arab oil embargo sent petroleum prices spiraling and touched off a frenzied search for energy alternatives. The price shock hit especially hard in Hawaii, which depends heavily on imported oil.
In 1974 Dr. Craven founded the Keahole site, known as the Natural Energy Laboratory of Hawaii. It was a state research center for the study of unconventional ways to produce power, especially ones that tapped the site's abundant supply of sunlight and cold water. In 1979 the lab undertook its first major test when a converted tanker off Keahole Point extended a two-foot pipe down some 2,700 feet. Its novel machinery was a big success, generating 50 kilowatts of gross power. Subtracting the electricity used to run the water-lifting pumps, the rig produced 15 kilowatts of surplus power.
"It seemed like perpetual motion," Dr. Craven recalled. "We had no fuel but it kept running. Watching it work was an incredible experience."
Fifteen kilowatts is no great crackle of electricity by commercial standards, being just enough to power a single modern household. But the experiment demonstrated for the first time anywhere the net production of electrical power from OTEC (pronounced OH-tek), or ocean thermal energy conversion.
This approach, whose working principle was first envisioned in the 19th century, uses the world's largest collector of solar energy, the ocean, to heat a fluid that rotates a turbine and generates electricity.
It works in one of two ways. Warm surface water in an evacuated chamber boils and generates vapor that rushes through a turbine as the vapor is cooled by frigid seawater and condenses back into liquid, a method known as an open system. Or the warm surface water vaporizes a working fluid such as ammonia that drives the turbine. Cooled ammonia is recycled in what is known as a closed system. In both cases, a temperature gap of about 35 degrees or more makes possible the production of net power.
Dr. Craven's ship used a closed-cycle system, which was more compact. But as his lab laid a series of pipelines from the shore into the sea in the 1980's, tests of open-cycle systems were also conducted. As a byproduct these produce a flood of desalinated water fit for agriculture or human consumption, since salt is left behind as ocean water turns to steam.
Today, the world's newest OTEC system is the $12 million, 43-foot-tall cylindrical power tower here, which is producing 210 kilowatts of electricity and about 50 kilowatts of surplus power. This open-cycle system came to life in January, and engineers here are now working to increase its running time slowly from eight hours at a stretch to continuous production. The aim is to gather solid operational data for two years.
The project is financed by the State of Hawaii, the Federal Government, and a not-for-profit consortium in Honolulu that has been supported by the Japanese Government.
With new kinds of turbines, an open-cycle system might scale up to plants no bigger than about 10 megawatts since efficiency is limited by the low-pressure steam. A closed-cycle system could in theory be as large as 100 megawatts (and would require a cold water pipe 60 feet in diameter or an equivalent collection of smaller ones). By contrast, a large nuclear reactor can produce 1,100 megawatts of power. An OTEC plant, though small by world standards, is attractive because its fuel is free and clean.
Another attraction is the spinoff industries, which are found with no other renewable source of energy.
 
'Watch the Stuff Grow'
 Dr. Craven and his crew in the 1980's began experimenting with aquaculture, finding that nori, the seaweed used to wrap sushi rolls, would increase its mass at a rate of 55 percent a day.
"You could literally watch the stuff grow," he said. "We were astounded."
The cold seawater is rich in inorganic nutrients like nitrates, phosphates and silicates, is almost devoid of pathogens since it comes from so far below the life zone found near the ocean's surface, and is very clean since it has been out of contact with the surface for centuries. Today, the mixing of warm and cold waters at the Keahole site allows temperatures to be tailored for the manipulation of growth and reproductive cycles.
Private companies line the main road here. The Cyanotech Corp. has 600-foot raceways filled with microalgae from which it extracts fluorescent pigments for medical research and diagnosis. It also grows microalgae that serve as food supplements.
Kona Cold Lobsters Ltd. raises lobsters, 25,000 of them at the present time. "There's no lobsters out there," said Phil Wilson, a company vice president, gesturing toward the nearby Pacific, "only in here."
The half-acre plant is both a holding tank for lobsters flown in from Maine for distribution here and the Pacific rim, and a maternity ward where experiments are under way in hybridization and growing tiny eggs into giant crustaceans.
Company buildings, like those of the lab, are air-conditioned by the cold water. Indeed, air-conditioning turns out to be one of the most economically attractive uses of cold water. It is easy to achieve technically and pays for itself rapidly.
Dr. Craven says a tenant researcher at the lab devised the technique in the mid-1980's, piping cold water through an automobile radiator and having a fan distribute cool air.
Clare Hachmuth, executive director of the Keahole site, said the lab now saves $1,300 a month on electricity by using cold water to cool its two major buildings. Now being planned, she said, is the first off-site cooling application, in which an 18-inch pipeline is to run to the nearby airport.
Dr. Craven, who no longer holds a post with the lab but instead acts as an elder statesman, says that what he prides himself on most in the course of a long oceanic career is learning how to innovate despite the frequent appearance of social obstacles.
"You can't to it if you stick to a big plan developed by the Harvard Business School," he says. "You've got to be a Brooklyn boy. You've got to sneak up on the thing."

HEADLINE: Is 42d St. Development in Hands of 'Professional Crackpots'?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Walking down the 42d Street entrance to the IRT subway, I glanced at a movie marquee reading, "A lot of professionals are crackpots," which you describe in a July 7 news article on the art that has replaced kung fu movies in Times Square because of the actions of the 42d Street Development Project. I had just left my office at Broadway and 43d Street after spending a hostile day on the phone with representatives of the Governor's office, the New York State Urban Development Corporation and the development project. 
 I am a lawyer who has been retained by the owner of a delicatessen on 43d Street between Broadway and Eighth Avenue in a last-gasp effort temporarily to save his store. For two years the delicatessen owner has fended off eviction attempts by the 42d Street Development Project. On July 1 an appellate court refused to prolong the delicatessen's existence. Impressing upon the 42d Street Development Project and the Urban Development Corporation the hardship for the 15 employees being fired and the advantage of retaining a 24-hour store on the now-tawdry 43d Street represented the last hope of saving the delicatessen until the "redevelopment" would begin.
The 42d Street Development Project responded to my inquiries with irritation and umbrage over the deli owner's two-year fight. After court battles and finally success, the imperious development project did not care about a man's desperate fight to save his business, about the unnecessarily unemployed or another boarded-up store on 43d Street. The Urban Development Corporation explained that it is independent of the development project, which has the ultimate decision-making powers.
I do not understand the public art exhibition in Times Square: the "Everybody" installation or the sign in a window that reads "No More Firs," nor do I understand the need for a pair of bright yellow mannequins clad in clothes made from different brands of condoms. I do understand the need for a reasonably priced, 24-hour deli on 43d Street, the need to minimize the boarding up of stores and to maintain employment -- at least until "redevelopment" begins.
The 42d Street Development Project leadership has lost the ability to proceed responsibly. The state may have created a megalomaniacal corporation unable to combine artistic insight with conscientiousness, pragmatism and sensitive direction. The leadership's inexcusable conduct does not engender enthusiasm for the future of Times Square. Perhaps it is not the "professional crackpots," but the impervious and overly zealous bureaucrats with their self-perceived mandate of esthetic superiority who should be debased on movie marquees.
 
ANDREW W. ALBSTEIN
New York, July 8, 1993

HEADLINE: BIG RISE IN BIRTHS OUTSIDE WEDLOCK

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13

 BODY:
Highlighting the changes sweeping the American family, the Census Bureau today reported sharp increases in the number of women who become mothers without marrying, an increase that was particularly steep among educated and professional women.
Nearly a quarter of the nation's unmarried women now become mothers, the bureau reported, an increase of almost 60 percent in the past decade. 
 The Census study controverted stereotypes that have tied out-of-wedlock births predominantly to women who are poor, uneducated or members of minority groups, although women in those categories still remain much more likely to become single mothers.
 
Some Numbers Triple
 The numbers painted a picture of surprisingly sharp change in the past decade alone. Among white women and women who attended college, the percentage who became mothers without marrying more than doubled. For women with professional or managerial jobs, it nearly tripled.
The numbers also grew for black women, Hispanic women and women with less education, but much more slowly.
The findings come at a time of vituperative debate over the causes and consequences of changing family structure, recalling the political food fight that erupted last year when Dan Quayle, the former vice president, attacked Murphy Brown, the sitcom character, for having an out-of-wedlock birth.
Mr. Quayle said children tend to suffer in single-parent families and accused Hollywood of using the fictional Ms. Brown, an affluent television anchor, to glamorize them. A number of liberals and feminists attacked Mr. Quayle, saying he exaggerated the problems of fatherless families and backed an agenda hostile to women and minorities.
 
Issue of Images
 The bulk of social-science research has indicated that children in single-parent families do tend to have more educational, financial, and emotional problems than those raised by two parents. But social scientists are at odds over the extent of the differences and the reasons for them.
Many studies have illustrated the erosion of the traditional American family, brought about by increases in both divorce and out-of-wedlock birth. The census study did not deal with divorced or separated mothers. But it went farther than others in examining the race, education, age and occupations of mothers who were never married.
"It says, in one respect at least, the Murphy Brown image was right -- out-of-wedlock childbearing is not limited to poor women or racial minorities," said Sara McLanahan, a professor of sociology and public affairs at Princeton University.
The study, by Amara Bachu, a census analyst, is called "Fertility of American Women: June 1992." It examined women between the ages of 18 and 44 who had never married. By 1992, 24 percent of them had become mothers, up from 15 percent a decade earlier.
For women who had attended at least a year of college, the rate rose to 11.3 percent, from 5.5 percent in 1982. For white women, the rate rose to 15 percent, from 7 percent. For women with professional or managerial jobs, it rose to 8.3 percent, from 3.1 percent.
 
Public Policy Impact
 Black and Hispanic women remain more likely than white women to have children without marrying. For black women, the rate rose to 56 percent, from 49 percent a decade earlier. For Hispanic women, it rose to 33 percent, from 23 percent.
Public policy has in many ways failed to keep pace with the transformation of the American family. The Government's system of collecting child support from absent fathers remains antiquated. Child care for working women is often scarce or expensive.
And record numbers of single women now rely on welfare, although the value of cash benefits has fallen sharply in the past two decades. In promising to reshape the welfare system, the Clinton Administration is searching for ways to bolster the financial status of single parents, without encouraging dependency.
Mr. Clinton has promised, for instance, to increase child support collections and to increase the tax credits available to low earners, many of whom are single mothers. David T. Ellwood, one of Mr. Clinton's top welfare aides, has often criticized the current system for "expecting one parent to do the work of two."
 
Searching for Explanations
 The Census Bureau's findings were contained in a single chart that was part of a larger study on unrelated topics. The report did not discuss the data's causes or implications, which have been a matter of heated debate among social scientists.
The rapid increase in single-parent families is occurring throughout the industrialized democracies, with the exception of Japan.
Some analysts have put forward economic explanations, stressing that women have fewer financial reasons for marrying than they did decades ago. That is because the gap between the earnings of men and women has narrowed, with women earning relatively more than they used to and men earning relatively less.
Other analysts have stressed social and cultural explanations, arguing that a feminist revolution has left many women with a new sense of independence. Witnessing the high divorce rates around them, they say, many women no longer trust the institution of marriage. And the taboos that discourage out-of-wedlock birth have waned.
 
Some Partners Present
 Ms. McLanahan noted that many women, while unmarried, are living with a partner when they give birth. "For them, they may say this is just like marriage," she said.
Children who grow up in single-parent families are much more likely than others to live in poverty. Last year the Census Bureau reported that 47 percent of the families headed by single mothers lived in poverty, as against 8.3 percent of the families headed by two parents.
Researchers have also found that children in single-parent families are more likely to have low grades, to drop out of high school, or to have their own children out of wedlock.
But social scientists disagree over cause and effect. Some stress that living in single-parent families can bring emotional and financial problems; others stress that emotional problems and financial problems can cause people to live in single-parent families.
Those who are less alarmed by the rise of single-parent families argue that, in some cases, marriage can make things worse. That might be the case, for instance, if a woman is living with an abusive man.
The subject of family structure has remained a sharply divisive one since at least 1965, when Daniel Patrick Moynihan, then a Labor Department official, issued a study on the black family.
It noted with alarm that a quarter of black children were being born out-of-wedlock, a figure which has now risen to approximately two-thirds. Approximately a quarter of all American children are now born out of wedlock.
Mr. Moynihan, now Democratic Senator from New York, was accused of "blaming the victim" -- chastising families for their own poverty and oppression.
Similar accusations, fair and otherwise, have been hurled at countless academics and politicians who have since criticized the rise of unmarried motherhood.
"It's seen as stepping on the toes of those who are trying to support women's independence," said Ms. McLanahan, who was once divorced and noted that she had been a single parent for 10 years.

HEADLINE: Unless Situation Improves, U.N. Should Quit Bosnia, Mediator Says

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, July 13

 BODY:
The United Nations mediator for the Balkans said today that he might have no choice but to recommend the withdrawal of United Nations forces from Bosnia and Herzegovina unless the situation improved.
Such statements have been made before, and the possibility surfaced again this month as peace talks stalled. But the mediator, Thorvald Stoltenberg of Norway, also repeated earlier denials that the threat of a withdrawal of United Nations personnel was being used as a way of pushing the Bosnian Muslims into agreeing to a peace plan proposed by the Serbian and Croatian sides. 
 "I don't know where the rumors come from, but I know that they are wrong," Mr. Stoltenberg told a news conference after briefing the Security Council.
 
'I Would Work Just as Hard'
 "Let's say that they decide not to negotiate," he said, referring to the predominantly Muslim leadership of the Bosnian Government. "I would work just as hard to get funds for relief and to get forces for safe areas. They know this."
In a report submitted to the Security Council today, Mr. Stoltenberg said the peacekeeping forces had suffered 548 casualties, including 51 deaths, in the Balkan conflict. He said there were not enough funds for food, fuel and medical supplies even for the rest of the summer, much less the coming winter season. Relief convoys carrying food, medicine and fuel are being blocked by all three sides, he said, and the fighting has spread into central Bosnia with the resumption of hostilities between Muslims and Croats.
"I hope that it will change," Mr. Stoltenberg said, "but if it continues, the combination of the deteriorating security situation and the lack of resources may lead to a situation where we will have to pull out. At least I will have to recommend it."
Mr. Stoltenberg, a former Norwegian Foreign Minister, replaced Cyrus R. Vance of the United States as the United Nations mediator two months ago. He offered some hope that the three sides, which may meet in Geneva next week, all at least want to try for a negotiated settlement of the conflict.
"I may be wrong," Mr. Stoltenberg said, "but I believe that all the parties now want to try to get a satisfactory solution. They more and more understand that as the war goes on, they will all lose."
 
Plight of Serbia and Croatia
 Citing the deteriorating economies of neighboring Serbia and Croatia and "the tragedy in Bosnia-Herzegovina," Mr. Stoltenberg said, "I see no reason why they should not at least try to see what is possible."
In denying that there was any intention to exert pressure on the Bosnian Government to accept the partition plan, Mr. Stoltenberg was repeating similar statements made last week by the European Community's mediator in the conflict, Lord Owen of Britain.
 Mr. Stoltenberg's grim description of conditions was seen here as part of a pattern that has repeated itself several times in the past, in which the mediators warn that conditions in the former Yugoslavia are reaching the point of collapse, and then the United Nations member countries commit themselves to a modest increase in the level of United Nations support.
"My prediction is that there's a certain wake-up-call quality to these briefings, and new steps will be taken to carry us forward for another short period of time," one diplomat here said. "But it's grim."
 
More Troops Said to Be Needed
 At the moment, the most urgent need seems to be raising additional troops to be used in the so-called "safe areas" for Muslims in Bosnia designated by the Security Council this year. Mr. Stoltenberg said that only about 1,100 of the needed 7,500 troops had been provided so far, though he said he was optimistic that the rest would be raised soon.

HEADLINE: U.S. Reviews How to Restore Utilities in Sarajevo

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13

 BODY:
President Clinton's top national security aides failed today to agree on how to break the Serbian blockade of basic services to Sarajevo, the Bosnian capital, which is in its fifth week without electrical service, tap water and natural gas.
Some senior Administration officials said today's meeting, which was attended by Secretary of State Warren Christopher, Defense Secretary Les Aspin and the national security adviser, Anthony Lake, among others, was never intended to decide on specific recommendations for Mr. Clinton. 
 But other officials insisted that President Clinton was deeply disturbed by dramatic television footage from Sarajevo, as well as a report Friday from State Department officials in the field who have urged Washington to take immediate action.
 
Six Options
 During his visit to Tokyo last week, Mr. Clinton told Mr. Christopher to develop a strategy for helping Sarajevo, officials said. The result was an informal paper prepared by the State Department European bureau that laid out six options, from continuing the current policy of diplomatic complaints and economic pressure to mounting a Somalia-style military operation that could involve air strikes and even some United States ground troops.
In between were intermediate steps to help the United Nations peacekeeping force to fulfill its mandate of using all "necessary means" to deliver food, fuel, medicine and other supplies.
The options involving the use of military force were described in the paper as short-term operations with objectives that were not military ones, as mandated in current United Nations resolutions, the officials said. The paper made no recommendations for Mr. Christopher, nor did it offer an estimate of how many troops would be needed to fulfill the most ambitious option, the officials added.
President Clinton has repeatedly said he would not send ground troops to Bosnia, even as part of the United Nations peacekeeping force, while the war is raging.
 
Some Private Advice
 Senior State Department, Pentagon and White House officials are examining proposals prepared by Frederick C. Cuny, an independent aid expert working in Sarajevo, on how to break the Serbian blockade.
Mr. Cuny, who has advised the United States in similar situations in northern Iraq and Somalia, has drawn up two plans: one to ease the city's privations without the use of military force, and one that involves limited military force under existing Security Council resolutions.
The first plan calls for the immediate airlift or airdrop of water-purification equipment. Mr. Cuny said the Soros Foundation, a private philanthropy in New York, had offered to buy simple purification systems for every family in Sarajevo if the Air Force would deliver them.
The United States has decided to airlift 500,000 water purification tablets into Sarajevo, State Department officials said. But they added that since the Serbs have recently blocked most aid that has arrived at the airport, it is likely that the tablets will end up in storage sites.
 
Airport Is the Key
 Mr. Cuny's more ambitious plan calls for absolute United Nations control over Sarajevo airport and the removal of all checkpoints on the two-mile road into Sarajevo. Both steps are authorized under current Security Council resolutions, and would require the United States to offer air protection for the peacekeeping troops, Mr. Cuny said.
Another suggestion is for the United States and its allies to order the Serbs to withdraw their tanks and artillery from the vicinity of Sarajevo, as mandated by the Security Council, so a United Nations peacekeeping force can be positioned between the Serbian nationalist forces and the city. If the Serbs did not meet a deadline, their positions would be attacked by allied warplanes.
Mr. Cuny is convinced the Administration is now determined to ease the crisis. "I think we've finally turned the corner," he said. "The Administration has finally realized that it has to do more to get forceful access to Sarajevo and get the aid in."
But Mr. Cuny's optimistic view is not shared by all relief officials.
"The very fact the Administration is still dithering while the fuel needed to pump water lies at the airport only two miles from the city is incredible," said Lionel Rosenblatt, president of Refugees International, a private aid agency. "This is not a Berlin-blockade-scale problem. It's very easily remedied by either sending the convoys in through one checkpoint with a determined United Nations escort or, if they're scared, to deliver it into the city by air."
 
Chart/Map: "Balkan Update"
 The UNITED STATES deployed 12 A-10 ground attack planes to Aviano Air Base in northern ITALY yesterday in case the craft are needed to protect safe areas the United Nations has designated in BOSNIA. The planes, designed to destroy tanks and artillery positions, will join F-16 fighter planes that have been based in Italy and used on patrol.
 In ISLAMABAD, PAKISTAN, six Muslim nations and the Palestine Liberation Otganization offered to send 18,000 soldiers to protect Muslims in the United Nations zones.
Muslim-led Bosnian Government forces launched a full-scale assault outside the disputed city of MOSTAR, United Nations officials said. Peacekeepers based in SARAJEVO said that Croatian militiamen have detained hundreds of Muslim men, women and children evicted from their homes in a new round of "ethnic cleansing."
In GENEVA, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, Sadako Ogata, said she would visit Sarajevo on Wednesday to assess deteriorating conditions in the capital.

HEADLINE: U.S. and Florida Growers Reach Pact on Everglades

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, July 13

 BODY:
In an action aimed at ending the biggest environmental debate in Florida history after five years of litigation, the Federal and state governments today announced an agreement with agricultural interests on a $465 million plan to help clean up the endangered Everglades.
Under the accord, made public this morning by Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt at a news conference in Washington, sugar companies and other large farming concerns would pay as much as $322 million over the next 20 years to restore the quantity and quality of water flowing into Everglades National Park. The Federal Government and state and regional agencies would bear the remaining costs. 
 With state officials and sugar company executives at his side, Mr. Babbitt said the agreement opened the way to "the largest restoration project in the history of the national park system." But he cautioned that today's accord was merely "a tentative settlement" that "does not by any means finish the task" of saving an ecological system that in recent years has shown alarming signs of decay, from sharp declines in wildlife populations to rising levels of pollution.
 
Plan to Buy Land
 A cornerstone of the plan is the purchase of 40,000 acres of farmland to be converted into six artificial marshes, which would cleanse runoff water of the chief pollutant, phosphorus. An ingredient in fertilizers for sugar cane and vegetables, phosphorus also stimulates the growth of plants like cattails that choke out the native species eaten by fish and wildlife. The agreement also calls for increasing the amount of fresh water flowing into the Everglades by 25 percent, a measure intended to restore plant and animals species that are vanishing because of declining water tables.
Extending south from Lake Okeechobee to the Florida Keys, the Everglades contain some of the most fertile farmland in the United States. Less than half of the land falls within the 1.4 million-acre Everglades National Park, established to protect the ecological system in 1947. The system has come under increasing stress because it provides drinking water to the more than four million people who now live in the narrow coastal strip between Key West and Palm Beach.
Today's agreement, the final details of which are to be negotiated during the next 90 days, calls for growers to reduce the amount of phosphorus flowing into the Everglades as runoff by 25 percent within two years and gradually thereafter through 2013.
If growers, which include United States Sugar, the state's largest, adhere to the timetable to be established in the agreement, they would be liable for $322 million of the clean-up costs. But if they reduce the phosphorus contamination at a faster pace, the clean-up costs could be cut by as much as $90 million.
 
Criticism Continues
 Don Carson, executive vice president of Flo-Sun, another sugar company that signed the accord, said the agreement, though financially painful to the industry, was "a breakthrough" that "would preserve jobs and economic activity" at the same time it guarantees the integrity of the Everglades. He expressed confidence that the industry would meet all goals ahead of time.
"The bottom line is that sugar is just biting the bullet," Mr. Carson said. "We know that we have got to deliver water to the system that is as good as if we weren't there at all."
But Dexter Lehtinen, the former United States Attorney whose 1988 lawsuit against the State of Florida and the South Florida Water Management District prompted the years of litigation, called the agreement "disappointing" and "vague." He said the Federal Government had "essentially immunized big sugar from having to reach the final water restoration goal" that he had been seeking through his suit.
