HEADLINE: Voices of Japan: Anger at the Old Politicians and Skepticism About the New

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 13

 BODY:
From the presidents of Japan's largest corporations to small shopkeepers, everyone in Japan seems to be wary over the recent political turmoil.
Elections for Parliament on Sunday could end nearly four decades of rule by the Liberal Democratic Party and set Japan on the road to a two-party system, or to a period of unstable rule by coalitions. Japan's industrial prowess and its relations with the United States could be affected. 
 People from different walks of life, ranging from a farmer to a literature professor, were asked in interviews what they thought would happen in Japanese politics, what changes they would like to see and how they thought the outcome of the elections would affect their lives.
Many common themes run through their comments: a revulsion against corrupt politicians, a skepticism that real change will occur and a sense that the public is still powerless.
Despite the disgust with the Liberal Democrats, however, there is also a measure of comfort with the party that presided over Japan's post-war economic miracle.
Here are excerpts from their remarks.
 
Yoko Tomiyama
Chairwoman, Consumers Union of Japan; 60, of Tokyo
 From my point of view, the entire political movement seems to be lacking any debate over policies. The only debate is over whether or not they will pursue political reform, and even there it's not clear what kind of political reform they are talking about. There aren't any policy debates on what everyday life should be, on peace, on the environment.
This is a chance for us consumers and voters to generate our own policies and politics. We should not just follow the people in power. Among activists, it seems like the changes are giving us more energy. But among the general public, we don't see much rise in interest in changing politics toward the consumer cause.
Most people basically are hoping for political reform, but they seem at a loss as to how to show it through their own actions. Some people are apathetic. Some people think that even if you do something, nothing will change.
 
Yoichi Aonuma
Rice farmer, 37, of Furukawa
 The current situation is a discharge of the pus that has accumulated gradually through one-party rule of the Liberal Democratic Party. The party itself became so gigantic and hard to understand by outsiders. It started to lie to people.
As for the Renaissance Party, now in the center of the hurricane, I'm skeptical. Mr. Ozawa [Ichiro Ozawa, the party's strategist] was the person who was in the center of the money politics. Even though they keep saying, "We are reformers, we are reformers," I think their main purpose is to take over political power.
I think the L.D.P. can change because there are politicians inside the L.D.P. who are thinking of reform. In a way it has already changed. Their character was that the big bosses ruled the party. Now that situation has changed.
I'm not worried that the rice market will be opened. The second-largest party, the Japan Socialist Party, has a policy to raise the self-sufficiency ratio of food. The parties that have been most helpful in taking on our requests have been the Socialists and the Communists. The L.D.P. raised its support of farmers' causes only when they wanted our votes.
 
Minoru Makihara
President, Mitsubishi Corporation; 63, of Tokyo

The political turmoil now is probably inescapable in the process of realizing political reform, which I think is essential for the future of Japan. I hope the result will be a system where the electorate is given clear alternatives. On the other hand, if the political scene remains confused, it will affect the confidence of the customers and market, and will not be good for companies like ourselves.
In times when political leadership is weak, the bureaucrats may make up for this lack of leadership. However, in this process they may entrench themselves in their own domains, which will not be good.
For example, in negotiations with the United States, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry and the Ministry of Finance may have differing priorities. In such cases, what we need is a clear political vision.
Several of the new opposition leaders are quite responsible people. They are advocating decentralization and deregulation, and I respect what they are trying to do.
 
Keiji Odashima
Owner of eyeglasses store; 46, of Kamaishi

The news media in Tokyo criticize the entire Liberal Democratic Party with a single broad stroke. But for us, it's not that simple.
I'm running a small business and it depends heavily on shoppers. The renovation of the shopping area was heavily supported by the Liberal Democratic Party. The L.D.P. in the prefectural assembly gave us the budget to put in a large new parking lot and to pay for tile to cover the sidewalk.
Still, I cannot forgive them for what they did in these corruption cases. The L.D.P. was really arrogant with power. The pus has poured out. As for the Hata group's members [the Renaissance Party], who claim they are reformers, when you think about what they did in the past, they were swimming in the mainstream of the money politics. People like me cannot simply accept their explanations.
I was watching a morning talk show on TV the other day. All the party members were talking only about themselves. I was disappointed with all the incumbents. They are far from the ordinary people in their feelings. It may be almost impossible to change.
 
Hiro Kawamoto
Research manager, electronics company; 55, of Nara

I was not interested in politics until now. To be honest with you, I didn't vote often, but when I would, I voted to make the balance better. I think this is a great opportunity for Japan to move to a two-party system like the United States, with each party checking the other. I thought it was a great system when I was in the States.
You have the Democrats and the Republicans, but from the outside the difference between them is small. In order to make that system operate, the policies of the two parties should not be that different. We businessmen do not want the policies to change drastically every few years. That's really crazy.
As for the scandals, you get sick of them. You don't want to talk about it. The Liberal Democratic Party has been guiding Japan for the last 40 years. They did a lot of crummy things, but I guess they were 60 to 70 percent right in guiding industrial development.
 
Kojin Karatani
Professor of literature, Hosei University; 51, of Tokyo

What's going on in Japan is not unique to Japan. The situation in Italy is similar, for example. All this is caused by the collapse of the cold war. The former regime was justified by anti-Communism and everything was passed under the pretext of anti-Communism. But now Communism does not exist as an effective force.
At present what's happening is a collapse from within the Liberal Democratic Party. It's not people's anger that caused it. But still, this situation might make people think that the system is changeable. Until now, they have been too used to the system.
There will be more and more small parties. They will all be shuffled again. What the new combination will be like is unpredictable. It depends on human elements.
 
Takashi Hashimoto
Student, international relations, Sophia University; 23, of Tokyo

When the L.D.P. split, I expected something drastic might happen. But now I'm rather disappointed and I wonder if anything will change. I was most disappointed by the Japan Socialist Party. This is the time people's expectations of the party as an alternative are high. But they never offered policies of their own, so I didn't vote for them in the municipal elections.
The biggest problem is the close ties between the politicians and businessmen. At the same time, that is the source of Japan's success. So I guess it's difficult for Japan to abandon that quickly and evolve into a free market system. I'm not from a farm household so I feel some kind of compromise is necessary on trade.
The best thing we can expect is to have two firm, stable parties that can offer us a choice of policies.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Producer prices fell three-tenths of 1 percent in June, the biggest monthly decline in more than two years. The decrease probably means the Fed will not raise interest rates soon to combat inflation, which had surged early in the year. [Page D1.]
The economic impact of the Mississippi flood is likely to be small. Although shipments of many products have been interrupted, most obstacles have been overcome or bypassed. [A17.] 
 Community-development loan funds have helped bring about a resurrection in a Camden, N.J., neighborhood, which has 300 vacant houses, few jobs and no banks to lend money. [D1.]
The nominee to head the S.E.C., Arthur Levitt Jr., wants to hire 170 inspectors to strengthen oversight of investment advisers. [D2.]
Washington officials began planning for the final push they hope will lead to enactment of the President's budget. [A15.]
 
Companies
First Boston's president and chief executive Archibald Cox Jr. resigned effective Sept. 1. John M. Hennessey, chief executive of CS First Boston, the firm's parent, will assume Mr. Cox's responsibilities. The move was said to reflect continuing turmoil at the firm caused by a push for increased profitability. [D1.]
Bear Stearns's president, James E. Cayne, will succeed Alan C. (Ace) Greenberg as chief executive. Analysts said Mr. Cayne will take over a larger portion of the firm but that Mr. Greenberg, who continues as chairman, will remain the final authority. [D1.]
General Motors will raise 1994 prices for its cars and trucks, but more optional equipment will become standard and be included in the base prices of the vehicles. [D4.]
T.W.A. named Piedmont's former head to be its chairman, as expected. The airline also said it expected to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection sometime before late August. [D4.]
Legent shares lost more than a third of their value after the software developer projected disappointing earnings. [D4.]
A shirt button made of sand transformed into zirconia can resist cracking, chipping and shattering from laundering. [D4.]
Merrill Lynch and Paine Webber, the two biggest public brokerage houses, reported strong second-quarter earnings. [D18.]
Sugar and farming companies agreed to a $465 million government plan to help clean up the Everglades. [A12.]
 
International
The North American Free Trade Agreement's budget cost is a focus of debate, and the Administration and Congress are seeking ways to get business and local government to pay the bill. [D2.]
 
Business Technology
Baxter International's at-home kidney dialysis machine is being praised by physicians and analysts as a design breakthrough that could free thousands of patients from dialysis centers by letting them cleanse their systems at home while they sleep. [D5.]
A.T.& T. announced a "major breakthrough" in sound quality for long-distance calls: more volume and more bass. [D5.]
 
Markets
The Dow Jones industrials slipped for the first time in five sessions, giving up 8.94 points, to close at 3,515.44. [D6.]
New York, New Jersey and Connecticut do not fare well in a new analysis of mortgage default rates. [D14.]
The dollar fell against the yen and most other currencies. Gold declined. [D16.] Coffee prices jumped to a six-month high. [D16.]

HEADLINE: THE MIDWEST FLOODING: Effects on Business;
U.S. Economy Too Vast To Be Hurt by Flooding

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
For all the spectacular devastation of the Mississippi flood of 1993, the impact on the huge American economy is likely to be very small, many experts say.
While the flood has threatened to interrupt shipments of food, chemicals, cars and other products, nearly every obstacle has so far been overcome or bypassed -- avoiding the damage that might have resulted from grain shortages or interrupted shipments from Midwestern factories. 
 When the floods washed away a railroad bridge across the Mississippi at East Hardin, Mo., cutting the Santa Fe's main line from Chicago to Southern California, trains were rerouted along another railroad's tracks to cross the river below St. Louis. When the water covered the tracks used by the Monsanto Chemical Company to ship herbicides from its plant in Muscatine, Iowa, the herbicide went by truck for two days, while new ties and track were laid on top of the old ones, bringing the rail line back above water.
And while 3,000 barges are stuck on the upper Mississippi and Illinois Rivers, the grain in them is mostly for export and not immediately needed, said Keith Collins, director of economic analysis at the Agriculture Department. Elevators in New Orleans, at the mouth of the Mississippi, currently hold enough grain to satisfy export orders, so the stuck barges are for the moment serving as warehouses for millions of tons of grain.
 
All Disruptions Local
 "There are all kinds of little disruptions and stress to the nation's economic system, and certainly Des Moines has a huge problem," said Robert Schnorbus, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago. "But nothing is shutting down in America beyond the actual flood area."
Federal officials are estimating damages at $2 billion to $3 billion, mostly in lost crops. That is far below the $18 billion in devastation from Hurricane Andrew last year.
There are many examples of a national economy largely untouched by record flooding that has brought hardship to the upper Mississippi Valley.
Five leading railroads, for example, have miles of track under water. "It could cost us $300,000 a mile to repair damaged track," said Frank Wilner, a spokesman for the Association of American Railroads. But by rerouting traffic over each other's track, the railroads have managed to maintain shipments, with 24-hour delays at most, Mr. Wilner said.
Similarly, the Olympic Marine Company, which operates 64 barges on the Mississippi, Missouri, Illinois and Ohio Rivers, mostly taking grain to New Orleans, found itself with 11 barges stuck on the Illinois, reducing the company's revenue from barge fees.
 
Thousands of Barges Stuck
 "I would estimate that one-third of the 9,000 barges carrying dry cargo on the rivers are stuck, unable to move on the flooded rivers," said Donald G. Leeker, Olympic's president. "What that means is that barge rates are higher and we are restricted to the Ohio. Nevertheless, the demand for barge equipment is meeting the supply of barges, and you can see this equilibrium in the falling grain prices this week."
As the flooding grew worse, prices of corn and soybeans, the principal grains in the northern Midwest, rose sharply, in anticipation of shortages, not only from transportation disruptions but also from widespread crop destruction. The Agriculture Department quieted some of this concern on Monday by issuing a new harvest estimate, one that lowered the harvests by a relatively mild 7.6 percent for corn and 3.5 percent for soybeans.
Some grain traders had predicted greater losses and a slight rise in the nation's inflation rate from shortages of corn and soybean used mainly as cattle feed and to make vegetable oils and sweeteners. But the Agriculture Department insisted that grain in storage from last year's record harvests would be more than enough to make up the shortfall -- although individual farmers with fields under water might lose a year's income.
 
'Too Small to Notice'
 "The effect of the crop loss on the consumer price index will be too small to notice," Mr. Collins said. He estimated that the loss might be close to $2 billion, part of it covered by Federal insurance. An additional $1 billion or so might be lost in damage to property other than crops, the Federal Emergency Management Agency says. But this is a very initial estimate of the impact on the states most affected by the floods: Wisconsin, Missouri, Minnesota, Iowa, Illinois and South Dakota.
Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said her office would wait a few more days to get a better sense of the damage before trying, through computer simulations, to determine the flood's economic impact. But most economists, comparing the flood with Hurricane Andrew, see a vast difference. While thousands of homes and commercial buildings had to be rebuilt after Andrew, the main flood loss is likely to be crops.
"They are going to be replanted anyway next year," said Lawrence J. Meyer, a St. Louis economics consultant. After Andrew, rebuilding the homes and buildings created thousands of jobs and contributed, economists say, to the surge in the nation's economic activity in the fourth quarter last year.


GRAPHIC: Twenty-four people have died because of the flooding in Illinois, Iowa, Minnesota, Missouri, South Dakota and Wisconsin. HEADLINE: A Look at the North American Pact's Added Costs

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13

 BODY:
As the Clinton Administration and Congress grapple with the political problems of the North American Free Trade Agreement this summer, one issue keeps coming up: the potential cost of the pact to the Federal budget.
Estimates range up to $40 billion in lost tariff revenue, benefits for American workers who are unemployed as a result of new competition from Mexican factories, and bridges and highways to carry additional traffic. 
 Congressional pay-as-you-go budget rules require that such revenue be made up. This has produced an increasingly desperate search in Washington for ways other than Federal taxes to raise money. The Administration and Congress are looking for as much of this money as possible from state, local and private sources.
 
One of Several Estimates
 In the Administration's first public discussion of some of the costs of the agreement, Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown said today that $15 billion to $20 billion would be needed over the next decade for roads, bridges, sewage-treatment centers, improved housing, electric-power plants and environmental cleanup projects along the Mexican border.
But he also said that the Administration expected business to provide most of that money, spurred by potential earnings from tolls and fees from the sewage and power facilities.
On Thursday and Friday, Mr. Brown said, Clinton Cabinet members will try to drum up commercial interest at a meeting in San Antonio with Mexican Cabinet ministers and with about 400 investment bankers, engineers and state officials.
The Secretary said that private companies had ignored the potential in border investments for many years and are now recognizing it because of the proposed North American pact.
Others, though, questioned some of Mr. Brown's assumptions, including the idea that industry would step forward to provide services often supplied by the Government.
"If they're going to try to do this on the cheap, my vote counts and everyone else's vote counts show they come up short," said Charles Kamasaki a vice president of the National Council of La Raza, a Hispanic advocacy group that supports the trade pact.
After several months of work, the Congressional Budget Office this week released a detailed analysis of the accord's prospective costs. It estimated a loss of $2 billion to $3 billion in tariff revenue over five years.
The pact would also result in extra spending on worker retraining, on agricultural programs and on transportation and environmental programs on the border, the budget office said. It provided few specific figures.
 
Inter-American Bank's Offer
 Another source of help is the Inter-American Development Bank, an institution like the World Bank, which seeks to help poor Western Hemisphere nations. It has quietly offered to create a $10 billion fund for project loans. The Federal Government would be required to contribute only $250 million of this, and the rest would be raised through bond issues, an international financial official with a detailed knowledge of the plan said.
Representative Esteban Torres, Democrat of California, said today that he plans to introduce legislation this week to create a North American Development Bank. The bank would be set up with $1 billion in Federal money and would issue $5 billion in bonds to pay for transportation, environmental and community-development projects anywhere in North America, not just in border states.
Creation of that bank is the idea of Raul A. Hinojosa-Ojeda, an assistant professor of planning at the University of California at Los Angeles. Mr. Hinojosa-Ojeda has strong political ties in Washington and Mexico City, and this, combined with his connections with national Hispanic groups, have gained attention for his idea in the Administration and Congress.
Mr. Kamasaki said his group supported the new bank partly because its proposed charter would provide for extensive consultation with local businesses and residents.
 
Diluting Opposition
 By making loans across the nation to communities struggling to cope with international competition, the bank could also lessen opposition to the trade agreement from members of Congress who feel that border states will be the main beneficiaries.
Representative Robert T. Matsui, a California Democrat who is organizing House support for the trade pact, said Congressional interest in the new bank was growing. But he said that a small tax on trade across the border might also be necessary.
Corporations bitterly oppose such a tax, arguing that it would undo part of the benefit of tariff reductions. Mr. Matsui said that a tax could be set as low as one-quarter of 1 percent.
Current United States tariffs on Mexican-produced goods average 4 percent, although a few items, like table glassware, face tariffs up to 30 percent.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Free Trade: The Costs . . ."
 
LOWER TARIFF REVENUES: Estimated by the Congressional Budget Office at $2 billion to $3 billion over five years.
 
RETRAINING OF WORKERS WHO LOSE THEIR JOBS: Predicted by the Clinton Administration to exceed the $1.68 billion over five years that had been estimated by the Bush Administration.
 
EXTRA BORDER BRIDGES, HIGHWAYS AND SEWAGE TREATMENT: Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown said today that it would cost $15 billion to $20 billion over the next decade.
 
EXTRA CUSTOMS INSPECTORS: Some in Congress want more staff members to prevent drug trafficking and other smuggling.
 
EXTRA SPENDING ON AGRICULTURAL PROGRAMS: Price supports and export-finance programs would rise slightly, according to the Congressional Budget Office.
 
". . . and the Potential Revenue Sources"
 
INTERNATIONAL BORDER AND WATER COMMISSION: This Mexican-American commision - whose limited authority along the border includes controlling the salinity of the Rio Grande, approving new bridges and maintaining boundary buoys - could issue bonds to pay for bridges.
 
NORTH AMERICAN DEVELOPMENT BANK: A new institution, backed by taxpayer money from Canada, Mexico and the United States, would issue bonds to pay for projects anywhere in North America.
 
INTER-AMERICAN DEVELOPMENT BANK: An existing lending institutions jointly controlled by Western Hemisphere governments. The bank's management has offered to create a $10 billion fund. Only $250 million in Federal money would be needed, and the rest could be borrowed using the bank's AAA credit rating.
 
FLAT TAX ON CROSS-BORDER TRADE IN GOODS AND SERVICES: Critics of the proposal by Senator Max S. Baucus and the House majority leader, Representative Richard A. Gephardt, say that it would merely replace tariffs with taxes.

HEADLINE: S.E.C. Nominee Would Scrutinize Advisers

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13

 BODY:
Arthur Levitt Jr., President Clinton's nominee for chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that he wanted to hire 170 inspectors to strengthen oversight of the increasing number of investment advisers.
Mr. Levitt said the number of such advisers had risen to 18,000 from about 5,000 five years ago. 
 "We are now inspecting these investment managers once every 30 years. That is no inspection," he told the Senate Banking Committee during confirmation hearings.
 
Better Way to Meet Expenses?
 Mr. Levitt also proposed that the S.E.C. keep all the money it raised from filing fees to pay for its operations. The agency currently hands over extra fee income to the Treasury.
He said self-financing would be a more effective way for the commission to regulate the financial-services industry. "An S.E.C. which is understaffed," he said, "is one that can seriously impair our capital markets, which would do more to damage our economic situation than anything else I can think of."
Mr. Levitt, a former brokerage executive, the former chairman of the American Stock Exchange and the son of Arthur Levitt, New York State Comptroller from 1955 to 1979, won bipartisan support today and is expected to be quickly confirmed.
He promised the senators to look closely at a proposal by the Financial Accounting Standards Board to require companies to deduct the value of stock options from their earnings. Several senators expressed concern that the proposal would harm emerging companies that rely on stock options to increase the compensation of their executives.
Mr. Levitt acknowledged that he was apprehensive about trying to solve accounting problems by legislation.
 
Sidestepping a Turf Battle
 Pressed for his views on merging the Commodity Futures Trading Commission with the S.E.C., a controversial matter on which opinion tends to divide between more conservative Easterners and free market-oriented Chicago traders, Mr. Levitt tried to finesse the question. He said that talk of an agency merger "has been like merging Israel and Syria."
A priority as S.E.C. chairman, he added, would be regular planning sessions with the Commodity Futures Commission, the Treasury Department, the Federal Reserve Board and the Federal Comptroller of the Currency on how the agencies might coordinate market regulation and respond to a financial crisis.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Mortgage Risk Great in 3 States

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
New York, New Jersey and Connecticut do not fare well in a new analysis of mortgage default rates. The three states are projected to have among the highest default rates over the next five years.
The analysis, done by Fitch Investors Service Inc., the credit rating firm, divides the country into 43 regions and uses a set of economic indicators -- unemployment rates, personal income growth, housing starts, existing home sales, industry diversification and population growth -- to project future default rates. 
 The projections provide Fitch and its customers with a yardstick to measure the risks associated with mortgage-backed securities that have credit ratings at the bottom of the investment-grade category (triple B and single A) and those below investment grade (single B and double B).
 
 
Mortgage-Backed Securities
 "Investors must be concerned with the regional makeup of mortgage-backed securities, especially when moving down the scale" of credit ratings, said James D. Nadler, a managing director at Fitch.
In the rankings, which will be updated each quarter, New Jersey and New York State are divided into several regions.
New Jersey, excluding Essex, Bergen and Passaic counties, has the highest projected default rate, 1.70 percent, of all residential mortgages outstanding. Connecticut is second at 1.46 percent, followed by Essex, Bergen and Passaic at 1.43 percent and metropolitan New York at 1.30 percent.
New York State, excluding several regions, is sixth with a rate of 1.24 percent, followed by Albany with a rate of 1.09 percent; Nassau and Suffolk counties are ninth with a rate of 1.02 percent. New York City is 10th with a rate of 0.99 percent.
 
 
National Average: 0.74%
 The rates are higher than the projected national average of 0.74 percent.
The region with the lowest default rate is Washington State, at 0.23 percent.
But Gregory G. Raab, an analyst at Fitch, said he expected that Washington's rate would rise sharply as the current economic conditions in the model were revised over the next several quarters.
He said the data in the projections were through the end of 1992, so they did not reflect more recent layoffs at the Boeing Company, which is based in Seattle. "There is not enough negative data in Washington yet," he said.
 
Treasury Market
 It appeared that investors and traders had done all their buying ahead of yesterday's release of the Producer Price Index for June. Prices fell by three-tenths of 1 percent, meeting analysts' expectations.
This meant there was little reaction to the report yesterday. The price of the 30-year bond edged up 4/32 , which dropped the yield from 6.62 percent on Monday to 6.61 percent, yet another low for the 16 years since the Treasury began to issue 30-year bonds regularly. But prices of Treasury notes fell slightly, while the discount rates on Treasury bills rose.
Many investors sat on the sidelines yesterday, waiting for the Government to release today its reports on consumer prices and retail sales for June, analysts said.
And there were signs that investors, in the corporate market at least, were still not very willing to make long-term investments despite the good news on inflation. Instead, money still seems to be flowing into shorter-term issues.
 For example, the Tennessee Valley Authority sold $150 million in two-year notes yesterday at a yield that matched the yield on current two-year Treasury notes.
William F. Malec, the chief financial officer of the authority, said that this was the first time a T.V.A. issue had a yield as low as a Treasury security since the authority re-entered the public debt market in 1989.
Although the T.V.A. is considered by investors to be a quasi-governmental agency, there has been a spread between the yield on its bonds and Treasury securities, which are believed to be the better credit.
Mr. Malec said that the low yield of 3.995 percent was a reflection "of our strength." But he also acknowledged that it showed there were many investors with cash who still do not want to risk it in longer-term securities.
The T.V.A. issue, which was a competitive bid, was won by the First Boston Corporation.

HEADLINE: With Congress Back in Town, Supporters of Budget Bill Gear Up

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13

 BODY:
With Congress back from a 10-day recess and most Administration officials home from the economic summit in Tokyo, the Government's top policy makers began planning today for the final burst of energy that they hope will lead to enactment of the President's budget.
At the White House, officials said a special office they call "the boiler room" was being set up under the direction of Deputy Treasury Secretary Roger Altman to coordinate the lobbying and public relations tactics for the deficit-reduction legislation. 
 In the Senate, George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Democratic leader, said he would set aside lunchtime Thursdays for the rest of the summer for special strategy sessions on the budget measure that is now before a conference committee.
In the House, Democratic leaders began counting votes and twisting the arms of potential defectors on the final vote and called a caucus meeting Wednesday of all Democratic representatives to drum up support for the budget.
 
Presidency to Be Tested
 The legislation would set the Government's tax and spending policy for the next five years. The prospects, officials agree, are touch and go, and Bill Clinton's ultimate success or failure as President may be in the balance.
A defeat, said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, who will be the chief Senate conferee on tax matters, would cause the Clinton Presidency to "close down."
A House-Senate conference committee is scheduled to begin work Thursday to resolve the differences between budget measures passed by the House in May and the Senate in June. The conference is expected to take at least two weeks, with a final vote likely the first week in August.
The two bills were approved by the narrowest of margins -- 219 to 213 in the House and 50 to 49 in the Senate with Vice President Al Gore voting to break a tie. No Republican voted for the measure.
The bills are similar in most important respects. They would lower the deficit by a total of about $500 billion over the next five years, mainly by raising the taxes of wealthy individuals and corporations, by reducing military spending and by limiting the growth in spending for Medicare.
 
Tough Talks on Energy Tax
 But delicate negotiations will be needed to resolve the differences over energy taxes and spending on social programs. With no Republican support whatsoever, a shift of three Democrats in the House or one in the Senate would be enough to kill the whole budget and, in the view of many politicians, render President Clinton politically ineffective for the rest of his term.
"The future of the Democratic Party and the future of the Congress as an institution are at stake," said Representative Bill Richardson of New Mexico, a chief deputy Democratic whip, who is working almost full time on the budget.
So how did he think it would turn out? Mr. Richardson was asked.
"It will pass, but it will be a huge battle, one that we are already working on," he replied.
And how were they working on it?
"By working on members and by praying," he said.
Mr. Richardson, whose special responsibility in the Democratic leadership is keeping tabs on lawmakers from the Western states, said that about 50 Democratic Representatives cannot be relied on to vote in favor of the budget. With all Republicans voting "no," the measure will fail in the House if more than about 40 Democrats vote against it.
The most important difference between the Senate and the House bills involves energy taxes. The House approved a broad tax on most forms of fuels that would generate $72 billion in new revenue over five years. The Senate bill would merely increase the Federal tax on gasoline and diesel fuel by 4.3 cents a gallon, raising only $23 billion over five years.
An Administration official said one compromise under consideration would be to add to the Senate's gasoline and diesel tax a new tax on utility bills and home heating oil.
 
Levy on Middle Class
 But the energy tax is essentially the only new levy in either bill that would affect families of modest means, and a coalition of liberal and conservative Democratic representatives would like to scrap it altogether and make up the lost revenue somewhere else, perhaps with a bigger increase in the corporate income tax rate. Both bills would lift the corporate rate to 35 percent of profits from 34 percent.
A leader in this coalition, Representative David R. Obey of Wisconsin, said the energy tax had become "a political nuisance getting in the way of Clinton's message."
It allowed Republicans, he said, to argue that Mr. Clinton was raising the taxes of the middle class, thus jeopardizing the entire program. On the other hand, Mr. Obey said, taxing rich people and corporations "has always been a unifying force in the Democratic Party."
But the White House and Congressional leaders believe that to raise the taxes on the wealthy and on corporations even higher would be bad economic policy.
Taxpayers with incomes of more than $200,000 would have their taxes raised by 18.6 percent under the Senate bill and 17.2 percent under the House bill. Those with incomes below $20,000, or even $30,000 in some instances, would get a tax cut, and few taxpayers with incomes below $200,000 would have their taxes raised by more than about 2 percent.
 
Misperceptions in Districts
 Lawmakers who spent the Fourth of July recess at home said many of their middle-income constituents were under the misperception that they would be hit by much higher taxes.
The Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley of Washington, accused Republicans of misrepresentation and said the President and Democrats in Congress needed to work harder to set the record straight.
Senator Max Baucus of Montana made a similar point. "This program has to be better sold, better explained," he said,
Some lawmakers said the solution might be to drop the energy tax and simply lower the sights for deficit reduction below $500 billion over five years.
"Nobody back home is saying, guys, it's got to be $500 billion, not $400 billion," said Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana. But few others agreed with Mr. Breaux, and at least for now, the $500 billion figure seemed to be a magic one.
"I don't believe in starting to erode the target," Mr. Foley said.
After a session this afternoon with some wavering Democratic representatives, Leon E. Panetta, Mr. Clinton's budget director, said it was important to keep the $500 billion target.
"Once you start moving away from that," Mr. Panetta said, "you're in danger of getting on a slippery slope."

HEADLINE: Renovations Set for Area Near Yankee Stadium

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
New York City is planning to renovate the Bronx Terminal Market, a hulking collection of warehouses and stores just south of Yankee Stadium, officials said yesterday.
City officials said the plan, which is to be announced at City Hall today, was an effort to reverse the blight in the neighborhood around the ballpark. But it could also provide additional parking space for the stadium, according to one City Hall official. 
 The announcement comes as both the Mayor and the Governor are mounting campaigns to save the Yankees for the city. The Yankees lease on the stadium expires in 2002 and in recent weeks, the team's owner, George M. Steinbrenner 3d, has again discussed the possibility of abandoning the city, citing falling attendance and concerns over safety and parking in the area.
Mayor David N. Dinkins has pledged to do all he can to prevent the team from leaving the Bronx. At the same time, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has been floating a plan to build a new stadium atop a rail yard on Manhattan's West Side. The Governor and Mr. Steinbrenner met in recent weeks to discuss the idea. The Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer, insisted that the plan for the market was not directly linked to the city's efforts to keep the Yankees in the Bronx. But he added that it would address Mr. Steinbrenner's concerns about improving the public perception of the South Bronx streets that surround the stadium.
"I presume the Yankees will not be unhappy we're finally dealing with the blight right next door," he said.
The announcement is planned for midday at City Hall, where Mr. Dinkins will join Mr. Ferrer.
"I applaud the Mayor in his boldness in asserting leadership and preserving the economic viability of the market and the Bronx," Mr. Ferrer said.
In order to renovate the market, the city would terminate the lease of the private company that runs the market.
 
Dispute With Leaseholder
 Through the Economic Development Corporation, the city has leased the market to the Arol Development Corporation through the year 2052 and has been entangled in litigation in recent years concerning repairs and rent. Structural problems with a viaduct that runs through the market led to its closing for safety reasons, as has been the case with a large warehouse on the edge of the property.
Borough officals said the area, with its dim and littered streets, has become a magnet for prostitutes and drug dealers, and that a procession of tenants have left for other locations.
"If we do not intervene now it will continue to decline and will eventually be a ghost town," Mr. Ferrer said. He said the plan called for the city's taking responsibility for the property, making improvements on some buildings and demolishing others, with the aim of establishing a co-operative market among the merchants. The market houses some two dozen merchants, mostly food wholesalers that supply bodegas and small supermarkets.
Officials at Arol Development said yesterday afternoon they were unaware of the city's decision, adding that they have tried without success to work with city officals on resolving the problems.
 
Part of Development Plan
 "They can't decide on our future without bringing us into the picture," said Gabriel Buntzman, a vice president of Arol Developoment.
He insisted that his company has met the lease conditions, which in his interpretation placed responsibility for repairs with the city. He said the city was responsible for driving some merchants from the market by closing off some of the ramps that lead to and from the market.
Mr. Ferrer said he has been calling for major changes at the market for the past six years, and criticized Arol Development for "milking" the site while allowing it to deteriorate.
He noted the plans for the market are in keeping with the proposals for the Bronx Center, an ambitious development scheme aimed at revitalizing a 300-block area of the South Bronx with new governmental, housing and commercial construction.
Those plans have touched on the topic of additional parking for the Yankees, including the possibility of a 3,000 car garage on the Harlem River. He insisted that the market plans were not explicitly part of any plan for providing parking.
"This is an announcement aimed at improving the market and the economic viability of the market," he said. "Anything that causes the market to rebound should improve the atmosphere around the Yankees."
 
'Why the Rush Now?'
 Several people familiar with planning for the area said that while nothing explicit has been mentioned about providing parking for the ballclub at the site of the market, it would be a logical choice, considering that the problems surrounding the market are long-standing.
"I would imagine they're tying it in," one source said, speaking on condition of anonymity. "This has been going on forever, so why the rush now?"
Ellen Baer, chief of staff to First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel, who has been coordinating the city's efforts to improve attendance at Yankee Stadium, said that during a meeting of city officals last week to discuss possible parking sites, the market and a city park across the street from the stadium were mentioned among other sites. She added that the discussions were in the early stages.
Howard J. Rubenstein, a spokesman for Mr. Steinbrenner, said he had not heard about any specific parking proposal. He said Mr. Steinbrenner was pleased that the city was making an effort to come up with the 1,000 additional parking spaces that are part of its agreement with the the ball team.
"However, he wants to see exactly what the proposal is before he says anything further," Mr. Rubenstein added. "Adequate parking was supposed to be forthcoming for quite a long time and wasn't. He has some cautious optimism about the city fulfilling its longstanding obligation."

HEADLINE: First Charges Are Brought In Inquiries Into Deaths

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., July 13

 BODY:
Joel Rifkin, the unemployed landscaper who the police say has confessed to killing 17 women, was indicted today on charges of murdering a 22-year-old Manhattan woman whose body was found here on June 28 in the back of his pickup truck.
In the first formal accusation to arise from investigations in several jurisdictions, a Nassau County grand jury indicted the 34-year-old East Meadow man on two counts of second-degree murder in the death of Tiffany Bresciani. Mr. Rifkin was also indicted on a charge of reckless endangerment for leading state troopers on a high-speed chase before crashing his pickup on a Mineola street, officials said. 
 Nassau County prosecutors said the two murder counts for one victim were intended to deal with different theories of Miss Bresciani's death. One count charges Mr. Rifkin with intentional murder, while the other charges that the crime was committed with "depraved indifference to human life." The trial jury will be asked to consider both.
Mr. Rifkin, who is being held without bail in the Nassau County Jail, faces a maximum prison sentence of 25 years to life if convicted on either charge, said Denis E. Dillon, the Nassau County District Attorney.
 
Plea of Not Guilty Planned
 Robert Sale, Mr. Rifkin's lawyer, said his client would plead not guilty to the charges at his arraignment on Thursday. He added that he had no plans to seek bail for Mr. Rifkin, because it would be "an exercise in futility."
Officials in some other jurisdictions where bodies have been linked to Mr. Rifkin said today that they would probably wait to see how the Nassau County case progressed before presenting their cases to grand juries.
The discovery of Miss Bresciani's body led to Mr. Rifkin's arrest and his confession to 16 other killings, the police say. Based on information developed since then, the authorities now believe that Mr. Rifkin killed 18 women in the New York City region over the last three years.
The police have so far identified 10 women, either through Mr. Rifkin's confession or through evidence found at his home or in his pickup truck. The bodies of four others have not been identified, and a further four bodies have yet to be found.
Besides Miss Bresciani, bodies linked to Mr. Rifkin have been discovered in New York City, and in Suffolk, Westchester, Orange and Putnam Counties.
 
Dogs Used in Search
 Today, for at least the second time, the state police used dogs to search an area of West Nyack in Rockland County, where the police say Mr. Rifkin told them he had dumped a body. No body was found, said Capt. Arthur Hawker of the State Police Troop F in Middletown.
The authorities say they believe that Mr. Rifkin picked up Miss Bresciani on a Manhattan street sometime around June 24 and was on his way to dispose of her body four days later when troopers attempted to stop him for driving without a license plate. An autopsy showed that Miss Bresciani died of asphyxia, Nassau County officials said.
In announcing the indictments at a news conference here, Mr. Dillon declined to discuss any of the specifics of the case. He said, however, that Nassau County's investigation probably progressed faster than those in other places because Miss Bresciani's body was the first to be linked to Mr. Rifkin.
In New York City, officials said their cases were still in the investigatory stage. "We intend to prosecute those cases in which we have jurisdiction," said Barbara Thompson, a spokeswoman for the Manhattan District Attorney's office.
Kevin L. Wright, the District Attorney in Putnam County, where the body of Ana Lopez was found, said that there was no need to rush the investigation in his county because "Rifkin isn't going anywhere."
"I believe we're going to await the results of the admissibility of the statements in Nassau, the admissibility of the physical evidence in Nassau, and to see what kind of defense he puts on," Mr. Wright said. "Then we'll basically have a clear picture of everything that he's got to present in the case."

HEADLINE: Dow Drops 8.94, for First Loss in 5 Sessions

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET

 BODY:
Despite the support of low inflation figures, the stock market slipped yesterday for the first time in five sessions. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 8.94 points to close at 3,515.44.
The Government reported that the Producer Price Index for June fell by three-tenths of 1 percent. But leading market indicators were mixed, as investors continued their anxious vigil for some clear sign of where to put their money. As they wait, they are becoming more finicky about equities, said Robert Freedman, chief investment officer of John Hancock Mutual Funds. 
 "Rather than a stock market, it's a market of stocks, where individual stocks which have good earnings are performing very well," he said. "It's a continued rotational market on a stock-by-stock basis."
In such a market, weak performers are swiftly punished. Yesterday, Procter & Gamble helped lead the decliners among blue chips, after the company announced that it would cut prices by as much as 15 percent on some cleaning and laundry products. Shares of P.& G. fell 1 1/2, to 51 1/2.
Sometimes, jumpy investors jump too fast. That was the case with Martin Marietta yesterday, analysts said. On no discernible news, its shares dropped 2 1/4, to 79 3/4.
"What I heard was speculation in the marketplace that they weren't going to have a good second quarter," said Peter L. Aseritis, aerospace and military electronics analyst at First Boston.
Mr. Aseritis said such fears were misplaced, since, as he wrote in a recent report, the earnings pattern at the company is shifting. The second quarter will be weaker, he said, but later quarters will be stronger, producing the expected level of overall earnings.
Mr. Aseritis said that "I just sort of chuckled" on hearing that the share price was slipping. He added, "I said, 'Is the market that inefficient?' "
Among other leading market indicators, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks sank 0.89, to 448.09. The Nasdaq composite index gained 0.80, to 708.47, and the American Stock Exchange composite index picked up 1.01, to 439.11. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 237 million shares, up from 202 million on Monday.
Some oil stocks slipped yesterday, evidently over continued concern about the low price of crude. Chevron closed down 1/2 at 84 1/2; Mobil lost 3/4 to close at 70 7/8.
"In early June, it became apparent that the demand wasn't there to soak up as much as OPEC was producing," said P. Timothy Lohmann, an energy analyst for Duff & Phelps in Chicago. "It's affected all the oil stocks. They're all off their highs."
Possibly also in reponse to low oil prices, airline stocks rebounded a bit yesterday, driving the Dow transportation average up 8.82 points, to 1,504.54. UAL, the parent company of United Airlines, climbed 3 3/8, to 126 1/4. AMR, the parent of American, gained 1/2, to 61 1/2, while USAir rose 7/8, to 14 5/8.
"They've come down a lot during a period when oil prices are coming down," said Kevin C. Murphy, the airline analyst for Morgan Stanley. "This may be some sort of last-minute catch-up to the news about oil."
After a fattening-up that lasted several weeks, bank stocks fell victim to some profit taking yesterday. J. P. Morgan led the losers, dropping 1 3/8, to 71 3/8. That makes this the fifth quarter in a row in which investors sold off bank stocks after earnings were reported, said James Schmidt, portfolio manager of the John Hancock Freedom Regional Bank Fund.

HEADLINE: June Drop In Producer Price Index

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13

 BODY:
Held down by persistent weakness in economic growth, prices received by American producers fell by three-tenths of 1 percent in June, the biggest monthly decline in more than two years, the Labor Department reported today.
This was the second consecutive reading of the Producer Price Index to provide reassurance that large increases early in the year were an aberration and not the early stages of revived inflation, analysts said. The index was unchanged in May after a six-tenths of 1 percent rise in April. It had risen at a 4.7 percent annual rate in the first four months of the year. 
 Analysts expect similar good news in the report on the Consumer Price Index for June, which will be issued Wednesday.
Producer prices last month were well behaved at the intermediate and crude stages of production as well on the finished-goods level, indicating little price pressure either in the manufacturing pipeline or on goods ready for the final user.
 
 
Rate Increase Is Unlikely
 With such compelling evidence, the Federal Reserve was seen as likely to abandon any thought of raising interest rates to combat inflation in the foreseeable future despite Midwest flooding that is expected to push food prices higher.
"Concerns about accelerating inflation in the early part of the year were misplaced," said Lacy H. Hunt, chief economist for HSBC Holdings in New York, parent of Marine Midland Bank. "Business conditions are soft -- and getting softer."
A rise in rates would be a blow to the Clinton Administration, which lost a Congressional battle to pass an economic stimulus program and is counting on low rates to spur the economy. And higher rates could weaken Congressional support for the President's $500 billion deficit-reduction program on the ground that higher rates combined with the program's higher taxes could send the country back into recession.
The June price decline for finished goods was the first time since November that prices fell and was the biggest decline since March 1991, the month that marked the official end of the recession.
The costs of food and energy both fell, but even with these erratic categories excluded, prices edged down one-tenth of 1 percent. Tobacco was a significant contributor as the industry's much publicized price war finally began to show up in the statistics.
"There's absolutely no reason to be concerned about inflation," said Mark Vitner, an economist for the First Union Corporation in Charlotte, N.C. "The only place where you have pricing power at all is in cars," he added. The auto industry is exploiting the yen's rise against the dollar this year to both recapture domestic market share and to raise prices. A higher yen makes Japanese products more expensive in the United States.
Automobile prices jumped six-tenths of 1 percent in June, the second price surge in three months, today's report showed. But pharmaceuticals, fish and residential gas were about the only other items moving significantly higher.
Over the latest 12 months, inflation at the producer level is just 1.4 percent, lower than the 1.6 percent year-to-year reading at the end of 1992. The so-called core rate, without food and energy, has improved comparably, to 1.7 percent from 2 percent.
Food prices dropped nine-tenths of 1 percent in June as fresh fruits and melons tumbled 11.4 percent, more than reversing a May surge, while fresh vegetables plunged a record 37.9 percent.
Energy fell five-tenths of 1 percent, about the same as in May, as lower prices for gasoline, lubricants and home heating oil more than offset another hefty rise, 1.1 percent, for natural gas.
 
 
Tobacco and Drugs
 Elsewhere, the price changes were dominated by tobacco, which dropped 5.9 percent after substantial increases in April and May. But both prescription and over-the-the counter drugs, which had shown little change in May, posted sizable increases of 1.1 percent and 2.6 percent, respectively.
Prices of finished capital equipment rose two-tenths of 1 percent in June for the third consecutive month, today's report also showed.
Among intermediate goods, such as a bolt of cloth or sack of flour, prices climbed a modest two-tenths of 1 percent last month after a decline of that amount in May. Prices for energy and durable manufacturing materials, such as mill shapes, turned up while construction materials fell less than in May.
There were big increases for both commercial and industrial electric power, liquefied petroleum gas, copper and brass mill shapes and cold rolled steel sheet.
 
 
Plywood Prices Ease
 On the other hand, plywood eased a bit more following steep drops in April and May while prices turned down for semifinished steel mill products, hot rolled steel bars, silver and cold finished steel bars.
Nondurable manufacturing materials, such as plastic resins, rose two-tenths of 1 percent in June despite declines for basic organic chemicals, paint and processed yarns and threats.
Among crude goods, the overall 1.1 percent decline following two sharp increases was broadly based and reflected declines in crude petroleum, hay, cattle, broilers, fruits, shellfish, corn, fresh and dry vegetables, cotton, cattle hides, copper ores and the softwood logs, bolts and timber category.
However, hogs, leaf tobacco and construction sand and gravel increased, while the rise in iron and steel scrap accelerated to 8.7 percent.
"Inflation determinants still appear benign," economists at Merrill Lynch concluded today, predicting that a bumper wheat crop would help counter the effects of flooded Midwest corn and soybean fields to keep the impact on overall inflation "minimal."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Yen in Rebound as Traders Rethink the Trade Accord

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar fell against the Japanese yen yesterday amid speculation that the new trade framework between the United States and Japan was unlikely to weaken the yen.
Gold prices declined. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, the actively traded gold contract for August delivery slipped 40 cents, to $394.50 an ounce. A late quote from the Republic National Bank put spot gold at $393.50 an ounce, down 50 cents. 
 The dollar also gave up on a recent rally against the German mark and French franc, as doubts grew about a near-term cut in French and German interest rates, prompting widespread profit taking.
A further excuse to sell dollars came from a drop of three-tenths of a percent in United States producer prices in June. This reinforced the view that United States interest rates will stay low, limiting the yields and allure of dollar-based investments.
"The yen has come back in vogue," a bank dealer said. The Japanese currency rebounded as new developments chipped away at a trade framework forged over the weekend that had been hailed as a major breakthrough in slashing Japan's trade surplus with the United States.
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, sowed doubts when he called the framework "only a first step" toward a full agreement.
"The market is starting to look at this and say, What's different now than before?" said Jack Griffin, vice president at the Fuji Bank. "Are we back where we started? The differences seem to still be there."
The dollar selloff snowballed after Martin Feldstein, president of the National Bureau of Economic Research, predicted the Japanese currency would soon surge to 100 yen to a dollar and would keep rising for years.
The dollar was quoted at 108.13 yen in late New York trading, down from 109.45 on Monday.
The currency also fell against the mark and French franc as fears of an imminent cut in German and French rates faded. In New York, The dollar dropped to 1.7195 marks, from 1.7300 marks late Monday. And it fell to 5.8695 French francs, from 5.9065.
The British pound settled at $1.4960 in New York, up from $1.4769 on Monday.

HEADLINE: Funds Lend Where Others Won't

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAMDEN, N.J.

 BODY:
"Come back next year and you'll see a miracle," said Michael Dawkins, muscling a concrete pillar as heavy as the July heat into the gutted row house he is helping to rebuild.
To call them decrepit would flatter the shells that Mr. Dawkins and other construction workers employed by the North Camden Land Trust are overhauling. And to call the neighborhood destitute would understate the enduring poverty on State Street, where the nonprofit organization is halfway through rehabilitating 20 units of affordable housing. 
 In a local economy as hollow as one of North Camden's 300 vacant houses, in a place with few jobs and no banks, the miracle is not just that abandoned buildings are being resurrected, but that somebody wrote a loan to make it possible. The odds against finding a mortgage in these parts would seem to be about as remote as the chances that it would ever be repaid.
But the Delaware Valley Community Reinvestment Fund, which is bankrolling the land trust's work, has grown steadily for eight years without ever having a loan go into default.
The track record of the fund has made it an exemplar for an increasingly vibrant form of financial institution: community development loan funds, which take cheap loans or donations from churches, charities, corporations and individuals, then reinvest the money at below-market rates of return in neighborhoods where conventional credit long since evaporated. Of 41 such funds for which there are industry data, losses to date are running at a very respectable 1 percent of total loans.
Community development loan funds like Delaware Valley would be among the financial institutions eligible to receive Federal support under proposed legislation that the Clinton Administration is expected to submit to Congress on July 15. The new program would provide $60 million in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1, and $382 million over five years.
During the election campaign, President Clinton spoke repeatedly of establishing 100 new "community development banks." At first, his objective seemed to be to create new institutions modeled along the lines of the South Shore Bank of Chicago, which makes loans to poor borrowers but operates like a traditional bank in the sense that it takes deposits as well.
But people with experience in financing development in poor neighborhoods have persuaded the Administration to broaden its bill to cover not only banks but also a panoply of alternative lending institutions.
The draft legislation that is now circulating in Washington would make any financial institution eligible for aid, in the form of Federal loans, grants or deposits, as long as its primary purpose is serving distressed communities. Conventional banks will not be eligible for assistance, not even if they have community development subsidiaries.
Martin Trimble, who heads the National Association of Community Development Loan Funds, which currently has 42 member funds, said that Mr. Clinton would be able to keep his campaign promise this way.
"He's going to get 100 large-scale community development financial institutions out of this," Mr. Trimble said. "But he is not going to get 100 South Shores, nor should he."
The association contends that it is better to support smaller entities that are already involved in development financing, and let them, if they choose, grow into full-fledged development banks.
Although there is little vocal opposition to the Administration's proposal to foster community development financial institutions, some lawmakers are expected to offer competing approaches. And conventional bankers are arguing that they, too, should be allowed to participate in the program to the extent that they write community development loans.
Supporters say that community development financial institutions will fill a crucial gap in reviving poor neighborhoods.
 
Credit Termed an Essential
 "If credit is systematically denied to a neighborhood, that community will almost certainly suffer economic decline," said one recent report by researchers at the Jerome Levy Economics Institute of Bard College.
Existing laws like the Community Reinvestment Act, requiring banks to lend to the disadvantaged wherever they do business, are necessary but not sufficient to assure adequate credit, the report said.
"It is easier to make a banker out of a community activist than it is to make a community activist out of a banker," said the Bard report, "A Path to Community Development."
The new breed of community development financiers hang few business school diplomas on their walls, but they seem willing to put on pinstripes if that's what it takes to succeed.
"Our motive is not profit, but we are trying to build viable, sustainable financial institutions, and we look at this as a business," said Mr. Trimble of the loan fund association.
 
Past Efforts Foundered
 Some past efforts at neighborhood reconstruction have foundered, said Jeremy Nowak, the Delaware Valley fund's executive director, because the programs were managed by "bleeding heart liberals who were doing God's work, but did not have the ethic of accountability."
He made the comment after visiting one vacant dwelling on State Street where the North Camden Land Trust recently evicted a tenant who had failed to keep up with the monthly payments on the property.
The Delaware Valley fund, which has $12 million in loans outstanding throughout the region, has too much at stake to think of its beneficiaries as victims to be treated gently, Mr. Nowak said.
In the fiscal year that ended on June 30, the fund lent $2.2 million in Camden, $835,000 of it in the North Camden neighborhood -- a Hispanic and black community of about 8,700, amputated from the rest of town by the highway feeding the Ben Franklin Bridge to Philadelphia.
In North Camden, the median household income is $11,000, 42 percent of households are headed by women, unemployment hovers around 25 percent of the labor force, 57 percent of the people live in poverty and 75 percent receive public assistance of some kind.
 
Reliance on Subsidies
 Almost all of the housing the fund finances relies on some form of public subsidy, such as state development grants or Federal housing payments. But the fund's mission is to attract private credit, and it has recently drawn increased support from conventional banks.
Last month, seven New Jersey banks agreed to form a $3.2 million loan pool with which the fund will underwrite more ventures in Camden. The fund will screen loan applications, help train the borrowers in sound business practices and monitor the financial status of the projects that the banks are financing. The banks are Chemical Bank of New Jersey, Corestates New Jersey National Bank, First Fidelity Bank, Meridian Bank, Midlantic National Bank, PNC Bank and United Jersey Bank/South N.A.
Such conventional banks are required by law to lend in disadvantaged communities and this agreement helps them meet the obligation.
The first loan written under the arrangement between the fund and the banks, worth $150,000, will go to the North Camden Land Trust. It will help finance construction of 10 of the three-bedroom homes being renovated on State Street.
The venture would make a conventional banker cringe.
One of the problems that prevents normal lending here is the stubborn refusal of housing values to reflect renovation investments. "We could never count on the fact that the real estate would go up in value," said Mr. Nowak of the Delaware Valley fund.
Nor can a typical family's income be expected to justify a loan. Usually, it costs $50,000 to renovate a dwelling. But with median family income of $11,000, Camden households can afford only about $280 a month in payments. After taxes and maintenance, that will cover a modest mortgage, but the state or a private charity must also make a major contribution.
 
Plain Houses, Complex Finance
 So the houses on State Street, despite the touch of elegance lingering in their characteristic peaked facades, are kept plain and simple, with only the financing tending toward the baroque.
The first renovated homes were sold to local families, with the North Camden Land Trust holding the mortgages and retaining title to the land. Predictably, this caused problems if a homeowner later wanted to sell. The trust also wanted to be sure that the rehabilitated homes were adequately maintained.
So the trust now owns the homes it develops but allows residents to build equity as members of what is, in effect, a co-op. The portion of the payment that is used to retire mortgage principal is credited to the resident's account, to be paid back if the family moves after having lived in the home for at least five years.
Such arrangements are a far cry from the rough early days of North Camden's renewal movement, which grew up in a town scorched by riots in the late 1960's and early 1970's.
The housing struggle began when squatters moved into 13 vacant homes in 1981, winning ownership of them from the city and rehabilitating them. The squatting program eventually took over 140 homes.
In 1990, local activists beat back a state proposal to build a second prison in North Camden. Now, the activists are planning their most ambitious step yet. They are taking to the city government a proposal for a 15-year, $100 million development plan for the neighborhood. The planning project has been sponsored by the Delaware Valley fund, the land trust and the city's Camden Redevelopment Agency.
"People have gotten tired of fighting against things," said Tom Knoche, who helped write the plan. "It's time to fight for things."

HEADLINE: Metropolitan Diary

BYLINE: By Ron Alexander

 BODY:
OVERHEARD by R. Chester Redhead in an outdoor cafe on upper Madison Avenue. Mother to boy, about 6: "Hurry and finish your soup before it gets dirty."
Overheard by Elizabeth Hunter in the cafe at the recently renovated Jewish Museum. Gray-haired woman, almost certainly a tourist, to gray-haired man: "Ellis Island was nice, but the Statue of Liberty I could have done without." 
 Dear Diary:
Last week I was in Katz's, the delicatessen on the Lower East Side, and as I ordered a couple of sandwiches at the counter, I instinctively took out a dollar bill to tip the counter man.
I had learned this time-honored technique from my father, who started taking me to Katz's when I was a kid. He would order a sandwich and then tap a quarter on the counter, indicating to the gruff-looking fellow on the other side that there was a little something extra in it for him if he piled on a few more slices of corned beef.
Some 30 years and much inflation later, the going rate for a Katz's tip is about a buck or two for two sandwiches. The amount may have changed, but the effect is still the same.
As I found a table and cracked open a bottle of Dr. Brown's cream soda, I thought about this valuable piece of New York City information and the person I had learned it from.
Other kids' dads taught them how to play second base or how to figure out higher mathematics. My dad taught me how to order a decent corned beef sandwich. WARREN SHOULBERG

HOME MOVIES AND ME
 
Charlie Chan and No. 1 Son
were always on some case;
the Whistler stalked a dark street
though you never saw his face.
There was Veronica Lake and Alan Ladd
and William Bendix being bad;
and somewhere outside was World War II
and rationing and meatless stew
and terrible problems across the sea
but you couldn't prove it
from my movies and me. ED ROSSMANN

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
 A busy corner on Wall Street. Jack Grubel stops to make a phone call. There on top of the phone is a small camera. Expecting a frantic owner to rush by, Mr. Grubel waits for someone in distress. But he waits in vain. His windfall: a 35-millimeter point-and-shoot camera with a German name. Only a few shots remain on the film. What has caught the eyes of what is probably a foreign family visiting New York? A few days later Mr. Grubel has his answer in 27 photos.
Start the odyssey with a Park Avenue street scene and then proceed in this order: surrey near the Plaza; the entrance of the Gainsborough Studios on Central Park South; woman posing by a Jackie Mason poster; the entrance of The New York Times; Empire State Building; outlandishly garbed store mannequins; Central Park jogging path; youngster basking in F.A.O. Schwarz teddy bear corner (three shots); Statue of Liberty ferry excursion; woman in green Liberty headdress; Trinity Church; Stock Exchange entrance.
Then, apparently, a stop to make a phone call. Then: "Honey, you left it where?"
 
Dear Diary:
The time has come to tell about my latest telephone reservations call.
When I made a dinner reservation at Montrachet, the restaurant in TriBeCa, the young woman who took the call asked if we preferred smoking or nonsmoking. "Oh, definitely nonsmoking," I said. "One of our party has asthma and a second person has breathing problems of her own."
With warm and sincere sympathy, our reservation-taker said: "I know how it is. I have asthma myself. I'll put you in severe Nonsmoking." And so she did. ALICE LIPTON ECKSTEIN

Dear Diary:
It is one of the more uncomfortable of recent afternoons. Wearing a tan poplin suit on a downtown E train, I am trying my best to remain natty despite the soaring thermometer. Barely penetrating my consciousness is the huckstering of a subway merchant selling a radio. After a few seconds I realize that he has picked me as his target market.
"Hey you! You want to buy a radio?"
"No thank you," I reply. There is the briefest of pauses and then the unique selling point. "It plays Beethoven!" DENNIS P. McGUIRE

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Dear Diary:
After hearing so many voice-mail instructions in the last few years, I tend to become discouraged at the long lists of instructions that never seem to apply to my situation. But the other day I heard one that confirmed my faith in the people behind the machines.
I was phoning a publishing company, and the message started in the usual fashion with a voice droning "Press 1 if you would like to order a specific publication, press 2 if you have a question about an invoice." I was listening halfheartedly when the last option caught my attention with "Press 6 if you would like to speak with a sales representative, if you are thoroughly confused or if you would like to speak with a thoroughly confused representative.
Sometimes there's hope. EMMY WYATT

HEADLINE: Review/Dance;
A Dark Meditation on Death by Martha Clarke

BYLINE: By ANNA KISSELGOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DURHAM, N.C., July 13

 BODY:
Past and present were united here this week on an unusual program at the American Dance Festival that ranged from a dumbfounding performance by Gary Chryst in a new work by Martha Clarke to major revivals, both rousing and poignant, of 1930's social-protest works by the modern-dance pioneer Helen Tamiris.
Miss Clarke's "Dammerung," created last spring in the Netherlands, received its United States premiere on Sunday night at the festival, and the effect of this 11-minute piece was nothing less than shattering. Mr. Chryst, a former leading dancer in the Joffrey Ballet who is often seen on Broadway (most recently in "Guys and Dolls"), has always been an outstanding, versatile artist. 
 Here he rises to a level of performance that any great actor would envy for its compelling profundity and projection. Yet only a great dancer's sense of phrasing could so dramatically fuse with the economy of movement in Miss Clarke's image of a man in the twilight of his life. His death onstage is so visibly a metaphor for Death in general that the end comes across as particularly brutal. Miss Clarke has outdone herself in this coup de theatre of a piece.
The dimension into which Mr. Chryst took his dance acting was so mesmerizing that he seemed -- with his partner Jeanne Solan -- in a different world from anyone else on the program. No one could match him on the same heightened scale of performance.
And yet the highly mixed bill at the Reynolds Industries Theater on the Duke University campus was far from a disaster. The six works on the program -- including three contemporary solos performed by Carol Parker -- shared a common theatricality. Certain connections were made. Both Miss Clarke and Miss Parker are former members of Pilobolus, and all the program's choreographers, except Tamiris, were associated with the festival. Moreover, social commentary ran through virtually each piece, past and present.
In Miss Clarke's "Dammerung," for instance, a character study becomes a social indictment. The work, performed to songs by Alban Berg, begins with Mr. Chryst wandering uncertainly in a black suit and hat that he takes off before dropping to the floor. After fumbling frantically in his pockets, he goes through a series of abstracted gestures and movements to the accompaniment of the song "Let Anguish Have Its Due." Mr. Chryst looks fearful and cold, but his collapses still have a dynamism. In the last section, some of these same movements will be recapitulated with ebbing energy.
There is a sudden entrance by Miss Solan, an American who has danced in the Netherlands Dance Theater under Jiri Kylian's direction. Dressed in black with a white lace collar, she is possibly an allegorical figure: the beloved or Death.
The action, filled with potential cliches, is nonetheless always so strongly on the edge of emotional pain that the final song, "Sleep," promises relief. Here Miss Clarke delivers her punch line, if that is the word. Mr. Chryst goes rigid (as if shot) and takes off his jacket. The audience sees his back and for the first time, a bloodstain on his shirt.
Robert Israel's cloudy backdrop, darkened by Joop Caboort's lighting, adds to the drama. The powerful resonance of the piece is such that it is open to various interpretations, but its emotional impact is unmistakable. Some saw "Dammerung" as a metaphor for the war in Bosnia; the solitude of an AIDS victim was ever present.
The social wounds that existed in the 1930's were evoked with astonishing fierceness in Dianne McIntyre's performance of "Negro Spirituals." Tamiris (1902-66) choreographed the work between 1927 and 1932. Miss McIntyre, a dancer and choreographer, supervised and researched the reconstruction of Tamiris's 1937 "How Long Brethren?" It was restaged here for students at the festival.
Beautifully reconstructed, the Tamiris pieces used choral movement, weighted power and militant gesture. In their obvious display of an early 1930's modern dance esthetic, they appeared remote from the program's contemporary pieces.
In discussions afterward, Miss McIntrye, who is black, rejected the idea that the solos by Tamiris, a white political radical, were naive. There was a basic truth, she said, in Tamiris's abstracted interpretation of the spirituals. There was also a shining truth to Miss McIntyre's performance. She lunged, she rocked, she plunged her arms down and always kept them in the asymmetrical shape that made the choreographic form so vibrant.
"Negro Spirituals" has been performed over the years. "How Long Brethren?," based on Lawrence Gellert's collection, "Negro Songs of Protest," was recently recalled from memory and photographs by Pauline Tish and two other members of the Tamiris company, Ida Little Arbeit and Sasha Pressman.
The reconstruction, commissioned by the Federal Theater Project of George Mason University in 1991, distills tragedy and hope in large and legible movements that are nonetheless too refined to turn into agitprop. A still shocking section is "Scottsboro," which evokes the famous trial in Alabama of young black men falsely accused of rape. Seven women on boxes or on the floor revolve or twist, implying a hanging.
Aziza, a guest artist, led the choral patterns, which were joyful or mournful. The sight of small choruses -- trudging in partial profile, bodies pressed close -- was dated in the best sense. They don't make dances like this anymore.
The proof came in the familiar contemporary solos performed by Miss Parker. These were Miss Clarke's "Nocturne," Alison Chase's "Moonblind" and Hercilia Lopez's "Amapola," a Venezuelan choreographer's study of a woman yearning for love in a macho society. Glossy and sophisticated, these dances suddenly looked lightweight.
