HEADLINE: ON TENNIS;
Red, White and Blue, Almost Out of the Blue

BYLINE: By Robin Finn

 BODY:
Surprise, surprise. Only a half-dozen years ago, the male selection of American tennis prodigies offered all the promise of a black hole; this year a half-dozen of these wunderkids reached the Round of 16 at the most intimidating Grand Slam in the world, Wimbledon.
"In 1987, nobody was willing to put a nickel on the prospects of the American men," said Ron Woods, head of the United States Tennis Association's player-development program. "Now we're looking around and shaking our heads trying to explain what happened, why this glut?" 
 Now, no other nation in the world can boast of producing a generation of tennis players this dominant--or this different. With nothing in common except their megamillion endorsement contracts, Pete Sampras, Jim Courier, Andre Agassi, Michael Chang and, in the not-so-distant background, David Wheaton, Todd Martin and MaliVai Washington have established the United States as the nation of record for men's tennis.
And in melting-pot tradition, there is no mass labeling for this occasionally gross national product of autonomous achievers. Sampras serves and volleys with imperial precision. Chang has girded himself with an unflagging mental positivism. Courier has removed the fire from his temper and injected it into his groundstrokes. Agassi is an improviser. Washington, Martin and Wheaton tuned up for tennis at college.
They hail from the Bible belt, from the corn belt and in the case of the Washington D.C.-born Sampras, the 1993 Wimbledon champion, from the Beltway. And Agassi, the only natural celebrity of this celebrated bunch, comes from Las Vegas, a place better known for producing plastic chips than tennis players.
And who wants to take credit for their collective presence?
"If we take credit, everybody gets annoyed," said Woods, "but we did have some effect on that crop of players as they just starting out. And I can't very well say we developed them: They're all too different."
The U.S.T.A. lent a helping hand, in the form of a starter program of free coaching for their fledgling years on the pro circuit, to Sampras, Chang, Courier, Wheaton and Washington, and is just now weaning Martin from his third year of assistance.
Sampras and Chang were, at 16 and 17, the first beneficiaries of the U.S.T.A.'s largesse. With the help of the U.S.T.A. contract coach Jose Higueras, Chang got the Grand Slam jinx lifted for American -born men by standing small at the baseline and capturing the 1989 French Open at 17. A year later, Courier asked for similar help when he turned pro, and he too was allied with Higueras, a pairing that continues.
As for the ongoing invention of Agassi, the U.S.T.A. is quick to issue a disclaimer. Only Nick Bollettieri knows for sure whether he's an act of God, a product of spontaneous combustion, or something else altogether.
"I didn't make Andre, I only helped him," said Bollettieri, who last week resigned as Agassi's head coach after a decade of togetherness turned into a Zen nightmare. "Andre is different, and he'll always be different. But we'll always have Wimbledon."
In varying degrees, so, too, will the rest of the Americans following what was, for several of them, their best and brightest Grand Slam appearance.
"It's our moment in the sun," said Sampras. "I really don't have any other great answer for it."
Their impact was almost comical at Wimbledon: even when the luck of the draw forced them to begin knocking each other off, they refused to go away.
Still reeling from Agassi's command performance as Wimbledon's hairiest White Knight ever in 1992, the once-sober Slam grew positively giddy in 1993. Agassi, this time decked out in a multihued Nike outfit that needed two trips through Wimbledon's sartorial scan committee before being approved, had the place in his sore right palm from start to finish.
Opponents and spectators swooned before him, and it took a level-headed effort from Sampras to subdue him in the quarterfinal round, where four Americans had advanced from the half-dozen United States men who reached the fourth round.
But Wimbledon was ablaze with All-American confrontations: Aaron Krickstein shut down Washington in the second round, and Wheaton disposed of Chang in the third only to fall in the fourth to Martin. Then, while Sampras went a full five sets against Agassi, Courier quelled Martin in straight sets to reach the semifinals.
At this point, Wimbledon faced the specter of an All-American final, but didn't quite take it seriously because of the arrival of two former champions in the semifinal round. Stefan Edberg, so All England Club-proper that he looks as if he'd just peeled himself off the ironing board, was tackling the baseliner in the baseball cap, Courier. And Boris Becker, who claimed to be feeling like the boy who owned Wimbledon in 1985 and 1986, was ready to outmuscle Sampras.
Wimbledon was guaranteed a Yankee champion for the second straight year, a travesty that hadn't happened since Jimmy Connors and John McEnroe ruled the lawns from 1981-84.
Bereft of legitimate complaints about the tennis skills of Sampras, whose classical strokes long ago received Fred Perry's seal of approval, and Courier, whose work ethic is above reproach even from the finicky British cognescenti, the keepers of Wimbledon's traditional flame were reduced to complaining about their language. As if the rest of the world's hopefuls, Britons included, never uttered an expletive in the heat of battle.
But in their final, Sampras and Courier played and behaved like the No. 1 and No. 2 players in the world ought to while at Wimbledon, or anywhere. And when Sampras stretched out in midair with saucer-eyes ablaze in pursuit of a textbook volley, he could almost be forgiven for being ao American. In that moment, he simply looked like the best of a very good bunch.

HEADLINE: Thinking Small -- A special report;
Is Smaller Better? Educators Now Say Yes for High School

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
The big urban high school, a place of opportunity, anonymity and most recently fear, is under siege by a growing army of critics who want to abolish it.
A generation ago, educators endorsed large high schools because they could offer a wide range of subjects and extracurricular activities at a relatively low administrative cost. But now many researchers and educators alike see big urban high schools -- those with 2,000 to 5,000 students -- as Dickensian workhouses breeding violence, dropouts, academic failure and alienation. 
By contrast, students in schools limited to about 400 usually have fewer behavioral problems, better attendance and graduation rates, and sometimes higher grades and test scores. At a time when more children have less support from their families, students in small schools can form close relationships with teachers.
"In the attempts to build the comprehensive, 'we can do everything' high school, we left out something to belong to, to believe in," said William Ayers, a professor of education at the University of Chicago who is helping several Chicago high schools create smaller schools within their walls.
 
A Nationwide Trend
 Educators across the country are moving to replace big high schools with smaller ones. Philadelphia's system is the furthest along; here, the school district aims to convert all 22 remaining big neighborhood high schools into smaller schools-within-a-school. In New York City, more than 30 new small high schools will open this fall, including six that are part of a five-year project to close two neighborhood high schools and replace them with about a dozen small ones that will be located at first in separate buildings. More modest efforts are also under way in Denver and Boulder in Colorado, San Francisco, Chicago, Providence, R.I., and other cities.
Unlike "magnet schools," which can be large and often impose admissions requirements, these new small schools are aimed at the very students who are left behind, struggling, in large neighborhood high schools. Educators argue that small schools allow students, teachers and parents to know each other well, building bonds that are particularly vital during the troubled years of adolescence.
While many believe that smaller high schools would also help suburban students, most of the large-scale projects have been in urban high schools. Researchers have found that the stakes are higher for poor children, who do worse than their better-off peers in large schools.
Advocates of small schools want to do more than reach out to adolescents; they believe that small schools can be both agents and models of school improvement. "I'm arguing you cannot make the kind of radical change in the nature of schooling this country is calling for without small schools," said Deborah Meier, founder and co-director of the Central Park East Secondary School in East Harlem, a small public high school with graduation and achievement rates that far outstrip other non-specialized high schools in the city. "You have to create a very thick culture within the schools that helps teachers, kids and parents to change their habits of work."
But these fledgling schools must battle perceptions that they cost more to run and administrative structures that prevent them from making their own decisions about budgets, hiring, and scheduling. Nor will making schools smaller alone make them better; teachers usually have to be willing to reshape curriculums and testing, work in teams and take on more responsibilities.
And there are start-up costs -- in New York City, for example, at least $15 million over five years, including leasing costs for new buildings that extend into the tens of millions. Long-term costs are so far unknown, and some analysts say savings lost in economies of scale will be balanced by the need for fewer administrators in the small schools.
 
Tactics
New Ideas Bring 'Shining Stars'
 In Joseph Conroy's introductory French class, laughing students clustered around a game they had designed called "Egarge au Centre Commerciale" (Lost at the Mall). Whoever first spent a fixed amount of money at the stores won, and the students had to draw on their French vocabularies to translate which goods they needed to buy.
Upstairs in English class, Carolyn Tripp led a discussion about the relationships between culture and identity in America by having them read a comparison between skinheads and punks.
The students were attentive and excited, their interest caught by the unconventional ways they were learning their lessons. "Here, you not only have to study, you have to think about what you study," said Shannon Stott, an 11th grader. "You can't just memorize it."
These students belong to the Temple Connection, a group of 400 ninth- through 11th graders at Lincoln High School in northeast Philadelphia. The school admits students regardless of their academic or disciplinary records. Many of the students have troubled home lives, and many were not top achievers. But most have thrived since the school opened three years ago. "They are shining stars you thought were dull," said Gregg Staples, who teaches foreign languages.
This school within a school, called a "charter" here, is part of an ambitious citywide program to create small high schools within all 22 of Philadelphia's large neighborhood high schools. So far, 15 of the high schools have been broken up entirely into smaller subschools; others contain at least one smaller school.
The Philadelphia plan, like other movements for small schools around the country, draws on research and the experience of pioneers like Ms. Meier. According to Anthony S. Bryk, a professor of education at the University of Chicago who has reviewed most of the existing research on school size, most studies find that small schools have less absenteeism, lower dropout rates, fewer disciplinary problems and higher teacher satisfaction than big schools.
The studies do not show as clear a link between size and academic performance, but the most recent review of national data shows that the larger the school, the worse students scored on four standardized tests. This study, by Valerie E. Lee of the University of Michigan and Julia Smith of the University of Rochester, examined a 1988 national study of eighth graders and also confirmed previous research suggesting that poor children did the worst in large schools.
 
Old Wisdom Reversed
 These findings reverse the conventional wisdom of the 1950's, when educators argued that big was better. Some still believe that large schools offer children more opportunity and more variety, particularly in advanced subjects. And many districts continue to worry that small schools will be more expensive because they duplicate people and facilities.
Several studies counter by suggesting that large schools breed unnecessary layers of administration, like assistant principals or deans of discipline. And Ms. Meier said small schools could band together to offer advanced courses or better sports teams.
"The average large high school has a small school within it -- the small school of kids who know the faculty, are in all the theaters and clubs, who are the stars of the school, who walk down the halls and say 'Hi' to everyone," she said. "That's what schools need to do for all kids."
 
Results
Signs of Progress After 3 Years
 In Philadelphia, teachers at the Temple Connection say their school works so well because they get to know their students better, demand high intellectual standards, design their own curriculum and tests and have a voice in running the program.
Because their school has 400 students, as against nearly 2,000 in Lincoln High School as a whole, the Temple Connection teachers tend to know more about their students' lives. While this knowledge does not always prevent trouble, it guides teachers trying to devise solutions. Recently, two students were arrested after a fight at school. One was a Temple Connection student who had been in a mental hospital for a month.
"In talking to the administration, they had no idea of her problems," said Zachary Rubin, a social studies teacher and co-director of the Temple Connection. "That's what the charter movement is all about."
 
What Students Say
 Students agree. "If you're under a lot of pressure and stress, they help you through that," said Joy Grimmage, an 11th grader. "They won't put you down or put you on hold."
But students also say they welcome the school's demanding curriculum. The teachers, working with Temple University, have designed courses that weave subjects from different disciplines, such as the impact of science and technology on American life. The school, open to any students who want to enter, requires four years of mathematics, a laboratory science and a foreign language to graduate.
One principle of the Philadelphia small schools movement is to uphold high academic standards for teen-agers who in the past were often written off as indifferent students unlikely to move on to college.
Although the neighborhood around Lincoln High School is predominantly lower middle class rather than desperately poor, many students are battling staggering problems. One group of students who spoke articulately about how much they like the school included an unwed mother whose boyfriend has another pregnant girlfriend in the same school; a boy whose mother moved away one day, leaving him homeless, and a boy who spent the year nursing his dying father.
The Philadelphia schools are struggling with problems endemic to small-school movements around the country.Many are not really separate schools, with the autonomy that that implies.
Teachers at the Temple Connection still do not entirely control their own budget, hiring, scheduling, disciplinary policies or student assignments. They have tried, so far unsuccessfully, to persuade the administrator in charge of scheduling to allow them to teach classes in 90-minute rather than 48-minute blocks so that they can cover subjects in greater depth.
These concerns raise broader questions about the limits of Philadelphia's small-school design. Should the old high school administrative structure, with its principals, assistant principals, deans of discipline and schedulers remain in place supervising a cluster of small schools, or should they be abolished to save money and allow the schools more autonomy?
Constance E. Clayton, Philadelphia's superintendent, said she was committed to small high schools but needed to consult parents, students, teachers and union officials. "These are things we are trying to work through: how can we give them autonomy and accountability at the same time?" she said.
 
Differences
Other Approaches For Other Cities
 These struggles are echoed elsewhere as different cities try different routes. While Providence, Boulder, San Francisco and Chicago are all experimenting with small high schools, the biggest effort outside Philadelphia is in New York City. Rather than create schools within schools, New York is creating more than 30 entirely new, independent, small high schools in its most sweeping expansion of high schools in decades. These schools include several based on themes ranging from music to finance to community organizing and run in partnership with churches, community groups or unions.
Unlike Philadelphia, New York is not moving to make all its big high schools smaller. But one part of the project, run by Ms. Meier and Marcia Brevot, principal of Manhattan Collaborative High School, aims to develop a strategy for improving schools that could be applied to more high schools later.
Under the plan, the city would shut down two high schools and replace them over five years with about a dozen smaller ones. Although the small schools might eventually move back into the old high school building, they will start in separate locations, and no final decision has been made on whether any new construction will be necessary, or affordable. Based on her experience, Ms. Meier believes small high schools need full autonomy and, at the beginning, a different location so that they can create their own distinctive culture. "It's like imagining changing an auto parts factory while it's working," she said.
The new schools will adopt features from Ms. Meier's school, which has high standards for the poor, minority students whom many other schools have largely written off. Central Park East has a core curriculum, including subjects like physics, with students required to prove what they have learned in presentation to graduation committees before they receive a diploma. Every full-time teacher in the school is responsible for getting to know a group of 15 students and their families well. In a city where fewer than 40 percent the students graduate within four years, Central Park East, which opened on Madison Avenue at 106th Street in 1985, graduated 71 percent of its ninth-grade class in four years. More than 90 percent are attending college.
Beginning this fall, Julia Richman High School, on the Upper East Side in Manhattan, will not accept ninth graders. Instead, the ninth graders will enter one of six new smaller high schools around Manhattan. Each year, the small high schools will add a grade, and Julia Richman will phase out a grade, until Julia Richman shuts down entirely and the new small high schools have grades 9 through 12. The high school, on 67th Street between First and Second Avenues, drew its students primarily from East Harlem and had very high dropout rates. Many neighborhood parents avoided it altogether, Ms. Meier said. Next year, another high school yet to be chosen in the Bronx will begin phasing out, to be replaced by another six small schools.
The new high schools will be housed in several other buildings, with directors of their own and teachers who chose to teach in them. Students can choose to attend the school after going to one required information meeting. This fall's class will be roughly split between students who would have gone to Julia Richman anyhow and others who will come from other school districts.
Over time, Ms. Meier wants to redesign the buildings to house elementary through high schools along with a range of social and community services, possibly including social workers, psychological counselors and the like. The new high schools will be limited to 400 students. To pay for leasing buildings for new schools and for the staff training that Ms. Meier considers essential, she and her partners have raised $3 million from several foundations. "If this works, maybe this allows other schools to say we can do this on our own and gives people a picture about what this could be like," she said.
This project, too, has weathered difficulties. Leasing school buildings was a tortuous process, and teachers spent months in junior high schools just trying to find students who would be in Julia Richman's zone. Nor is it clear how enthusiastic a new schools chancellor will be about small high schools. But Ms. Meier believes this project offers her a chance to bring her ideas into the mainstream.
"This is a critical time," she said. "We can see whether this is a strategy for changing existing large high schools."

HEADLINE: Newspaper Guild Once Again Finds Itself Left Out

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON

 BODY:
When 10 unions of The New York Post made their deals with Rupert Murdoch on Monday, it was no surprise in the newspaper industry that there was one newspaper union that was left out.
The New York Newspaper Guild, which represents reporters and some editors as well as advertising, clerical and circulation employees, has grown accustomed to that position. It seems always to be the left-out union. 
 Its battle at The Post comes on the heels of a devastating defeat at The Daily News this winter, when more than 170 members found themselves suddenly unemployed at the behest of the new owner, Mortimer B. Zuckerman.
At The Post, the guild's battle provides a snapshot of an unusual labor confrontation with roots in changes under way in big city journalism. And it provides insight into the immovable force of Rupert Murdoch as he solidifies his hold on a newspaper that obviously matters greatly to him, no matter how vast his international empire.
 
'Free Fire' Proposal
 On Monday, the guild won from Mr. Murdoch only the right to continue bargaining with the possible assistance of a state mediator. Mr. Murdoch's representatives said they were willing to talk. But they did not retract what the union calls a "free fire" proposal that would give managers the right to dismiss union members freely, and other demands that union officials have characterized as aimed at destroying the union.
Arthur M. Siskind, general counsel and executive vice president of Mr. Murdoch's International News Corporation, said the company's managers remain steadfast. "The issue really is: Do you have the right to determine who is going to work for you?" Mr. Siskind said. "We feel very strongly about that."
The guild brought trade unionism to people who wore white collars in journalism. It derived its once considerable power from alliances with unions representing people who set type, ran presses and drove trucks. Those alliances are frayed now, as illustrated most graphically by the inaction of the production unions when Mr. Zuckerman began his assault on the guild on the same day he took title to that newspaper.
But underlying the complex union politics are other issues. Newspaper publishers across the country argue that trade unionism in the newsroom has protected unproductive journalists and robbed news room managers of too much power. They say that is a luxury they can no longer afford. Privately, they also say they believe that the guild is so weak that the publishers have the power to do something about it.
In New York, both Mr. Zuckerman and Mr. Murdoch have embarked on a determined course to weaken the guild's hold on the newsroom. Mr. Zuckerman has yet to sign a contract with the guild, which is the bargaining agent for many Daily News employees.
 
Warding Off Attacks
 Mr. Siskind said Mr. Murdoch's executives believe that it will be difficult to improve The Post "if we don't have people who can produce for us." He said that if The Post suffered in the quality of its content that might be the responsibility of newsroom employees "because they are not afraid of losing their jobs because of the way seniority works."
The contract between the guild and The New York Times expired in March and negotiations are under way. New York Newsday's editorial employees are represented by a different union.
For the guild, the problem has always been that a union could never sanction attacks on its members. Without job security for its weakest members, any union would wither.
In the Sheraton Hotel on Monday when Mr. Murdoch's executives reached their agreements with the other unions, there was a delicate dance with the guild. The guild, which has won assurances of support from the other newspaper unions, had its maximum leverage while all the unions were out of work together. Once the other unions were back at their stations, the chances of union solidarity in support of the guild, if it was ever substantial, would diminish.
The guild's willingness to work while negotiating gave management the right to claim a clear victory against its unions and to start the paper's presses again with a flourish. In exchange, the guild got to hope.
 
Review of Editorial Staff
 "We are certainly hoping that we, in a way, did them a favor," said Harry Leykis, president of the guild local at The Post, "and that we're going to get a little more humane treatment than The Daily News got."
Management, too, used the crisis to maximum advantage. By maneuvering the other unions back to work and promising only to negotiate with the guild, it worked to isolate the guild once again.
Mr. Murdoch's representatives also opened the possibility that in negotiations, the guild would consent to some form of review of current editorial staff. A negotiated settlement would give both sides the chance to avoid cataclysm and claim victory.
John F. Hudacs, the New York State Commissioner of Labor, who helped bring about the talks at the Sheraton, said he saw some hopeful signs for the guild-Murdoch confontation. He said there was some "common ground upon which they can have some discussions that can enable them to achieve competitiveness and still respect the guild as a labor organization." Mr. Hudacs said he was available to mediate, if invited.
For the moment yesterday, some guild members at The Post said they were so happy to be back they were trying hard not to think about what the other shoe would be like when it finally dropped.
Mr. Leykis said he was hopeful. But he knew there were some who were convinced Mr. Murdoch's people were simply talking about talking as a smokescreen for another onslaught against their union.
"I wasn't born yesterday," Mr. Leykis said, "and I know that's a definite possibility."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 15, 1993, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, a news analysis article yesterday about the New York Newspaper Guild misidentified the international company headed by Rupert Murdoch. It is the News Corporation.

HEADLINE: Forget the Tiananmen Fixation

BYLINE: By Kenneth Lieberthal; Kenneth Lieberthal is professor of political science at the University of Michigan and a member of the university's Center for Chinese Studies.

DATELINE: ANN ARBOR, Mich.

 BODY:
The U.S. should stop punishing China for the massacre of demonstrators in Tiananmen Square in 1989. China is too important to make this the pivot of our policy.
China -- a nuclear power with intercontinental ballistic missiles and a permanent member's seat on the United Nations Security Council -- has enormous capacity to do mischief on the world stage. 
 Besides, China contains 22 percent of the world's population and has perhaps the world's third largest and most rapidly expanding economy. Unlike Japan and the four "tigers" of East Asia -- South Korea, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Singapore -- China has an entire continent to develop, and this will provide major opportunities for foreign business.
America alone among the industrial countries still imposes sanctions because of the massacre. In May, President Clinton slightly modified our policy. He achieved bipartisan support in the Congress to renew China's most-favored-nation trade status without conditions this year. But he also tied renewal of that status in 1994 to Chinese progress on specific human rights and trade issues. He also suggested that he is seeking additional channels in which to resolve issues such as allegations of proliferation of Chinese missile and nuclear technology.
While Mr. Clinton's incremental steps are welcome, our approach needs a new foundation, not minor tinkering. We should stop viewing everything in terms of rewarding and punishing China and try instead to maximize our overall effectiveness in dealing with Beijing.
The President ought to take the following steps:
Declare that America has a national interest in a China that is reform- minded, stable, modernizing and that plays a constructive international role.
This could shift our relationship from constant niggling to a focus on broad mutual strategic interests. Without this change, our relations will remain deeply troubled and fragile.
Renew regular cabinet-level contacts between both governments.
Our refusal since the crackdown to deal regularly with Beijing at the cabinet level imposes a very high cost on relations. No Clinton Cabinet secretary has visited China in the past two years in any capacity -- but China has changed enormously in that time. Cabinet contacts greatly increase mutual understanding. Besides, almost without exception recent Congressional visitors have found China more vibrant and open than they had expected. But virtually no top Chinese leader has heard the views of his U.S. counterpart argued forcefully and directly, and this does us little good. High level visits also force both bureaucracies to resolve issues, which makes the whole relationship more dynamic.
Renew direct military-to-military contacts.
China's military is extremely important politically, especially in view of the impending succession. Its officers deeply resent our refusal since Tiananmen to deal directly with them. We discuss nonproliferation matters with the Foreign Ministry, but the military appears to delight in demonstrating that the ministry does not speak with authority on such issues. This may be affecting the military's decisions on some weapon and missile sales, especially those controlled by the military itself, from current stocks.
Establish a bilateral human rights commission to discuss broad human rights issues and specific cases of rights violations regularly.
Nothing will quickly change China's grossly inadequate record on civil liberties, as further evidenced by the arrest of Fu Shenqi, an outspoken Shanghai dissident, on June 26. But this commission would keep the issue on the agenda and might make the successors to Beijing's gerontocratic leadership more amenable to considering international standards on human rights. There is evidence that Beijing would agree to formation of such a commission.
Drop restrictions on providing assistance to China in the United States-Asia Environmental Partnership, led by the Agency for International Development.
China's huge size, rapid economic growth and coal-based energy structure will make it a prime source of increased global environmental damage during the decade. We cannot deal realistically with environmental issues in Asia without cooperating with China in this arena.
In short, China can vastly complicate or simplify international efforts to insure peace, to control proliferation of weapons and to deal with environmental change.
Beijing's actions are especially important for East and Southeast Asia. Instability in China would more likely increase the flows of refugees than usher in democracy.
In sum, America must be tough and effective with Beijing in the 1990's. We can do both only by putting the Tiananmen fixation behind us.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Embargo on Iraq Backfires for Israel

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, July 14

 BODY:
Presumably, Israel would rank far down on lists of countries eager to ship arms, or anything else for that matter, to Iraq.
And since that is so, officials here say, they do not understand why the United States, French and British navies, in the name of enforcing the embargo against Iraq, have been stopping Israeli ships headed for the southern Israeli port of Eilat and, in some instances, diverting them to Mediterranean harbors. 
 "This situation is unacceptable and unnecessary, even if we agree that it is important to uphold the sanctions against Iraq," Foreign Minister Shimon Peres told a parliamentary committee today.
At issue is an international naval blockade of the Strait of Tiran, connecting the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aqaba. It keeps ships from sailing unimpeded up the gulf to Eilat or to the nearby Jordanian port of Aqaba, and this week it produced an Israeli complaint to the United States and accusations from the political opposition that the Government has not pressed Israel's case hard enough.
 
No Choice, Americans Say
 As chief enforcers of the embargo, the Americans insist that they have no choice but to stop everyone. They have no way of knowing, they say, whether a ship sailing through the strait will indeed wind up in Eilat, or whether it will instead turn into Aqaba or even stop somewhere else along the way with goods that could then be carried overland to Iraq.
"We're consistent, and we're unbiased," Lieut. Comdr. Bruce Cole, a United States Navy spokesman, told The Associated Press recently. "Vessels of all nations, including the United States, are subject to inspections."
But to Philip Earon, Eilat's Deputy Mayor and acting harbor master, that argument is "quite absurd."
"How can anyone think than any Israeli ship coming to Eilat could be carrying any kind of goods, let alone weapons, for Iraq?" he said. "The only missiles are coming from Iraq to us, not from us to Iraq."
Part of Israel's unhappiness is rooted in historical memory: Blockades of the Strait of Tiran have led to war in the past, conspicuously in 1967 after Egypt closed it to Israeli shipping. The fact that the intercepting is being done by friends this time is not seen as much of an improvement by some Israelis.
 
Port's Economy Hurt
 Perhaps more to the point, the blockade has put a dent in the economy of Eilat, where 700 families depend for their livelihood on a port that has turned dormant in recent weeks as the United States Navy has apparently tightened its controls.
In the last month, Eilat officials say, six container ships have been turned back by the Americans at the strait, and forced to go instead through the Suez Canal to the Israeli ports of Ashdod and Haifa, on the Mediterranean. Because of safety rules for the inspections, United States fleet commanders have begun waving off any ship approaching the strait that carries more than three tiers of containers. That works conspicuously against the Israelis, whose ships routinely stack containers four rows high or more.
In the end, the cargo still makes it to Israel. But the detours amount to an economic punch in the stomach for Eilat, and going through Suez to the Mediterranean adds several expensive days to the journey.
"We're losing quite a bit of money," said Rivka Benvenisti, a spokeswoman for Zim, the Israeli shipping line.
The issue is taken seriously enough here for Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin to have raised it with a high-ranking State Department team that left Israel today after spending several days in the region trying, without visible success, to break a stalemate in the Middle East peace talks.
One idea floated by the Israelis is that they give the Americans five days' warning that a cargo ship is headed for the Strait of Tiran, and then reconfirm once the ship reaches Eilat.
Thus far, United States officials have done little more than cluck in sympathy and say they are studying the proposal. But they also note that the three-year-old embargo against Iraq was authorized by the United Nations and that therefore any decision is not up to Washington alone.
Some right-wing Israeli politicians go so far as to suggest that the inspections are a plot by Boutros Boutros-Ghali, the United Nations Secretary General and an Egyptian, to divert Israeli ships through Suez to bring his country extra canal fees.
It is "a dangerous ploy, rude and sly," Rafael Eitan, leader of the Tsomet Party, told Mr. Peres today. Mr. Peres seemed little impressed.

HEADLINE: JITTERY IRAQ HIDES INDUSTRIAL ASSETS

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 14

 BODY:
In anticipation of renewed American and allied air strikes, President Saddam Hussein is trying to protect strategic industries and important Government installations by removing crucial machinery, records and equipment and hiding it, foreign diplomats and Iraqis say.
This wholesale dismantling of the light industrial and Government sites thought to be targets appears to have begun in earnest in June, they say, before President Clinton launched a Cruise missile attack against an intelligence center in Baghdad. 
 But it has accelerated since then, particularly in the military-industrial sector, with factories being stripped of whatever machinery can easily be removed and the workers sent away indefinitely. Offices in the rebuilt presidential palace here have also been evacuated. And in some cases, Government officials have been ordered to take files home for safekeeping.
Iraqis here say the foreign intelligence service headquarters, which the United States attacked on June 27 with the loss of six civilian lives, was one of the Government sites that had already been evacuated in the belief that it might be targeted again.
 
Hussein Relative in Charge
 This effort to protect Iraq's crucial industrial and governmental centers from another bombing attack is being organized by President Hussein's son-in-law, Hussein Kamel Hassan, who oversees military industries.
And it is occurring as Iraq finds itself at another standoff with the United Nations Security Council over plans for monitoring two missile testing sites to insure that Baghdad does not develop forbidden weapons.
Rolf Ekeus, the head of the special commission overseeing the elimination of Iraq's weapons of mass destruction, is expected here on Thursday for talks with the Iraqis about their refusal to let his weapons inspectors install surveillance video cameras at these sites or to seal the equipment to prevent its use.
Under the Security Council's gulf war cease-fire terms, Iraq is required to give up its weapons of mass destruction and to allow long-term monitoring of its industries.
 
Warnings From U.N. and U.S.
 The Security Council has already warned Iraq that it faces "serious consequences" if it continues to prevent the inspectors from carrying out the monitoring. And President Clinton and Secretary of State Warren Christopher have both hinted at possible new military action.
According to a recent United States Congressional study, despite the trade embargo Iraq has succeeded in rebuilding about 80 percent of its military industry, which was heavily bombed during the gulf war.
The assumption among diplomats here is that Iraq still wants a negotiated settlement to the dispute, particularly since the Security Council has made it clear that Baghdad's request for a partial lifting of the oil embargo so it can buy more food and medicine will not be considered until the quarrel is resolved. [Talks at the United Nations on the oil sales were suspended tonight, Reuters reported, when the Iraqi delegate said he needed instructions from Baghdad.]
But it is not clear whether a resolution will be possible because Iraq is effectively challenging the special commission's right to carry out the long-term monitoring, which Baghdad has not accepted in principle.

HEADLINE: Balkan Envoy To U.S. Gets New Respect

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 14

 BODY:
Two months ago, Ljubica Acevska could barely get her phone calls to the State Department returned. Her requests for appointments with top officials at the National Security Council went unanswered.
Now, with some 300 American troops in Macedonia, Ms. Acevska, the country's representative in the United States, says there has been a "tremendous change in our interaction." 
 "People are more accessible," she said, referring to Government officials here. "I get my calls returned. I get briefed."
Ms. Acevska said relations had been looking up since Macedonia's President, Kiro Gligorov, met with Mr. Christopher in Vienna on June 14 to discuss the troop deployment there.
Macedonia, the tiny republic south of Serbia that split from Yugoslavia last year, is seen by many as a dike preventing civil wars in Bosnia and Croatia from spilling over into the rest of the Balkans. Macedonia has so far avoided being dragged into the conflict.
 
A Strategic Location
 "For months, I've been telling anyone who would listen that we are strategically located, that we can play a key role in this," said Ms. Acevska.
But she said that her main concern is United States diplomatic recognition for Macedonia, and on that, Washington has not changed its position. The United Nations and 30 countries recognize Macedonia, but the United States does not.
Ms. Acevska, a Macedonian-born American, has spent the last 18 months lobbying the State Department, the National Security Council and Congress for recognition.
"They're still not treating us as a sovereign nation," Ms. Acevska said. "We think it's a good idea to send troops, but the key to a peaceful Macedonia, and the Balkans, is recognition and economic assistance."
The United States has indicated that it will deal with Macedonia's recognition once Greece resolves the dispute it has with Macedonia's name, flag and parts of its Constitution, all of which Athens sees as implying that the Government in Skopje harbors a claim to the northeastern Greek province also called Macedonia.
"They will support whatever is acceptable to Greece, but Greece has a consulate in Macedonia," Ms. Acevska said. "Why can't we have one here?"
 
A Thaw in Relations
 Still, she is heartened by the thaw in relations between her office and the United States Government.
"For the first time people began to hear what we've been saying," she said. But even when she couldn't get her calls to the State Department returned, Ms. Acevska said, the State Department would call from time to time to chastise her because Macedonia exported more finished woolen goods than the United States wanted, or to complain some Macedonians weren't honoring the sanctions against Serbia.
"The U.S. doesn't recognize us, the economy is deteriorating, nobody is helping and I'm getting a lecture," she said. "But I am diplomatic. I say, 'The official policy is that we are complying, but it would help if Macedonia was recognized as a sovereign country and compensated for its hardship from the sanctions.' "
The 36-year-old Ms. Acevska, who grew up in Mansfield, Ohio, said she had no idea she was descending into a diplomatic twilight zone when she left her job as a partner in Gulf Enterprises, an international trade and development company here, to become Macedonia's representative in January 1992. Ms. Acevska said she receives $2,500 a month in expenses from the Goverment in Skopje and lives on savings from her previous job.
"Financially, I went from the top to the bottom," said Ms. Acevska, whose designer suits, jewelry, and Jaguar XJS raise eyebrows when she pleads Macedonia's case.
"When people see me in the car, the clothes that I wear, I have to explain that this is from my past life," she said. "This is not a reflection of the way things are. Macedonia is only paying expenses. This is a labor of love. I still have relatives over there. I want to make a contribution. I'm in a position to do that."
 
Passports and Debt Problems
 Ms. Acevska, who is registered as a lobbyist for Macedonia with the United States Department of Justice, juggles a myriad of diplomatic housekeeping tasks, from making arrangements to settle Macedonia's debt with the International Monetary Fund to trying to help Macedonians who want to visit Macedonia but whose Yugoslav passports have expired.
"I am the ambassador, the cleaning lady, everything," she said. Since Ms. Acevska is an American, she could not be the Ambassador, when one is appointed, unless she gave up her United States citizenship, something she has not considered to date.
All kinds of economic and cultural relations ensue from normal diplomatic recognition by the United States. Macedonia is one of a number of countries and organizations that lead lives on a sliding scale of recognized non-recognition.
The United States also may recognize a country but not have formal relations with it, each country doing business with the other through an interest section in a third nation's embassy in each country. For example, the United States operates an interest section in the Swiss Embassy in Havana; Cuba operates out of the Swiss Embassy in Washington.
Beyond that, said Joseph C. Snyder, a spokesman for the State Department, "There are a lot of ad hoc arrangements."
Ms. Acevska does not like to think of herself or the country she is representing as an ad hoc relationship.
"You don't commit American lives to places you consider ad hoc," she said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Consumer inflation disappeared for June, with prices remaining level with May. It was the first time in two years that prices did not rise in a month. Another report showed that retail sales rose four-tenths of 1 percent last month. [Page D1.] Sales of domestically built cars and trucks rose 14.6 percent in early July. [D3.]
The Government sold six prestigious golf clubs at auction for $395.4 million, ending one chapter in the history of Oak Tree Savings Bank of New Orleans, which was taken over in 1991. [D1.] 
 American dependence on imported oil jumped by 9.2 percent as domestic production plunged to the lowest level in 35 years. [D2.]
The issue of writing off intangible assets is causing nearly as much debate as are better-known issues in President Clinton's economic package. [A1.]
 
Companies
A former Prudential-Bache officer received gifts and special deals from sponsors of speculative real estate transactions that were sold by the firm, according to a report. [D1.]
ABC will not charge Continental Cablevision for carrying ABC broadcast channels, and Continental will carry ABC's ESPN2 for a fee in a deal that separates the network from CBS and NBC in the conflict over retransmission fees. [D1.]
Southwest Airlines is in some ways the nation's pre-eminent airline, flouting conventional industry thinking. [D1.]
Dell Computer expects to report its first quarterly loss ever, which would violate financial covenants with seven banks. [D4.]
Intel's business practices do not constitute unfair competition as some small competitors had charged, the F.T.C. said. [D4.]
Macy junk bonds soared in price on a rumor that Laurence A. Tisch was preparing another bid to buy the retailer. [D4.]
Sundstrand will sell its aviation instruments business to Allied Signal for $195 million, slightly more than the unit's sales. [D5.]
ITT is studying personnel cuts that could result in layoffs and savings of about $100 million a year. [D5.]
Trans-Alaska pipeline's owners will pay $98 million to Alaskans harmed by the grounding of the Exxon Valdez. [A16.]
 
International
China began a far-reaching effort to rein in its overheated economy, in which inflation is spinning out of control. [A13.]
The British House of Lords rejected an effort by Margaret Thatcher to require a referendum on European unity. [A14.]
Russia, Belarus and Ukraine agreed on an economic integration that would create a "single economic space." [A15.]
A Lloyd's of London underwriter, Gooda Walker, is the subject of a criminal investigation by Britain's Serious Fraud Office. [D4.]
Japan's top trade official said the U.S. should not expect his country's trade surpluses to go down in the next two years. [D6.]
 
Markets
Money poured into stocks, driving up most leading market indicators. Small-stock indexes rose to record highs. [D10.]
The 30-year Treasury yield fell to another low and note yields slipped to their lowest levels in more than two decades. [D18.]
Oil prices declined and talks on resumption of Iraqi exports were halted. [D20.] The dollar fell and gold rose. [D20.]
